taxonomicNotes: Deltochilum was described in 1822 by Eschscholtz. The main diagnostic characteristic is the presence of short carinae or tubercles at the apex of some elitral interstriae. The genus is composed by eight subgenera: Aganhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Calhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Deltochilum s. str.; Deltohyboma Lane, 1946; Euhyboma Kolbe, 1983; Hybomidium Shipp, 1897; Parahyboma Paulian, 1938; Rubrohyboma Paulian, 1938.

The genus is exclusively Neotropical and most species occur in South America (Canhedo 2006). The group was reviewed by Canhedo in 2006. However, ten new species were described by the same author in 2004 parallel to the process of publication of taxonomic revision, so that the works that complement the taxonomic revision were published even before the own revision of the genus (Canhedo 2004a, 2004b, 2006). After the publication of these papers the genus now includes 58 species. Although there is a taxonomic revision with a relatively recent identification key for the genus, it still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

Ateuchus is a diverse genus, with approximately 70 species, distributed from the United States to Argentina and Lesser Antilles. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy of identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

The genus is exclusively Neotropical and most species occur in South America (Canhedo 2006). The group was reviewed by Canhedo in 2006. However, ten new species were described by the same author in 2004 parallel to the process of publication of taxonomic revision, so that the works that complement the taxonomic revision were published even before the own revision of the genus (Canhedo 2004a, 2004b, 2006). After the publication of these papers the genus now includes 58 species. Although there is a taxonomic revision with a relatively recent identification key for the genus, it still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

This genus was created to group three species (two of them described as Canthon and the third as Deltochilum) and now contains four species described. Currently, its geographic distribution is restricted to the South American continent.

Scatonomus is a small genus, containing only eight described species, of which little taxonomic and biological information is available. The genus is known from Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, and its species are distributed throughout “Cerrado”, “Pampa” and Atlantic forest.

A review of Canthon lamproderes by Fernando Vaz-de-Mello will soon be published which places some specimens previously identified as Canthon lamproderes within Canthon corpulentus - this has been taken into account in this assessment.


Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically relatively well known.

The genus is exclusively Neotropical and most species occur in South America (Canhedo 2006). The group was reviewed by Canhedo in 2006. After the publication of these papers the genus now includes 58 species. Although there is a taxonomic revision with a relatively recent identification key for the genus, it still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: (Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia). Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus can be changed.

According to Edmonds and Zidek (2010), the Neotropical genus Coprophanaeus Olsoufieff (1924) is currently represented by 38 species, distributed among three subgenera (Megaphanaeus Olsoufieff, Metallophanaeus Olsoufieff, and Coprophanaeus s. str.) and eight species groups.

According to Edmonds and Zidek (2010), C. terrali can be near, or perhaps synonym to C. dardanus. Thus, the authors consider the status of C. terrali uncertain.

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout the Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The group was reviewed by Cook in 1998. According to Cook (1998), Bdelyrus is endemic in tropical America and is widespread throughout this region, ranging from Nicaragua to southern Brazil and occurring in humid forest at elevations between 10 and 1,800 m. Adults have been found in detritus accumulated in reservoirs of both terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads. Species of this group are recorded in dung-baited pitfall traps, carrion-baited pitfall traps, wet forest litter, and flowers of Heliconia (Cook 1998).

Deltorhinum presents 8 described species, distributed through Amazonian Forest. Currently, the genus has been revised by F. Génier (2010). Might be associated with leafcutter ants.

The genus Phanaeus was revised by Edmonds (1994). Its species are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in Mexico. The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera (Notiophanaeus and Phanaeus s. str.).

The genus Oxysternon was recently revised by Edmonds and Zídek (2004). It consists of approximately 11 species which are distributed throughout tropical South America. The species that are found within the genus are divided into two subgenera: Oxysternon s. str. and Mioxysternon. According to Edmonds and Zídek (2004), Mioxysternon species occur along the periphery (or outside) of the Amazon Basin, whist those of Oxysternon s. str. are found within.

According to Cook (2002), Cryptocanthon is a genus of wide occurrence in the New World tropics. They inhabit the litter of wet forests, both lowland rain forests and higher elevation montane and cloud forests, and occur from Brazil to Mexico.

Zonocopris is known for its relationships with giant South American land snails. The genus was revised by Vaz-de-Mello (2007). Currently, it consists of two species, Z. gibbicollis (Harold 1868), distributed in Bolivia, Argentina, Paraguay and Brazil and Z. machadoi Vaz-de-Mello, 2007, from Paraguay and Brazil.

The genus Trichillidium was described and positioned in the subtribe Scatimina (Coleoptera: Scarabaeinae: Ateuchini) by Vaz-de-Mello (2008). It is comprised of four species that are distributed throughout southern Nicaragua to central Argentina (although they are absent in western Amazonia), central and northeastern Brazil. The species that compose the genus were originally described in Trichillum or Pedaridium.

Besourenga (Coleoptera: Scarabaeinae: Ateuchini) was described by Vaz-de-Mello (2008). Currently, the genus represents approximately 25 species which are yet to be described. Four of which are distributed throughout Bolivia, Peru, Brazil and Paraguay. All species that compose the genus were originally described in Trichillum or Pedaridium.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus Isocopris is currently represented by three species described, distributed among Brazil, Argentina, Bolivia and Paraguay. So far, the specimens were recorded in Amazonian forest, Cerrado and Chacoan region. The genus is being revised by Fernando Vaz-de-Mello.

Uroxys presents about 60 valid species, distributed from Mexico to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

Deltochilum was described in 1822 by Eschscholtz. The main diagnostic characteristic is the presence of short carinae or tubercles at the apex of some elitral interstriae. The genus is composed by eight subgenera: Aganhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Calhyboma Kolbe, 1893; Deltochilum s. str.; Deltohyboma Lane, 1946; Euhyboma Kolbe, 1983; Hybomidium Shipp, 1897; Parahyboma Paulian, 1938; Rubrohyboma Paulian, 1938.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout the Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.

Canthidium is a diverse genus, distributed from the United States to Argentina. The diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems (Martínez and Halffter 1986). In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.The genus still presents a considerable number of species to describe.
The genus is endemic to South America and currently has five valid, described species. They are specialists of beaches (riverine and sea).

The genus Oxysternon was recently revised by Edmonds and Zídek (2004). Its consists approximately of 11 species that are distributed throughout tropical South America. The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera: (Oxysternon s. str. and Mioxysternon). According to Edmonds and Zídek (2004), Mioxysternon species occur along the periphery (or outside) of the Amazon Basin, while those of Oxysternon s. str. fill it.

Oxysternon pteroderum Nevison, 1892 has been considered a rare and endemic species from the Brazilian Atlantic forest (Arnaud 2002, Edmonds and Zidek 2004, França et al. 2012).

The genus Phanaeus was revised by Edmonds (1994). Its species are distributed throughout continental tropical and subtropical Latin America. However, the greater diversity of the group occurs in Mexico. The species that compose the genus are divided into two subgenera (Notiophanaeus and Phanaeus s. str.).

Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

The genus is exclusively Neotropical and most species occur in South America (Canhedo 2006). The group was reviewed by Canhedo in 2006. However, ten new species were described by the same author in 2004 parallel to the process of publication of taxonomic revision, so that the works that complement the taxonomic revision were published even before the own revision of the genus (Canhedo 2004a, 2004b, 2006). After the publication of these papers the genus now includes 58 species. Although there is a taxonomic revision with a relatively recent identification key for the genus, it still presents a considerable number of species to describe.

Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

D. calcaratus is in the process of being synonymised with D. mamillatus. Therefore, the older synonym mamillatus and data referring to this is being used. Revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello in prep.
This genus presents only one species described (Hansreia affinis).

The genus Scatimus was recently revised by Génier and Kohlmann (2003). According to the authors, Scatimus is a small genus, containing only twelve described species, of which little taxonomic and biological information is available. Its species are distributed across Mexico, Peru and Brazil.

Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

This genus was recently revised by Edmonds (2000). According to the author, Sulcophanaeus is a Neotropical genus comprising five species groups (faunus, carnifex, auricollis, imperator and menelas). Currently, the genus presents 15 valid species and some infraspecific taxa.
Sylvicanthon is known from South America, except Chile and Uruguay. Little taxonomic and biological information is available. Currently, it needs taxonomic revision.

The genus consists of approximately 160 valid species that are distributed throughout Americas. However, the greater diversity of Dichotomius occurs in Brazil. The species that compose the genus are divided into four subgenera: Dichotomius, Homocanthonides, Selenocopris and Luederwaldtinia. Currently, Dichotomius is being revised by F. Vaz-de-Mello. Thus, the number of valid species and the internal structure of the genus may change.

According to Vaz-de-Mello (2008), the genus Pedaridium is monotypic. However, it contains at least one undescribed species currently under study, in addition to the type species. It is present only in the Eastern Parana subregion, in the Parana Forest and Araucaria angustifolia Forest provinces.

Onthophagus is a diverse and cosmopolitan genus, with approximately 2,000 species distributed worldwide. The great diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

The group was reviewed by Cook in 1998. According to Cook (1998), Bdelyrus is endemic in tropical America and is widespread throughout this region, ranging from Nicaragua to southern Brazil and occurring in humid forest at elevations between 10 and 1,800 m. Adults have been found in detritus accumulated in reservoirs of both terrestrial and arboreal bromeliads. Species of this group are recorded in dung-baited pitfall traps, carrion-baited pitfall traps, wet forest litter, and flowers of Heliconia (Cook 1998).

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Onthophagus is a diverse and cosmopolitan genus, with approximately 2,000 species distributed worldwide. The great diversity of the group is also accompanied by various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task.

Paracanthon comprises only four species which are distributed throughout the Atlantic forest of south and southeastern Brazil. Its species are usually recorded in elevated areas above 1,000 m. Currently, this genus needs taxonomic revision.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America. The genus is taxonomically well known.

The genus is currently being reviewed by Patrick Arnaud and François Génier. Therefore, it is not safe now to report data on the number of species or internal structure of the genus. The species of Dendropaemon are restricted to South America, except Chile.

Canthidium is a diverse, species rich genus, with many species unknown.  They are distributed from the United States to Argentina. The group also has various taxonomic and nomenclatural problems. In addition to this, the need for taxonomic revisions makes the accuracy in identification of most South American species an extremely difficult task. There are still a considerable number of species to describe in this genus.

The genus Scybalocanthon Martínez (1948) is a small genus of dung beetle from Central and South America. It needs taxonomical revision and many of its species can not be securely identified at this moment. So far, Scybalocanthon has 18 described species.
two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. bradei (Porto & Castell.) Barthlott & N.P.Taylor.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. buenekeri (Swales) P.J.Braun & Hofacker. The latter was previously considered a good species, genetic studies are required to see if it should be raised to species level again.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. angelsiae R.Kiesling & Metzing.
Was considered by some authors to be a form of H. salicornioides Britton & Rose, but is now treated as a good species.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. densispina Hofacker & Herm.
This former subspecies was promoted to species level (Menezes et al. 2011). The two former subspecies can be found growing together in Bahia and Ceara.

Marceniuk (2005) placed this species in Aspistor, but it is now generally agreed that the appropriate name is Sciades parkeri. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Published data: This species has two subspecies:  Hyporhamphus roberti hildebrandi and Hyporhamphus roberti roberti.
Jamaica Caribbean Workshop:Early records of Hyporhamphus roberti from continental United States refer to either H. meeki or H. unifasciatus.

Two other common and very similar species of western Atlantic Strongylura occur alongside Strongylura marina in the Western Central Atlantic: Strongylura notata and Strongylura timucu. Until the late 1960s, S. timucu was largely considered to be synonymous with S. marina (Berry and Rivas 1962). Collette (1968) notes that S. notata differs from S. marina and S. timucu in having fewer anal rays and fewer predorsal scales, and internal examination also reveals fewer vertebrae and other distinguishing skeletal features. Internal examination also reveals that both gonads are developed in S. tumucu while only the right gonad is developed in S. marina. Typically, S. timucu is also somewhat darker in coloration than S. marina (Hoese and Moore 1977). Strongylura notata differs externally from S. marina, possessing 13-15 dorsal rays and 13-16 anal rays (Hoese and Moore 1977).

Genetic studies of Pagrus pagrus have shown Western Atlantic samples to be more closely related to each other than to samples from the Eastern North Atlantic. Within the Western North Atlantic, no significant population differentiation was observed, and within the eastern North Atlantic, only the Azores sample showed detectable differences from those from Crete and Madeira. These data indicate general homogeneity within large areas, and deep divisions between these areas (Ball et al. 2007).

The type locality for this species is Surinam. There are currently five recognized subspecies in this taxon: Battus belus belus (Cramer, 1777); aureochloris (Brown, 1994); belemus (Bates, 1864); cochabamba (Weeks, 1901) and varus (Kollar, 1850).

The American Snout (Libytheana carinenta) has several subspecies: L. c. carinenta, L. c.mexicana, L. c. streckeri, L. c. larvata, and L. c. bachmanii (the Mexican Snout); the latter was formerly recognised as a separate species, Libytheana bachmanii (Warren et al. 2016).
This species is split into several subspecies across its range (Scott 1986).

The type locality for this species is Suriname. There are currently six recognized subspecies in this taxon, according to Warren et al. (2010): Parides lysander lysander (Cramer 1775); antalcidas Tyler, Brown & Wilson, 1994; brissonius (Hübner, [1819]); mattogrossensis (Talbot, 1928); orinocoensis Costantino, Le Crom & Salazar 2002; and parsodes (Gray, [1853]).

The type locality for this species is Surinam. There are currently 4 recognized subspecies in this taxon: Battus crassus crassus (Cramer 1777); hirundo (Röber 1925); lepidus (Felder and Felder 1861) and paraensis (Brown 1994)
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

Records of eastern Atlantic Myliobatis aquila from southern Brazil probably refer to this species, if both species are indeed distinct (if not, the name M. aquila has priority). There are two sister species in the southern part of its range under the present name M. goodei, with a description of the second species pending (Ruocco et al. 2012).
The similar, but larger, Etmopterus bigelowi was previously confused with this species until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).

Taxonomy remains unresolved for this species, with nominal records from various locations likely to represent other species (Ebert et al. 2013). This species is frequently misidentified with other regional etmopterids, e.g., Etmopterus burgessi (Schaaf-DaSilva and Ebert 2006). Therefore, care should be taken when identifying similar looking lucifer-group lanternsharks.

This species can be visually distinguished from two morphologically similar regional congeners, the Dusky Smoothhound (Mustelus canis) and the Gulf of Mexico Smoothhound (M. sinusmexicanus) by several characters including fin shape and ampullary pore patterns (Giresi et al. 2013).
The Bignose Shark is morphologically distinct but genetically similar to the Sandbar Shark (Carcharhinus plumbeus) (Naylor et al. 2012, Duffy and Struthers 2017).

White et al. (2017) concluded that Mobula rochebrunei (East Atlantic Devilray) is a junior synonym of M. hypostoma (Atlantic Devilray), with the latter species being confirmed as occurring in both the Western and Eastern Atlantic.
Last et al. (2016a) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed.

Spirula's discontinuous distribution in the northern and southern hemisphere has led to suggestions that more than one species exists (e.g., Warnke 2007). Currently, this is the only species in the family Spirulidae.
Vosseledone charrua is the type species of the genus Vosseledone by monotypy.
The type locality is the Old Rhodes Key, Florida, Gulf of Mexico (Sweeney 2012).

Thore (1949) moved to place V. alberti Joubin, 1924, V. ingeborgae Joubin, 1929 and V. translucida Robson, 1930 into the synonymy of V. richardi after examination of these and 113 specimens of various sizes caught during the Dana expeditions.
The type locality is Martinique, West Indies, western North Atlantic Ocean (Sweeney 2012).

Earlier workers attribute the name to Solander. This attribution relates to an unpublished manuscript (which fails to meet Art. 8 and hence does not constitute a nomenclatural act) referred to in Lightfoot's (1786) sale catalogue. There is no description in the sale catalogue but this also refers to Rumphius (1705). Although the latter predates the starting point for zoological nomenclature (Art. 3) the information therein may be referred to. Hence A. nodosa Lightfoot, 1876 is a valid name.
The genus Eledone contains six species and is in need of revision.

Treated as a subspecies (A. pelagicus thielei Robson, 1930) by Nesis (1987) and as a synonym of A. pelagicus by many authors, O'Shea (1999) recognised A. thielei to merit specific status based primarily on differences in number of gill lamellae and suckers on the hectocotylized arm, and its association with different water masses.

Numerous species of Argonauta have been described. A full list is given by Mangold, Vecchione and Young (2008). Taxonomic work on this genus is required, but A. argo is undoubtedly a good species and is the type species of the genus. We treat A. pacifica (type locality California) as a junior synonym of A. argo (type locality Mediterranean Sea).
The type locality is given as "Brazil and Carolina strands" (Sweeney 2012).

Ommastrephes bartramii has a cosmopolitan distribution in temperate to subtropical waters. However, genetic tests of populations in different oceans, to determine if gene flow occurs, have not been made.
The type locality is in the western South Atlantic Ocean at 41° 47'S, 63° 35'W (Sweeney 2012).

Numerous synonyms have been proposed including Alloposus mollis Verrill, 1880, Octopus alberti Joubin, 1895, Alloposus pacificus Ijima & Ikeda, 1902, Heptapus danai Joubin, 1929, Alloposus hardyi Robson, 1930 and Alloposina albatrossi Robson, 1931. Although the genus name is recognized as Haliphron, the correct family name is Alloposidae.

Earlier workers attribute the name to Solander. This attribution relates to an unpublished manuscript (which fails to meet Art. 8 and hence does not constitute a nomenclatural act) referred to in Lightfoot's (1786) sale catalogue. There is no description in the sale catalogue, but this also refers to Rumphius (1705). Although the latter predates the starting point for zoological nomenclature (Art. 3) the information therein may be referred to. Hence A. hians Lightfoot 1876 is a valid name. However, A. hians appears to be very variable in form and taxonomic work is required to delineate the species limits.  According to Jereb et al. (2014), Moolenbeek (2008) designated a neotype with type locality Ambon Indonesia.
The genus Eledone contains six species and is in need of revision.
Following Young (2008), we treat Bolitaena microtyla Steenstrup in Hoyle, 1886 as a junior synonym of Bolitaena pygmaea.
The type locality is Martinique (Sweeney 2012).

The genus Octopus is currently under taxonomic revision. It is for this reason that the species originally treated under the genus name Octopus have provisionally remained as such until they are reviewed. Type locality: Coast of Patagonia, bay of San Blas (Jereb et al. 2014).

Originally described from a single specimen as Opisthoteuthis agassizii Verrill 1883, this is the type species of the genus Opisthoteuthis. The type locality is off Grenada, Lesser Antilles, tropical Western North Atlantic, 535 m depth.

A portion of the genus Polygonum was separated as Persicaria leaving only members of the Polygonum aviculare group in the original genus. Whilst generally widely accepted, IPNI (for example) appears to retain Polygonum as the correct genus for this species, under which name it would be P. lapathifolium L. TROPICOS cites Polygonum lapathifolium var. lapathifolium as the accepted name. P. lapathifolium is a very variable taxon, to the extent that Tela Botanica lists 43 sub-specific taxa, but IPNI and TROPICOS list only between 10 and 20. Hybrids have been reported between this taxon and other Persicaria species, but reliable evidence is sparse; as suggested by Flora Nordica hybridisation is likely to be rare and is unlikely to affect the red list assessment. In the Arabian Peninsula, it appears likely that the treatment of taxa such as P. lapathifolia and P. persicaria is not consistent throughout the region.

An accepted synonym is Veronica chillensis Kunth.
Its common name is Necklace Weed.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.
S. supina is treated by many authors as Schoenoplectus supinus (L.) Palla.

Plants green to yellowish green or dark red, with 2 growth stages; plants fertile only in mature stage, generally in late spring. Stems prostrate when immature, 1-3 cm, internodes elongate to 5 mm, becoming nearly erect to 5 cm or more when mature and crowded. Hairs on upper leaf lobes strictly unicellular. Megaspores warty with raised angular bumps, each with a tangle of filaments

Archosargus probatocephalus is subdivided into three subspecies by some authors: A. probatocephalus probatocephalus for the northern form from Nova Scotia to Cedar Key on the west coast of Florida; A. probatocephalus oviceps Ginsburg (which is associated with muddy bottoms) in the Gulf of Mexico from St. Harks, Florida to the Campeche Bank; and A. probatocephalus aries from Belize to Bahia de Sepetiba, Brazil (Carpenter 2002).

The Chesapeake Bay Sheepshead population is suggested to constitute a separate population, as large differences in vital rates are often indicative of this. The differences observed in growth could arise due to a variety of factors, including differences in mortality rates, environmental conditions, food sources, or genetic variation (Ballenger et al. 2007).

Frequency distributions of each of five meristic counts are significantly different between the subspecies found in the northeastern Gulf of Mexico: A. probatocephalus probatocephalus and A. probatocephalus oviceps (P < 0.05). However, Bayesian structure analysis of microsatellite genotypes indicated that all Gulf of Mexico Sheepshead populations constitute a single stock.Variance partitioning of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) haplotypes suggests significant but limited divergence between subspecies (genetic differentiation index FST = 0.036, P < 0.005). Molecular data from North American subspecies of  Sheepshead indicate very limited genetic subdivision between the subspecies despite considerable divergence of morphological characters. Genetic structure is defined primarily by the geographic distance between sampling locales from the Gulf of Mexico and the Atlantic. Overall, Sheepshead molecular genetic data indicate very limited genetic subdivision between the subspecies despite considerable divergence of morphological characters (Anderson et al. 2008).

Vigna juruana (Harms) Verdc. is classified in Taxon Group 4 of both Bambara Groundnut [Vigna subterranea (L.) Verdc. var. subterranea (L.) Verdc.] and Cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp. var. unguiculata (L.) Walp.] (Vincent et al. 2013), following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Vigna longifolia (Benth.) Verdc. is classified in Taxon Group 4 of both Bambara Groundnut [Vigna subterranea (L.) Verdc. var. subterranea (L.) Verdc.] and Cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp. var. unguiculata (L.) Walp.] (Vincent et al. 2013), following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Vigna luteola (Jacq.) Benth. is a genepool tertiary wild relative of both Bambara Groundnut [Vigna subterranea (L.) Verdc. var. subterranea (L.) Verdc.] and Cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp. var. unguiculata (L.) Walp.]. The species is also classified in Taxon Group 2 of Bambara Groundnut and Taxon Group 3 of Cowpea (Vincent et al. 2013), following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

Vigna marina Merr. comprises two subspecies: subsp. marina and subsp. oblonga (Benth.) Padulosi (Maxted et al. 2004). Vigna marina is also cultivated (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019) but only wild populations will be considered in this threat assessment. In its wild form, V. marina is a primary wild relative of dine bean, the cultivated form of the species. Vigna marina is a genepool tertiary wild relative of both Bambara Groundnut [Vigna subterranea (L.) Verdc. var. subterranea (L.) Verdc.] and Cowpea [Vigna unguiculata (L.) Walp. var. unguiculata (L.) Walp.]. The species is also classified in Taxon Group 2 of Bambara Groundnut and Taxon Group 3 of Cowpea (Vincent et al. 2013), following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).

The systematics of Tremoctopodidae was reviewed by Thomas (1977). He concluded that two species existed, T. violaceus, comprising the subspecies T. v. violaceus in the Atlantic Ocean and T. v. gracilis in the Pacific Ocean, and a new deep-water species T. gelatus Thomas, 1977.  O'Shea (1999) resurrected the New Zealand species, T. robsoni. Given that T. v. violaceus was no more different from T. robsoni than it was from T. v. gracilis, Mangold et al. (2008) elevated the two subspecies of T. violaceus to specific level.

Some authorities treat Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani as a subspecies of S. lacustris (e.g., Sell and Murrell 1996, Castroviejo et al. 2008) while others (such as TROPICOS) maintain it within Scirpus. In Euro-Med checklist this is a synony of S. lacustris subsp. glaucus (Sm.) Bech (Euro+Med PlantBase). 

Schoenoplectus tabernaemontani hybridises with S. triqueter (L.) Palla and is reported to hybridise with S. lacustris, however the latter is unproven whilst the former is not sufficiently frequent to affect the Red List assessment for this species (Jermy et al. 2007).
Given its wide geographic distribution and morphological variation between regions it is likely that more than one species is present (Roper and Young 1999).
O. grandiglumis (Doll) Prodoehl is a secondary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.).
Not in India.
This species is not found in India (Kew World Plant Database)
Oryza latifolia Desv. is a secondary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2017).
There was a significant level of genetic structure observed between North and South Atlantic populations, suggesting limited dispersal across the Amazon barrier (Rocha et al. 2002).

Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) survey reveal strong separation between the Brazilian and Carribean provinces, and no significant population structure across the oceanic gap separating Brazil and the mid-Atlantic ridge. The genetic differences between the Brazilian and Carribean populations is matched by colour differences: in the North Atlantic, individuals show a distinguishing arrow, bluish posterior margin on the caudal and dorsal fins, whereas in the South Atlantic, individuals have a bright yellow margin (Rocha et al. 2002). Morphological and genetic data indicate that Acanthurus bahianus is now split into two species: Acanthurus tractus, which is distributed in the northwestern Atlantic and  A. bahianus distributed from eastern Brazil to Ascension and St. Helena Islands (Bernal and Rocha 2011).

Many of the currently valid Enneanectes spp. are likely species complexes (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). There are four valid species present in the Gulf of Mexico as of January 2014: E. altivelis, E. boehlkei, E. jordani, and E. pectoralis, and these have been assessed as currently valid.
Halodeima surinamensis and Semperothuria surinamensis may be other names for this species.
This species is also known as Sticopus macroparentheses.
This species is sometimes confused with Holothuria cubana (Deichmann 1930).
The Holothuria arenicola reported for the Caribbean may be a different species (Samyn et al. 2006). Current status of this species is likely to be a complex and taxonomic revision is needed.
This species is easily confused with Holothuria surinamensis.

Recent genetic analysis has shown that the Atlantic and Pacific subpopulations of H. steindachneri should be treated as different species. However, a distinctive name has not been attributed to the Atlantic subpopulation as of yet (Rocha et al. 2008).

This species has previously been identified as Gerres simillimus, however, G. simillimus occurs in the eastern Pacific (Robertson 2006) and Gerres cinereus in the western Atlantic is considered a distinct species.
The species was described as subspecies of Siccobaccatus estevesii but has been elevated to species level in 2008 (Braun and Esteves 2008).

The morphology of this species is more similar to the genus Arrojadoa and it was originally described under that genus but recent molecular work has revealed that it belongs under the genus Micranthocereus and therefore it was moved there (Machado 2006). This species is most likely of intergeneric hybrid origin.

Hunt et al. (2006) indicated that this taxon was best assigned to either A. dinae or A. eriocaulis, but thought the latter to be the most likely. It is considered to be a good species here.

A. dinae, A. multiflora, A. eriocaulis and A. beateae are a group of clearly distinct but related species occurring in Minas Gerais and Bahia. In the past some authors regarded them as conspecific under the oldest name A. dinae. Recent studies and better knowledge in the field, however, show that it is better to maintain these taxa at the rank of separate species. In some cases they even grow together (A. dinae, A. eriocaulis) without hybridization (P. Braun pers.comm. 2012).

The species was described as distinct but then it was regarded as a possible hybrid between A. rhodantha and A. dinae (Taylor and Zappi 2004). However, it occurs as a large population of morphologically uniform plants and it comes true from seed, hence it is treated here as a good species.

This species is sometimes included in D. heptacanthus (Barb.Rodr.) Britton and Rose and Hunt et al. (2006) place it under D. catingicola Buining & Brederoo. It is treated here as a distinct species in this assessment.
The species is sometimes included in D. heptacanthus (Hunt et al. 2006) but is treated as distinct species in this assessment.

The type collection (in Berlin) for this taxon was destroyed  during the Second World War, and Nigel Taylor thought that it could not be referred to any known material. However, recent reports of a triangular Rhipsalis from Rio de Janeiro seem to be this species and are treated here as such (N. Taylor and W. Barthlott pers. comms.).
Originally described as subspecies of C. pluricostatus but was recently elevated to species level (Braun et al. 2007).
Western Atlantic subpopulations are now recognized as a separate species (Ophioblennius macclurei).
Phylogenetic analysis has placed this species within the genus Eucinostomus (Chen et al. 2007).
This species was recently re-described following a split to Acyrtus lanthanum (Conway et al. 2014).
This may be a species complex of several species.

A revision of the Acyrtops genus is currently under way. Due to questions surrounding the validity of Acyrtops amplicirrus (a very similar species), the distribution of A. beryllinus is not clearly understood at this time (K. Conway pers. comm. 2015).
There are known taxonomic issues with this species; more than one undescribed species may be masquerading as A. quadrisquamatus.
Records outside of Brazil for A. tajasica may refer A. banana.

This species is sometimes misidentified as Coryphopterus tortugae or C. venezuelae. Furthermore, although genetically distinct, C. glaucofraenum and C. venezuelae are extremely similar (Baldwin et al. 2009).
Older records of Coryphopterus in the western Atlantic may need to be verified as the genus has recently been revised (Baldwin et al. 2009).
Eleotris perniger has generally been reported as E. pisonis, but the latter is a continental South American species ranging only from southern Brazil to eastern Venezuela (Pezold and Cage 2002).

Unfortunately, members of the Eucinostomus genus are continually being misidentified. This species was once thought to occur in the eastern Pacific Ocean, but these specimens are now treated as E. dowii (Page et al. 2013). It may be conspecific with E. jonesi (Lee et al. 1980).
This species is valid, however, the genus may not be monophyletic.
Western Atlantic species of this genus are in need of revision (E. Murdy pers. comm. 2009, F. Pezold pers. comm. 2010).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.

Several nominal species of Plagioscion were included as junior synonyms of P. squamosissimus by Casatti (2005). The current name, P. squamosissimus, may include several species of Plagioscion. Further studies are necessary to discern this group accurately (Chao et al. 2015).

O nome B. devillei foi utilizado por Vieira et al. (2008) para as subpopulações de Brycon dos rios Jequitinhonha e Doce de forma provisória. A espécie de Brycon do rio Jequitinhonha é certamente distinta daquela do rio Doce (Lima 2001), e provavelmente nenhuma das duas é co-específica ao “verdadeiro” B. devillei, que resta ser redescrito (Viera et al. 2008).

Trachelyopterus leopardinus é provavelmente sinônimo de Trachelyopterus galeatus (F.C.T. Lima com. pess. 2011), no entanto, como esta informação não está oficialmente publicada, as duas espécie são consideradas válidas. Há ainda a possibilidade que essa espécie esteja sendo classificada como T. galeatus (R.E. Reis com. pess. 2011).

The wholesale synonymisation of many species of Rhamdia with R. quelen by Silfvergrip (1996), based solely on morphometrics, is not accepted by most fish systematists (e.g. Miller et al. 2005, Eschmeyer et al. 2018). One Mexican species that should be recognised as valid, and assessed properly, is R. guatemalensis (Miller et al. 2005).

Hoplias malabaricus undoubtedly comprises a species complex (Hauser and Benedito 2012, Aguirre et al. 2013, Marques et al. 2013, Mattox et al. 2014, Grassi et al. 2017). As cryptic diversity becomes more clear, formal descriptions at the species level may result in a non-genuine change in the distribution of the species.

O gênero Pimelodella é taxonomicamente confuso com vários morfotipos de difícil reconhecimento. A última revisão taxonômica do gênero (Eigenmann 1917) lista cinco espécies para o estado do Rio de Janeiro. Nesta revisão o autor assinala que há variação de uma série de características entre as espécies, o que suscita dúvidas quanto a sua identificação precisa das mesmas da bacia do rio Paraíba do Sul e rios costeiros, desde o sul do Rio de Janeiro até o rio São Francisco (inclusive).

A diagnose de Trichomycterus potschi não justifica plenamente a sua diferenciação de T. vermiculatus, descrita anteriormente para o rio Paraíba do Sul, drenagem próxima à localidade tipo de T. potschi (W. Wosiacki, A. Datovo e M. Mehanna com. pess. 2013).
This species is likely part of a species complex (Whitehead et al. 1988)

Hyphessobrycon latus é uma espécie inquirendae em Characidae (Lima et al. 2003). Conforme nota de Heraldo Antônio Britski (janeiro de 1999) no frasco do holótipo, o holótipo de H. latus é um exemplar de Serrapinnus cf. piaba (Lütken, 1875), identificação confirmada por Carvalho (2011). Carvalho (2011) propõe a classificação de Hyphessobrycon latus como Serrapinnus piaba.
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.

A diagnose de Aspidoras carvalhoi não é precisa, sendo a espécie de difícil identificação, o que compromete o conhecimento sobre sua distribuição, possíveis ameaças, entre outras características relevantes à avaliação do estado de conservação da mesma.
O gênero Pimeodus apresenta, entre várias de suas espécies, problemas taxonômicos decorrentes da falta de caracteres identificadores únicos (Rocha e Pavanelli 2014).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations

O gênero Pimelodella apresenta problemas taxonômicos associados a possíveis sinonímias e ao reconhecimento de suas espécies. A dificuldade de identificação taxonômica gera incertezas na determinação destes táxons (T.P.A. Ramos com. pess. 2013).

Trachelyopterus lacustris é provavelmente sinônima de Trachelyopterus galeatus (F.C.T. Lima com. pess. 2011). No entanto, como não há oficialmente essa informação até o momento, as duas espécie são consideradas válidas. Há ainda a possibilidade que essa espécie esteja sendo classificada como T. galeatus (R.E. Reis com. pess. 2011).
Apresenta status taxonômico duvidoso, necessitando maiores amostragens para conclusões mais precisas.
Espécies de Aspidoras de bacias costeiras do Nordeste apresentam problemas taxonômicos, com vários morfótipos que não podem ser precisamente assinalados a espécies válidas.

Leporinodus retropinnis foi descrita em Leporinodus Eigenmann, 1922 e incluída na sinonímia de Leporellus posteriormente. Leporellus retropinnis é considerada por Géry (1977) como possível sinônima de L. pictus e por Garavello e Britsky (2003) como possível sinônima de L. vittatus.

Last revision was published by Casatti (2001), who proposed to use the name Pachyurus squamipinnis instead of P. squamipennis, in order to maintain the stability of the most used name (article 33.2, ICZN). Eschmeyer's Catalog of Fishes (Updated July 1, 2019) stated that Jordan & Eigenmann 1889:410 regarded the spelling squamipennis as a misprint; squamipinnis Jordan & Eigenmann is an unjustified emendation (contrary to the discussion in Casatti 2001). We here follow Casatti (2001) in regarding the valid name for this species as Pachyurus squamipinnis Agassiz 1831.

Rineloricaria cubataonis é conhecida somente do holótipo, que está perdido, proveniente do rio Cubatão (Ferraris Jr. 2003). Provavelmente, R. cubataonis é sinônimo de R. henselii (M.S. Ghazzi com. pess. 2013).
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.
O exame do material-tipo revelou que o material pertence a outra espécie, Compsura sp. Os estudos estão sendo realizados por Fernando Jerep (F. R. Carvalho com. pess.).
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.

Although it has been reported from many places in the Neotropics, according to current taxonomic theory, this species does not occur in the Orinoco River Basin. It was recently studied by Teran et al. (2020) who separated it out as a species endemic to just the Sao Francisco River drainage in Brazil. The similar species found in other places are currently considered either undescribed, or in some cases they will receive the names once considered synonyms of P. fasciatus, but this has not yet been resolved.

Segundo Bockmann e Miquelarena (2008), Rhamdella é considerado o grupo irmão de um grande clado heptapteridae composto do subclado Nemuroglanis junto aos gêneros Brachyglanis, Gladioglanis, Leptorhamdia e Myoglanis. Rhamdella é limitada a cinco espécies válidas: R. aymarae, R. cainguae, R. eriarcha, R. longiuscula e R. rusbyi.

A espécie foi descrita do rio Mogi-Guaçu, em Pirassununga, São Paulo. Há dúvidas quanto à validade da espécie.

Conforme nota de Heraldo Antônio Britski (janeiro de 1999) no frasco do holótipo, o tipo de H. iheringi é um exemplar de Serrapinnus piaba (Lütken 1875), identificação confirmada por Carvalho (2011). Carvalho (2011) propõe a classificação de Hyphessobrycon iheringi como Serrapinnus piaba.
De acordo com Bockmann (1998), esta espécie não pertence ao gênero Heptapterus, embora sua posição genérica ainda não esteja determinada.

Designação não clara do lectótipo do espécime MNRJ 924A por Miranda Ribeiro (1953). Uma revisão taxonômica das espécies de Hypostomus do Nordeste Meridional está sendo realizada por C. H. Zawadzki e T. Ramos. Esta espécie necessitará de uma reavaliação futura. Hypostomus carvalhoi é sinônimo júnior de H. jaguribensis. Um trabalho de redescrição de H. jaguribensis está sendo realizado por C. H. Zawadzki, T. Ramos, M. Sabaj-Perez.

Espécie originalmente descrita como Otocinclus paulinus, atualmente alocada em Hisonotus. Várias referências dessa na literatura tratam-se na verdade de outras espécies no gênero (e.g. Aquino e Schaefer (2001) trata-se de Hisonotus notatus). Acredita-se que o tipo dessa espécie aparentemente seja válida, porém a taxonomia confusa de espécies de Hisonotus no alto Paraná prejudica a delimitação acurada das distribuições das mesmas (Carvalho e Reis 2009, 2011).
