The Brazilian population is genetically distinct and is being described as a different species by a Brazilian group (L.A. Rocha pers. comm. 2010).
Stegastes partitus shows weak genetic differentiation across the entire Caribbean basin (Hogan et al. 2012).

Rivas (1960) considered Stegastes otophorus (Poey 1860) a junior synonym of S. leucostictus (Müller & Troschel 1848), but Topp (1970) redescribed S. otophorus as a valid species (Garrido and Varela 2011) and both species are considered valid in the Catalog of Fishes (Eschmeyer 2015).
The eastern Atlantic population is genetically distinct from that in the western Atlantic, but the distinction is below the species level (Rocha et al. 2008).
The species was listed in the genus Notarius by Betancur-R. et al. (2007). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Three distinct lineages of this species have been identified through mitochondrial DNA analysis: 1) a northern type found from the Carolinas south to the Florida Keys, and off Panama City, Florida; 2) a southern form found in the Florida Keys, Yucatan, Belize and Puerto Rico; and 3) a third found exclusively in Trinidad (Chapman et al. 1999).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Genetic analysis revealed no difference between three similar Atlantic species, C. rostrata (Bloch), C. figueiredoi Moura & Castro, and C. supramacula Moura & Castro (L.A. Rocha, unpublished data).

In a study focusing on Colomesus pufferfishes, Amaral et al. (2013) produced evidence suggesting that Sphoeroides pachygaster be excluded from Sphoeroides based on the few species of that genus that this study sampled; further comparative investigations on the molecular and morphological features of all Sphoeroides spp. is highly desirable.
This species may be confused with Sciades couma, although it is much more frequent than S. couma.
Based on various rationale, the proper name is Genyatremus cavifrons, not G. luteus (Tavera et al. 2011).
The possibility that a subspecies exists is likely as the population in the Gulf of Mexico has significantly fewer vertebrae than those in the Caribbean (D. Smith pers. comm. 2015).
Polydactylus oligodon is difficult to distinguish from P. virginicus (Feltes 2002, B. Smith-Vaniz and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
This species presents a superficial ressemblance to Facciolella oxyrhyncha.
Some authors believe that this species is not clearly distinguishable from Thecadactylus solimoensis (R. Caicedo pers. comm. 2013)

This species can be distinguished from Lophogobius cristulatus by the lateralis (sensory pore) system (Bouchereau and Gros 2010). Lophogobius androsensis, currently considered a synonym of L. cyprinoides, should be further examined using the lateralis system and 18S RNA sequence (Bouchereau et al. 2010).

authority: Moravec, Aparicio, Guerrero-Reinhard, Calderón, Jungfer & Gvoždík, 2009

taxonomicNotes: Chávez (2018) reassigned the Brazilian records of Scinax iquitorum to Scinax onca.
There are two subspecies recognized: A. l. lyolepis from Bermuda, the Antilles and Brazilian islands, and  A. l. continentalis from the continental shore (Robertson and Van Tassell 2015).
Suggested synonym of Conus richardbinghami Petuch, 1993
[Conus carcellesi, Conus clenchi and Conus tostesi are valid species and need their own Red List assessment - Jose Coltro]

This is considered a valid species by Filmer (2001) but was recently considered by Tucker (2010) to be a synonym of the wider-ranging Conus jaspideus Gmelin, 1791 which is a polytypic species consisting of three subspecies. Until further evidence is provided, this species is considered valid.
C archetypus is now known to be part of a large species complex found from the lesser Antillies to central Brasil, comprising at least eight species.
This species is easily confused with Diapterus auratus.

The most recent revision of this species (Watson 1996) considers the species to occur on both sides of Central America, however, there is disagreement. For this assessment we consider only the Western Atlantic species to be Awaous banana. There has not been a genetic analysis that supports the synonomy of A. transandianus (Pacific) and A. banana (Atlantic). It should be noted that the common trend in gobioid fauna is that morphologically similar species that occur on opposite sides of the istmus of Panama have been recognized as distinct species based upon combined morphological and molecular analysis.
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

The genus Canthigaster is hypothesized to undergo fast morphological/colour differentiation and slow mtDNA evolution (Randall et al. 2008).

Genetic analysis revealed no difference between three similar Atlantic species, C. rostrata, C. figueiredoi, and C. supramacula (L.A. Rocha, unpublished data).
The genus Sphoeroides may be paraphyletic, and is in need of revision (Amaral et al. 2013).

Some Brazilian specimens of Chilomycterus antillarum are intermediate in colour between the crisp, dark hexagonal pattern typical of the species and the dark background with vague lighter spots typical of C. spinosus spinosus. The significance of this is unknown, and further investigation is required (Leis 2006).
Magnolia amazonica is the accepted name for Talauma amazonica.

Elops saurus was recently split into two largely allopatric species, E. saurus and E. smithi (McBride et al. 2010). In Florida waters, E. saurus and E. smithi may occur sympatrically at early life stages, though this does not appear to persist into the adult stage (McBride and Horodysky 2004).  E. saurus and E. smithi can be differentiated by myomere or vertebral counts;  the more northern E. saurus is characterized by a higher count while the more southern E. smithi exhibits a lower count (Smith 1989, McBride and Horodysky 2004, McBride et al. 2010). These phenotypic differences are corroborated by genetic data (McBride et al. 2010). The sequence divergence in mtDNA cytochrome b (d = 0.023-0.029) between E. smithi and E. saurus is similar to or greater than that measured between recognized species of Elops in different ocean basins (McBride et al. 2010). We recommend the vernacular name Malacho, which is already used for Elops in several countries bordering the Caribbean basin." (McBride et al. 2010; see 'etymology').
Some authors suggest this species should be classified in the genus Lutjanus.

Kaupichthys hyoproroides was previously known as a highly variable, circumglobal species. Recent studies show that the western Pacific distribution is K. japonicus and K. diodontus is known from islands of the central Pacific. The western Atlantic and western Indian Ocean distributions are currently in place for K. hyoproroides, however, these distributions may represent a cryptic species pair. Studies are underway to resolve this taxonomic issue. Until this is published, we accept current taxonomy of this species (K. Tighe pers comm. 2011).
A taxonomic revision of this family is needed (A. Roa-Varón and T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2018).

Bagre marinus is a species complex that includes two species, Bagre marinus sensu strictu and Bagre bahiensis (Betancur and Marceniuk pers. comm. 2011). This assessment refers to Bagre marinus sensu strictu. A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Cathorops spixii is often treated as the only coastal marine species in the genus from the western Atlantic. There are at least eight species widely cited in the literature as C. spixii. The taxonomic revisions follow Betancur and Acero (2005), Marceniuk and Betancur (2008), Marceniuk (2007) and Marceniuk et al. (in press). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
Among the Cathorops species in the Atlantic, Cathorops arenatus is the most similar, and frequently confused with Cathorops spixii.

Vences et al. (2004) confirmed the validity of Hemidactylus mercatorius as a species distinct from H. mabouia, with which it had previously been confused, considering that it represented mainland African and Madagascan members of this species complex. Uncertainty over the exact definitions of these two species, and potential confusion with additional species of Hemidactylus, remain, making it difficult to establish the global distribution of either H. mercatorius or H. mabouia. Vences et al. (2004) found that Madagascan H. mercatorius were genetically distinct from a sample from Mozambique. Within Madagascan H. mercatorius, at least three distinct lineages appear to exist (Vences et al. 2004, Boumans et al. 2007). Rocha et al. (2005) found that Gulf of Guinea "H. mabouia" identified by Jesus et al. (2005) belonged to the northern Madagascar lineage of H. mercatorius identified by Vences et al. (2004). This concept of H. mercatorius as a widespread island species appears to correspond to Clade A of the H. mabouia-mercatorius complex identified by Rocha et al. (2010), which is also found in Tanzania, South Africa (where three separate lineages have been identified), Uganda, the Seychelles, including a lineage endemic to the Aldabra archipelago, and Réunion (Sanchez et al. 2012). However, given the apparent basal relationships of mainland African members of this clade and continuing uncertainty over their taxonomic assignment, this assessment follows Rocha et al. (2010) in restricting the name H. mercatorius to island populations within this clade, with continental populations remaining under the name H. mabouia until the taxonomy of this species complex is resolved. This treatment is acknowledged as being "completely inadequate" (Rocha et al. 2010) as East African coastal populations alone exhibit substantial variation both between and within several recognized major lineages, and the taxonomy of this species complex, and clarification of the mainland African range of H. mercatorius, is in need of further resolution. Based on current understanding, Clade A of H. mercatorius also appears to represent introduced populations in South America and Cape Verde traditionally referred to H. mabouia (Carranza and Arnold 2006, S. Rocha pers, comm. April 2012). Research into the genetics of South American H. mabouia is however preliminary. Only one lineage has so far been identified from Brazil, however there is insufficient data to clarify whether this is the only introduced lineage in the Americas (D. Borges pers. comm. April 2012). Pending resolution of this issue, all Neotropical introductions of this species are referable to H. mabouia (D. Borges pers. comm. April 2012), and this treatment is followed here. Within mainland West Africa, populations of H. mabouia ranging from Senegal to Guinea, Ghana, Togo and Cameroon are genetically similar (J-F. Trape pers. comm. April 2012), but these have not been compared with East African samples and so the relationship between this widespread form and the present concept of H. mercatorius is unclear.

Butler et al. (2019) report that work is ongoing to revise the systematics of the H. mabouia complex, and that this will recognize Hemidactylus benguellensis, presently a junior synonym of H. mabouia (but tentatively recognized as distinct by Marques et al. 2018), as a genetically and morphologically distinct species. This account refrains from accepting this taxonomic change pending the completion of this wider-ranging revision.

The species Mugil gaimardianus was supressed. Many specimens misidentified as M. gaimardianus are actually M. rubrioculus (Harrison et al. 2007).

Mugil rubrioculus can easily be confused with Mugil curema. They are very similar morphologically, but separation is easier in fresh specimens due to coloration differences.  They are however clearly separated genetically both by karyotype and molecular analysis (Nirchio et al. 2005, Fraga et al. 2007, Gonzalez-Castro et al. 2009).

This species is listed in the genus Notarius by Betancur et al. (2007), but was reverted back to Amphiarius by Marceniuk (2012). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).
This species is listed in the genus Notarius by Betancur et al. (2007). A revised (unified) nomenclature for Ariidae is currently underway (R. Betancur pers. comm. 2014).

Until recently, the widespread Boa constrictor was the only recognized species within the genus Boa, with multiple morphological variants across its range described as subspecies. Two Caribbean populations, described as Boa constrictor orophias and B. c. nebulosa, have been informally recognized as full species for almost a decade (Henderson and Powell 2009). Multiple recent studies (summarized in Card et al. 2016) have investigated the systematics of Boa constrictor across its wider range on both morphological and molecular grounds. The name Boa constrictor was subsequently confined to the South American clade defined by Reynolds et al. (2014), with North and Central American taxa referred to Boa imperator.

The systematics of Boa constrictor may require further research to resolve: Card et al. (2016) applied a model that made the a priori assumption that South American samples comprised a single species and so were unable to discriminate between South American clades. These authors did, however, report a sister relationship between a Colombian clade and the remainder of Boa constrictor + imperator based on mitochondrial data and also found support for three distinct mitochondrial clades within the remainder of B. constrictor. In their text these authors assigned records from the Choco of Colombia and Ecuador to B. imperator, apparently following the division between northern and southern clades first identified by Hynková et al. (2009), and suggested that the latter may range into Peru, but did not discuss the basis for this assignment their map of the three clades indicates a southern range limit for B. imperator in northernwestern Colombia.
There is a single record of this species in Mexico that is based on a misidentified Clelia scytalina. It is not thought to occur in Mexico.
This is part of a species complex. Taxonomic work is underway to resolve this complex.
Leptophis santamartensis is considered a junior synonym of L. ahaetulla occidentalis (Albuquerque et al. 2012).
The nomenclature of this species is confusing, but has been recently fully resolved by Wowor and Ng (2007) and Ng and Wowor (2011).

A recent molecular phylogenetic analysis covering northern populations of Oxybelis aeneus (from North America to Panama) found three distinct clades in this area, all of which differed from a fourth clade from Trinidad and Tobago (Jadin et al. 2019). These authors refrain from taking taxonomic action pending the results of ongoing research incorporating both molecular and morphological data across the full distribution of this species complex (Jadin et al. in preparation), and suspect that additional cryptic species will be recognized as a result of this work.

This species and Oxyrhopus petola, both originally described by Linnaeus (1758), have long been recognized to be synonymous. Savage (2011) investigated the complex nomenclatural history of this taxon, and determined O. petolarius to be the correct name for this species.

Xenodon rabdocephalus is believed to be a species complex. Populations from Central America and Colombia that "almost certainly" fall outside the true range of Xenodon rabdocephalus sensu stricto were tentatively assigned to the resurrected Xenodon angustirostris by Myers and McDowell (2014). These authors were however not able to examine the holotype of X. angustirostris, and as such the status of this taxon requires confirmation. Morphological differences between Central American populations identified by Myers and McDowell (2014) further suggest that multiple species may fall within their concept of X. angustirostris. These authors note however that the distribution they propose for this taxon is "zoogeographically plausible" and that any effort to delimit species within this group based on the identified differences would amount to guesswork. Myers and McDowell (2014) are more confident in resurrecting Xenodon suspectus from synonymy with X. rabdocerphalus, but this account follows the Reptile Database (Uetz et al. 2018) in retaining both taxa within the X. rabdocephalus complex until its taxonomy is more fully-resolved.
The eastern and western Atlantic subpopulations may represent two separate species (D. Smith pers. comm. 2012).

MolluscaBase (2019) has officially recognised Crassostrea tulipa to be the correct name of the West African Crassostrea populations, described as G. gasar. But molecular studies recently revealed that some tropical West Atlantic oyster populations were identical to this species, which hence occurred on both sides of the Atlantic. Consequently, the name gasar for the East Atlantic populations was replaced by the older name of Lamarck, used for West Atlantic populations, namely tulipa. The taxonomic change is very recent, e.g., Poutiers (2016)  still uses G. gasar as the valid name.

According to Gans (2005), Amphisbaena fuliginosa ranges from Trinidad to French Guiana (Starace 1998), including Venezuela, Guyana, and Suriname (Hoogmoed 1973). Subpopulations in Colombia, formerly included in A. fuliginosa, were recognized by Gans (2005) as A. amazonica and A. varia. This split was not supported by any data or analyses, and it is not accepted in this assessment. Thus, A. amazonica, A. varia, along with A. bassleri, are here included in A. fuliginosa.

Peloso and Avila-Pires (2010) examined the taxonomic history of this species in detail, and re-evaluated characters previously considered to distinguish it reliably from Ptychoglossus nicefori. These authors concluded that a number of these characters were unreliable, and that as many specimens originally used to diagnose P. nicefori were damaged or juveniles, there is currently insufficient evidence to justify considering P. nicefori a valid species, and referred it to the synonymy of P. brevifrontalis.

Ameiva ameiva is a known species complex, but its taxonomy has never been investigated in detail and species boundaries are not clear. Ugueto and Harvey (2011) conducted a preliminary study of variation in this group, which strongly suggested that Lesser Antilles populations attributed to this species are specifically distinct from forms found in the mainland, Swan Island, and Trinidad & Tobago. These authors recognized two species, A. atrigularis and A. praesignis, from within Venezuelan populations attributed to this species, but indicated that additional species exist within the complex. Henderson and Powell informally recognize the Lesser Antilles populations under the name Ameiva aquilina, and this name has recently been used in grey literature (Sadjak et al. 2016); this form is retained here within Ameiva ameiva pending clarification of species boundaries within this complex.

McCranie and Hedges (2013) examined the systematics the Cnedmidophorus lemniscatus complex across Central America and Colombia. These authors elevated the northern Central American subspecies C. l. ruatanus to specific status and assigned Panamanian populations to the new species C. duellmani. These authors also recommended elevating the South American forms C. l. gaigei, C. l. espeuti, C. l. splendidus, and C. l. arenivagus to specific status, with the caveat that these were not the focus of their research and further work including molecular research is required to confirm this arrangement. This validity of C. arenivagus and C. splendidus was subsequently supported by molecular research (Goicoechea et al. 2016) and these authors also accepted C. gaigei as a valid species. These authors do not discuss the Colombian C. espeuti, referring to it in passing as C. l. speuti but not including it within the content of their Cnemidophorus lemniscatus species group. C. espeuti is considered valid here following Uetz et al. (2018) but the taxonomic status of this form is consequently unclear

Sudré et al. (2017) examined 155 Atlantic Forest Chironius specimens, representing the recognized species C. exoletus and C. quadricarinatus as well as specimens identified as C. pyyrhopogon (the types of the latter having been lost). These authors found no morphological or meristic differences between Atlantic Forest C. exoletus and C. "pyrrhopogon" and provided the first photographic evidence of similar labial markings in other species of Atlantic Forest Chironius, suggesting that this is not a reliable diagnostic character. These authors consequently followed Dixon et al. (1993) in treating C. pyrrhopogon as a junior synonym of C. exoletus. These authors note that, as suggested by Dixon et al. (1993), the widespread C. exoletus is likely to be a species complex, and that the name C. pyrrhopogon will be available if Atlantic Forest populations prove to represent a distinct species.
This taxon may represent more than one species.

The western population of this species in Ecuador is apparently a new species (J. Valencia pers. comm. 2014). The form on Tobago may represent a distinct species, for which the name M. dunni is available (Montingelli 2009).

The taxonomic relationship between this species and other species of Tantilla needs to be resolved. Variation within the T. melanocephala species complex, as then understood, was characterized across the species' range by Wilson and Mena (1980) and several subsequent studies (discussed in Mata-Silva and Wilson 2016) have revised the systematics of T. melanocephala, primarily in Central America, Colombia and Ecuador, recognizing a number of previously cryptic species and referring T. equatoriana, described by Wilson and Mena (1980), to the synonymy of T. melanocephala (Greenbaum et al. 2004). A subpopulation recently recognized from Brazil as a separate species, T. marcovani, was subsequently found to represent a junior synonym of T. melanocephala (Mata-Silva and Wilson 2016). The resulting species concept is of a trans-Andean snake confined to South America and Panama, however, subpopulations east of the Andes - which are thought to include the topotypical subpopulation (which has the type locality "America", but is thought likely to refer to a locality on the Guiana Plateau - P. Passos pers. comm. 2016) have received less attention and their systematics remain unclear. Recent unpublished work has investigated the systematics of Brazilian subpopulations (A. Silveira unpubl. thesis), but this did not include comparisons from subpopulations elsewhere in the species' range. Based on scale counts Trinidad and Tobago each appear to possess an endemic species within this complex, separate from mainland populations (J. Murphy pers. comm. 2015).
This species may represent a species complex containing at least 16 species (Curcio 2008).

Two varieties are recognized: the typical variety which is by far the more widespread of the two and P. sellowii var. angustifolius Pilg. This latter variety is only known from two localities both of which are near or within urban areas. It has been separately assessed as Critically Endangered.

First described in 1983 (as Decussocarpus piressii Silba) based on collection by Rosa & Pires 856 (Dups. K, MO, US) it has not been collected with any certainty since then. Because of the lack of material and its similarities with R. rospigliosii (also from South America) it is still difficult to ascertain its exact taxonomic status.

The Dusky Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Galapagos Shark (Carcharhinus galapagensis). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).
This is the revised taxonomic concept of Centrophorus grandulosus, which includes C. lusitanucs as a junior synonym; C. lesliei and C. longipinnis are also now split out as newly recognised species.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).

Some confusion exists regarding the publication date of the description of S. occulta (Faria et al. 2014). Some taxonomic literature sources list 1991 as the publication date while others list 1992. This confusion is probably due to the distribution of pre-prints of the article in 1991 before the full issue of the journal was printed in 1992. According to The International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature, the publication date of the S. occulta description is 1991. There has also been discrepancy in referencing the species authority for S. occulta, particularly the name of the second author (Faria et al. 2014); K.G. da Silva’s surname has been spelled ‘da Silva’, ‘Da Silva’, and ‘Silva’. Faria et al. (2014) suggested using the one in the revisions by Vaz and Carvalho (2013) and in online taxonomic databases. Thus, the recommended citation is S. occulta Vooren & da Silva, 1991.

A study using allozymes as a genetic marker (Eitner 1995) indicated that an unrecognized fourth species of Alopias may exist, however this claim was based on data from a single shark specimen likely to have been A. vulpinus. Recent work investigating population structure of all three Alopias species using mitochondrial DNA control region sequences (Trejo 2005) has found no evidence indicating that a fourth species of thresher sharks exists.

This species is comprised of two valid subspecies: Mustelus canis canis occurs on the continental shelf, whereas M. c. insularis occurs on insular shelves in the Caribbean (Heemstra 1997, Ebert et al. 2013).
The specific name for this taxon is sometimes also spelt as santipaulae, santipaule and santipauli.
Was previously treated as a subspecies of Tacinga saxatilis.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. catenulata (Kimnach) Barthlott & N.P.Taylor. The latter subspecies was previously assessed as Data Deficient in 2002, but it has not been reassessed and is now excluded from the Red List.

A. dinae, A. multiflora, A. eriocaulis and A. beateae are a group of well distinct but related species in Minas Gerais and Bahia. In the past some authors regarded them as conspecific under the oldest name A. dinae. Recent studies and better knowledge in the field, however, proof that it is better to maintain these taxa in the rank of separate species. In some cases they grow even together (A. dinae, A. eriocaulis) without hybridization (P. Braun pers.comm. 2012).
Espécie descrita em: Cactaceae Consensus Init. 3: 8. 1997.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. alvinii M.Machado & Hofacker, although M. Machado (pers. comm. 2010) feels the latter should be placed under M. flaviflorus.
The former subsp. ferreophilus is now treated as a good species.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. meninensis (Buining) P.J.Braun & Esteves.

Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. flavispina (Buining & Brederoo) P.J.Braun & Esteves and subsp. horrida (P.J. Braun) P.J. Braun & Esteves. All the subspecies were previously assessed in 2002 as Vulnerable, but as they have not been reassessed they are now excluded from the IUCN Red List.
Last et al. (2016) revised the genus Rhinobatos, transferring glaucostigma, horkelii, lentiginosus, leucorhynchus, percellens, planiceps, prahli, and productus to the new genus Pseudobatos.

The Galapagos Shark is extremely similar genetically and morphologically to the Dusky Shark (Carcharhinus obscurus). These species share mitochondrial DNA haplotypes but are distinguishable based on single nuclear polymorphisms (SNPs) (Corrigan et al. 2017) and also occupy different habitats (insular vs. continental).
Genetics studies have led some researchers to suspect that there may be an undescribed species of Echinorhinus off Oman and elsewhere in the Arabian Sea region (Henderson et al. 2016).

According to Eckenwalder (2009) Podocarpus barretoi de Laub. & Silba is a taxonomic synonym of P. sellowii; Farjon (2010) placed it as a synonym of P. brasiliensis de Laub. The type of P. barretoi was collected in Goiás, Brazil, far from the mostly coastal southern Brazil distribution of P. sellowii. Its morphology fits that of P. brasiliensis and it does belong here rather than with P. sellowii.
There is a single extant species in the family Mitsukurinidae.

Soares et al. (2016) redescribed Scyliorhinus haekelii, placing S. besnardi Springer & Sadowsky, 1970 as a synonym. Species of Scyliorhinus were further reviewed and redescribed by Soares and De Carvalho (2019), who recognised 16 valid species. Soares and De Carvalho (2019) also revised the geographic distribution of S. haeckelii, restricting its range to the southwestern Atlantic from southern Bahia, Brazil, to northern Argentina.

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera bonasus, which can only be distinguished by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).
The specific name has been misspelled and consistently used in the literature as Rhizoprionodon lalandei, but the original spelling R. lalandii should be retained.

Caiman crocodilus has four subspecies currently recognized:  C. c. crocodilus, C. c. fuscus, C. c. chiapasius, and C. c. apaporiensis. Caiman yacare previously was considered to be a fifth subspecies (i.e., C. c. yacare). However, it is now generally accepted as a full species (King and Burke 1989), and is no longer treated as a subspecies (Escobedo-Galván et al. 2011).

Busack and Pandya (2001), using morphological analysis, stated that there were no differences between subspecies. However, Venegas-Anaya et al. (2008), using mitochondrial DNA analysis, recognized three out of these four subspecies (no samples from C. c. apaporiensis used in this study) and delimited geographically distributions within the C. crocodilus complex. DNA analyses also suggest a geographic divergence in two groups: the Mesoamerican group including C. c. fuscus and C. c. chiapasius and the South American group, which includes C. c. crocodilus and C. yacare (Amato and Gatesby 1994; Venegas-Anaya et al. 2008).

Recent morphological analysis of the Apaporis River caiman (C. c. apaporiensis), based on holotype and paratypes skulls from the Chicago Field Museum (USA), corroborates a significant morphological differentiation with the rest of the C. crocodilus subspecies (Escobedo-Galván et al. 2015a) as reported by Frederico Medem in 1952. However, DNA analysis conducted with additional paratypes from Colombian collections showed that several of those skulls identified as C. c. apaporiensis in the Instituto de Ciencias Naturales, National University of Colombia collection fall into the C. c. crocodilus clade (Bloor 2013). Nevertheless, a more in-depth study is being initiated in late 2018, to collect less fragmented DNA (from live individuals rather than ancient bones) and larger sample sizes (for both morphological and genetic analyses), which will hopefully provide new evidence on the validity of this subspecies.

The species is closely related to, and approximately 6 mya, and derived from Caiman crocodilus, the Common or Spectacled Caiman (Godshalk 2006). The two species are sympatric in the Madeira River from its confluence with the Amazon, south to approximately the Bolivian border. Studies of morphology (Brazaitis et al. 1998,  Busack and Pandya 2001) and genetics (Hrbek et al. 2008) suggest a cline of introgression between the two species along this transect although each species retain distinctive and non-overlapping genetic features at the limits of their distributions. Biogeographic investigation suggests that the species arose in its southern range as a vicariance event related to movement of the Brazilian shield and has subsequently re-invaded the Amazon system via the Madeira and its tributaries (Godshalk 2008 a,b). Caiman crocodilus and C. yacare have been considered as the same or as subspecies. However, careful review of large samples, in regard to both morphology and genetics, indicates that C. yacare is a Significant Evolutionary Unit with distinct species level distinction (Vasconcelos and Campos 2007,  Hrbek et al. 2008).
This is a restricted concept of Oreobates cruralis following the revalidation of O. granulosus which was previously placed in synonymy with this species (Padial et al. 2008).
Eleutherodactylus johnstonei populations have often been referred to E. martinicensis (Tschudi, 1838).

The high genetic distances between the specimens analyzed by Peloso et al. (2014) suggest the existence of more than one species within Chiasmocleis antenori. Peloso et al. (2014) implied some controversy over the identity of some Peruvian records. A specimen identified as Chiasmocleis carvalhoi from San Martin, Peru (de Sá et al. 2012) is regarded as a confirmed record of this species for Peru (Peloso et al. 2014).
Gymnura micrura has been redescribed with G. lessae and G. sereti split out from G. micrura as separate species (Yokota and Carvalho 2017).

This species is sometimes confused with Rhinoptera brasiliensis, which can only be distinguished from R. bonasus by counting the series of toothplates. Rhinoptera bonasus usually have seven series of plates in both jaws, while R. brasiliensis teeth are typically arranged in series of nine (Last et al. 2016).

This species has been mistaken mainly for Dasyatis (=Hypanus) say but also for Dasyatis pastinaca in the past. The specific name has been misspelled as hipostigma, including in the original description.

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

Until recently, the species name usually was spelled as sayi rather than say. This is not a synonymy, simply a change to conform to original spelling.
The western Atlantic and Pacific Ocean forms are thought to be different species (Ebert et al. 2013)
This species might be confused with the congener Cookiecutter Shark (Isistius brasiliensis).

Seigel et al. (1977) considered Squaliolus sarmenti and S. aliae as synonyms of S. laticaudus. Sasaki and Uyeno (1987) subsequently removed S. aliae from the synonymy as distinct and the genus now contains these two widely recognised species. Squaliolus laticaudus is sympatric with S. aliae in some regions.
The scientific name for this species is often misspelled as Carcharhinus perezii. Carcharhinus springeri Sadowsky & Amorim 1977 is considered a synonym (Soto 2001).
Castro (2011) resurrected Carcharhinus cerdale, considering it distinct from C. porosus. Carcharhinus cerdale is restricted to the Eastern Pacific and C. porosus to the Western Atlantic.

Nurse sharks occurring in the eastern Pacific were formerly considered part of this species concept, however the Pacific Nurse Shark (Ginglymostoma unami) has now been formally described as a separate species (Del Moral-Flores et al. 2015).
Previously confused with the similar but smaller Etmopterus pusillus until described as a distinct species by Shirai and Tachikawa (1993).

Poecilia obscura was originally elevated as a distinct species based on molecular phylogenetic analysis utilizing mitochondrial DNA, and based on differences in gonopodial characteristics (Schories et al. 2009). The authors of this description were unable to describe this new species based on morphological characteristics alone, and therefore conclude that it comprises a cryptic species complex with P. reticulata (Schories et al. 2009). A  number of authors have expressed concern regarding the validity of P. obscura as a distinct species from P. reticulata, versus considerable intraspecific variation or sub-species status (Sievers 2011, Baillie 2012). Phillip et al. (2013) follows Baillie (2012) in rejecting P. obscura as a valid species, whose analysis indicates substantial gene flow between the Quare River (Oropouche watershed) and the Madamas River (situated on the north shore and known to harbour P. reticulata). Further evidence suggests the occurrence of individuals that display both Caroni and Oropouche genotypes, corresponding to P. reitculata and P. obscura, respectively (Baillie 2012). Further study failed to detect behavioural or life history differences between P. obscura and P. reticulata and rapid production of viable hybrids offspring is apparent (Sievers 2011).


Therefore, P. obscura is included within the existing assessment of P. reticulata as a junior synonym of the latter.
This species is sometimes confused with Squalus clarkae and may be confused with recently described or undescribed species in the South Atlantic (C.F. Cotton unpubl. data 2020).

Wüster et al. (2001) described a new species of Drymarchon from northwestern Venezuela, bringing the species total for the genus to four (five if couperi is recognized as a species). This taxonomic rearrangement treats D. corais and D. melanurus as distinct species. The species in the United States, Mexico, Central America, and South America west of the Andes and in Venezuela is D. melanurus. D. corais occurs in South America east of the Andes (Wüster et al. 2001).  Wüster et al. (2001) also recognized D. couperi and D. margaritae, previously considered subspecies, as full species but without examining specimens, based on previously published (but unspecified) morphological differences and application of the evolutionary species concept. Subsequent checklists (e.g. Crother et al. 2003, Collins and Taggart 2002) have adopted this taxonomy.

McCranie (2011) agreed with these taxonomic changes, but noted that these actions were taken on the basis of limited sampling and emphasized the need for further study to clarify the taxonomy of this group. The resulting concept of D. melanurus is likely to be a species complex; McCranie (2011) suggested that two species-level taxa may be included under the name D. melanurus in Honduras alone.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. flavisetus (F.Ritter) N.P.Taylor & Zappi. The latter was assessed in 2002 as Vulnerable, neither subspecies is assessed here.
Molecular studies are required to determine the level of genetic distinctness between the species in the Southwest Atlantic and the Southeast Pacific.

The spellings Dipturus trachyderma and Dipturus trachydermus have been used for this species. The basionym is Raja trachyderma and the valid name is Dipturus trachydermus following grammatical rules. While Fricke et al. (2019) use Dipturus trachyderma, we follow Last et al. (2016) which correctly uses Dipturus trachydermus.

Dipturus diehli Soto & Mincarone, 2001, as known only from the holotype taken off Santa Catarina, Brazil (29°39´S, 47°50´W) at a depth of 480 m, is likely a synonym of D. mennii and is treated here as such.

Based on geographical separation and differences in tooth row counts and coloration, Carvalho (1999) considered Narcine bancroftii and N. brasiliensis to be distinct species. However, intraspecific differences in tooth row counts among individuals of varying sizes were observed. Genetic analyses of Narcine specimens from throughout their range in the Western Atlantic Ocean are needed to confirm the presence of two species. Narcine bancrofti is a frequent misspelling of the species name.

Compagno (1999, 2005) reallocated this species from Bathyraja to the genus Rhinoraja but the validity of this move remains unconfirmed. Both are currently in use, until a definitive systematic revision of these genera is conducted.

Bathytoshia formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis, which is now recognised as a valid species (Last et al. 2016); hence Dasyatis (Bathytoshia) centroura is now Bathytoshia centroura. This western Atlantic species is not conspecific with Bathytoshia of the eastern Atlantic (Last et al. 2016); the eastern Atlantic population that was formerly included within Dasyatis centroura is now included within B. lata (Last et al. 2016). The status of the single record from India is unknown.

Recent revisions have subdivided the previously wide-ranging Narcine brasiliensis into Narcine bancroftii (Griffith, 1834) which is widely distributed from North Carolina, USA, through parts of the Gulf of Mexico, the Caribbean Sea, the Greater Antilles, the Lesser Antilles and the northern coast of South America and Narcine brasiliensis (Olfers, 1831) which is endemic to the Southwest Atlantic in Brazil, Uruguay, and Argentina (Carvalho 1999, Last et al. 2016).
This species was previously included in the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The taxonomy of this species is confused and the identity of this species is unclear (Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm.).

There is no evidence that the population of Itatiaia is Hylodes sazimai. It may be a new species. Apparently, Hylodes sazimai is only known from the Campinas region (C. Haddad pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). Specimens from Mantiqueira and Itatiaia, called as Hylodes aff. sazimai, should be treated as another species (C. Haddad pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Although this species is commonly considered to occur in the Caribbean (southern Caribbean to Jamaica and the Cayman Islands), it is likely that the form in the Caribbean is a different taxon (Weil 1992). For the purposes of this Red List assessment, and until further taxonomic study is conducted, it is considered valid in these areas of the Caribbean.
This species was at one point considered a synonym of M. alcicornis (Boschma 1948) but is now considered a distinct species (Boschma 1962).
{Attention RLU: Please change the family from Mussidae to Faviidae.}

Recent genetic evidence suggests this species forms a species complex with Millepora complanata, M. alcicornis and M. complanata can only be differentiated morphologically, but not genetically (Ruiz-Ramos et al. 2014).

This species could be conspecific with Meandrina meandrites. 

{Please add further detail that justifies this taxonomic problem - citations? C. Linardich 26July2021}

Attention RLU: Please change the name of this species to Mussismilia leptophylla. 

While species level distinction has been long accepted, Favia leptophylla was recently transferred to the genus Mussismilia based on phylogenetic (Fukami et al. 2004, Nunes et al. 2008) and micromorphological data (Budd et al. 2012).
Subfamily Dilocarcininae. This species was originally assigned to the genus Holthuisia.

Dilocarcinus pagei enriquei Pretzmann, 1978.
Subfamily Dilocarcininae. Some authors treat this taxon as a subspecies (S. p. pictus).

There are two subspecies included in this sepcies: Fredius adpressus adpressus Rodriguez and Pereira, 1992; and Fredius adpressus piaroensis Rodriguez and Pereira, 1992.

Subfamily Dilocarcininae. Two subspecies are included in this species: Valdivia serrata serrata White, 1847 (= Valdivia (Valdivia) serrata surinamensis Pretzmann, 1968; Valdivia (Valdivia) serrata cururuensis Bott, 1969; Rotundovaldivia hartii gila Pretzmann, 1978); and Valdivia serrata harttii (Rathbun, 1905) [Trichodactylus (Valdivia)].
Subfamily Pseudothelphusinae; tribe Kingsleyini.

Both S. melanoleucus melanoleucus and S. m. crandalli were considered to be subspecies of S. fuscicollis by Hershkovitz (1977). Saguinus f. melanoleucus, S. f. acrensis, and S. f. crandalli were listed as subspecies of S. melanoleucus by Coimbra-Filho (1990). Saguinus fuscicollis acrensis Carvalho 1957 is not considered a valid form, but a hybrid between S. f. fuscicollis and S. f. melanoleucus on the upper Rio Juruá, following Peres et al. (1996). S. f. crandalli may well be a hybrid of S. f. fuscicollis × S. f. melanoleucus. Listed as a subspecies of S. fuscicollis by Hershkovitz (1977) and Rylands et al. (1993; 2000). Taxonomy here follows Groves (2001, 2005).

In the Bokermannohyla alvarengai group. Bokermannohyla itapoty differs from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters, colour patterns and advertisement call features (Lugli and Haddad 2006).
Hylodes pipilans differs from similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Canedo and Pombal 2007).

In the subgenus Eladinea and in the adspersa species group. Parra-Olea et al. (2004) removed Bolitoglossa paraensis from synonymy with Bolitoglossa altamazonica. M.S. Hoogmoed (pers. comm. 2008) indicates that B. paraensis is a complex of 3-4 species. The nominal species occurs between Belém and Bragança, with one outlying record in Amapá, all other records from Brazilian Amazônia would be other taxa. However, data on habitat, habits and threats of these taxa are included as separate notes under B. paraensis, but their distribution has not been mapped, the map only reflects the known distribution of B. paraensis. Work on the resolution of the taxonomy of this complex is underway.

Nascimento et al. (2006) proposed that Eupemphix fuscomaculatus be considered as Pleurodema fuscomaculata. Specimens previously assigned to Physalaemus fuscomaculatus are now considered to be Physalaemus marmoratus.
Brachycephalus alipioi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Pombal and Gasparini 2006).
In the Bokermannohyla pseudopseudis group. Bokermannohyla oxente can be distinguished from other species of the group by acoustic and morphological features (Lugli and Haddad 2006).
Leptodactylus sertanejo is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of both morphological characters and advertisement call features (Giaretta and Costa 2007).

Phyllomedusa bahiana was elevated to full species status by Silva-Filho and Juncá (2006) on the basis of differences in vocalizations and tadpole morphology.

Andrade et al. (2018) could not distinguish this species from Phyllomedusa burmeisteri on the basis of morphometrics or acoustic parameters but did not suggest a taxonomic change.

This assessment includes the Argentinean subpopulations referred to in Lavilla et al. (2000) as Pseudis paradoxus platensis and Pseudis paradoxus occidentalis according to Aguiar-Jr. et al. (2007). Although Aguiar et al. (2007) have proposed that Pseudis paradoxa and P. platensis are valid species, further studies based on the external morphological characterization of adults, as well as bioacoustic characters and larval morphology, have not found sufficient evidence to support the recognition of P. platensis as a valid taxon (Garda et al. 2010, Santana et al. 2016, Pérez-Granados et al. 2020).
In the genus Rhinella following Frost (2007). Rhinella veredas can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Brandão et al. 2007).
Gastrotheca fulvorufa was revalidated by Caramaschi and Rodrigues (2007) based on morphological features.
In the Bokermannohyla circumdata group according to the original publication.
Proceratophrys paviotii is related to Proceratophrys boiei. It can be differentiated from the latter species by morphological and advertisement call data (Cruz et al. 2005).
Brachycephalus pombali can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and colour features (Alves et al. 2006).

A member of the Physalaemus signifer group according to the original publication. The new species can be differentiated from similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Weber et al., 2006).
Gastrotheca pulchra can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (Caramaschi and Rodrigues 2007).
Frostius erythrophthalmus can be distinguished from Frostius pernambucensis by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Pimenta and Caramaschi 2007).
In the Scinax perpusillus group. Scinax peixotoi is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and distinct advertisement call (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

Phyllomedusa itacolomi is considered to be a member of the Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis group according to the original publication. It is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (Caramaschi et al. 2006).

A member of the Hyla circumdata group according to the original publication. Bokermannohyla vulcaniae is diagnosed by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (De Vasconcelos and Giaretta 2003).

In the Scinax ruber clade according to the original publication. Scinax cabralensis is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and a distinct advertisement call (Drummond et al., 2007).
Scinax camposseabrai was revalidated by Caramaschi and Cardoso (2006) based on morphological comparisons.
In the Physalaemus signifer group. The species can be distinguished from others by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Pimenta et al. 2005).

Leptodactylus lauramiriamae is provisionally included in the genus Leptodactylus. It is differentiated from other species through a combination of morphological, myological and osteological features (Heyer and Crombie 2005).


The type series of L. lauramiriamae was revised, it is a very different species from all the others and has characteristics that may be of another genus (T. Carvalho pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Adenomera nana was revalidated based on bioacoustic data (Kwet 2007).
Chiasmocleis mantiqueira can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Cruz et al. 2007).
Separated from Leptodactylus labyrinthicus by Heyer (2005).

In the Physalaemus signifer species group according to the original publication. Physalaeumus irroratus is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Cruz et al. 2007).
In the Cycloramphus eleutherodactylus group. It can be distinguished from other congeners by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, which was recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). In the Boana pulchella group. Boana curupi can be distinguished from other species in the group by larval, morphological and advertisement call features (Garcia et al. 2007).

Allocated to the genus Ischnocnema following Heinicke et al. (2007). The name Ischnocnema henselii is resurrected to accommodate a species that was first detected through differences in advertisement call parameters (Kwet and Solé 2005).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Gehara et al. 2013).
Ischnocnema penaxavantinho is diagnosed on the basis of adult morphology, advertisement call, and ecology (Giaretta et al. 2007).
Hylodes fredi is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters and advertisement call features (Canedo and Pombal 2007).
Phyllomedusa araguari differs from other similar species in colour pattern, size, advertisement call and breeding site (Giaretta et al., 2007).

In the R. marina group according to the original publication. Rhinella achavali can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features and colour patterns (Maneyro et al. 2004).

In the Rhinella margaritifera group according to the original publication. Rhinella martyi can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and vocalization features (Fouquet et al., 2007).

In the Rhinella marina group, Rhinella cerradensis can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological characters (adult and tadpole), colour patterns and advertisement call features (Maciel et al. 2007). Ferraro et al. (2018) noted problematic subpopulations of Rhinella cf. cerradensis in Argentina. The taxonomic status of these populations still needs defined, so it has not been included in this assessment.
In the Chiasmocleis leucosticta group according to the original publication. Chiasmocleis sapiranga is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters and colour patterns (Cruz et al. 2007).
In the Scinax perpusillus group according to the original publication. Scinax faivovichi is diagnosed by a combination of morphological characters (Brasileiro et al. 2007).

Phyllodytes maculosus is believed to be related to Phyllodytes kautskyi. It is distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Cruz et al. 2006).

Specimens named as P. maculosus would actually represent one of the morphs of P. kautskyi (Novaes-e-Fagundes and Solé 2021).
See comments by Garda et al. (2010) regarding the evidentiary ambiguity of distinctiveness from Lysapsus limellus.

Based on morphometric and call differences, Funk et al. (2007, 2008) suggested that E. petersi (termed Physalaemus petersi by those authors) encompasses the north-western Amazon clade while the south-western Amazon clade corresponds with E. freibergi (termed Physalaemus freibergi) corroborating the proposal of Ron et al. (2006).
Gastrotheca ernestoi was revalidated by Caramaschi and Rodrigues (2007) based on morphological features.

In the Crossodactylus gaudichaudii group according to the original description. Crossodactylus cyclospinus is differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological and advertisement call features (Nascimento et al. 2005).
This is a species complex (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously known as Astacus Brasiliensis Von Martens (1869).

It is likely that this species represents a species complex with one or more distinct species in the Caribbean region.  The nominal species occurs in southeastern Brazil (J. Williams pers. comm. 2009).
In the tropical Eastern Pacific, Caranx crysos is replaced by Caranx caballus (Günther 1869)
The taxonomy and key characteristics of Brama spp. are in need of review (FAO ECA guide in prep RL Haedrich).
Potential taxonomic problem: Amphichthys hildebrandi (Breder 1925) may be a valid species, although Collette (2003) considered it as a junior synonym of A. cryptocentrus.
There is some genetic differentiation between samples from the Atlantic and those from the Mediterranean, but not at the species level (Vinas et al. 2010).

The synonymy of Chromis bermudae under C. flavicauda was recently revisited by Smith-Vaniz and Collette (2013). They concluded that C. bermudae is a valid species, therefore, C. flavicauda is now known only from Brazil.

This species also seems to be sympatric with Macroramphosus gracilis around the world (Dyer and Westneat 2010). However, there is still some debate about the taxonomic separation of the two species (Granadeiro and Silva 2000). The latest research suggests that M. gracilis represents a different ontological stage of M. scolopax rather than a separate species (Robalo et al. 2009, Noguchi et al. 2015), and this approach is followed here.

However, Noguchi et al. (2016) have foreshadowed that it is likely two different species in the Atlantic and Pacific. Noting that M. scolopax was described from the Mediterranean and that M. gracilis was described from Madeira in the eastern Atlantic, there is probably an undescribed species from the Pacific. The description of this Pacific species of Macroramphosus may be forthcoming from Noguchi et al., but this needs to be confirmed with those authors.

This species has been divided into several subspecies (Shakhovskoy 2007): Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus pinnatibarbus (Bennett 1831), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus altipennis (Valenciennes 1847), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus californicus (Cooper 1863), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus japonicus (Franz 1910), Cheilopogon pinnatibarbatus melanocercus (Ogilby 1885).
Previously in Remorina, but is currently placed in Remora (Gray et al. 2009).
At least six subspecies have been recognized.
This species was previously within the genus Strabomantis but has been moved to the genus Haddadus (Amaro et al. 2013).
In the Leptodactylus fuscus species group according to the original description (Caramaschi et al. 2008).

Associated with the Dendrophryniscus brevipollicatus group according to the original description (Cruz and Fusinatto 2008).


Species with taxonomic, distribution and threats uncertainties. The specimens from Santa Catarina are D. berthalutzae, and there is an indication that D. berthalutzae may be synonymous with D. krausae, but there is no material from specimens from Rio Grande do Sul to verify and confirm that it is the same species (Paulo Garcia, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
There is a taxonomic problem with this species, Phasmahyla spectabilis may be synonymous of P. timbo (D. Baêta and I. Dias pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
There is a taxonomic problem with this species, Phasmahyla timbo may be synonymous with Phasmahyla spectabilis (D. Baêta pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
In the Physalaemus olfersii species group according to the original description (Cruz et al. 2008).
The taxonomic status of the population in São Bento do Sul is uncertain (A. Kwet pers. comm. June 2009). Was confused with Trachycephalus imitatrix (Miranda-Ribeiro, 1926) prior to its naming.
In the Hylodes nasus species group according to the original species description.
In the Melanophryniscus moreirae group according to the original description (Maneyro et al. 2008).
This species is commonly misidentified in collections with Chiasmocleis bassleri and Chiasmocleis shudikarensis (P. Peloso pers. comm. 2009).
Garrison (2006) considers this species as a possible junior synonym of Mnesarete guttifera, although he did not formally synonymize them pending examination of more specimens from Bahia State
This is the smallest Argia species (20-23 mm).
Was included in R. cornigera (Aeshna cornigera) until von Ellenrieder (2003).

This species is distinguished by the following characters: dorsal surface of the disc dark brown, with irregular yellow spots, oval to reniform, usually larger than eye diameter, teeth relatively, small, wider than long, with flat crowns. lack prominent cusps except in mature males. Middorsal tail spines low relatively to basal diameter, in irregular parallel rows (Rosa 1985).

Taxonomic issues with this species are due in part to the fact that the holotype was originally in the private collection of Fernándo-Yépez and only the caudal sting, mouth and edge of the disc remain. Rosa (1985) when referring to Potamotrygon schroederi may have mistaken this species for a new species (presently in description by Ricardo Rosa and Maria Lúcia Araújo).
This species could be misidentified as P. scobina (Almeida, pers. obs.) and P. castexi (Rosa 1985), which have similar colour patterns.

This species is often misidentified and may be mistaken with P. scobina, P. signata and P. falkneri (author's personal observations). Rosa (1985) indicated that these species together with P. castexi may form a species complex.

This species shows a wide range of colour variation. Misidentifications occur with other potamotrygonid species such as P. constellata, P. castexi and possibly with P. motoro (Rincón pers. comm.) and P. humerosa.

Records from French Guiana, Guyana, Suriname and Venezuela this species are probably P. orbignyi (Carvalho et al. 2003). Live and fixed specimens are easily mistaken with P. orbignyi, P. humerosa and juveniles of P. brachyura (Charvet-Almeida and Almeida pers. obs.). P. histrix is also often misidentified as Potamotrygon sp. or Potamotrygon cf. histrix ("arraia cururu" from the Negro River basin) (Araújo pers. com.).

The lectotype designated by Castex (1969) is not considered valid (Rosa 1985, Carvalho et al. 2003).

The antenna ray is a well-established species with only one congener, the dwarf antenna ray (Plesiotrygon nana). This species differs from it by different colour, spiracles, snout, nasal curtain, and numbers of teeth, vertebrae and tail length (Last et al. 2016).

Specimens recorded at Estação Biológica de Boracéia, in the municipality of Salesópolis, São Paulo State, were assigned to P. gaigeae by Heyer et al. (1990). Later, Pombal and Haddad (1999) reallocated these specimens to P. poecilogaster (1990).
The taxonomy of Ruppia is not completely clear and there are some anomalous populations (e.g. in western Ireland) which do not conform well to described taxa.

Marajó Freshwater Stingray was first described as a subspecies of Potamotrygon hystrix by Engelhardt (1912), and later reclassified by Rosa (1985) as a valid species. The type specimen described by Engelhardt was lost during the II World War, then Rosa (1985) based his reclassification on another specimen collected in the same area. So based on those data and that there was no record of the species after, Last et al. 2016 remarks this species as a possible synonym of Potamotrygon motoro.
Holacanthus ciliaris are closely related to blue angelfish Holacanthus bermudensis Goode, and colouration is the only reliable character to separate these species (Feeley et al. 2009).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
Sem sinonímias nos últimos cinco anos. Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.

There have been no published papers synonymizing this species in the last five years.

There are no taxonomic limitations relevant to taxon validation.

There have been no published papers synonymising this species in the last five years.

There are no taxonomic limitations relevant to taxon validation.

Valid, well diagnosed species (see Marinho & Ohara, 2013). Recently transferred to the genus Makunaima (Téran et al., 2020).

Glanidium catharinensis é conhecida apenas do holótipo. Até abril de 2013 não existiam outros registros da espécie desde sua descrição. Recentemente, foi encontrado um lote (MCP 29701) com exemplares da localidade tipo, na qual poderá ser feito um estudo detalhado a respeito da validade da espécie. Há fortes evidências, já levantadas por outros autores como (Mees 1974), de que esta espécie pode se tratar de um sinônimo júnior de Glanidium ribeiroi (Haseman 1911), (B.B. Calegari com. pess. 2013).

The taxonomic status of all these populations is not completely clear, populations outside the upper Paraná basin in Brazil being much more variable in meristics and mouth position (which is always sub-inferior in the upper Paraná population, but often sub-terminal in other populations). The taxonomy of the species (or species-complex) is currently under study by Heraldo Britski and Júlio Garavello (2007).
The species is valida as Megaleporinus obtusidens.

Para essa espécie só pode ser atribuída, no momento, uma descrição genérica de Rineloricaria lima, que é taxonomicamente problemática. O espécime de R. lima foi perdido e foi baseado em uma amostra seca que caracteriza a maioria das espécies do gênero (Ingenito  et al. 2008).

Electrophorus electricus corresponded to a complex of species widely distributed throughout the Amazon. With the review by de Santana et al. (2019), the distribution of the species was restricted to the drainages of the Guiana shield.

Phenacogaster beni belongs to the Phenacogaster pectinatus species complex and cannot be clearly diagnosed from P. suborbitalis, P. microstictus, and P. pectinatus (Lucena & Malabarba, 2010).

A taxonomia da espécie é incerta (Reis e Lima 2009). A série-tipo (cinco exemplares) atribuída a Hypostomus unae possui localidade incerta. Existe forte indício de se tratar da espécie presente no rio Una, nas proximidades da cidade de Valença e são necessários maiores estudos para avaliar a real distribuição e aspectos biológicos da espécie. Estudos de ecologia no Estado da Bahia, especialmente nas bacias dos três rios de nome Una, atribuem a exemplares de Hypostomus o epíteto unae. Entretanto, em função da taxonomia incerta, existe a necessidade de confirmação efetiva dessas identificações.
Taxonomic revision has just commenced.  Therefore nobody can tell what is meant by this species.

There is confusion about what entity the specific name refers to, however the genus is widespread throughout the Amazon.
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.
This species has been confused with P. guttatus (Vianna 1986).
This species continues to be confused with S. brasiliensis (Rathbun 1906), due to their similar colour patterns and locally sympatric distributions (Tavares et al. 2009).

There are two recognized subspecies for the species. Panulirus argus argus is found north of the equator and Panulirus argus westonii is found south of the equator in Brazil, however this is an invalid name (Sarver, Silberman and Walsh, 1998).
Justitia mauritiana is now a synonym of this species.

The Pacific Chub Mackerel (Scomber japonicus) has a Pacific distribution,and is replaced in the Atlantic by Scomber colias (Scoles et al. 1998, Collette 1999). Microsatellite and mitochondrial cyt b confirm that Scomber australasicus and S. japonicus are also separate species (Tzeng et al. 2009). Scomber japonicus is apparently absent from Indonesia and Australia, where it is replaced by Scomber australasicus (Collette 2001). The population from the Red Sea and northern Indian Ocean (the Gulf of Aden and Oman) is Scomber australasicus (Baker and Collette 1998).
Confused with the eastern Atlantic T. belone until described as a distinct species by Robins and de Sylva (1963).

Blue Marlin (Makaira nigricans) of the Indo-Pacific and the Atlantic are conspecific (Buonaccorsi et al. 1999, 2001; Collette et al. 2006). The Indo-Pacific Blue Marlin previously was known as Makaira mazara (Jordan and Snyder).

This species was previously known as Tetrapturus albidus (Collette et al. 2006). There is a question as to whether this species is distinct from the Pacific Striped Marlin, Kajikia audax (Graves 1998, Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011).
Recent genetic information suggests that this species is one highly connected population worldwide (Garber et al. 2005, Theisen et al. 2008).
Although the most distinct genetically of the four species of spearfishes (Collette et al. 2006, Hanner et al. 2011), this species was only recently confirmed as a valid species (Shivji et al. 2006).

Literature records previous to 1978 for Scomberomorus maculatus from the Caribbean and the Atlantic coasts of Central and South America apply to Scomberomorus brasiliensis, which was previously considered as Scomberomorus maculatus by many authors (Collette and Russo 1985).

There is no genetic evidence in the mtDNA control region to indicate that the Atlantic (Istiophorus albicans) and Indo-Pacific (Istiophorus platypterus) Sailfishes are separate species (Collette et al. 2006). However, there are two distinct mtDNA clades, both evident in the Atlantic while only one is found in the Indo-Pacific (McDowell 2002). There is also no difference in pectoral fin length or in any other morphometric or meristic characters between Atlantic and Indo-Pacific populations of sailfish (Morrow and Harbo 1969, McDowell 2002).
This species has been described four times in three different monotypic genera.
Prior to 1960, many authors have used the name Auxis thazard as including Auxis rochei in the belief that there was only a single worldwide species of Auxis.
Auxis rochei rochei (Risso, 1810) is worldwide except for the eastern tropical Pacific where it is replaced by A. r. eudorax Collette and Aadland, 1996.

This species is frequently misidentified as juvenile or female of Coryphaena hippurus.

The specific name is sometimes misspelled as equisetis instead of equiselis (Gibbs and Collette 1959).

Before 1960, many researchers thought that there was only one world-wide species in the genus Auxis, which was recorded as Auxis thazard (Collette and Aaland, 1996).

The species contains two subspecies;  A. rochei rochei (Risso, 1810) worldwide except for the eastern tropical Pacific where it is replaced by A. r. eudorax Collette and Aadland, 1996.
This species is now recognized as distinct from the Indo-Pacific Scomber japonicus (Collette 1999, Infante et al. 2007).

This species was assigned to the Boana benitezi group in its original description (Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carias 2008), and encompasses all the eastern Guiana populations previously determined as B. benitezi. The only specimen of B. tepuiana included in phylogenetics studies, comes from Vila Pacaraima in Brazil (Faivovich et al. 2005, Sturaro et al. 2020), but was erroneously determined as B. benitezi (USNM 302435).

A localidade-tipo da espécie é a caverna Areias de Cima, parte do sistema Areias, na margem esquerda do rio Betari, de onde provém a maior amostra estudada. As amostras provenientes das demais cavernas dessa margem, as quais, inclusive, localizam-se em aquíferos distintos, são relativamente pequenas, insuficientes para estudos morfológicos conclusivos no que diz respeito à identidade da espécie que, em princípio, encontra-se fragmentada. Além disso, essas populações estariam isoladas daquelas da margem esquerda do rio Betari, pois este corre sobre um dique de diabásio, insolúvel, que impede a conexão subterrânea entre esses dois conjuntos de cavernas. Diferenças morfológicas foram observadas, mas, novamente, o pequeno tamanho das amostras disponíveis, condicionado pelas dificuldades de acesso e pela aparente extinção de uma das populações da margem direita devido à poluição por mineração, ainda não permite conclusões robustas sobre o status taxonômico dessas populações. No entanto, a presença do dique de diabásio intersectando a área atribuída à espécie nominal é forte evidência de que existam pelo menos duas espécies crípticas; o nome P. kronei fica para a população das Areias, resultado de colonização e isolamento independentes, seguido de evolução paralela, fenômeno constatado para outras espécies troglóbias, tais como os lambaris cegos mexicanos do gênero Astyanax (E. Trajano e M.E. Bichuette obs. pess.).

The taxonomy of this species is questionable and it may eventually be found as conspecific with Halodule wrightii. Its taxonomic status is based on leaf-tip morphology which is highly variable (Larkum et al. 2006).
This species has often been confused with Halophila ovalis. Halophila decipiens is monoecious, has serrate leaf tips and hairs on both sides of its leaves.

Halodule wrightii is a well established species. However, the taxonomy of the other species of Halodule in the Atlantic is less certain (Larkum et al. 2006) and there are questions about its taxonomy in the Indo-Pacific as well (Green and Short 2003).
This species is sometimes included under the genus Abildgaardia.
This species is commonly confused with Acrostichum aureum. These species are often lumped together making it difficult to know the limits of the distribution.
This species is differentiated from A. germinans by cuticular waxes and AFLPs (see Dodd and Rafii 2002). It is a sister to A. bicolor (a Central American Pacific coast endemic).
Synonyms: Arctus americanus (S.I. Smith, 1869), Scyllarus gundlachi (Von Martens, 1872).
This species was split by Holthuis 1960 into S. chacei and S. americanus, as previous specimens have had some confusion between these two species.
This species was previously identified as H. cyanocephalus, but recent genetic research revealed that Brazilian populations belong to a valid species now recognized as H. dimidiatus (Rocha 2004).
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002). Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus, and I. verrens.
For taxonomic treatment see Gomon (2006).

There is some taxonomic confusion between the species under Xyrichtys and Iniistius. The genus Iniistius has been considered a synonym of Xyrichtys by some authors but it is now recognized as a separate genus, distinct from Xyrichtys (Randall and Earle 2002, Randall et al. 2002).

Seventeen species are included in Iniistius and they are: I. aneitensis, I. auropunctatus, I. baldwini, I. bimaculatus, I. cyanifrons, I. dea, I. evides, I. griffithsi, I. jacksoniensis, I. melanopus, I. pavo, I. pentadactylus, I. spilonotus, I. trivittatus, I. twistii, I. umbrilatus and I. verrens.

Halichoeres sazimai, n. sp. is described from the Western South Atlantic. During many years it was misidentified as H. bathyphilus from the Northwestern Atlantic, but it can be distinguished from the latter by striking color differences between the two species, with H. sazimai being characterized by a white body with a midline, zigzag patterned stripe on body, black and brownish in terminal males and yellow or golden in females and juveniles (Luiz et al. 2009).
This species was recently described in Heiser et al. (2000).
This species was previously identified as H. radiatus, but recent genetic research revealed that Brazilian populations belong to a valid species now recognized as H. brasiliensis (Rocha 2004).
This species was thought to occur along the Brazilian coast, but genetic research revealed that coastal Brazilian populations belong to a different species (Rocha 2004).
This species was previously identified as H. maculipinna, but recent genetic research revealed that Brazilian populations belong to a valid species now recognized as H. penrosei (Rocha 2004).
This species was previously recorded as Julis noronhana (Boulenger 1890).

The citations of C. ambigua to La Plata, Paraná and Paraguay rivers, and the lower reach of the Uruguay River must be carefully studied with the support of genetics considering the similarities to Castalia inflata, which predominates in these Southern hydrographic regions. It is possible that both species could be considered as synonyms.

There is still taxonomic uncertainty regarding the placement of the genus Gundlachia within the family Planorbidae/Anyclidae. Among recent molecular phylogenetic analyses, Albrecht et al. (2007) and Walther et al. (2006) both included Gundlachia in a Neotropical clade with Laevapex. Walther et al. (2006) also included Uncancylus within this group. However, these two authors disagree on the taxonomic implications of these phylogenies, with Walther et al. (2006) classifying the above genera within the Ancylidae, but Albrecht et al. (2007) including them within Planorbidae and creating a sub-family Ancylinae.
This species was originally classified as Gundlachia concentrica by d'Orbigny (1835). Fernandez (1981) reclassified it as Uncancylus concentricus.
There is some debate over whether the genus Musculium should in fact change to Sphaerium, with Musculium becoming demoted to subgenus level (Lee and O'Foighil 2003).

Haas (1969) recognises two subspecies D. p. parallelopipedon in the Paraguay and Parana Rivers, and D. p. acutirostris in the Uruguay River and adjacent coast streams. Parodiz (1968) recognised D. trifidus as valid.

There is some confusion as to the genus- and family-level classification of this species. Da Silva and Davis (1983) place records from Patagonia and the Falkland Islands under the genus Paludestrina and state that it does not belong to the family Hydrobiidae. Forcelli (2000) records the species from Chile under the genus Hydrobia, from the family Hydrobiidae. Previous classifications have all been based on morphological characters.

According to Cowie and Thiengo (2003), P. scalaris is considered a separate species, but Ghesquiere (2007) considers it to be part of the P. bridgesii complex. Cowie et al. (2006), however, consider it to be the head of the complex.

DeJong et al. (2001) found that the genetic distance between this species and other Biomphalaria was approximately the same as that between this species and Helisoma trivolvis. They suggest that this species might represent a third distinct genus-level lineage (DeJong et al. 2001).

At present, there are several subspecies; R. hylaea guaraniana, R. hylaea asuncionis and R. hylaea pazi. The status of this species is uncertain due to a lack of anatomical and glochidal information (A. Bogan pers. comm. 2011). Therefore the southern records for this species will probably be altered to Rhipidodonta guaraniana (d'Orbigny 1835) when this group is revised (K. Cummings pers. comm. 2011).

This species is placed in the family Mycetopodidae, not Unionidae (K.Cummings pers. comm. 2010). Work in progress suggests that there is more than one species represented under this name (A. elongatus). Until taxonomic issues are resolved this species cannot be assessed (K.Cummings pers. comm. 2010).
Graf and Cummings (2007) place this species in the genus Lamproscapha, which is a subgenus of Anodontites. Furthermore, they list Spix and Wagner, 1827 as the taxonomic authority for this species.
