The record of this species for the Orinoco must be revised because it may have been confused with the related species A.(A). crispatus or A. elongatus (Pereira et al. 2013).

Although some authors regard the Pisidium as worthy of listing as a distinct family (Pisiidae), traditionally it is still placed as a subfamily of the Sphaeriidae. We have followed this traditional placement in this assessment.
This species was originally of the genus Paludina.
This species was originally of the genus Ampullaria Montfort (1810).

This species has three subspecies: subspecies granosus (Bruguière, 1792), subspecies ellypticus (Spix, 1827) and subspecies multistriatus (Lea, 1834). Numerous taxa have been synonomised under granosus, and much work is needed to clarify this species' taxonomy (K. Cummings pers. comm. 2010).
This species is referred to as Asolene (Pomella) megastoma in Pilsbry (1933) and Darwich et al. (1989), but Pomella megastoma in Damborenea and Brusa (2008).
This species is a synonym of Castaliella sulcata (Krauss, 1849) (Simone 2006).
This species is classified under the Canaliculata complex.
This species was placed in the genus Stenophysa by Taylor (2003), but subsequent molecular analyses included it within the family Physidae and genus Physa (Wethington and Lydeard 2007).

A population known from Perau de Janeiro, Municipality of Arvorezinha, is regarded as belonging to this species (A. Kwet pers. comm. October 2010), although differences noted by the describing author (Kwet 2008) may justify its future description as a separate named species.

Species of Gastrotheca were briefly included within the family Amphignatodontidae, in which the describing authors placed G. flamma (Juncá and Nunes 2008). This family is no longer recognized (Frost 2010).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
A monograph of Castelnavia (Podostemaceae) (Philbrick et al. 2009) documents the known distribution of the species.
A monograph of Castelnavia (Podostemaceae) (Philbrick et al. 2009) documents the known distribution of the species.

A monograph of Castelnavia (Podostemaceae) (Philbrick et al. 2009) documents the known distribution of the species.

Philbrick et al. (2009) recognize two taxonomic forms of C. multipartita (f. multipartita, f. pendulosa), the latter of which may be an environmental form of the former. Additional field study is needed before this issue is resolved. Consequently, this assessment makes no attempt to distinguish between the two taxonomic forms.
A recently described species.
A monograph of Castelnavia (Podostemaceae) (Philbrick et al. 2009) documents the known distribution of the species.
The taxonomy is discussed in Philbrick et al. (2004).
The taxonomy is discussed in Philbrick et al. (2004).
This species was described by Philbrick et al. (2004).

The species was originally described in 1849. Recent taxonomic study (Philbrick and Novelo 2004) confirmed the species status but indicated that only a single collection documented the location of this species.
The taxonomy of the species is discussed in the monograph of Podostemum (Philbrick and Novelo 2004).
Philbrick and Novelo (2004) discuss the nomenclature of the species.
The taxonomy of the species is discussed in the monograph of Podostemum (Philbrick and Novelo 2004).

Stygichthys typhlops é uma espécie altamente especializada para a vida no meio freático. É o único Characiforme troglóbio da América do Sul. Gênero monotípico, descrito de um único exemplar coletado na década de 1960, foi então atribuído ao complexo Hyphessobrycon-Hasemania de Tetragonopteridae (Characidae). Com base em amostra de 26 exemplares coletados 40 anos depois, Moreira et al. redescreveram a espécie, porém a questão da posição taxonômica ainda não estava resolvida. Oliveira et al. (2011), entretanto, encontraram evidências morfológicas e filogenéticas para manter a espécie em Characidae, sendo que S. typhlops forma um grupo robusto com Coptobrycon bilineatus, tendo como grupo-irmão, o grupo composto por Probolodus heterostomus, Deuterodon iguape e Myxiops aphos. Todas essas espécies habitam formações geológicas antigas das regiões nordeste e sudeste do Brasil, que também são áreas de residência de linhagens primitivas de outros importantes grupos de peixes, como aqueles pertencentes às famílias Trichomycteridae e Loricariidae. Note-se que, a despeito da grande diversidade de Characiformes em corpos d´água epígeos, apenas S.typhlops especializou-se para a vida subterrânea, em contraste com as mais de 36 espécies troglóbias de Siluriformes na América do Sul. Tal característica, muito rara entre Characiformes, ilustra a relevância taxonômica dessa espécie singular (M.E. Bichuette ob. pess.).
The identity of subpopulations outside the state of Rio de Janeiro require clarification.

The West Indian manatee (Trichechus manatus) is currently divided into two subspecies: the Florida (T. m. latirostris) and Antillean (T. m. manatus) manatees (Hatt 1934, Domning and Hayek 1986). The mtDNA data (García-Rodríguez et al. 1998) and molecular data (Vianna et al. 2006) revealed a population structure with three distinctive lineages corresponding geographically with: (1) Florida, Mexico, the Greater Antilles, Central America, and the Caribbean coast of South America; (2) Mexico, Central America, and the Caribbean coast of South America; and (3) NE South America from Guyana to Brazil. Evidence exists for viable hybridization with T. inunguis near the mouth of the Amazon River, Guyana, French Guiana, and possibly Suriname (Lima et al. 2019).

Recent cranial and chromosomal geographic variation data from Antillean manatees in Brazil show morphological discontinuity and chromosomal divergence within T. m. manatus and the Brazilian population south of the Amazon. These data suggest that the current taxonomy of T. manatus needs to be revised (Barros et al. 2016).

A strangely disjunct population from Óbidos, Pará State, Brazil, was described as a subspecies by Cochran (1948). Bokermann (1967) doubted the correctness of this locality and assumed that the specimens came from Itatiaia.
In the Physalaemus signifer group according to the original publication (Frost 2007). In the Physalaemus olfersii group of Nascimento et al. (2005).
The generic name for this was misspelt in the 1996 Red List as Orymaeus.

In the 1996 Red List this was incorrectly listed as Tornigenus gibberulus ssp. Digerus. The generic name was misspelt and the ssp. given was in fact the subgeneric name. It is still considered a valid species.
In the 1996 Red List this was incorrectly listed as Tornigenus turbinatus ssp. Biolocus. The generic name was misspelt and the ssp. given was in fact the subgeneric name.
Some taxonomists still refer to the species under the small genus Myracrodruon.
In the 1997 and 1998 assessments this species was under the misspelled name Mazilaurus itauba.
Morphologically a very distinct species from a monotypic section of Ludwigia.
Espécie descrita em: Revue Horticole (Paris) 154. 1868. Nome vulgar: buxo de boi, culhões de bode, ipê branco (Lohmann, L.G., 2020), Ipê felpudo (Zuntini 89), ipê-bóia (Mattos-Silva 2341).

Descrita em: Brittonia 33: 17, fig. 1981. É conhecida vulgarmente como imbirema (Prance, 1981; Lorenzi, 2002), e pode ser diferenciada das outras espécies que compõem a seção Echinata por apresentar indumento estrelado mais curto nas pétalas e por apresentar indumento estrelado extremamente visível no exterior do hipanto e dos lobos do cálice (Mori et al., 1990).

Descrita em: Brittonia 33(3): 469 (1981). Conhecida vulgarmente como falsa sapucaia ou sapucarana (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019). Durante o estudo de Smith et al. (2016) foi descoberto que a espécie E. alvimii como circunscrita por Mori e Prance (1990), provavelmente contém mais de uma espécie.
​Descrita em: Brittonia 33(3): 359 (1981).

Espécie descrita em: Repertorium Specierum Novarum Regni Vegetabilis 35: 340. 1934. Caracterizada por apresentar flores maiores que Cariniana legalis (Mart.) Kuntze e Cariniana estrellensis (Raddi) Kuntze e pecíolo não alado. Difere particularmente de C. legalis pela margem foliar crenada e base foliar reta não dobrada e de C. estrellensis, da qual é mais similar morfologicamente, pelas inflorescências terminais e pelos pedicelos curtos (Prance e Mori, 2019; Mori, 1995). Popularmente conhecida por Jequitibá-açu em português (Ribeiro et al., 2020).

Descrita em: Annalen des Kaiserlich-Königlichen Naturhistorischen Hofmuseums 5: 13. 1890. Árvore ou Arbusto conhecida popularmente como oiti boi, milho torrado da folha larga (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019). Folhas oblongas, estípulas e brácteas caducas (Prance, 1972).
Descrita em: Perkins, J., 1900. Botanische Jahrbücher für Systematik, Pflanzengeschichte und Pflanzengeographie 27(5): 656, f. 10C.

Descrita em: Vattimo-Gil, I., 1959. Archivos do Jardim Botânico do Rio de Janeiro 16: 42.Ocotea basicordatifolia tem semelhança com o grupo de O. velutina pelas características do indumento, porém, no aspecto geral lembra mais algumas espécies de Endlicheria (Rohwer, 1986). É caracterizada pelos ramos cilíndricos, ferrugíneo-tomentosos. Folhas alternas, coriáceas,obovadas a largo-elípticas. Inflorescência racemosa, ferrugíneo-tomentosa. Floresdiclinas, tépalas face ventral e dorsal ferrugíneo-tomentosas, papilosas. Fruto bacáceo, elíptico a ovalado pareliforme de margem simples tabacaeiro (Quinet, 2008).
Commonly known under the name of O. odorifera (Vellozo) Rohwer.
Descrita em: Proc. Kon. Ned. Akad. Wetensch. Ser. C, 85(4): 451. 1982. Espécie próxima a C. curranii (Berg et al., 1990).
Descrita em: Contr. U.S. Natl. Herb. 20: 237. 1919. Espécie muito próxima a C. floccosa (Berg et al., 1990).

Espécie descrita em: Synopsis Plantarum 1: 431, f. 95a, 96. 1839. Caracterizada por apresentar frutos lignificados por pedicelos puberosos mais curtos e folhas eucamptódromas (Mônico et al., 2017). Popularmente conhecida por abiu-grande no Pará, abiurana no Amazonas e abiu-cabeça-de-macaco (Cruz, 2017; Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2020). Esta espécie não ocorre na Costa Rica (esta espécie é P. lecythidicarpa) (Zamora pers. Comm. 2020).
The taxonomic status of the genus is not consolidated, there being confusion between this and A. cearensis (Allemão) A.C.Sm. The former is sometimes treated as a variety of the latter.
No passado, a espécie foi confundida com Ficus catappifolia e F. longifolia.
According to Eschmeyer the species Caecorhamdella brasiliensis is a valid name but also a synonym of Pimelodella kronei. Specific name corrected from brasilensis to brasiliensis.
Descrita em: Sellowia 8: 71. 1957. Conhecida pelo nome popular Guabirobeira, Guabiroba (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019) e Pitangueira (Stellfeld 1720) em Balneário Piçarras (SC).

Descrita em: Revis. Gen. Pl. 3[3]: 89. 1898. Conhecida popularmente como jequitibá-rosa, jequitibá-vermelho, jequitibá-cedro, jequitibá-de-agulheiro, estopa, jequitibá-grande, pau-caixão, pau-carga, jequitibá-branco, congolo-de-porco e caixão (Prance, Mori, 1979; Mori, 1995; Lorenzi, 2002). Possui proximidade morfológica com Cariniana parvifolia S.A.Mori et al. sendo diferenciada por apresentar ângulos dos ramos dentro da copa geralmente retos, casca interna avermelhada e fruto estreitando do anel calicino ao ápice (Mori 1995).

Descrita em: Bol. Tecn. Inst. Agron. N., n. 19:7., 1950. Aniba santalodora foi fundida a A. ovalifolia por Kostermans (1953), e de fato ambas as espécies correspondem pela superfície abaxial das folhas glabras e esterilidade no terceiro estame. Estas podem ser distintas, entretanto, pelo formato dos estames e das flores (parte tepalíferas superiores não maior que o tubo floral na antese em A. hypoglauca, onde é muito maior em A. santalodora. Apresenta folhas coriáceas, ovato-lanceoladas, brilhantes glabras na face adaxial. Inflorescências em panículas agrupadas no topo dos ramos. Flores amarelas, tomentosas (Kubtzki e Renner, 1982). Nome popular: Louro-jacaré (Carneiro, 2010). Madeira marcadamente aromática (Rodrigues 5297).
Descrita em: Eichler, A., 1870. Videnskabelige Meddelelser fra Dansk Naturhistorisk Forening i Kjøbenhavn 1870: 206.Popularmente conhecida por bapeba veludo (Lima, 2017).
Descrita em: Revis. Tabernaemontana 2. New World sp. & Stemmadenia 283 (1994).

Descrita em: Systema Vegetabilium, editio decima sexta 1: 666. 1825[1824]. Árvore que ocupa floresta em diferentes estágios de regeneração. Está intimamente relacionada a C. paranaense e C. flexuosum. Difere bastante das espécies C. flexuosum e C. paranaense pelo seu indumento ferrugíneo característico e pela forma do fruto Pennington (1990), sua coloração é facilmente observada em campo.
Descrita em: Bentham, G., & Hooker, J., 1876. Genera Plantarum 2: 653. Popularmente conhecida por guapeba e marmeleiro-do-mato (Bentham e Hooker, 1876).
Closely related to L. pubescens. The separation of the two taxa in Sâo Paulo poses such difficulty that it is possible they may be considered taxonomically the same species.
Descrita em: Flora Brasiliensis 4(1): 281, pl. 77. 1857. (Fl. Bras.)
Descrita em: Trans. Linn. Soc. London 30(2): 248. 1874. Conhecida vulgarmente por ibiribá-rana e sapucaia miuda (Flora do Brasil, 2019).

El material tipo de Lecythis ollaria colectado por Loefling se perdió y esto ha sido causa de confusión en la nomenclatura de la especie. Por esta razón, fue designado un neotipo por Prance y Mori (1977). Sin embargo, de acuerdo a lo indicado por Dorr y Wiersema (2010), la especie fue tratada erróneamente por los autores antes citados como publicada por Loefling, cuando fue publicada por Linneo con base en las descripciones del primero. Por lo tanto su nombre correcto no es Lecythis ollaria Loefl. sino Lecythis ollaria L (Dorr y Wiersema 2010, Tropicos.org 2021). Adicionalmente, existen cuatro homónimos de la especie: Lecythis ollaria Vell., Lecythis ollaria Saldanha y Lecythis ollaria Spruce que hoy tienen otros nombres válidos (Tropicos.org 2021).
Descrita em: Flora Ilustrada Catarinense 436. 1970. Conhecida pelo nome popular Guamirim em

Descrita em: Annales du Musée Colonial de Marseille, sér. 3, 3: 22. 1915.Popularmente conhecida como maparaju, massaranduba (maçaranduba), massaranduba folha de jaca, massaranduba rosa (Bahia) ou paraju (Penninton, 1990).

Descrita em: Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 48–50, 4A–D. 1990. Manilkara maxima é uma espécie arbórea, distinta com flores consideravelmente maiores que as demais espécies do gênero. Possui folhas e corola glabras (Penninton, 1990). Conhecida popularmente como maçaranduba e geralmente são indivíduos emergentes nas florestas.

Descrita em: Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 208–210, f. 39B. 1990. Arbustos ou Árvores pequenas. Suas folhas densamente coriáceas, obovadas e emarginadas com face abaxial intensamente sericea vermelho-ferrugineo, corola e frutos pequenos (Pennington, 1990).
Possibly not distinct from M. guyanensis (A.DC.) Pierre.

Espécie descrita em: Memoirs of The New York Botanical Garden 23: 210. 1972. Caracterizada por apresentar folhas finamente estriadas, com indumento marrom-avermelhado persistente na superfície inferior das folhas, as flores grandes com estames exsertados e frutas em bico (Pennington, 2006).
Descrita em: Comunicaciones Botanicas del Museo de Historia Natural de Montevideo 2(28): 6. 1953.
​Descrita em: Comunicaciones Botanicas del Museo de Historia Natural de Montevideo 2(28): 4. 1953.
Descrita em: Brittonia 32(3): 372. 1980.
​Descrita em: Sellowia 13: 306, f. 11, 30D. 1961.
Descrita em: Coe-Teixeira, B., 1975. Acta Amazonica 5(2): 170 (–171), f. 9.
Additional material is required to confirm its taxonomic status as separate from N. hihua (Ruiz & Pav.) Rohwer and N. leucantha Nees & Mart..
Descrita em: Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 269–270, f. 59E–G. 1990. (26 Apr 1990) (Flora Neotropica, Monograph). Popularmente conhecida como massaranduba na Bahia (Alves-Araújo et al., 2019).

Descrita em: Pennington, T., 1990. Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 328–329, f. 70A–D. Pouteria bapeba pertence ao grupo de P. durlandii e P. anteridata. Difere destas por possuir indumento marrom na face abaxial foliar e quanto às proporções florais (Pennington, 1990).  Popularmente conhecida por bapeba e bapeba-branca (Alves-Araújo et al., 2019).
Descrita em: Baehni, C., 1942. Candollea 9: 257. Popularmente conhecida por Guacá, Guapeva, Guapeva-vermelha
Descrita em: Pennington, T., 1990. Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 501, f. 114a.Popularmente conhecida por cupão, fruta-de-manteigae pão-do-mato (Alves-Araújo et al., 2019).
Descrita em: Rizzini, C., 1976. Rodriguésia 28: 174. Popularmente conhecida por "Bapeba-branca, Guapeba".

Descrita em: Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 440. 1990. Pouteria furcata está relacionada a P.beaurepairei, P. psammophoila e P. fimbriata as quais apresentam o hilo da semente em posição adaxial. Sedistingue das demais espécies por apresentar distinto indumento e venação. Pouteria cicatricata é a únicaespécie que se assemelha ao padrão de venação de P. furcata, mas se difere desta por apresentar o hilorecobrindo maior área da superfície da semente (Pennington, 1990). Popularmente conhecida como goiaba-leiteira ou tuturuba (Alves-Araújo et al., 2019).

Descrita em: Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52:: 321. 1990. (Pennington, 1990).Popularmente conhecida como Massaranduba, massaranduba-mirim (Pennington, 1990), abiu-de-macaé (Santos, 2017), Bapeba (Thomas 8715) na Bahia e Ripeira branca (Folli 6363) no Espírito Santo.

Descrita em: Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 411. 1990. Pouteria oxypetala difere de todas as outras espécies do grupo por possuir folhas grandes com numerosa venação secundária, indumento seríceo pálido na face abaxial, pecíolos longos, flores grandes, corola com lobos levemente agudos. Somente P. grandis tem o mesmo tipo de indumento, mas este é ferrugíneo-avermelhado, com folhas mais estreitas, pecíolo fortemente canalizado e lobos da corola obtusos (Pennington, 1990).

Descrita em: Pennington, T., 1990. Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 409–411, f. 90A–B.Popularmente conhecida por Bapeba no Brasil (Tropical Plants Database, 2019), guapeba (Feitosa, 2004), manteiguinha (Germano Filho et al., 2000).

Descrita em: Phytologia 43: 474 (-475), pl. 1979. Rinorea bicornuta é próxima de R. guianensis, R. bahiensis e R. paniculata, caracterizando-se dentre estas espécies pela inflorescência curtamente tirsóide contendo címulas laterais, geralmente com 3-5 flores; pedicelos com 1-3 mm de comprimento; flores e ramos florais mais velhos notavelmente deflexos; ramos florais cônicos e ápice da antera arredondado apendiculado por duas extremidades agudas (Hekking, 1988).

Descrita em: Pires, J., & Pennington, T., 1990. Flora Neotropica, Monograph 52: 645–646, f. 149c, 151K–N. Pradosia granulosa se difere de P. subverticillata por apresentar fino indumento nas partes jovens e pelas nervuras quaternárias formarem um retículo areolado e por seu fruto ser granular-papiloso, verrucoso (liso e glabro em P. subverticillata) (Penninton, 1990).
Descrita em: Toledo, J., 1946. Arquivos de Botânica do Estado de São Paulo 2: 29.Popularmente conhecida por Buranhém, Casca-doce no Brasil (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019)

Descrita em: Phytologia 53: 255 (-257), fig. 1983. Rinorea ramiziana se diferencia de R. maximiliani e R. laevigata pelas inflorescências tirsóides, e pelos pedicelos e estilete menores que 3 mm (Hekking, 1988).

Descrita em: Phytologia 53(4): 254 (1983). Rinorea villosiflora se caracteriza por apresentar folhas glabras; pétalas maiores que 4 mm e com ápice agudo; anteras com 1,75 mm de comprimento; escamas do conectivo 1-1,5 vezes maior que as anteras; cápsulas densamente pilosas (semelhante as de R. vaupesana) com valvas internamente (Hekking, 1988).

Descrita em: Ducke, W., 1942. Tropical Woods 71: 13–14. Pradosia subverticillata é uma espécie distinta por possuir folhas glabras subverticiladas, com nervuras secundárias paralelas e nervuras terciárias finas. Possui semelhanças com P. granulosa, P. glaziovii e P. verrucosa (Penninton, 1990). Popularmente conhecida como pau-doce (Ducke s.n.).
Descrita em: Pennington, T., 1981. Flora Neotropica, Monograph 28: 185–187, f. 38, map 37.
Descrita em: Flora Neotropica, Monograph 28: 172–174, f. 32, map 34. 1981.

Descrita em: Meisner, C., 1870. Videnskabelige Meddelelser fra Dansk Naturhistorisk Forening i Kjøbenhavn 8–11: 141. Popularmente conhecida como: "Louro" (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019) e "Canela-amarela" (Moraes, 2005).Nectandra warmingii é semelhante a N. puberula, parecendo sua forma maior, ou a uma N. hihua pilosa. Porém pode ser separada de N. puberula pelas diferentes proporções das flores. A principal característicaque a separa de N. hihua é realmente a densidade da pilosidade (Rohwer, 1993). Rohwer (1993) apontou também a possibilidade da espécie não ser nativa de Brasília, uma vez que nos rótulos de Heringer 6870 e Heringer 17572 (e também Heringer 18670) há as indicações da espécie ter sido plantada por Heringer e ter sido cultivada de sementes procedentes da divisa de Minas Gerais e Espírito Santo, respectivamente (Moraes, 2005). É caracterizada pelas folhas alternas, lanceoladas. Inflorescências na axila de folhas jovens. Flores com 6 a 9,5 mm (Rohwer, 1993).
This species is also known under the name Cyphomandra fragrans (Hook.) Sendtn. It was on the Red List under Solanum prior to 2005.
The genus is in need of taxonomic revision.

Descrita em: Van der Werff, H., 1993. Kew Bulletin 48(1): 25. Persea glabra se assemelha a Ocotea langsdorffii (Meissner) Mez; ambas possuem folhas epecíolos similares, porém Ocotea langsdorffii, restrita à Serra do Cipó, MG, possui nervuras de ambas a faces levantadas e difere também nas detalhes florais. P. glabra é próxima à P. venosa Nees, a qual se diferencia por apresentar folhas mais largas, brotos terminais pubescentes e flores maiores (van der Werff, 1993).
Descrita em: Memoirs of The New York Botanical Garden 74(1): 237. 1996.
Until the fruit is discovered, there will be some doubt as to the taxonomic placement of this species.
Descrita em: Memoirs of The New York Botanical Garden 74(1): 135. 1996.

Descrita em: Anales Jard. Bot. Madrid 50(2): 200. 1992. Chionanthusmicranthus é distinta por suas flores bastante pequenas, reunidas em uma panícula axilar, frequentemente a alguma distância do ápice caulinar (Green, 1994).
Descrita em: Kew Bull. 49(2): 272. 1994 [25 May 1994]

The genus Licania, which is confined to the Neotropics, is highly polyphyletic in molecular phylogenetic analyses. These studies show that the three subgenera of Licania, as well as sections within them, are not supported as monophyletic. Sothers et al. (2016) have re-delimited the genus using a molecular phylogenetic analysis as a framework and placed the former Lincania species under eight genera, namely Licania, Moquilea, Leptobalanus, Hymenopus, Microdesmia, Parinariopsis, Geobalanus and Cordillera.
Descrita em: Bol. Ci. Técn. Mus. Comercial Venezuela 1: 16. 1927

Espécie descrita em: Nat. Pflanzenfam. [Engler & Prantl] 3, Abt. 8: 36 (1894). Nome aceito Sciodaphyllum sprucei Seem.: Sciodaphyllum sprucei Seem., J. Bot. 3: 268 (1865). Brassaia sprucei (Seem.) Hutch., Gen. Fl. Pl. 2: 623 (1967). Schefflera sprucei (Seem.) Harms in H.G.A. Engler & K.A.E. Prantl, Nat. Pflanzenfam. 3(8): 36 (1894). Brazil, Ecuador and Peru. (Lowry et al. 2019)

Descrita em: Flora Brasiliensis 7: 102. 1863. Chrysophyllum viride pode ser confundida com C. gonocarpum por ambas possuírem órgãos reprodutivos muito semelhantes, a distinção é baseada na morfologia das folhas (Penninton, 1990).

Descrita em: Linnaea 11: 396. 1837, como Sclerolobium denudatum, foi recombinada em 2006 como Tachigalia denudata em Catalogo das Arvores Nativas de Minas Gerais 140. 2006. Nome popular ingá-ferro (Smith s.n.) em Ubatuba, (SP).

Descrita em: Botanische Jahrbücher für Systematik, Pflanzengeschichte und Pflanzengeographie 33(Beibl. 72): 24. 1903 como Sclerolobium pilgerianum. Recombinada como Tachigali em 2006 em Catalogo das Arvores Nativas de Minas Gerais 140. 2006. Nomes vulgares: "caingá" (RJ), "ingá-louro" (ES) e "mucambo" (BA) (Silva, 2007); e "tapassuaré" (RJ) (Medeiros, 2009).
Descrita em: Brittonia 39(2): 245–247, f. 1. 1987. Conhecida pelo nome popular Araçá miúdo (Siqueira 1228) em Linhares (ES).
Descrita em: London J. Bot. 4: 601. 1845. Nome vulgar: ingá-da-restinga (Flora do Brasil, 2019).
It is possibly of hybrid origin.
Descrita em: London J. Bot. 4: 602. 1845
Descrita em: Gen. Inga, Bot. 542. 1997
Descrita em: Genus Inga. Botany 245 (1997). Nome vulgar: ingá-miudo (ES) (Flora do Brasil, 2019).
Descrita em: London J. Bot. 4: 583. 1845. Nomes populares: "ingá mirim", "ingá ferro" (SC), "ingá xixica", "ingá xixi" (SP, RJ) (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019).
Descrita em: Brittonia 46(1): 66 (1994)
Descrita em: London J. Bot. 4: 592. 1845
Descrita em: Gen. Inga, Bot. 678. 1997. Nome popular: "inga-preta" (Flora do Brasil, 2019).
Descrita em: Gen. Inga, Bot. 683. 1997. Nome vulgar: ingá-preta, ingá-veludo (Flora do Brasil, 2019).
Descrita em: Kew Bull. 54(4): 982. 2000
Descrita em: London J. Bot. 4: 607. 1845
Descrita em: Rodrigues, W., 1982. Acta Amazonica 12(2): 295–297.
Following Eschmeyer (2004) Catabasis acuminatus was transferred to Brycon acuminatus.
Following Eschmeyer (2004) Cynolebias marmoratus was transferred to Leptolebias marmoratus.
Outros nomes aplicados ao táxon: Cynolebias minimus (Myers 1942); Leptolebias minimus (Myers1942); Cynolebias ladigesi (Foersch 1958).
Sometimes misidentified with P. leopoldi or P. motoro. Needs correct identification and reliable diagnosis in order to control the ornamental fish trade in Amazonas, Pará and Tocantins States.
This freshwater stingray presents a moderate chromatic variation. It could be mistaken for Potamotrygon henlei, which has very similar colour patterns (authors´ pers. obs.).
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.
Rhinella marina is generally considered to be a complex of several species.
Genus and author names were incorrectly spelled as "Megalolulimus" and "Moiretes" in 1996 and 2000 Red Lists.

Sachsse et al. (1999), noted that this species was probably most closely related to Gastrotheca microdiscus, and transferred this species to Gastrotheca from Hyla, where it had been placed in the Hyla albomarginata Group by Duellman (1970). This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was placed in family Dicotylidae by Jones et al. (1992) and in Tayassuidae by Grubb (2005). The appropriate generic name has been debated. It was placed in genus Dicotyles by some authors, the genus Pecari by Grubb (1993, 2005), and the genus Tayassu by Jones et al. (1992). MtDNA data support the recognition of three genera of extant peccaries: Catagonus, Pecari, and Tayassu, with this species in the genus Pecari (Theimer and Keim 1998, Gongora and Moran 2005). DNA studies suggest that P. tajacu may consist of at least two major clades or lineages comprising specimens from North/Central and South America (Gongora et al. 2006, 2011) with structural chromosomal differences (Gongora et al. 2000, Adega et al. 2006). Additional studies are needed to clarify whether intra and/or inter-specific genetic and chromosomal variation is occurring within this species.

The degree of genetic separation between Polyprion americanus populations in the Atlantic, and those occurring in the southern Pacific (Australia and New Zealand) is similar to the degree of separation seen between P. americanus and congener P. oxygenios. Given ongoing developments in genetic sequencing, further examination may re-define Polyprion systematics.

The spelling of this species' name presents some variations. The original description contains Potamotrygon schuhmacheri and P. schühmacheri (Castex 1964). Taniuchi (1982) deleted the second ?h? (latinization) and the spelling P. schuemacheri was retained according to the first reviser principle (ICZN, article 32c) (Rosa 1985).

Misidentifications occur with other potamotrygonid species such as P. brachyura and P. histrix (Almeida and Charvet-Almeida, pers. obs.). Some authors suggest that this species could be a junior synonym of P. histrix (Carvalho et al. 2003). However, at present P. schuemacheri is considered a valid species. Further research and collections are needed.

This species shows a wide range of color variation within juvenile and adult specimens (adults may present up to four completely different color patterns) (Almeida 2003). Misidentifications occur with several other freshwater stingray species, but especially with P. motoro (Rosa 1985), P. castexi and P. signata (Almeida 2003, author's pers. obs.).

This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Brachycephalus ephippium by Heyer et al. (1990). The population to which this name has been applied by Heyer et al. (1990) does not agree with the diagnosis of B. nodoterga, and so questions remain over the taxonomic validity of this species.
Céspedez (2000) separated the taxon formerly known as Rhinella pygmaea into two species: R. pygmaea of coastal Brazil and R. bergi in the interior of the continent.

Cocroft et al. (1990) and Lötters et al. (2002b) suggested that Atelopus spumarius might be a complex of more than one species. Lescure and Marty (2001) recognize two subspecies: A. s. barbotini Lescure 1981; and A. s. hoogmoedi Lescure 1973 without arguments and in contrast to their earlier opinion. Lötters et al. (2002b) suggested that A. spumarius occurs in the upper Amazon Basin only (Peru, Colombia, Brazil); populations from southern Peru, Ecuador and central Brazil might refer to undescribed taxa within A. spumarius sensu lato. Populations from the Guianas and eastern Amazonia might be treated as A. hoogmoedi complex (maybe within A. spumarius sensu lato). Atelopus spumarius hoogmoedi is a synonym of A. spumarius under Lescure and Gasc (1986). This form is understood by Lescure and Gasc (1986) to be more or less A. spumarius sensu lato; however, A. spumarius hoogmoedi is not conspecific with A. spumarius sensu stricto (S. Lötters pers. comm.)
Lötters et al. (2011) elevated A. spumarius barbotini to species level.
This species might comprise a complex of more than one species. There are two subspecies in Argentina: R.a. mendocinus and R.a. arenarum.

Records of this species from Uruguay are in error. It has recently been shown to be a complex of more than one species, and R. abei, R. henseli, R. ornata, and R. pombali recognized (Baldissera et al., 2004).
There are significant differences among the specimens currently assigned to Rhinella dapsilis. Further systematic work is urgently required to resolve these difficulties.

This species has an uncertain status and is not known from the Amazon basin. It might be a synonym of Rhinella poeppigii. Duellman and Schulte (1992) pointed out that there is no known type specimen for this species, although Frost (2000) listed the distribution as "Peru and Paraguay", and Rodriguez et al. (1993) listed it as occurring in Puno Department, Peru. It is believed that the Peruvian record is a misidentification.
This species was elevated from subspecies status under Rhinella granulosa by Cei (1972). This species probably represents a complex of several cryptic species (D. Barrasso pers. comm. November 2017).
This species' taxonomic status is unclear, since it is probably a complex of several species.
This species does not occur in Goiás and Bahia states, Brazil; the erroneous records are probably related to Rhinella cerradensis (M. Solé, R. Bastos and D. Silvano pers. comm. 2020).
This taxon is a complex of more than one species. Subpopulations in Panama refer to an unnamed species in the Rhinella margaritifera complex.

Hoogmoed (1990) noted that this species was referred to erroneously as Rhinella dapsilis by Zimmerman and Bogart (1988), who removed it from the synonymy of Rhinella margaritifera (referred to as Bufo typhonius). The diagnostic differences between this form and geographically proximate members of the Rhinella margaritifera group are not well documented.

This species has often been considered a subspecies of Rhinella granulosa (e.g., Gallardo 1965). Céspedez (2000) separated R. pygmaea into two species: R. pygmaea of coastal Brazil and R. bergi in the interior of the continent.
The diagnostic differences between this form and geographically proximate members of the Rhinella margaritifera group are not well documented.
This species was formerly confused with Rhinella marina.
Ávila et al. (2012) suggest that the genus Amazophrynella may contain additional species. Rojas-Zamora et al. (2018) discussed that species diversity of the genus is grossly underestimated
This species might be a complex of more than one species.

This species was elevated to species level from M. stelzneri atroluteus by Klappenbach and Langone (1992). However, the external morphology and advertisement calls are almost indistinguishable between M. atroluteus and M. montevidensis (Kwet et al. 2005, Maneyro and Kwet 2008).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.

This species was elevated to species status by Cruz and Caramaschi (2003). Prior to this, it was considered to be a subspecies of Melanophryniscus stelzneri. Reexamination of specimens from the Argentinean provinces of Santa Fe (Baldo and Arzamendia 1997) and Santiago del Estero (Basso and Williams 1996) revealed that these records actually belong M. klappenbachi (Baldo 2001).
Elevated to full species status by Klappenbach and Langone (1992).
The species was revalidated by Caramaschi and Cruz (2002).
It may be a complex of species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2020).

Populations from Misiones formerly associated to this species are believed to pertain to Melanophryniscus aff. tumifrons (Baldo and Basso 2004).

This species has taxonomic problems. A study not yet submitted found strong evidence that this species needs to be synonymised (P. Colombo pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

The forms spectabilis and simplex were elevated to species status by Caramaschi and Cruz (2002). These authors also resurrected the species Melanophryniscus pachyrhynus, formerly considered a synonym of M. tumifrons. Records from Cambará do Sul e Canela (Braun and Braun 1980), Santa Catarina state, now refer to Melanophryniscus simplex (Colombo et al. 2007). The current concept of M. tumifrons is considered a complex of additional undescribed species; and some of these subpopulations may be under some degree of threat (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Vitreorana oyampiensis was synonymised with this species (Guayasamin et al., 2008).

Morales (2002 "2000") noted that earlier records from Ecuador, Suriname, Venezuela, French Guiana, and Peru apply to other species. Frogs known as Allobates brunneus from northern Orinoco in Venezuela have been separated as A. pittieri (La Marca et al. 2004). All reports of Allobates brunneus from Venezeula are considered A. aff. marchesianus rather than aff. brunneus as the marchesianus type locality is closer to the Venezuelan southern border (Barrio-Amoros et al. 2019). Records of this species from Mount Duida, Venezuela is probably applied to an undescribed species (Barrio-Amorós and Santos 2009). Reports from the Guianas and Brazilian state of Paraná, probably refer to other species (Santos-Pereira et al. 2018).

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) provided a corrected morphological diagnosis, restricted the range of the species based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and discussed the identities of some of the paratypes of this species noting that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) restricted the range of Allobates fuscellus based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and noted that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.
The status of this species is uncertain, it is possible that it may be a junior synonym of Hyalinobatrachium iaspidiensis (Ernst et al., 2005).
It is probably a complex of more than one species.

Several still undescribed species with exotrophic larvae have been confused with A. baeobatrachus (Vacher et al. 2017) in Suriname (Ouboter and Jairam 2012) and in Pará state, Brazil  (Avila-Pires et al. 2010). Fouquet et al. (2019) noted that subpopulations from southern French Guiana and Amapá, Brazil, differ genetically, morphologically, and in calls from each other and the subpopulations bearing the name in northern French Guiana.

Melo-Sampaio et al. (2018) restricted the range of Allobates fuscellus based on reidentifications of both morphologically and genetically identified specimens, and noted that some must be reassigned to Allobates trilineatus or Allobates gasconi.

Réjaud et al. (2020) noted a cryptic species within this taxon. Jaramillo-Martinez et al. (2021) provided a redescription of the species, including the recognition of a cryptic species including what they referred to as Allobates aff. trilineatus from the Brazilian state of Acre and from southern Peru in Panguana, Huanuco, and Puerto Maldonado, Madre de Dios and Allobates sp. from Requena, Loreto, Peru.

All reports of Allobates brunneus from Venezeula are considered A. aff. marchesianus rather than aff. brunneus as the marchesianus type locality is closer to the Venezuelan southern border (Barrio-Amoros et al. 2019, C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020).

Based on M. Napoli pers. comm. (2018), the species Allobates olfersioides (Lutz 1925) is an endemic species with wide geographic distribution throughout the Atlantic Forest, occurring from southeast to northeast of Brazil. The subpopulations of this taxon were allocated until recently in four valid species: A. alagoanus (Bokermann 1967), A. capixaba (Bokermann 1967), A. carioca (Bokermann 1967), and A. olfersioides. However, Verdade and Rodrigues (2007), in a taxonomic study that considered variables of external morphology, traditional morphometry, and color patterns of external surfaces, did not find support for the maintenance of four distinct species, which led them to gather all population samples until then known under the name A. olfersioides. This act, therefore, resulted in the synonymization of A. alagoanus, A. capixaba, and A. carioca (junior synonyms) with A. olfersioides (senior synonym), a decision that has been maintained until the present moment.A decade has passed since the study of Verdade and Rodrigues (2007) and, in the meantime, there has been a considerable increase in the integration of different disciplines in the solution of taxonomic problems. In this context, Forti et al. (2017) performed an acoustic analysis of the advertisement chants of specimens from A. olfersioides subpopulations in the states of Rio de Janeiro, Bahia (Igrapiúna), and Alagoas (Passo de Camaragibe), a study in which they found differences in the chants of these subpopulations. This result is in agreement with that suggested by Bokermann (1967), who indicated possible acoustic differences in relation to the temporal properties between A. olfersioides (Rio de Janeiro) and A. capixaba (Espírito Santo). Finally, the authors indicated the possibility of revalidation of at least two of the junior synonyms (A. alagoanus and A. capixaba). More recently, Grant et al. (2017), in a phylogenetic study of Dendrobatoidea species that included molecular data, found that samples from two subpopulations of A. olfersioides differed strongly from each other, one from the state of Rio de Janeiro (type-locality of A. carioca, two specimens) and another from the state of Alagoas (type-locality of A. alagoanus, one specimen), which led the authors to state that such populations could represent different species.Although the last two studies have shown important differences between A. olfersioides subpopulations, most notably among those located in the state of Rio de Janeiro (A. olfersioides and A. carioca), Espírito Santo (A. capixaba) and Alagoas (A. alagoanus), such studies did not aim to taxonomically review the above species and, no less important, did not constitute nomenclatural acts concerning the revalidation of the junior synonyms proposed by Verdade and Rodrigues (2007).

Most records of this species before 1990 refer to Dendrobates ventrimaculatus. Caldwell and Myers (1990) and Martins and Haddad (1990) independently concluded that the name Dendrobates (now Adelphobates) quinquevittatus Steindachner, 1864, had been misapplied in recent literature. It is currently restricted to a species that is neither as variable or widespread as previously thought, and which is known only from the upper Rio Madeira drainage of Rondonia and adjacent (southern) Amazonas, Brazil. In this account we follow the traditional, broader definition of the species.

This taxon might be comprised of several species, specimens from the type locality in the highlands being very different to specimens from the main part of the range. The Brazilian records reported as Colostethus peruvianus in Heyer (1976) from the Amazon basin in Brazil definitely do not correspond to this species, and probably belong to Allobates bacurau, A. caeruleodactylus, A. grillisimilis or A. masniger (T. Grant pers. comm. 2021).
In the Anomaloglossus stepheni group of Vacher et al. (2017) who noted that this clade is composed of several cryptic species in Suriname, French Guiana, and Brazil.
Assessors at the Amazon GAA workshop in Brazil raised questions as to the taxonomic validity of this species, but Morales (pers. comm.) is convinced that it is a valid species.

We follow Wollenberg et al. (2006) in considering Dendrobates azureus as a junior synonym of this species. Hoogmoed (2019) discussed nominal Dendrobates azureus and suggested reasons for doubting its synonymy.

Caldwell and Myers (1990) formally revived Ranitomeya ventrimaculata from the synonomy of Adelphobates quinquevittatus, where it had been placed by Silverstone (1975), but urged caution in dealing with it systematically. They emphasized that R. ventrimaculata contains an unknown number of undiagnosed species, some of which might be difficult to separate even when sympatric, but the name serves to accommodate certain populations previously assigned to A. quinquevittatus. 

This species was long referred to as Ranitomeya (or Dendrobates) duellmani. However, inspection of the original type series of Dendrobates ventrimaculatus Shreve revealed that the holotype was actually duellmani. Thus, duellmani Schulte was designated a junior synonym of ventrimaculatus Shreve (Brown et al. 2011). Genetic studies allowed the taxonomic separation between this species and Ranitomeya amazonica (Brown et al. 2011). Estupiñán et al. (2016) suggested on the basis of COI barcodes that cryptic species are likely.
The Bolivian subpopulation is geographically separated from the main subpopulation in Brazil, and has been confirmed as a different species, A. boehmei (Lötters et al. 2007).

Haddad and Martins (1994) noted that a similar, apparently unnamed, species occurs in the Amazonian lowlands of Peru, and that the review of Phyllobates pictus by Lescure (1976) is probably based on this species. Silverstone (1976) regarded this species as a pattern class of Phyllobates pictus.
One of the Brazilian subpopulations actually belongs to A. ignipedis - misidentified in the field (J. Brown pers. comm. April 2017).
Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.

The taxon was reviewed and separated into several species by Haddad and Martins (1994). At present this species includes the Venezuelan subpopulation of Heatwole, Heatwole and Solano (1965). It is thought to be a composite species (see Frost 2007).
Blotto et al. (2021) redeﬁned Nyctimantis to include Aparasphenodon.

Originally described under the genus Corythomantis (Mertens 1950), it was later reassigned by Trueb (1970) to the genus Aparasphenon based on morphological characteristics. Recently, Blotto et al. (2021) transferred it to Trachycephalus based on a phylogenetic analysis of the Lophyohylini tribe.
Guillory et al. (2020) consider Ameerega peruviridis a synonym or nomen dubium of this species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Aplastodiscus perviridis by Garcia et al. (2001).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla by Faivovich et al. (2005).
The species previously belonged to the family Hylidae (Faivovich, et al., 2005) and was subsequently moved from the genus Flectonotus by Duellman et al. (2011).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This genus has been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
Sachsse et al. (1999) suggested that it is a complex of more than one species. This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus is included in the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This name has been widely used for certain frogs from Colombia, Venezuela, the Guianas and the lower Amazon basin. It is highly likely that the subpopulations along the Caribbean lowlands and the Amazon basin are either specifically distinct (Duellman 1985 In: Frost (ed.), Amph. Species World: 123) or misidentified Boana punctata or Boana cinerascens (Hoogmoed and Gruber 1983; M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2018) or other species. For the purpose of this assessment, we treat B. albomarginata as a Brazilian endemic.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

According to the work of L. Malagoli, this species only occurs in the central portion of Serra do Mar. They are exclusive to Serra do Mar, and the other locations must be an unnamed species (C. Haddad pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). The specimens listed at the Museu Nacional in Rio de Janeiro and the records of the tombos for the municipality of Resende, state of Rio de Janeiro, are not B. astartea and must be a new species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, which was recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017).

It was previously known as Hyla biobeba, but taxonomic research has shown that the older name of Hyla lundii is correct (Caramaschi and Napoli 1994). This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas by Faivovich et al. (2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana by Dubois (2017).

Boana boans from the Venezuelan Gran Sabana are smaller than those in the lowlands and do not construct basin-like nests; instead, they breed in small, permanent streams. Their discs more closely resemble those of B. wavrini, and the tadpoles are also different. Duellman (1997) concluded that they might be specifically distinct from the widespread B. boans in the lowlands.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005). This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The subpopulation in Sao Paulo might be a different species.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). This is a species complex (Fouquet et al. 2021).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). 

It was considered a synonym of Boana (Hyla) granosa by Hoogmoed and Gruber (1983), and an application to the ICZN was made so that Hyla granosa had priority. However this was not achieved and hence B. cinerascens has priority. Much of the literature on this species refers to Boana (Hyla) granosa. Rivero (1964) noted differences between the northern and southern Venezuelan subpopulations, hence two species might be covered by this name. The subpopulations of French Guiana may belong to an undescribed species (Fouquet et al. 2019).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).  It was formerly considered by some authors (i.e., Miranda Ribeiro 1926, Barrio 1962) to be a synonym of Hypsiboas pulchellus.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was described from a single population and may be a synonym of D. jimi, a species morphologically indistinguishable from D. cerradensis and known from several locations in the southern part of the Cerrado, including the municipality of Campo Grande, in the state of Mato Grosso do Sul. Taxonomic and genetic studies are needed to determine whether this species is valid and has a restricted distribution, or whether it is a synonym of D. jimi (P.H. Valdujo pers. comm. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla by Faivovich et al. (2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). Throughout its extensive range from Central America to eastern Brazil, Hypsiboas crepitans, as now recognized, is variable in coloration, size, advertisement call, and calling sites. Consequently, it is highly likely that several species are recognizable within H. crepitans; one such probable taxon includes the frogs of the Gran Sabana.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla until it was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The characters reported in the account of the Suriname subpopulation by Ouboter and Jairam (2012) render the specimens to be members of the Boana semilineata group and not the Boana albopunctata group according to Marinho et al. (2020).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
There is a taxonomic problem and this species still needs to be better differentiated or synonymized with D. pseudomeridianus (Orrico et al. 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probable that this is a complex of several species. Further systematic studies are needed to resolve the taxonomy of the complex.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is a complex of a few species (S. Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm. 2003, V. Dill pers. comm. 2021).

It was originally described under the genus Hyla (Cochran and Goin, 1970). Duellman (1974) synonymized it with Hyla punctata, but then it was revalidated by Pyburn (1978). Faivovich et al. (2005) transferred it to the genus Hypsiboas as part of the punctatus group, based only on morphological data. More recently, it was placed in Boana after Dubois (2017) justified the replacement of Hypsiboas with this last genus name. Its phylogenetic relationship within Boana remains untested as this species has not yet been included in any quantitative phylogenetic study.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is definitely a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species is considered incertae sedis, and is presently left in the genus Hyla pending resolution (Faivovich et al. 2005). The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). It was removed from the synonymy of Hypsiboas pulchellus by Garcia et al. (2003). More than one species could be covered by this name.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

Two subspecies are recognized in Venezuela, according to Barrio et al. (1999): Hypsiboas lanciformis guerreroi and H.l. lanciformis. This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla then moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It might be a complex of more than one species that needs further revision. De la Riva et al. (2000) discuss the confusion between this species and Dendropsophus rossalleni. Ecuadorian specimens tentatively assigned to D. leali by De la Riva and Duellman (1997) differ in coloration from the holotype and allotype (Duellman 1978). Some subpopulations in Peru and Bolivia may be confused with D. joannae and D. riveroi (Köhler et al. 2005, Duellman 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Estupiñán et al. 2016).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form might not be a valid species (Rodrigues pers. comm.).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species is easily confused with Dendropsophus acreanus (Melo-Sampaio and Souza 2015).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
It has been considered to be a subspecies of Dendropsophus seniculus (Bokermann 1964). More than one species is probably covered under this name.
This name is not assignable to any known species in the wild, and hence is considered a nomen dubium.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There is uncertainty regarding the taxonomic identity of this species since only one specimen has been found despite subsequent surveys in the type locality. It most likely belongs to another well-known species from the area (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. January 2016).

This species may be close to species of Dendropsophus minusculus. There are problems with recognition of this species (Victor Dill, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021). The type specimen is young and quite deteriorated, making it impossible to make comparisons with other species of the genus (M. Hoogmoed, Brazilian pers. comm. Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Dendropsophus minutus is a nominal species, that may represent a complex of multiple species, each with a more limited distribution (Gehara et al. 2014). Gehara et al. (2014) found 43 lineages, several of which may represent currently unrecognized distinct species. In Bolivia, the larvae were characterised and two morphologically, distinguishable species are discernible (Schulze et al. 2015).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It is probably a complex of several species.

This species was previously in the genus Hyla, but was then moved to Scinax (Faivovich et al. 2005). Duellman et al. (2016) created the new genus Julianus for the species in the Scinax uruguayus group, but this assessment follows Baldo et al. (2019) in considering Julianus as a synonym of Scinax.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Many colour morphs of this species have been recognized taxonomically.
This form is a complex of more than one species (for example, within Bolivia at least two different species are distinguishable).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich, et al., 2005).

This species was previously with the genus Hyla, but was recently moved to Scinax (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Hyla minuta bivittata by Langone (1990). Duellman et al. (2016) erected the new genus Julianus for the species in the Scinax uruguayus group, but this assessment follows Baldo et al. (2019) in considering Julianus as a synonym of Scinax.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich, et al., 2005). Hypsiboas prasinus and H. joaquini are often considered to be subspecies of H. pulchellus. H. cordobae and H. riojanus were previously considered subspecies, but have been recently separated by Faivovich et al. (2004).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There is a strong taxonomic problem for this species, as it could be D. jimi (V. Dill and B. Teixeira pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). Some specimens identified as Hyla boans in the literature for Venezuelan localities, might represent Hypsiboas wavrini (see Hoogmoed 1990, La Marca 1992).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, but was moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was resurrected from the synonymy of Dendropsophus nanus by Basso et al. (1985).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). It was removed from the synonymy of Bokermannohyla pseudopseudis by Pombal and Caramaschi (1995). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Nascimento et al. 2018).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).

There are taxonomic uncertainties between B. sazimai and B. nanuzae (P. Garcia pers. comm. 2021).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005). The recently described Hypsiboas curupi was previously confused under H. semiguttatus, which was redescribed by Garcia et al. (2007). This species was moved subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).

There is an undescribed species within B. geographica that is aff. with this species and when further taxonomic studies have been done, it may expand this species ranges into the Guianan Shield (P. Kok and A. Fouquet pers. comm. November 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Dendropsophus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Phyllomedusa but moved to the genus Hylomantis (Cruz 1991) and then to Agalychnis (Faivovich et al. 2010), but was moved back to the genus Hylomantis (Duellman et al. 2016).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Osteocephalus buckleyi by Duellman and Mendelson III (1995). However, its taxonomy is still unclear.
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but was moved to the monotypic genus Itapotihyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
A taxonomic revision of this species is needed. We follow Jungfer and Hödl (2002) in considering Osteocephalus ayarzaguenai Gorzula and Señaris, 1997 "1996", to be a synonym of O. leprieurii.

Lysapsus limellum occurs only in the Prata and Paraguay River Basins; records from the Amazon basin are L. bolivianus (Aguiar et al. 2007, Garda and Cannatella 2007, Diego Santana and Adrain Garda pers. comm. 2021).
The call variation of this nominal species might conceal a number of cryptic species.
The record of P. exilis in Bahia corresponds to P. spectabilis (Délio Baêta, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Two species are included under this name (A. Kwet pers. comm.). This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005). Blotto et al. (2021) suggested that the taxonomic status of this taxon relative to Trachycephalus dibernardoi requires additional study.
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which has since been synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was synonymized with Trachycephalus by Faivovich et al. (2005). Garcia Marsà et al. (2020) reported the species from Argentina and discussed its range, however, this extension was based on a specimen of Kaloula pulchra (Microhylidae), according to Faivovich and Elias-Costa (2020).
This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich, et al., 2005).
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Phrynomedusa fimbriata by Cruz (1985).
This form is probably a complex of several species (O. L. Peixoto pers. comm.). P. wuchereri was recently revalidated by Caramaschi et al. (2004).
There are taxonomic problems and a difficulty in separating this species of Phyllodytes luteolos (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation.
The Argentinian population might be Phyllomedusa tetraploidea (see Pombal and Haddad 1992).

Specimens from Estado Bolívar, Venezuela, agree with characters for Phyllomedusa tarsius from the Amazon Basin. Duellman (1997) doubted that the population on Trinidad (the type locality of P. trinitatis) were distinct from P. tarsius.
This species is a complex of more than one species.
This species was placed in the synonymy of Pseudis paradoxa by Gallardo (1961), but was re-validated by Caramaschi and Cruz (1998).
Some specimens of this taxon in Venezuela have been referred to as Hyla boulengeri and H. garbei.

This form is probably a complex of several species. Scinax trachythorax and S. megapodius are treated as separate species by some authors, but the most recent review of Hylidae considers them both to be a synonym of S. fuscovarius (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Caramaschi and Cruz (1998) revalidated this species and resurrected it from the synonymy of Pseudis paradoxa.
This form is a complex of more than one species. Scinax eringiophilus has been synonymised with this species by Kwet (2001).

Six subspecies were recognized by Gallardo (1961). On the basis of a phylogenetic analysis and pair-wise comparisons among gene sequences, Aguiar-Jr et al. (2007) recommend that subspecies of Pseudis paradoxa, including P. platensis, be considered full species. However, Garda et al. (2010) and Santana et al. (2016) suggested that P. platensis may not be distinguishable from this species.
The species name is a noun in apposition and therefore does not change with the gender of the generic name.
This form is a complex of more than one species.
Lescure and Marty (2000) placed Scinax cynocephala in the synonymy of Scinax nebulosus. This is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Scinax fuscomarginatus by Duellman and Wiens (1992) and De la Riva, Marquez and Bosch (1997).
There is a good possibility that many or all specimens referred to S. nebulosus from central and western Brazil and Bolivia in fact are S. pedromedinae (Hoogmoed and Ávila-Pires 2012 "2011").
Peixoto (1988) noted that this name covers a complex of species.
For a discussion of the status of this species, see Heyer (1980).
This species was removed from synonymy (as a subspecies) of Scinax catharinae by Peixoto (1988).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Scinax catharinae, without comment, by Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva and Peixoto (1991). It was treated as a synonym of Scinax rubra by Duellman and Wiens (1993). Pombal, Haddad and Kasahara (1995), Pombal, Bastos and Haddad (1995), and S. Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva (pers. comm.) noted that there might be several species covered by the name Scinax alter.
Species with taxonomic problems, may be confused with O. trapicheiroi and O. coastalis (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species. Based on molecular evidence, it is thought that three different species exist under this binomial in Colombia alone (Guarnizo et al. 2016). Lynch (2006) suggests that it is probable that Scinax ruber is being confused with Scinax x-signatus in the Villavicencio region of Colombia.

It is probably a complex of more than one species. Geographic variation amongst subpopulations of Scinax squalirostris shows evidence that the subpopulation from Cristalina Municipality (state of Goiás, Brazil) might be a distinct species (Faria et al. 2013).

Previously this name had not been assigned to a species group or to any known population in the wild (Duellman and Wiens 1992) as the holotype was lost. Pimenta et al. (2007) redescribed the species and designated a neotype.
Some of the possible identifications outside of Itatiaia may be another species being confused with O. atrata (J. Lacerda pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessement Workshop 2021).
This could be a complex of more than one species (C. Arzabe pers. comm.).
Haddad and Pombal (1987) removed this species from the synonymy of Scinax catharinae, without comment.
This form is a complex of more than one species.

Many of the subspecies cited by Lutz (1973) and by Duellman (1977) are recognizable as distinct species. Although this taxon is probably composed of a complex of species, it was considered as a taxonomic unit for this assessment.

De la Riva et al. (2000) point out that the males in the Peruvian site have pronounced coloration patterns, very different from those in Bolivia. The taxonomic status of the Peruvian specimens should be reviewed.
This species might consist of a complex of more than one species.
This species is probably a complex of several species (B. Pimenta pers. comm. 2004, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Pombal, Haddad and Kasahara (1995) and C.A.G. Cruz (pers. comm.) noted that this name might cover more than one species. A new species, Scinax curicica, was recently separated from S. duartei (Pugliese et al., 2004).
It is probably a complex of several species (A. Carnaval pers. comm.)
In the Scinax staufferi group, according to Duellman (1986). In the Scinax ruber clade, but unassigned to any group (Faivovich et al. 2005).
Specimens from Espírito Santo might belong to a separate species (O. Peixoto pers. comm.).
This is most likely a species complex. There are at least five species in Venezuela under this name (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus orophilus, according to the original description.
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus lacteus according to the original description.

This species was previously included in the genus Sphaenorhynchus but has recently been moved to the genus Gabohyla (Araujo-vieira et al. 2020).

This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus prasinus, according to the original description.
This species is similar to Sphaenorhynchus planicola according to the original description. Indeed, their ranges overlap in Bahia and Espirito Santo (I. Machado pers. comm. 2021).
Some subpopulations formerly considered under Sphaenorhunchus surdus are now allocated to Sphaenorhynchus caramaschii (Toledo et al. 2007).
The records of this species are old and there is no new material to compare and certify the identity of the species (P. Garcia pers. comm. Brazil Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

It can be a species complex composed of at least three lineages. It is uncertain whether all records in the state of Paraná refer to this species. A new species is being described for the Babitonga region (J. Monteiro pers. comm. Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

The name Adenomera andreae is composed by a clade of species not well defined yet, widely distributed in the Amazon forest, and with some sympatric and syntopic species (Fouquet et al. 2014, Carvalho et al. 2019, Thiago de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020). Cryptic species associated with the morphotype of A. andreae are expected to be concentrated in Amazonian regions across north-central Peru, eastern Ecuador, southern Colombia and Venezuela, and northwestern Brazil (Fouquet et al. 2014). According to Carvalho et al. (2019), the combined use of acoustic and genetic data is necessary to better understand this species complex.
