The specimens from the eastern slopes of the Venezuelan Andes have been identified as Adenomera aff. simonstuarti (C. Señaris pers. comm. February 2020). One of the paratypes of A. andreae, a forest-associated species with toe tips fully expanded, shares a morphotype with the open-habitat species and is reassigned to A. hylaedactyla by de Carvalho et al. (2019).

Sampling efforts and the use of integrative taxonomy tools are needed to resolve the taxonomic status of this species. Records from Paraná and São Paulo States can be another species instead of C. izecksohni (Brazil Red List Assessment 2021).
This species is composed of several cryptic species (A. Kwet pers. comm.).
This species has been moved to the genus Phantasmarana by Vittorazzi et al. (2021).

This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus hylaedactylus by De la Riva (1995).

Subpopulations outside of the Pantanal biome in Brazil possibly do not correspond to this species (Workshop on Assessment of the conservation status of Pantanal amphibian species 2020).

This species was firstly described only from its type locality and a nearby site in French Guiana (Boistel et al. 2006). Its potential distribution was confirmed over most forested parts of the northern Guiana Shield lowlands (Fouquet et al. 2011). Carvalho et al. (2020) revised the systematics and historical biogeography of the Adenomera heyeri clade and uncovered ten new candidate species with interfluve associated distributions across Amazonia, and formally described six new species from the clade.

This form is a complex of more than one species currently undergoing revision (A. Angulo pers comm. 2008). Brusquetti and Lavilla (2006) suggested that Paraguayan records previously assigned to this species are based on misidentifications, probably belonging to Adenomera diptyx following De la Riva (1996). Fouquet et al. (2019) noted that the inselberg subpopulation of southern French Guiana and farther south is unlikely to be conspecific with the nominate species found along the coast. 

Morphology of toe tip fragments and the original species description suggest that A. hylaedactyla could correspond to at least two described species (A. andreae or A. simonstuarti) or additional unnamed genetic lineages of the A. andreae clade. While additional data can be obtained from the holotype of A. hylaedactyla, at this time this type cannot be unequivocally assigned to any species of Adenomera distributed across eastern Ecuador and Peru’s northernmost region of Loreto (de Carvalho et al. 2019).

Several linages belonging to the Adenomera hylaedactyla clade have been identified in the Brazilian biomes of Amazonia, Cerrado and Atlantic Forest (de Carvalho et al. 2019). These authors attributed a pan-Amazonian distribution for the nominal A. hylaedactyla and discussed that linages outside the Amazon biome may be undescribed species and needs to be studied further.
This species is a complex of several cryptic species. Kwet (2007) recently removed Adenomera nana from the synonymy with Adenomera marmorata.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Cycloramphus asper by Heyer (1983).
This species is an octoploid species most closely related to Ceratophrys ornata according to Mercedal de Barrio (1986), but it is genetically distinct.

Brusquetti and Lavilla (2006) suggested that reports of this species for Paraguay are based on specimens of Ceratophrys cranwelli. The historical record of “Montevideo, Uruguay” based on a specimen deposited in the Royal Museum of Natural History of Belgium (Museu Royal d 'Histoire Naturelle, Brussels) (Cochran 1955) requires confirmation (Maneyro et al. 2019).
The validity of this species is in doubt (Pimenta pers. comm.).

Species with problems in taxonomic nomenclature. There are two species with this name, as Zachaenus was synonymous with Cycloramphus and Zachaenus carvalhoi is now Cycloramphus carvalhoi. They are different entities with name overlapping problems. The authors of the publication “Brazilian Amphibian List” are trying to solve this problem (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Sampling efforts and the use of integrative taxonomy tools are needed to resolve the taxonomic status of this species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Canedo and Haddad (2012) suggested on the basis of molecular evidence that this species is not an Eleutherodactylus or Ischnocnema, but rather of uncertain position, likely close to Noblella + Barycholos within Holoadeninae (Frost 2015). This species was transferred from Eleutherodactylus to Bahius by Dubois et al. (2021).
This species is a complex of several species requiring systematic revision (S.P. de Carvalho-e-Silva pers. comm.).

Ortega-Andrade et al. (2017) resurrected Pristimantis brevicrus from the synonymy of this species and noted two allied unnamed species in Bolivia and Brazil, usually referred to as Pristimantis altamazonicus.
The species has a disjunct range; the northern subpopulations might refer to a new or different species.

Described originally in the genus Eleutherodactylus (Myers and Donnelly 1997), then subsequently transferred to Pristimantis by Heinicke et al. (2007), and posteriorly to Ceuthomantis by Heinicke et al. (2009) whom also erected a new family, Ceuthomantidae, for this taxon. This diverse group of Terrarana is still under phylogenetic revision, and different family and subfamily arrangements for the genus Ceuthomantis have been suggested (Pyron and Wiens 2011, Padial et al. 2014, Heinicke et al. 2018) (see Frost 2019 for a summary). In all these studies, Ceuthomantis appears as the most basal lineage within the Terrarana (New World direct-developing frogs).

The specimens reported as Pristimantis cf. cavernibardus from the Cerro Sarisariñama by Barrio-Amorós and Brewer-Carías (2008), were described two years later as a new species, Ceuthomantis duellmani (Barrio-Amorós 2010).
The validity of this species needs to be assessed.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Pristimantis fenestratus by Heyer and Muñoz (1999), where it had been placed by Lynch (1980).The phylogenetic relationships of members of Oreobates are not fully resolved, and deserves further study and that should shed light on the origin and diversification of the group in those habitats. A rigorous reassessment of the identity of the Bolivian populations would require gathering additional specimens from the type localities of O. crepitans and O. heterodactylus to assess intraspecific variation (Padial et al. 2012).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Ischnocnema bolbodactyla by Pombal and Cruz (1999).
This taxon is believed to consist of a complex of more than one species.

This species is a complex of several species (C.A.G. Cruz pers. comm.).

This is a restricted concept of I. lactea, that occurs only from São Paulo State. The populations of Minas Gerais, Rio de Janeiro and Espírito Santo states refer to other species, not yet named (Thomé et al. 2020).

In 2004, Ischnocnema guentheri was known to occur in Argentina and Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. Kwet and Solé (2005) removed I. henselii from the synonymy of I. guentheri and reassigned the subpopulations from Argentina and some from Rio Grande do Sul and Santa Catarina, Brazil to I. henselii. However, the map in the 2008 Red List assessment did not remove these records in error. This is corrected in the 2021 map. Gehara et al. (2013) subsequently assigned additional records of I. guentheri from Santa Catarina, Paraná, and São Paulo to I. henselii. In addition to this, Gehara et al. (2013) also identified that some records from Santa Catarina, Paraná, São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, and Minas Gerais states also belong to four other unnamed species (represented as Candidate Species 1–4 in Gehara et al. 2013). These subpopulations are retained within the distribution map until they are formally assigned to other species and coded as Presence Uncertain. Therefore, this concept of Ischnocnema guentheri is restricted to an area within the city of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Ischnocnema nigriventris by Heyer (1985).
There might be several species confused under this name.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Eleutherodactylus bolbodactylus (Pombal and Cruz 1999).

This species is believed to be a multi-complex of more than one species. The southern and northern populations in Ecuador are probably separate species; specimens from Manaus in Amazonian Brazil might be incorrectly identified.
This is a complex comprising many species (C.A.G. Cruz pers. comm. 2004, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

A record for Alagoas, Brazil, provided by Lima and Skuk (2006) may represent Ischnocnema ramagii. Napoli et al. (2009) provided additional karyological evidence for the distinctiveness of this taxon from Ischnocnema ramagii and discussed the lack of any definitive morphological features between the two species. Canedo and Haddad (2012) suggested on the basis of molecular evidence that this species falls within the Pristimantis conspicillatus group and may represent a species complex. Included in the Pristimantis conspicillatus species group by Padial et al. (2014).
This species is possibly a complex of more than one species.
This species was moved from the genus Leptodactylus to the genus Hydrolaetare by de Souza and Haddad (2003).
This species was redescribed as Hydrolaetare schmidti by Gallardo (1963).
The grammatically incorrect name Hylodes asperus has had some use.
The incorrect spelling Hylodes glabrus has had some use.

The 2004 assessment reported that this concept "might be a complex of more than one species." Since that time, the 2004 distribution, which extended from the state of Rio de Janeiro to the northeastern corner of the state of Santa Catarina has been revised and records reassigned to species in the Hylodes nasus and H. lateristrigatus groups. For example, inland Rio de Janeiro state records belong to H. lateristrigatus (de Sá et al. 2015); other coastal records from Rio de Janeiro and northeastern São Paulo states belong to H. asper (Canedo and Pombal-Jr. 2007); southeastern São Paulo and eastern Paraná states belong to H. cardosoi (Lingnau et al. 2008); records from Santa Catarina state belong to H. perplicatus (Lingnau et al. 2008).

The species has recently been assigned to the genus Pristimantis following Heinicke et al. (2007) (Frost, 2007). It was redescribed by Barrio-Amorós and Molina (2006) based on morphological features and colour patterns of additional specimens.
This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Trevisan et al. 2020).

Fouquet et al. (2019) suggested that this binomial represents a species complex. Records from southern Venezuela are misidentified specimens of L. riveroi (Heyer and Pyburn 1983). Gorzula and Señaris (1998) confused a large specimen of L. guianensis (as L. bolivianus) with L. rhodomystax (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019).
Subpopulations in the north region of Minas Gerais State, may represents another species under this name, to be described (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This species has taxonomic problems, with at least three possible species (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

This species is in the Leptodactylus melanonotus group, Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex (Heyer 1994). Fouquet et al. (2007) provided molecular evidence that this is a species complex
This species is often confused with Eleutherodactylus lineatus (Brocchi 1879).
Lynch (1972) provides a discussion on the nomenclatural confusion surrounding this species, together with a redescription of the holotype.
This species has been moved to the genus Phantasmarana by Vittorazzi et al. (2021).

We follow Heyer (1968, 1974) and Savage (2002) in considering Leptodactylus insularum to be a synonym of L. bolivianus. Further investigations into the taxonomic status of animals from southern South America currently alloted to L. bolivianus is needed.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Megaelosia goeldii by Giaretta et al. (1993), where it had been placed by Lutz (1930).
This form was previously included within Leptodactylus latinasus, but it is now considered to be a distinct species.
This species is a complex of more than one species.
Lavilla et al. (2000) do not recognize the presence of this species in Argentina, and there are no specimens from Paraguay in the Museo Nacional de Historia Natural del Paraguay.

This species is in the <i>Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus</i> complex, according to the original description. Heyer (1998) suggested that this species might be the sister taxon of <i>Vanzolinius</i>.
As suggested by Amaro et al. (2009), the species Odontophrynus salvatory was formally transfered to the genus Proceratophrys (Magalhães et al. 2020).
A closely related, but still unnamed, species has been collected from the state of Paraná in southern Brazil (Lourenco et al. 2003).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Fouquet et al. 2007, Guarnizo et al. 2016). Based on molecular evidence, it is possible that a cryptic species exists within the subpopulation found in Bolivia (Jansen et al. 2011) and that two species exist within the subpopulation in Colombia (Guarnizo et al. 2016).
This species is a complex of more than one species.

Heyer (2000) reviewed the nomenclatural and taxonomic history of the nominal species, redescribed the lectotype, and posited that it represents a species of Leptodactylus currently known only from the type specimen.
Leptodactylus jolyi was redescribed on the basis of adult morphology and calls (Giaretta and Costa 2007).

Subpopulations from the coastal areas of Venezuela formerly allocated to this taxon, are now considered to be a distinct species, Leptodactylus turimiquensis (Heyer 2005). This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Jansen et al. 2011, Jansen and Schultze 2012).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus wagneri by Heyer (1994), who provided an account and considered it to be in the Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex.
The frogs identified as Leptodactylus mystaceus in Paraguay are actually L. elenae. Heyer (1983) synonymized Leptodactylus amazonicus Heyer, 1978 with this species.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.

This species is in the Leptodactylus wagneri-Leptodactylus podicipinus complex. It is well delimited after a recent review of the Leptodactylus melanonotus group, however, not yet published (T. de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020). Formerly called Leptodactylus gr. melanonotus or L. petersii, L. leptodactyloides and Leptodactylus sp. along the Cerrado. Occurrences in the Cerrado were not included in the systematic review published by de Sá et al. (2014).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species. It was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus podicipinus by Heyer (1994) where it had been placed by Heyer (1970). In the past, Venezuelan populations were referred in the literature as Leptodactylus wagneri. At least the lowland populations in this country seem to correspond to L. pallidirostris.

Central American records of Leptodactylus formerly allocated to L. pentadactylus are now recognised as the distinct species L. savagei (Heyer 2005).

Vouchers absent from Venezuelan museums (Barrio-Amorós et al. 2019); all pentadactylus-like frogs from southern Venezuela identified as Leptodactylus knudseni. Heyer’s (2005) review of the pentadactylus species group does not mention any voucher from Venezuela. De Sá et al. (2014) show four Venezuelan localities in a distribution map, but without vouchers.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Leptodactylus podicipinus by Heyer (1994) where it had been placed by Rivero (1961), and (as a synonym of Leptodactylus caliginosus) by Boulenger (1882).

Currently, the species is well delimited after a systematic review of the Leptodactylus melanonotus species group (de Sá et al. 2014, Gazoni et al. 2021). Specimens from Cerrado that were previously named as Leptodactylus gr. melanonotus, Leptodactylus petersii or Leptodactylus leptodactyloides should now be treated as Leptodactylus natalensis (Gazoni et al. 2021). Therefore, the application of this name outside the Amazon biome may be a mistake (T. de Carvalho pers. comm. 2020).


Gazoni et al. (2021) did not find any specimen of L. petersii from Ecuador at the QCAZ collection using DNA sequences and morphological evidence. A previous report from Ecuador by Ron (2002) was based on a series of specimens from Provincia Sucumbíos (QCAZ 20242–7). Subsequently, the specimens were examined by Thiago R. de Carvalho, who suggested that the series should probably be conspecific with L. wagneri.
This species is assigned to the Leptodactylus melanonotus species group based on its morphology, although it was not included in the molecular analysis by De Sá et al. (2014).
The species in different localities in southeastern and northeastern Brazil, correspond to Leptodactylus barrioi or L. watu, or additional candidate new species (Silva et al. 2020).

This form is probably a complex of more than one species. It was long confused with Pleurodema thaul, until the work of Donoso-Barros (1969). In Paraguay, this taxon was previously confused with Physalaemus fuscomaculatus (Cei 1990, Kolenc et al. 2011).
Proceratophrys palustris is similar to this species.
This species is a complex of several species (S. Potsch de Carvalho-e-Silva and A. Carnaval pers. comm.).
This species is a complex comprising several species (G. Andrade pers. comm.). Records from Argentina are apparently based on confusion with Physalaemus biligonigerus.
This species is a sibling species of Physalaemus cuvieri and Physalaemus cuqui. It is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.

Jansen et al. (2011) suggested on the basis of molecular data the existence of unnamed cryptic species, possibly two, in Bolivia. Schulze et al. (2015) characterized as Physalaemus centralis A and B, noting substantial differences from Brazilian Physalaemus centralis from São Paulo. Description, diagnosis, and picture of the larvae characterized as Physalaemus centralis A and B was published by Schulze et al. (2015), where the authors evidenced substantial differences from Brazilian Physalaemus centralis from São Paulo and genetic differences from each other.

The Physalaemus cuvieri species group represents a complex of cryptic species (Lourenço et al. 2015). Nascimento et al. (2019) reported on the phylogenetics of the Physalaemus ephippifer–Physalaemus cuvieri group, suggesting that Physalaemus cuvieri is a complex of at least six species.
The record from Rivera mentioned in the 2004 assessment belongs to Pseudopaludicola falcipes (Maneyro et al. 2019).

Nascimento et al. (2006) associate Gomphobates marmoratus to the genus Physalaemus, and indicate that this name refers to specimens previously identified as Physalaemus fuscomaculatus. All literature prior to 2006 using the name Physalaemus fuscomaculatus should be used with great caution and with reference to the discussion provided by Nascimento et al. (2006).
This form is probably a complex of more than one species.
This species is similar to Proceratophrys cristiceps and P. goyana according to the original description.

De la Riva et al. (2000) point out that more studies on its phylogenetic relations and its taxonomic status are necessary. As presently understood, this taxon is likely to be a complex of species in need of critical review (Myers and Donnelly, 2001). Venezuelan localities south of the Orinoco river, assigned previously by Lynch (1979) to P. pusilla are here considered to be P. boliviana.

Carvalho et al. (2015) suggested that on the basis of morphology and acoustic characteristics that Pseudopaludicola parnaiba is not diagnosable from Pseudopaludicola canga but did not make the taxonomic change. Recently it was considered as a junior synonym of P. canga by Andrade et al. (2020).
This species was described only from museum specimens; there is no consensus on its validity, and there have not yet been any field observations of it.
This species was resurrected from the synonymy of Pseudopaludicola falcipes by Haddad and Cardoso (1987).

Molecular studies conducted by Santos et al. (2020), report the cryptic status of the northern subpopulation of this species, naming it "Rupirana cardosoi Lin-B" but did not describe it as a separate species. This subpopulation is retained in the current concept of R. cardosoi until further work confirms its identity as a distinct species.
This species was discussed as Thoropa sp. by Maxson and Heyer (1982). It is close to Thoropa miliaris according to the original description.

Recent analyses have shown that there are at least two species under this name. The occurrence in Guyana can be attributed to an undescribed species (P. Peloso, Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
This taxon can represent more than a species, the subpopulation from Espírito Santo probably represent a distinct species (Jennings et al. 2015).
Peloso and Sturaro (2008) reported considerable morphological variation among populations suggestive of cryptic species.

High morphological variation associated with geographical distribution has been reported for this species, and museum specimens have been incorrectly identified as belonging this species due to the poor condition of the holotype (Peloso and Sturaro 2008). It is possible that further studies may uncover more misidentified subpopulations. Specimens reported from Santa Cecilia, Ecuador, and Iquitos, Peru show distinctive characteristics which may suggest that they do not belong to this species (Morales and McDiarmid 2009), although this has not been confirmed.

Bokermann (1952) suggested that Chiasmocleis centralis is allied with C. shudikarensis, but Carvalho (1954), suggested an affinity with C. albopunctata. It has been described from poorly preserved collection-type material and has not been found in the field since the collection of the type specimens in 1950, despite sampling efforts in the region. It is possible that it is a synonym of C. albopunctata, however, morphological and molecular studies are needed before this can be confirmed.
Chiasmocleis jimi was synonymised with this species by Peloso et al. (2014), but this was reversed by da Sá et al. 2018 "2019".
This species is a tetraploid species according to Kasahara and Haddad (1997).
Zweifel and Myers (1989) have posited that the name Ctenophryne geayi actually represents two species (northern and southern populations).
This species was removed from synonymy with Elachistocleis ovalis by Lavilla et al. (2003).

There is a single historical record of the species from central Mato Grosso in the ICMBio database, but this is likely a misidentification and belongs to Elachistocleis matogrosso or E. corumbaensis (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).
Some specimens identified in the past as Otophryne robusta, are now included under this species, specially the populations in the Amazonas State of Venezuela.
Albuquerque and Izecksohn (2001) separated the populations from Rio de Janeiro as a separate species, reviving the previous name Stereocyclops parkeri.
Albuquerque and Izecksohn (2001) separated the populations of Stereocyclops incrassatus from Rio de Janeiro as a separate species, reviving the previous name Stereocyclops parkeri.

This species was previously considered to belong to the genus Adelophryne in the family Leptodactylidae, but it was transferred to the genus Syncope in the family Microhylidae by Silva and Meinhardt (1999) and then to the genus Chiasmocleis by Peloso et al. (2014).
This form is a complex of species.
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.

This is a very poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2003). Most attenuate caecilians in the Amazon basin and the Guianas are associated with this name, but their conspecificity is uncertain.
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It is probably conspecific with Siphonops paulensis.
Caecilia pressula was placed in synonymy with this species by Wilkinson (2020).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). It is not clear that all populations throughout its range are conspecific.
Known only from the holotype which is now lost (Frost 2021).
Populations from Santa Catarina in southern Brazil might belong to a different species.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. There is a history of confusion between this species and Luetkenotyphlus brasiliensis (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear. It has frequently been confused with Chthonerpeton viviparum.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
Wilkinson (1996) doubted the distinctiveness of this taxon from Typhlonectes compressicauda.
This is a problematic taxon that has been assigned to different families (Allophrynidae, Bufonidae, Centrolenidae, Hylidae, Leptodactylidae).
This species might consist of more than one species (M. Wilkinson pers. comm).

Fricke et al. (2020) notes that this species was placed into synonymy with Cynolebias sandrii, but sandrii is no longer available and so splendens should be treated as a valid species. Costa (2016) transferred Leptolebias splendens to a new genus Leptopanchax.
This species has recently been separated from Rhinella crucifer by Baldissera et al. (2004).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Aplastodiscus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has since been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was separated from Bokermannohyla circumdata (Napoli 2005). It was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the genus Bokermannohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla , then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017).
This species was described by reallocation of some specimens originally allocated to Phyllodytes tuberculosus (Caramaschi and Peixoto 2004).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Phyllodytes luteolus by Caramaschi et al. (2004).

In the Scinax catharinae group, and possibly confused as Scinax berthae in Brazil, according to the original publication. Specimens treated as Scinax cf. berthae by Kwet and Di-Bernardo (1999) and by Kwet (2001) could instead belong to this species (Faivovich 2005).

This species was described by reallocation of some specimens originally allocated to Scinax duartei (Pugliese et al. 2004).

This species has taxonomic problems and needs investigation (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021)

authority: Ribeiro, Alves, Haddad and Dos Reis, 2005
Ribeiro, Alves, Haddad and Dos Reis, 2005

taxonomicNotes: This species has recently been separated from Rhinella crucifer (Baldissera et al. 2004).
This species was removed from synonymy of Rhinella crucifer by Baldiserra et al. (2004).
This species was removed from synonymy of Rhinella crucifer by Baldissera et al. (2004).
Its former position in Cryptophyllobates or now in Hyloxalus might be doubtful (R. Schulte pers. comm. April 2018).
Descrita em: An. Acad. Bras. Cienc. xli. 239 (1969). Nome popular: "faveiro-de-Wilson".

Atelocynus is a monotypic genus. The species has formerly been placed in the genera Lycalopex, Cerdocyon, and Dusicyon. Phylogenetic analysis has shown Atelocynus microtis to be a distinct taxon most closely related to another monotypic Neotropical canid genus, Speothos.

Genetic analyses in the Atlantic and Indo-Pacific indicate that nesting populations comprise separate and identifiable stocks that should be treated as separate management units (Bass et al. 1996, Bowen et al. 1996, Bowen and Karl 2007). Hawksbill aggregations on foraging grounds comprise animals from multiple nesting populations and often include animals from distant rookeries (Broderick et al. 1994, Bowen et al. 2007).
Species of the Acropomatidae family are ill-defined (FAO ECA guide in prep PC Heemstra).

Lythrum hyssopifolium is one of a complex of small Lythrum species typically occurring in ephemeral wetlands and in association with larger, more permanent wetlands some of which are recognised by some authors as species (e.g. L. thymifolia). Taxonomic treatment of these entities is inconsistent.
Known only from 32 specimens from throughout the Cerrado region. A morphometric assessment of these specimens did not indicate any significant morphological differentiation (Bezerra et al. 2011).
Until recently this species was considered a subspecies of Epicrates cenchria, but was elevated to species status by Passos and Fernandes (2008).

This species was described as Rhynchonyx ambiniger; upon transfer to the feminine genus Apostolepis the specific epithet was emended to ambinigra by Boulenger (1896). This was considered an unjustified emendation by Peters and Donoso-Barros (1970), and subsequently both forms of the name have been used by recent authors (e.g. ambiniger - Cacciali et al. 2016, Uetz et al. 2018; ambinigra - Wallach et al. 2014, Nogueira 2018).

This species was described from São Paolo State in Brazil, far from any subsequent records, and the attribution of material away from the type locality to this species has long been uncertain. The same specimens from Asunción in Paraguay were attributed by Boulenger to both A. dorbignyi (Boulenger 1894) and A. ambiniger (Boulenger 1896). The latter scheme has since been accepted, and records of A. dorbignyi from Paraguay appear to be errors based on the earlier paper (Cacciali et al. 2016), but no work appears to have formally attempted to resolve the taxonomy of this species.

Until recently the Brazilian holotype, which is thought to have been lost, was the only known specimen of this species, although it was included in historical checklists for Paraguay following Bertoni (1914). The assignment of recent material from a second Brazilian locality (Albuquerque and de Lema 2012) and Paraguay (Cacciali et al. 2016) to this species is therefore provisional pending further taxonomic research into this poorly-known taxon (Cacciali et al. 2016).

De Lema and Albuquerque (2010) placed Apostolepis quinquelineata Boulenger, 1896  in synonymy of A. nigrolineatus (Peters, 1896); although this scheme has not been universally adopted (e.g. Curcio et al. 2011, Starace 2013) it is now generally accepted (Borges-Nojosa et al. 2016) and is followed here. Curcio et al. (2011) also assigned A. pymi and A. rondoni to the synonymy of A. nigrolineatus.
De Lema and Renner (2016) redescribed this species, formally removing Apostolepis borellii from its synonymy.

This species was synonymized within Apostolepis assimilis within a year of its description (Ferrarezi et al. 2005) on the basis that the described characters fell within the latter species' range of variation. These authors did not, however, examine the holotype of A. tertullianobeui, and following a subsequent comparison of the holotypes of the two species, Lema and Renner (2007) revalidated it. This was not followed in the checklist by Wallach et al. (2014) but was accepted by Costa and Bérnils (2015), who determined that A. parassimilis represents a junior synonym of A. tertullianobeui. The validity of this species remains in question (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020); and is considered doubtful, but it is accepted as valid in a recent atlas to Brazilian snakes (Nogueira et al. 2019).

The identity of two records from Santa Cruz in Bolivia, assigned to this species by Harvey (1999), based on two specimens that these authors acknowledged differ from the holotype, remains uncertain. Entiauspe and Lema (2015) concluded that these represented Apostolepis christineae based on photographs of the museum specimens, but did not examine the specimens to confirm this identification and A. christineae is so far known with certainty only from the Brazilian type locality. Pending direct examination of the specimens it is considered speculative to assign these records to either species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020), and they are consequently excluded from this assessment.

The most recent treatment of this species is that of Hoogmoed (1980), who considered that the previously-described range of this species, which extended through much of South America east of the Andes and south as far as Argentina, was likely to represent a species complex. Although this author indicated that a full evaluation of records assigned to this species throughout South America was necessary to resolve the taxonomy of this form, no such revision appears to have been attempted. Pending clarification on the taxonomy of this species, this account considers only records confirmed by Hoogmoed (1980) as representing A. badius.
This species is presumably a species complex.

Passos et al. (2010) discussed the taxonomic history of Atractus paraguayensis and uncertainty about its range limits in Argentina, as following Williams and Gudynas (1991) and subsequent authors, Argentine and southern Brazilian records had been attributed to A. taeniatus. Passos et al. (2010) compared data from the holotypes of A. paraguayensis and A. taeniatus and concluded that Argentine and Brazilian records previously attributed to A. taeniatus in fact represent A. paraguayensis. Giraudo et al. (2012) subsequently argued that in Argentina, the name A. paraguayensis should be restricted to populations from northwest of Corrientes, which Giraudo and Scrocchi (2000) had found to be distinct from A. taeniatus, and that records from Misiones, Corrientes and Entre Rios included within A. paraguayensis by Passos et al. (2010) instead represent an indeterminate species, for which these authors use the name "Atractus sp."

Passos et al. (2010) synonymized Atractus kangueryensis within A. thalesdelemai, based on their finding that a re-examination of the holotype of the latter showed no reliable morphological differences between the two taxa.

authority: Franco, de Carvalho Cintra & de Lema, 2006

taxonomicNotes: The authorship of the specific name for this species has been contentious. Some researchers have have suggested that Jan (1863) was the author of the species since he first described C. flavolineatus, but other researchers contend that Jan's description was so incomplete that it was not possible to ascertain what snake he had in mind and therefore suggested Boettger (1885) as the author, since he was the first to provide a detailed description of the species. The discovery by Hamdan et al. (2014) of a surviving syntype permitted a full diagnosis and clarification of the taxonomic identity of C. flavolineatus, and these authors confirmed Jan (1863) as the correct author.

Neither Hydrodynastes bicinctus nor its proposed subspecies H. b. schultzi was well-characterized in the original descriptions (Castroviejo-Fisher et al. 2015). These authors examined variation throughout the species' Brazilian range and found no evidence to support the distinctiveness of H. b. schultzi, and synonymized it within the nominate form.

Liophis longiventris and Liophis canaima were relegated to the synonymy of Liophis (now Erythrolamprus) breviceps based on morphological characters by Fernandes et al. (2002). The names Liophis longiventris and Erythrolamprus longiventris have since been used to refer to a valid species by multiple authors (Franca et al. 2006, Grazziotin et al. 2012) but none of these was a taxonomic treatment, and the action by Fernandes et al. (2002) appears to have been overlooked rather than rejected (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019), and the species is listed as a junior synonym by Wallach et al. (2014). Accordingly these taxa are treated as junior synonyms of E. breviceps in this assessment.

Historically, the name Oxyrhopus formosus has been applied to a widespread snake in much of northern South America and its range limits relative to O. occidentalis (which was included within O. formosus prior to Hoge et al. 1973) have been poorly-characterized. Partial revisions in Colombia (Lynch 2009) and the Guiana Shield (MacCulloch et al. 2009) removed O. formosus from these territories and Ecuador (Lynch 2009), but no study to date has evaluated the taxonomic status of this species using material from throughout its range (H. Zaher pers. comm. 2019). H. Zaher (pers. comm. 2012) suggests that O. formosus sensu stricto may be confined to Bahia in northern Brazil. Pending the completion of a formal revision presently in preparation (H. Zaher pers. comm. 2019), this assessment follows the published concept applied by MacCulloch et al. (2009).
It comprises four subspecies (Leynaud and Bucher 1999), three of which are found in Argentina: Oxyrhopus rhombifer rhombifer, O. r. bachmanni, and O. r. inaequifasciatus (Giraudo et al. 2012).

The recent description of Oxyrhopus vanidicus, which very closely resembles O. melanogenys, makes the specific identity of previously reported records of O. melanogenys in Peru, Brazil, Ecuador, and Colombia uncertain (Lynch 2009). Examining specimens from Venezuela, Rivas et al. (2012) could find no consistent differences between O. vanidicus and O. melanogenys, raising doubts about the specific validity of O. vanidicus. Records for Brazil in Lynch (2009) were not based on examined specimens, but from images from Martins and Oliveira (1998).

Elapomorphus bilineatus was described based on a specimen considered to be a hybrid between E. suspectus and E. spegazzinii (de Lema 1984), the former form itself recognized as a subspecies of E. spegazzinii (Lema 1984). It therefore appears that the names E. (now Phalotris) bilineatus and E. spegazzinii refer to the same species, and recent authors have considered E. spegazzinii a junior synonym of P. bilineatus (e.g. Giraudo and Scrocchi 2002). The systematics of this taxon are further complicated by suggestions that P. bilineatus is itself a junior synonym of P. lemniscatus (Lema 1979, Carreira et al. 2005). This account treats P. bilineatus as valid pending resolution of this issue.

This is a species complex whose systematics are under review (Arredondo 2011). As presently understood three subspecies are recognized: Philodryas olfersii olfersi, P. o. herbeus and P. o. latirostris.

Sibynomorphus inaequifasciatus is known from a single specimen from "Sudamerica", probably collected in Brazil but never subsequently recorded there. A specimen from Paraguay originally assigned to this species (Cope 1862) was later included in the type series of the new species Sibynomorphus turgidus by the same author (Cope 1868). Recent examination of this individual confirmed its identity as S. turgidus (P. Cacciali, unpubl. data), and the holotype is therefore the only example of S. inaequifasciatus known to exist.

Based on the original description Peters (1960) noted that all but one of the holotype's characters have been reported from aberrant individuals of S. vagans and that it also shares characters in common with S. neuwiedi. It is therefore possible that S. inaequifasciatus is conspecific with one of these two species, in which case the name S. inaequifasciatus would have priority (Peters 1960). In the absence of additional specimens and reliable information on its provenance its appropriate taxonomic status cannot be verified and the holotype ("Probably in the Paris Museum" - Peters 1960) has not been located. Peters (1960) recommends "discarding" the name on this basis, but despite this recommendation the name S. inaequifasciatus has subsequently been used to refer to a valid species in checklists for Brazil and (erroneously) Paraguay.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.
Specimens from northeastern Peru present morphological variations and may represent a distinct species (G. Gagliardi pers. comm. 2014)

The name Thamnodynastes nattereri has been used informally in several papers (e.g. Bailey et al. 2005) to refer to an "easily-diagnosable" Atlantic Forest population of this species thought likely to be specifically distinct (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2017), but the type of this taxon is lost and research is ongoing to determine the status of this population and whether T. nattereri is the appropriate name.

It is necessary to perform a morphological and genetic study of this species throughout its range, as it is thought possible that more than one species may be included under this name (R. Maneyro pers. comm. 2016).
Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the relation between Epictia munoai and other species of the genus.

In a recent review of the Bothrops neuwiedi complex based on morphology and mitochondrial genes, Carrasco et al. (2019) suggested that B. matogrossensis is a complex of species. Additional taxonomic review is needed to clarify this problem.

Silva (2004) and Silva and Rodriguez (2008) consider that Bothrops diporus is found in Missiones in Argentina, eastern Paraguay, and west of Parana and Sao Paulo in Brazil. These populations are, however, morphologically distinct from animals found at this species' type locality (Rio Bermejo, in the Chaco ecoregion) (Giraudo 2004, Cacciali et al. 2016). It is possible that these populations are specifically distinct from 'true' B. diporus found in central and northern Argentina, and west of the Rio Paraguay in Paraguay (A. Giraudo, unpubl. data). These may prove to be referable to B. pubescens, B. neuwiedi, B. mattogrossensis or populations intermediate between these taxa (A. Giraudo pers. comm. 2016), but molecular studies to resolve the systematics of this taxon and of the B. neuwiedii group as a whole are presently lacking. As such, the taxonomy and distribution of every member of this group remains unclear.

Silva (2004) and Silva and Rodrigues (2008) consider that Bothrops diporus is found in Missiones in Argentina, eastern Paraguay, and west of Parana and Sao Paulo in Brazil. These populations are, however, morphologically distinct from animals found at this species' type locality (Rio Bermejo, in the Chaco ecoregion) (Giraudo 2004, Cacciali et al. 2016). It is possible that these populations are specifically distinct from 'true' B. diporus found in central and northern Argentina, and west of the Rio Paraguay in Paraguay (A. Giraudo, unpubl. data). These may prove to be referable to Bothrops pubescens, B. neuwiedi, B. mattogrossensis or populations intermediate between these taxa (A. Giraudo pers. comm. 2016), but molecular studies to resolve the systematics of this taxon and of the Bothrops neuwiedii group as a whole are presently lacking. As such, the taxonomy and distribution of every member of this group remains unclear.

Bothrops pauloensis is a species complex (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014). Cacciali et al. (2016) described problems assigning material from Paraguay to members of the former Bothrops neuwiedi. These authors tentatively assigned this material to two former members of this group: B. diporus and B. pauloensis, while emphasising that further work was needed to confirm this assignment.

Silva (2004) and Silva and Rodriguez (2008) consider that Bothrops diporus is found in Missiones in Argentina, eastern Paraguay, and west of Parana and Sao Paulo in Brazil. These populations are, however, morphologically distinct from animals found at this species' type locality (Rio Bermejo, in the Chaco ecoregion) (Giraudo 2004, Cacciali et al. 2016). It is possible that these populations are specifically distinct from 'true' B. diporus found in central and northern Argentina, and west of the Rio Paraguay in Paraguay (A. Giraudo, unpubl. data). These may prove to be referrable to Bothrops pubescens, B. neuwiedi, B. mattogrossensis or populations intermediate between these taxa (A. Giraudo pers. comm. 2016), but molecular studies to resolve the systematics of this taxon and of the Bothrops neuwiedii group as a whole are presently lacking. As such, the taxonomy and distribution of every member of this group remains unclear.
The species has also been referred to as Bothrops bilineata in the literature.

Four subspecies are recognised:
  • T. a. acus (Lacepède, 1803) in the western Atlantic (Massachusetts, USA to Brazil) and east Atlantic (off Morocco and the western Mediterranean Sea);
  • T. a. imperialis (Rafinesque, 1810) in the Mediterranean Sea and Cape Verde Islands);
  • T. a. rafale Collette and Parin 1970 from the Gulf of Guinea; and
  • T. a melanotus (Bleeker, 1850) in the the Indo-West Pacific and oceanic islands in the eastern tropical Pacific (Revillagigedos, Clipperton, and Cocos).

Exocoetus obtusirostris is endemic to the Atlantic Ocean and showed no significant differences from different parts of this ocean. It was thought to occur circumglobally before it was split into three other closely related species (Parin and Shakhovskoy 2000).
Subpopulations south of Mauritania may represent another species; further taxonomic research is warranted (T. Iwamoto pers. comm. 2012).

Two subspecies are recognized by Collette (2003), T. crocodilus crocodilus (Peron and Lesueur 1821) from the Atlantic and Indo-West Pacific and T. crocodilus fodiator (Jordan and Gilbert 1882) in the eastern tropical Pacific.
Subpopulations of this species should be further investigated as they may represent separate species (Tomio pers. comm. 2012).

Cheilopogon melanurus has been reported from the eastern Atlantic, from Senegal to Angola (Parin 1999). The eastern tropical Atlantic population was studied earlier by Gibbs and Staiger (1970). They discovered significant differences in pectoral-fin pigmentation and barbel structure between juvenile specimens of this population and similar-sized western Atlantic specimens and suspected, even not finding any distinctions between adults of both populations, the presence of yet undescribed species near the shores of West Africa. Parin and Belyanina (2000) reexamined three of these smaller eastern Atlantic specimens (USNM 203903, 203905 and 218912) and re-identified them as C. milleri (Gibbs and Staiger 1970). However, the western and eastern populations are so different in predorsal-scale number (25-33, mean 28.4, by 8 specimens, vs. 31-36, mean 33.7) that recognition of another species is highly probable (Parin in prep).

Parin and Belyanina (1998) separated the subspecies Cheilopogon furcatus furcatus from two new subspecies in the Indian and Pacific oceans. Another subspecies, C. furcatus neimani Parin & Belyanina occurs in the Indian Ocean and the third subspecies C. furcatus fisunovi Parin & Belyanina is widely distributed in the Pacific Ocean from western to eastern Pacific.
The correct spelling for this species is Omosudis lowii (Günther, 1887), though other spellings are in use (Eschmeyer 2014). This species is also referred to as Omosudis loweii by FAO.

The name S. brasiliensis (type locality: Cape Frio, Brazil) has been generally used for this species.  However, genetic evidence indicates approximately 5-6% divergence in CO1 between eastern and western Atlantic populations, which suggests the populations on either side of the Atlantic are distinct species [Baldwin et al. in press]. Thus, the name S. parri Norman 1935 (type locality: Angola) should be applied to this species.
Hemiramphus balao is frequently misidentified as Hemiramphus brasiliensis.

Oxyporhamphus micropterus similis is replaced in the Indo-Pacific by the nominal species Oxyporhamphus micropterus micropterus.  It is considered to be Exocoetidae by some authors (Collette 2002). The recent acceptance of Oxyporhamphus similis as a species by Eschmeyer should be reviewed (B. Collette pers. comm. 2012).
This species is sometimes placed in its own genus, Nanichthys (Collette 2004). It is also often confused as the juvenile form of Scomberesox saurus scombroides (Bianchi et al. 1999).

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).

This taxon is not mentioned in The New Cactus Lexicon (Hunt et al. 2006), but The Plant List (2012) treats it as a synonym of Discocactus bahiensis Britton & Rose. It is treated as a good species here.
The genus of this species was recently changed from Carangoides to Caranx (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2012, Page et al. 2012).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
This species can be commonly misidentified as B. maculiferus (Weigt et al. 2012).

Many specimens historically identified as A. maculatus that have been found off the coast of Brazil around St. Paul's Rocks may have been misidentifications of A. strigosus, which has been recorded there based on molecular evidence (Bowen et al. 2001).
Page et al. (in press) accept the present taxonomic standing of Foetorepus agassizii.
In Brazilian waters, this species has been previously misidentified as Saurida suspicio (Carvalho-Filho et al. 2010).
There are multiple undescribed species in this group which may have been confused with this species.
The West Pacific population may represent another species.
Brotula barbata may be a species complex (Nielsen et al. 1999, de Paiva et al. 2010, R. Robins pers. comm. 2013).
Lycengraulis batesii may be misidentified as L. grossidens in the lower portions of river basins and near-shore coastal habitats (F. Di Dario pers. comm. 2017).
Some workers consider the genus of this species to be valid as Serranus, not Centropristis.

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).
Lonchopisthus meadi (Menezes and Figueiredo 1971) is a junior synonym of L. lemur (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2012).
Common names and scientific names for non-Atlantic and non-South African localities are probably missapplied (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2013).

Knudsen and Clements (2013) recently revised the family Kyphosidae. They determined that microcanthids, oplegnathids, kuhliids and terapontids are more closely related to Kyphosus than is Girella. Knudsen and Clements (2013) concluded that Girella, Scorpis, and Kyphosus should not be included within the same family and instead, be separated as individual families. Their study recognized 11 species of Kyphosus in Kyphosidae, and the monotypic Neoscorpis. Thus, there are 12 species total in the family Kyphosidae. 

Kyphosus lutescens and K. pacificus are now treated as synonyms of K. sectatrix (Knudsen and Clements 2013). Both K. incisor and K. analogus are now considered synonyms of K. vaigiensis (Knudsen and Clements 2013). Kyphosus sandwicensis is a junior synonym of K. elegans (Knudsen and Clements 2013). 

Before Knudsen and Clements (2013) it was thought that only two Kyphosids occurred in the Atlantic, but there may in fact be four species, K. sectatrix, K. vaigiensis, K. bigibbus, and K. cinerascens. However, Sakai and Nakbo (2014) have presented an alternative view on the kyphosids occurring in the Atlantic.
The genus of this species was recently changed from Hemanthias to Baldwinella (Anderson and Heemstra 2012)
There is ongoing debate as to the taxonomic status of M. antillarum; Munroe (2002) considered it a junior synonym of M. sessilicauda.

Etropus crossotus was originally described from specimens collected in the eastern Pacific Ocean. Populations identified as this species from the western Atlantic, though morphologically similiar, have not been examined from a genetic perspective to determine if they are conspecific with the eastern Pacific populations (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015). For now, we continue to use E. crossotus for Atlantic populations.

There are three co-occurring species of the genus Syacium in the western Atlantic. Identification of specimens to species is difficult because the species are morphologically similar and there is a significant amount of sexual dimorphism. Often times, these fishes are not identified to the species level and it is likely that in some studies catches consist of more than one species (T. Munroe pers. comm. 2015).
Polydactylus oligodon is difficult to distinguish from P. virginicus (Feltes 2002, B. Smith-Vaniz and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2015).
There should be some investigation into the taxonomic standing of this species (i.e., whether it it belongs in the Syngnathiformes or Gasterosteiformes).
In the field, this species is difficult to distinguish from Stephanolepis hispidus (R. Robertson and J. Tyler pers. comm. 2015).

This species has been frequently misidentified as S. taeniopterus and S. iseri. Its status as a distinct species was recognized by Moura et al. (2001) on the basis of scale counts and color pattern.

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

This species is a sister species of S. atomarium.

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

The east and west Atlantic populations of N. usta were designated as separate subspecies by Schultz (1968) on the basis of minor morphometric divergences in preserved fishes (Nicholsina usta usta and Nicholsina usta collettei ).

Recent data show that these two forms are highly divergent genetically, more so than many of the Sparisoma species are from each other (Robertson et al. 2006). Hence, the east and west Atlantic forms represent a sister pair of species, N. collettei and N. usta, respectively (Parenti and Randall unpublished).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

This species has been frequently identified by Brazilian authors (e.g. Menezes and Figueiredo 1985) as its sister Caribbean species, S. viride (Bonaterre 1783), the stoplight parrotfish, due to their similar morphology and similar color pattern of initial phase specimens. Its status as a distinct species was recognized by Moura et al.(2001) on basis of color pattern, and confirmed by molecular study (Robertson et al. 2006).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

Sparisoma frondosum was identified as the Caribbean species S. chrysopterum (yellowtail parrotfish) until its revalidation in 2001 (Moura et al. 2001).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.
Robertson and Van Tassell (2015) treat the Caribbean population as S. griseorubrum.
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).

Sparisoma axillare was identified in Brazil as the Caribbean species S. rubripinne (yellowtail parrotfish) until its revalidation in 2001 (Moura et al. 2001).

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.
Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae. The genera Chlororus and Scarus are two distinct monophyletic lineages (Smith et al. 2008).

The population in Fernando de Noronha are genetically distinct and probably represents a separate species (R. Robertson pers comm. 2008). Juveniles of this species are easily misidentified in Brazil as other species of Sparisoma and Nicholsina.

Westneat and Alfaro (2005) recognize the Scarini as a tribe within the family Labridae.

Saguinus n. graellsi is listed as a full species by Hernández-Camacho and Cooper (1976) and Defler (1994), on the basis that it is sympatric with a population of S. nigricollis in the region of Puerto Leguízamo in southern Colombia. Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1991) listed it as a subspecies of S. nigricollis, agreeing with Hershkovitz (1977). It was listed as a distinct species by Groves (2001, 2005) following the supposition of its sympatry with S. n. nigricollis. However, Defler (2003, 2004) has indicated that the occurrence of S. n. nigricollis north of the Rio Putumayo is doubtful. Based on a multi-locus phylogeny and a biogeographic analysis, Buckner and collaborators (2014) divided the genus Saguinus into two: the small-bodied tamarins Leontocebus, and the large-bodied tamarins Saguinus; this species belongs to the small-bodied tamarins (Leontocebus).

Formerly this species was in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 1993, 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) leucippe.

It is similar to Mico argentatus, predominantly white, but with tail and feet pale gold. The face and ears are largely unpigmented (Hershkovitz 1977). The taxonomy here follows Rylands (2012).

Formerly in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 1993, 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) intermedius. 
Mico intermedius is similar to M. melanurus by the distinct pale thigh stripe, similarly coloured hindquarters, dark crown (just a little paler than melanurus), but lacks the ear-tuft (it has a rudimentary tuft from only behind the pinna and not the well-developed tuft from within and around the pinna as in humeralifer). The face is variably depigmented (some individuals have quite dark-greyish faces), the forequarters are paler, and varying parts of the tail are pale off-white rather than black (Hershkovitz 1977).

Formerly this species was in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 1993, 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) nigriceps.

This marmoset is darker than Mico emiliae, described by Vivo (1985) from adjacent Rondônia, but differs in the pigmentation of face and ears, pheomelanisation of the forelimbs, mantle and ventrum, a brown rather than grey dorsum, an orange to russet colouration of the posterior limbs, and pale hips and upper thighs (Ferrari 2008).

Alperin (1995) argued that Mico nigriceps (Ferrari and Lopes 1992) and “Mico emiliae” from Rondônia belong to the same species.

This work follows Rylands (2012).

The lion tamarins, Leontopithecus spp., are listed as separate species following Della Serra (1951), Rosenberger and Coimbra-Filho (1984), Snowdon et al. (1986), Mittermeier et al. (1988), Natori (1989) and Rylands et al. (1993). Leontopithecus chrysopygus and L. chrysomelas have been listed as subspecies of L. rosalia by Coimbra-Filho (1969), Coimbra-Filho and Mittermeier (1972, 1973), Hershkovitz (1977), Mittermeier and Coimbra-Filho (1981), Forman et al. (1986) and Seuánez et al. (1988), the latter two publications on the basis of identical chromosome morphologies. Coimbra-Filho (1990) has suggested that L. caissara was a subspecies of L. chrysopygus, which was not supported neither morphologically (Burity et al. 1999) nor molecularly (Perez-Sweeney et al. 2008). A molecular phylogeny recovered three obvious clades: L. chrysomelas, L. caissara and L. chrysopygus / L. rosalia, where L. chrysomelas is the first to diverge from the other three (Perez-Sweeney et al. 2008). Here we follow the taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012).

Saimiri vanzolinii Ayres 1985 was described based on 13 specimens collected at the confluence of the Solimões and Japurá rivers and deposited in the Museum of Zoology at the University of São Paulo. The type locality is the northern shore of Lake Mamirauá, Amazonas, Brazil. Ayres (1985) allocated S. vanzolinii in the species group "Saimiri boliviensis" (Roman group), based on the taxonomic arrangement of Hershkovitz (1984). Saimiri vanzolinii was referred by Hershkovitz (1987) as a subspecies of S. boliviensis. Although no specimen was examined, Costello et al. (1993), based on the data described by Ayres (1985), considered S. vanzolinii as a junior synonym of S. sciureus. All subsequent authors followed Ayres (1985), considering S. vanzolinii as a valid species. Lynch Alfaro et al. (2015) analysed biogeographical and mitochondrial molecular data for the genus and concluded that S. vanzolinii is a valid species. More recently, Mercês (2018) performed an extensive morphological review of museum specimens of Saimiri species from throughout the Amazon basin; she also employed RAD-seq to sequence nuclear genomic markers to construct a Saimiri phylogeny. The nuclear genetic and morphological analyses by Mercês (2018) both provide strong evidence to place Saimiri vanzolinii as a distinct taxon and the sister species to Saimiri boliviensis.
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).

Kobayashi and Langguth (1994) first reported and later described (Kobayashi and Langguth 1999) Callicebus coimbrai after analyzing five specimens collected at three sites of the coastal Atlantic Forest in Sergipe State, in northeastern Brazil. Based on their study of this new species, along with previous craniometric studies by Kobayashi (1995), Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) argued that the titis of eastern Brazil constitute a separated group within the genus —  the personatus group — and should be considered a full species rather than a subspecies of C. personatus. In addition to C. coimbrai the authors listed C. nigrifrons, C. personatus, C. melanochir and C. barbarabrownae for that group. Based on molecular data, Byrne et al. (2016) proposed to split the genus Callicebus in three different genera (Callicebus, Cheracebus and Plecturocebus), with the ‘personatus group’ as the only component in the genus Callicebus.

Byrne et al. (2016) have separated the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely: Cheracebus (torquatus group sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002)), Plecturocebus (cupreus + moloch + donacophilus groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002)), and Callicebus (personatus group, sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002)). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species and P. dubius is a junior synonym of P. caligatus. However, the situation is still under debate, and we will regard these as two separate taxa until further evidence has been published.

authority: M. van Roosmalen, T. van Roosmalen & R.A. Mittermeier, 2002
taxonomicNotes: Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.

Byrne et al. 2016 have separated the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (Torquatus group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (Cupreus + moloch groups sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002 and Callicebus (personatus group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002).  According to Byrne et al. (2016), Cheracebus includes six species, C. torquatus, C. lugens, C. lucifer, C. purinus, C. regulus and C. medemi.

Byrne et al. 2016 have separated the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (Torquatus group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (Cupreus + moloch groups sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002 and Callicebus (personatus group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002).  According to Byrne et al. (2016), Cheracebus includes six species, C. torquatus, C. lugens, C. lucifer, C. purinus, C. regulus and C. medemi.

Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) and van Roosmalen et al. (2002) recognize five species groups for Callicebus: cupreus, donacophilus, moloch, personatus and torquatus. Based on craniometric and other morphological studies, Kobayashi (1995) and Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) argued that C. nigrifrons – and the other forms of the personatus group should be considered full species rather than subspecies of C. personatus, as proposed by Hershkovitz (1988, 1990) and Groves (2001). In addition to C. nigrifrons they listed C. personatus, C. melanochir, C. barbarabrownae and C. coimbrai. Based on molecular data, Byrne et al. (2016) proposed to split Callicebus in three different genera (Callicebus, Cheracebus and Plecturocebus), with the species of the personatus group as the only components of the genus Callicebus in this new arrangement.

Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) and van Roosmalen et al. (2002) recognize five species groups – cupreus, donacophilus, moloch, personatus and torquatus. Callicebus brunneus belongs to the moloch group, which also includes: Callicebus baptista, Callicebus bernhardi, Callicebus cinerascens, Callicebus hoffmannsi and Callicebus moloch. Based on molecular data, Byrne et al. (2016) reassed the Callicebus genus and placed this species in the genus Plecturocebus.

Ferrari et al. (2000) report the possible existence of a contact zone between P. brunneus and P. moloch in southern Rondonia, somewhere between the Serra dos Pacaás Novos, to the north, and the Chapada dos Parecis, to the south. The characteristics of this contact zone remain unclear, i.e. whether sympatry or even hybridization occurs, but it is interesting to note that at two sites located south of the Pacaás Novos, some monkeys observed were relatively lightly-coloured (more similar to P. moloch) in contrast with the typical dun tones of P. brunneus. Local residents also confirmed the existence of two distinct types of titis in different areas at this site.

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002).  According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.  Callicebus baptista’s Lönnberg, 1939, type locality is unknown. Restricted by P. Hershkovitz (1963) to the Lago do Baptista, in the Brazilian state of Amazonas.  It was considered to be a subspecies of C. hoffmannsi by P. Hershkovitz (1990). In 2001, Groves (2002) listed it as a full species. The species is monotypic (Mittermeir et al. 2013).

Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) and Van Roosmalen et al. (2002) recognize five species groups – cupreus, donacophilus, moloch, personatus and torquatus. Callicebus melanochir belongs to the personatus group, which also includes: Callicebus barbarabrownae, Callicebus coimbrai, Callicebus nigrifrons and Callicebus personatus. Following the taxonomic revision of Byrne et al. (2016), the genus Callicebus is now endemic to Brazil.

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.

Hill (1960) listed three species of bearded saki: Chiropotes chiropotes, C. satanas and C. albinasa [sic]. Hershkovitz (1985) described a new species, utahickae, and classified satanas and utahickae as subspecies of C. chiropotes. Groves (2001, 2005) followed the taxonomy of Hershkovitz (1985). The three subspecies of Chiropotes satanas (satanas, chiropotes and utahicki) are here listed as full species following the recommendation of Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002), Figueiredo et al. (2006), and Silva-Júnior et al.(2013). Bonvicino et al. (2003) resurrected the name Chiropotes israelita (Spix, 1823) for the bearded saki discovered by Boubli (2002) to the west of the Rio Branco, a tributary of the Rio Negro, Amazonas, Brazil. Genetic and pelage differences, notably a greenish brown (olive) dorsum as opposed to light golden brown as is typical of C. chiropotes, distinguish it from the bearded sakis of the Guianas to the east of the Rio Branco. There is however, a possible confusion concerning the correct names. Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus.

Hill (1960) listed three species of bearded saki: Chiropotes chiropotes, C. satanas and C. albinasa [sic]. Hershkovitz (1985) described a new species, utahickae, and classified satanas and utahickae as subspecies of C. chiropotes. Groves (2001, 2005) followed the taxonomy of Hershkovitz (1985). The three subspecies of Chiropotes satanas (satanas, chiropotes and utahicki) are here listed as full species following the recommendation of Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002), Figueiredo et al. (2006), and Silva-Júnior et al.(2013). Bonvicino et al. (2003) resurrected the name Chiropotes israelita (Spix, 1823) for the bearded saki discovered by Boubli (2002) to the west of the Rio Branco, a tributary of the Rio Negro, Amazonas, Brazil. Genetic and pelage differences, notably a greenish brown (olive) dorsum as opposed to light golden brown as is typical of C. chiropotes, distinguish it from the bearded sakis of the Guianas to the east of the Rio Branco. There is however, a possible confusion concerning the correct names. Silva-Júnior and Figueiredo (2002) argued that the form west of the Rio Branco is, correctly Chiropotes chiropotes (Humboldt, 1811), according to its type locality, and the form to the east of the Rio Branco, extending through the states of Pará and Amapá, and into the Guianas (Guyana, Suriname, French Guiana) is C. sagulatus (Traill, 1821) from Demerara (see Silva-Júnior et al. (2013). Doubts still remain, however, concerning Hershkovitz’s interpretation of Humboldt’s type locality of C. chiropotes, which would accordingly alter the nomenclature (J. P. Boubli, pers. comm). With the further research and phylogenetic analysis, both Traill’s sagulatus and Spix’s israelita may be valid species names for different populations of this wide ranging genus. 

The species name is currently in dispute. Hershkovitz (1985) named the subspecies Chiropotes satanas utahicki. However, as the species is named after a woman, in subsequent revisions authors renamed the species Chiropotes (satanas) utahickae (Silva Jr. and Figueiredo 2002; Groves 2005). Brandon-Jones et al. (2006) argue that the Latin gender suffix is part of its etymology and therefore unregulated by Article 31 of the International Code of Zoological Nomenclature, and that the author's selected suffix should be respected and the original spelling preserved.

Leontocebus cruzlimai was previouly reconized as a subspecies of the Saguinus fuscicollis (Hershkovitz 1977, see also Cheverud and Moore 1990), however Sampaio et al. (2015) elevated this taxa to the species level.

The taxonomy of Saguinus fuscicollis is based on Hershkovitz (1977; see also Cheverud and Moore 1990). In a molecular genetic study of the phylogeny of the genus, Cropp et al. (1999) found that the form fuscus was closer to S. nigricollis than to S. fuscicollis and gave it species status.
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014)

Caramaschi (2010) considered Elachistocleis ovalis a nomen dubium associated to a species inquirenda (a species of doubtful identity requiring further investigation); biological populations in Brazil formerly associated to this name were reassigned to other species, including this one.

Caramaschi (2010) considered Elachistocleis ovalis a nomen dubium associated to a species inquirenda (a species of doubtful identity requiring further investigation); biological subpopulations in Brazil formerly associated to this name were reassigned to other species, including E. helianneae.

Caramaschi (2010) considered Elachistocleis ovalis a nomen dubium associated to a species inquirenda (a species of doubtful identity requiring further investigation); biological populations in Brazil formerly associated to this name were reassigned to other species, including this one.

Caramaschi (2010) considered Elachistocleis ovalis a nomen dubium associated to a species inquirenda (a species of doubtful identity requiring further investigation); biological populations in Brazil formerly associated to this name were reassigned to other species, including this one.
The taxonomy and key characteristics of Brama species are in need of review (Haedrich in press).

The western Pacific/Indo-Pacific populations of this species were previously considered a subspecies Lagocephalus lagocephalus oceanicus, while those in the Atlantic were previously considered the subspecies Lagocephalus lagocephalus lagocephalus.
Most species of Abarema were at one time or another placed in Pithecellobium.

Espécie descrita em: Leg. Ilha de Maracá 42. 1989. Popularmente conhecida como angico (Barneby e Grimes, 1996). É afim de A. niopoides, mas difere pelos frutos com valvas tardiamente segmentadas e pela sutura ventral não alada (Barneby e Grimes, 1996).
The genus Arachis comprises 80 wild species and the cultivated crop Arachis hypogaea L. (Fabales, Leguminosae) commonly known as groundnut or peanut. All Arachis species are native to South America.

There is an inland and a coastal form for this species. The coastal form is a tree 10 metres or more in height, and the inland form is up to 4 metres tall with smaller, more coriaceous leaflets (Lewis 1987). The species differs from Abarema filamentosa in (inter alia) dense capitula of sessile or subsessile flowers and dull blackish, densly papillate pod-valves (Barneby and Grimes 1996).
This assessment uses the taxonomy of Plants of the World Online (2021), with Schnella cupreonitens (Ducke) Wunderlin as the accepted binomial nomenclature.
Easily confused with Aeschynomene marginata. Further studies are needed for a better taxonomic delimitation.
Previously Cassia caracensis H.S.Irwin & Barneby.
Dalbergia monetaria is a climbing shrub, small tree or liana.
Erythrina variegata is a tree usually between 6-12 but up to 20 m, with much branched crown and coral flowers.
Espécie descrita em: Bol. Mus. Goeldi Hist. Nat. Ethnogr. 5: 385 (1909). Nome vulgar: jutaí (AC) e jutaí-mirim (AM) (Pinto et al., 2020).
This taxon is recognised as a synonym of Machaerium latifolium Rusby in Flora do Brasil (2020) but not in Plants of the World Online, nor in International Plant Names Index (2020).
Three separate varieties of Mimosa albida are recognized.
Mimosa brachycarpa most closely resembles M. somnians, but they are distinguished on the dissection of the ovary (Barneby 1991).
Mimosa nuda is considered by Barneby (1991) to consist of five main varieties var. glaberrima, var. gracilipes, var. ramosa, var. angusta and var. nuda.
Mimosa insidiosa is considered to have two main varieties, var. insidiosa and var. major.
Mimosa xanthocentra is known from eight main varieties.

Mimosa mensicola appears to be a specialized local derivative of the widespread M. ophthalmocentra. Flowers and pods similar but foliage of M. mensicola is greatly modified by reduction of leaf-formula and reciprocal amplification of the leaflets (Barneby 1991).

Zollernia glabra and Zollernia splendens were considered as distinct species mainly on the basis of the size of the leaves and stipules. Observations of plant growth, especially comparison of the collection Lima et al. #4834 and the individual cultivated in the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew (grown from a seed of Lima et al. #4834), show that young plants have leaves similar to specimens named as Z. splendens while mature individuals are more similar to specimens identified as Z. glabra (Mansano et al. 2004).

The genus Monopteryx is considered to be endemic to the basins of Rios Negro, Solimoes and the upper Amazonas in the Brazilian provinces of Amazonas and Roraima and reaches just over the border into Amazonas, Venezuela (Barneby and Grimes 1984).
Rhynchosia minima is exceedingly difficult to divide into lower taxa, its range of variation is very great and experimental techniques are needed (Gillett et al. 1971).
Swartzia Schreb. is a genus of ca. 180 species of trees and shrubs that are prevalent in lowland Neotropical moist forests from southern Mexico to Bolivia and southern Brazil (Torke 2007).
Swartzia Schreb. is a genus of ca. 180 species of trees and shrubs that are prevalent in lowland Neotropical moist forests from southern Mexico to Bolivia and southern Brazil (Torke 2007).
Swartzia Schreb. is a genus of ca. 180 species of trees and shrubs that are prevalent in lowland Neotropical moist forests from southern Mexico to Bolivia and southern Brazil (Torke 2007).
Swartzia Schreb. is a genus of ca. 180 species of trees and shrubs that are prevalent in lowland Neotropical moist forests from southern Mexico to Bolivia and southern Brazil (Torke 2007).
Swartzia Schreb. is a genus of ca. 180 species of trees and shrubs that are prevalent in lowland Neotropical moist forests from southern Mexico to Bolivia and southern Brazil (Torke 2007).
