Swartzia Schreb. is a genus of ca. 180 species of trees and shrubs that are prevalent in lowland Neotropical moist forests from southern Mexico to Bolivia and southern Brazil (Torke 2007).
Swartzia Schreb. is a genus of ca. 180 species of trees and shrubs that are prevalent in lowland Neotropical moist forests from southern Mexico to Bolivia and southern Brazil (Torke 2007).

Zapoteca formosa consists of six highly variable subspecies: formosa, salvadorensis, gracilis, rosei, mollicula and schottii. This infraspecific classification is based primarily on leaf and flower characters (Hernandez 1989).
This may be a subspecies of Anchoviella perfasciata (Whitehead et al. 1988).
There has been some uncertainty surrounding the family and genus placement of this species (Prokofiev 2007).
Benthodesmus tenuis may represent a group of closely related species (Parin and Nakamura 2002).
The taxonomy of this species needs review.
A subspecies, Hoplostethus mediterraneus trunovi, has been reported off of Namibia (Moore in press).
Howella atlantica is considered by some a subspecies of Howella brodiei Ogilby, 1899, although accepted by Eschmeyer (2015).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.

Neobythites ocellatus was split into two species based on differences in color patterns, which resulted in the naming of a new species (Neobythites multiocellatus) and restricted the distribution of N. ocellatus to Brazil between 233-641 m depth (Nielsen et al. 2009).
Ipomoea ramosissima (Poir.) Chiosy is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of sweet potato, Ipomoea batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas  (Vincent et al. 2013).

Ipomoea grandifolia (Dammer) O’Donell is in the series Batatas (Khoury et al. 2015). It is a tertiary wild relative of Sweet Potato, I. batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas (L.) Lam. (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).
It has been considered a hybrid, with I. cordatotriloba as one parent, but this has not been proven (Wood et al. 2015).

Ipomoea cordatotriloba Dennst. is in the series Batatas (Khoury et al. 2015) and comprises three varieties (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018): var. australis (O’Donell) D.F.Austin, var. cordatotriloba and var. torreyana (A.Gray) D.F.Austin. The latter should not be recognised for this taxon (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018).

Ipomoea cordatotriloba is a tertiary genetic wild relative of Sweet Potato, I. batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas (L.) Lam. (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).
Manihot brachyloba Müll.Arg. is a gene pool secondary wild relative of cassava, M. esculenta Crantz ssp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013).

The assessment is undertaken for the species sensu lato as it has more than 20 synonyms (J.M. Mendoza F. pers. comm. 2018).

Manihot caerulescens Pohl is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

According to M. Mendoza (pers. comm. 2018) Manihot catingae Ule is a dubious species and Allem et al. (1999) suggest that it may be a synonym of M. glaziovii Muell. Arg. Nevertheless, if it is a good species, it is a secondary genetic wild relative of cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

Manihot epruinosa Pax & K.Hoffm. is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). According to J.M. Mendoza F. (pers. comm. 2018) M. epruinosa is a dubious species and Allem et al. (1999) suggest that it may be a synonym of M. glaziovii Muell.Arg.
Manihot gracilis Pohl is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

According to M. Mendoza (pers. comm. 2018) Manihot neusana Nassar is a dubious species as there are only three records, of which the type comes from a biological station where it was cultivated. It is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

Manihot oligantha Pax & K.Hoffm. is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

Manihot pilosa Pohl is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

According to J.M. Mendoza F. (pers. comm. 2018) Manihot pohlii Wawra is a dubious species, also Rogers and Appan (1973) recorded only two specimens. It is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). It is also closely related to M. neusana Nassar (Nassar 1985).

Manihot pruinosa Pohl belongs to the primary gene pool of cassava (Manihot esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta) being its closest wild relative (Allem 1999, Olsen and Schaal 1999, Allem et al. 2001, Vincent et al. 2013).

Manihot pseudoglaziovii Pax & K.Hoffm. is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018). Allem et al. (1999) suggest that M. pseudoglaziovii may be a synonym of M. glaziovii Muell.Arg.

The large number of synonyms and strong variability showed in Manihot tripartita (Spreng.) Müll.Arg. justifies the urgent need for taxonomic studies (J.M. Mendoza F. pers. comm. 2019). It is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, Manihot esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Allem 2002).
Manihot triphylla Pohl is in the section Graciles (Rogers and Appan 1973) and is a secondary genetic wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta (Allem 2002).

Manihot tristis Müll.Arg. is in the section Heterophyllae (Rogers and Appan 1973) and is a wild relative of Cassava, M. esculenta Crantz subsp. esculenta. Following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006), it is in Taxon Group 4 of Cassava, although it is noted that section Heterophyllae contains species which are most similar to the cultigen (Grattapaglia et al. 1987). In fact, Martins et al. (2017) shows that M. tristis has great morphological similarities to Cassava which makes it difficult to differentiate among them.

According to some taxonomic treatments, it is a synonym of M. esculenta subsp. flabellifolia (Pohl) Cif (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018), which is the result of hybridisation between escapes of cassava from cultivation and wild Manihot spp. (Nassar and Mendoza 2017). However, it is listed as an accepted name in The Plant List (2013) and Board of Trustees, RBG Kew (2018). In addition, the differences with the cultivated species are uncertain and a taxonomic review is need (J.M. Mendoza F. pers. comm. 2019).
This species was previously known as Parexocoetus brachypterus or Parexocoetus brachypterus hillianus, but the Atlantic population was raised to species level by Parin (2003).
Before its description by Parin in 1999, it was usually misidentified as Prognichthys gibbifrons (Valenciennes 1846).

Previously known as Prognichthys gibbifrons throughout the Atlantic, but Parin (1999) described P. occidentalis for the western Atlantic population and P. glaphyrae for open waters of the tropical Atlantic, leaving the eastern Atlantic population to retain the name of Prognichthys gibbifrons.

At least four species of the subgenus Thoracobombus from Central and South America have many individuals for which the pubescence is almost entirely black. The genitalia of the males are quite distinctive, but association of the conspecific females with these males has caused problems (Williams 1998).

The single known female of B. abditus was described as originating from 'Rep. de Guinée Beyla' (equatorial Africa). However, it is indistinguishable from B. brevivillus according to Sakagami (1976:427) and probably represents an introduced or mislabelled individual (Michener 1979, Williams 1998). This specimen was also examined by P.H. Williams (pers. comm. 2016), and his assessment agreed with that of Sakagmai

This specimen was collected at least 180 years ago and possibly more than 200 years ago. Given the high level of survey effort applied to bumblebees in general and the knowledge that there is only one other bumble bee species (among ca. 250 species) known from a single specimen, it seems reasonable to infer from available information that B. rubriventris is likely to be extinct. However, the location of the type locality remains uncertain. Although there is no reason to challenge the original description placing the type locality in Brazil, there are reasons to doubt whether a label“St. Domingue.” (interpreted by later authors as placing the type locality either in Goiás or in the Dominican Republic) originally belonged to the specimen. Indirect evidence from morphology and from the historical biogeography of bumble bees supports a South American type locality, with the Brazilian Atlantic Forest as a likely candidate (Williams 2014).

The orthography of Olivier (1789) and Fabricius (1798) employs a long 's' (similar to 'f' or 'f'), a common practice of the period. This convention has since changed and recent authors have consistently used 's'. (Williams 1998).
This species had a genus change in 2016 according to Poulsen et al., and should now be considered as Monacoa grimaldii. need to request change in SIS
Hordeum euclaston Steud. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Arena strigosa Schreb. belongs to the tertiary Gene Pool of A. sativa L.
Eleusine tristachya (Lam.) Lam. belongs to the secondary Gene Pool of Finger Millet E. coracana (L.) Gaertn. (Phillips 1972).
Hordeum stenostachys Godr. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
Hordeum flexuosum Steud. is a tertiary genetic relative of Barley (H. vulgare L.) (von Bothmer et al. 1995).
This species was originally described as Dactylostomias ater.
This species was first described as Echiostoma micripnus.
The Trachipteridae family needs revision (Olney in press).
This species is sometimes referred to as Argyropelecus olfersi.
Preliminary molecular studies suggest that the genus Schedophilus is not monophyletic (Milana et al. 2011)

The taxonomy of C. niger does not appear to be resolved; while Melo (2009) recognizes seven species in the genus, Prokofiev and Kukuev (2009) placed many of these species in synonymy with C. niger, only recognizing two species in genus.
This species has been confused with P. lineatus, and there may be an overlap in size (Ditchfield pers. comm.). A review of museum specimens is required to separate P. lineatus and P. recifinus.
This genus was recently revised (Velasco pers. comm.).
Eptesicus chiriquinus is distinct from andinus and brasiliensis; see Simmons and Voss (1998). this speies includes montosus (Ochoa pers. comm).
The name is sometimes spelled youngii, but youngi is the original spelling (Simmons 2005).
Formerly Natalus espiritosantensis was considered a subspecies of N. stramineus.
Micronycteris megalotis subsp., recognized as species by Simmons 1996. Synonymous with M. megalotis (unpublished molecular data).

Controversy abounds over who deserves the credit for naming D. albus. Oken may have been responsible, but credit is usually given to Wied-Neuwied (1820) (Potchynok and Myers 2006). Populations in Central America may be distinct species referable to D. virgo but more study is needed (B.K. Lim pers. comm.).
This includes nigellus (Simmons 2005).
Some authorities consider this species to be in the Vampyressa genus and it can be easily confused with other species in this genus.
This is a species complex of at least three species (Tavares pers. comm.), which was previously included in V. pusilla, and separated by Lim et al. (2003).

This is part of the subgenus Artibeus. It includes palmarum and intermedius. It is not appropriate to treat intermedius as a subspecies of lituratus because it supposedly co-occurs with other populations of lituratus (referred to palmarum, which has priority) at several Central American localities. As there are no characters that unambiguously separate palmarum and intermedius, it seems most likely that intermedius simply represents individuals of palmarum that fall at the lower end of the normal range of size variation. Accordingly, intermediusis treated as a junior synonym of A. lituratus palmarum (Simmons 2005).
This is a newly described species. It was previously confused with T. lavali. It is possible that T. devivoi will be further split, separating the Guyana and Brazil subpopulations (Lim pers. comm.).
Simmons (2005) treats planirostris under jamaicensis pending further study.

The definition of this species has changed through the years and distinct researchers, Handley (1987) included A. ravus as a synonym, without further discussion, but previously Davis (1970) also synonymized other names under A. phaeotis. This view was kept by subsequent authors, like Simmons (2005). However, the molecular analyses by Solari et al. (2009) plus the side-by-side comparison of the type specimens (S. Solari pers. comm.) showed these two names represent distinct entities, and therefore valid species.
Old records may have been called A. fuliginosus

This was previously listed under the genus Artibeus, but a phylogenetic study by Hoofer et al. (2008) and Solari et al. (2009) suggested these two names, considered subgenera: Artibeus (or large Artibeus) and Dermanura (or small Artibeus), although sister to each other are better considered as valid genera. The previous definition of D. glauca included several names as junior synonyms or subspecies (see Simmons 2005), but most of these are not closely related as revealed by morphological (Lim et al. 2008) and molecular analyses (Solari et al. 2009), and are better considered as valid species (i.e. bogotensis, rosenbergi).
This is sometimes placed in its own monotypic genus Koopmania.

Subgenus Dermanura (Simmons 2005). This subgenus has been recognized as a separate genus on molecular grounds, but there are no diagnostic morphological differences from Artibeus (Lim et al. 2004). Previously listed under genus Artibeus.

Subgenus Dermanura (Simmons 2005). This subgenus has been recognized as a separate genus on molecular grounds, but there are no diagnostic morphological differences from Artibeus (Lim et al. 2004).

The previous (2008) assessment for this species was published under the genus Artibeus. This is an amended assessment, under the newly recognised genus Dermanura.
C. centralis recently split from this species (Simmons and Handley 1998, Simmons 2005).
Several subspecies have been recognized, but these do not appear justified; see Simmons and Voss (1998).
This species was split from T. bidens.
This species may be confused with Saccopteryx antioquensis, although they are not sympatric (Munoz and Cuartas 2001).
This species may be confused with S. gymnura.
The genus Cormura is monotypic (Bernard 2003).
It was a subspecies of levis; Barquez et al. (2006) treat as species.
Nyctinomops aurispinosus includes similis; see Jones and Arroyo-Cabrales (1990).
The genus is monotypic.

This species includes yucatanicus, europs and gracilis; see Freeman (1981), and Avila-Flores et al. (2002). It includes espiritosantensis, see Zortéa and Taddei (1995) and Avila-Flores et al. (2002). Note that the correct spelling for the specific epithet in combination with Nyctinomops is laticaudatus (not laticaudata) because the generic name is masculine. It was reviewed by Avila-Flores et al. (2002).

This species has been split. Records from northern Brazil are R. io and from southern Brazil are R. hussoni. R. tumida is now restricted to Central American populations. Museum records should be reviewed.
This species is in the subgenus Noctilio. See Hood and Jones (1984). The Antillean form was reviewed by Timm and Genoways (2003)
Karyotypic and genetic studies of a population of Rhogeessa io from western Ecuador, revealed that the form referred to as R. io velilla should be treated as a valid species (Baird et al. 2008).

This species is in the subgenus Dirias. It was formerly referred to as labialis. See Simmons and Voss (1998) for discussion of Amazonian subspecies. Also see Hood and Pitocchelli (1983). It may include more than one species; see Lewis-Oritt et al. (2001). Anwarali et al.(2014), indicate that additional genetic data doesn't support polyphyly of the species. Clear genetic and geographic structure exist in the species, but no instances of ongoing hybridization exist between N. albiventris and N. leporinus.
The species is most similar to Platalina genovesium.
The genus is monotypic.
This taxonomic concept includes amazonicus; see Gardner et al. (1970) and Eger (1977). Also see Best et al. (2001). It may be confused with E. bonariensis.

McDonough et al. (2008) and Baker et al. (2009) provided support for the elevation to species of two taxa within E. glaucinus, E. ferox and E. wilsoni, using mitochondrial gene sequence, karyotypic, morphological, and amplified fragment length polymorphism data. Their analysis supported three distinctive clades within the E. glaucinus complex: E. glaucinus from Paraguay and Venezuela, E. ferox and E. floridanus from Cuba, Jamaica, Mexico, and the United States, and a new species from Ecuador, E. wilsoni (Baker et al. 2009).
Does not include patagonicus or beckeri; see Barquez and Ojeda (1992), Barquez et al. (1993), and Saralegui (1996). See Hunt et al. (2003), but note that they included patagonicus in bonariensis.
This species has been previously confused with Peropteryx macrotis (Simmons and Voss, 1998).
This species includes pamana; see Goodwin and Greenhall (1961). It may include davisoni; see Freeman (1981).
Includes gorgasi.

Moratelli and Dias (2015) described the species Lonchophylla inexpectata from the Caatinga of north-eastern Brazil, and noted that specimens of L. inexpectata have in the past been misidentified as L. mordax. Lonchophylla mordax occurs along the eastern border of the Caatinga and in the Atlantic Forest–Caatinga ecotone in North-eastern Brazil (Moratelli and Dias 2015).
This includes occidentalis. Some specimens previously referred to this species actually represent inusitata.
Specimens of this species have frequently been confused with concava, mordax and Lionycteris spurrelli.
The new molecular and morphological evidence places Lophostoma yasuni within the clade of L. carrikeri. L. yasuni should therefore be considered as a synonym of L. carrikeri (Camacho et al. 2016).

Includes laephotis and amblyotis. The species name for this taxon was formerly spelled silvicola when used in Tonatia, but must be spelled silvicolum when combined with Lophostoma, which is a Greek neuter noun (Simmons 2005).
Split from Tonatia.
Includes C. intermedius (Simmons 2005).
Simmons and Voss (1998) discussed problems with previously recognised subspecies.
This may be a species complex.
Eumops trumbulli was included in perotis by Koopman (1994) but see Eger (1977).
This is distinct from bonariensis; see Barquez and Ojeda (1992), Barquez et al. (1993), Mares et al. (1995), Saralegui (1996), Barquez and Diaz (2001), and Gregorin and Taddei (2002).
Some specimens of U. bilobatum may refer to this species (Patterson pers. comm.).

This may be a species complex (Mantilla pers. comm.), as it currently consists of six subspecies. It is a polytypic species. Hybrid zones in Central America need further study to ensure that it is not a composite (Patterson pers. comm.)
This is the new taxonomic concept for S. lilium. Previously it included as subspecies S. l. angeli, S. l. parvidens and S. l. paulsoni, now elevated to species rank (Velazco and Patterson 2013).
Apparently closely related to nigricans, levis, and oxyotus.
Might be confused with S. lilium in older collections. Does not include luisi; see Simmons and Voss (1998).
The previous (2008) assessment for this species was published under the genus Vampyressa. This is an amended assessment under the newly recognised genus Vampyriscus; see Jones and Carter (1976).

This species may be confused with Vampyressa thyoni in the field (Tavares pers. comm.).
The previous 2008 assessment for this species was published under the genus Vampyressa. This is an amended assessment under the genus Vampyriscus.
Previously Vampyrodes caraccioli included V. major, now considered a distinct species (Velazco and Simmons 2011).
Apparently closely related to riparius.
Apparently closely related to ruber.
Recently described species.
This is a recently described species, split from L. aurita. It can be confused with other species of Lonchorhina.
A recently described species.

Woodman (1993) notes that many mammalian generic names ending in -otis use the wrong gender for specific names. If this advice is to be followed, the species name should be M. sima. The Chiroptera SG advise keeping the names as they are for now while a decision is still to be made on these.
Includes P. suapurensis.
In revision (Tavares pers. comm.).
Tavares et al. (in press) and Simmons (2005) consider H. alienus as a species. Gardner (2008) consider alienus as a subspecies of H. montanus. Further taxonomic clarity is needed.
This species may be confused with others therefore current collections may require reevaluation (Y. Munoz pers. comm.).
Peropteryx leucoptera is a species complex and a new species will be described by Lim et al. (in prep).

This species does not include trinitatis or phaea. This complex may include more than one species; see Reid et al. (2000) and Yee (2000), but note that Yee included trinitatis and phaea in this species.
Mimon bennetti does not include cozumelae; see McCarthy et al. (1993), and Simmons and Voss (1998).
This species is sometimes listed as a synonym of rufus, but see Dolan (1989). Does not include macdougalli; see Dolan (1989).

This includes fortis, milleri, debilis and tropidorhynchus. It does not include aztecus, barnesi, coibensis, cherriei and lambi; see Dolan (1989) and Simmons and Voss (1998). It also includes daulensis. The Antillean subpopulations were reviewed by Genoways et al. (1981) and Timm and Genoways (2003). This complex is desperately in need of revision.
It now includes Molossus barnesi previously assessed as a separate species (Catzeflis et al. 2016).
Molossus currentium previously included M. bondae as synonym. M. bondae is now considered as a valid species (Eger 2008).
Included in Molossus by Koopman (1994).
This concept may contain more than one species; see Hoffmann and Baker (2001) and Simmons (2005).

This species is called ater by many authors, but see Dolan (1989), who argued, based on descriptions of head and ear shape of both taxa, and examination of the specimens labelled as types of rufus in the Muséum National d’Histoire Naturelle in Paris, that Molossus ater Geoffroy, 1805, is really an Eumops, and that rufus is really the correct name for the large Molossus often incorrectly called ater. This species requires taxonomic revision and studies (Barquez pers. comm.).
Needs taxonomic revision (contains many subspecies) (Tavares pers. comm.). Includes elongata.
Subgenus Molossops.

The lectotype was designated by Carter and Dolan (1978). It does not include milleri or paranus. Specimens previously reported from Ecuador apparently represent paranus; planirostris is not presently known from Ecuador (Reid et al. 2000).

Cynomops generally is regarded as either a monophyletic genus or, in some cases, a subgenus of Molossops. In the molecular analysis, species traditionally included within Molossops and Cynomops each comprised two well-supported monophyletic lineages. The data also support the recognition of Cynomops and Molossops as divergent lineages worthy of generic status. Species limits and phylogenetic relationships within Cynomops, however, remain unresolved (Peters et al. 2002).
Subgenus Molossops.
Subgenus Neoplatymops. Listed as a subspecies of Molossops temminckii by Cabrera (1958), but Peterson (1965), who considered Neoplatymops a distinct genus.
Some put Cynomops in the genus Molossops, however, it is now recognized as Cynomops (Peters et al. 2002). Cynomps mexicanus was removed from greenhalli.

Cynomops generally is regarded as either a monophyletic genus or, in some cases, a subgenus of Molossops. In the molecular analysis, species traditionally included within Molossops and Cynomops each comprised two well-supported monophyletic lineages. The data also support the recognition of Cynomops and Molossops as divergent lineages worthy of generic status. Species limits and phylogenetic relationships within Cynomops, however, remain unresolved (Peters et al. 2002).
Apparently includes Eptesicus dorianus, but questions still remain about the identity of the holotype (Simmons 2005).
Recent studies consider Lasiurus salinae and L. varius as separate from L. blossevillii, but treat L. brachyotis as a subspecies of the latter (Gardner and Handley 2008).
This species is in the aegyptiaca species group.The Caribbean subspecies was reviewed by Timm and Genoways (2003).
This was raised to generic level as a monotypic genus (Simmons and Voss 1998).
This species previously included Glyphonycteris benhi.
Ascorra et al. (1991) reviewed schmidtorum but referred some specimens to this species that were subsequently re-identified as either sanborni (Simmons 1996) or brosseti (Simmons and Voss 1998).
Placed in subgenus Xenoctenes.
Formerly included in the monotypic genus Barticonycteris.
This species may include homezi (Ochoa and Sanchez 2005).
Micronycteris microtus has been split from M. megalotis but recent unpublished molecular data indicate it should be synonymous with M. megalotis.
Was previously confused with G. silvestris. The genus was recently separated from Micronycteris.
Includes platyceps.
This includes tricolor (Simmons 2005).
Includes septentrionalis.
This species may be confused with C. perspicillata, especially in southeastern Brazil. The Central American populations have recently been split into Carollia sowelli (Baker et al. 2002).
Difficult to distinguish in the field from P. elongatus.

Six morphological forms pertaining to the concept of Brown Brocket adopted here have been described as subspecies of Mazama simplicicornis (= M. gouazoubira) or M. gouazoubira ( Pinder and Leeuwenberg 1997). They are argentina Lönnberg, auritus Gray, kozeritzi Miranda-Ribeiro, mexianae Hagmann, namby Fitzinger, and superciliaris Gray. In his review of Brazilian species of Mazama, Rossi (2000) interpreted the morphological differences that led authors to describe auritus Gray, kozeritzi Miranda-Ribeiro, mexianae Hagmann, namby Fitzinger, and superciliaris Gray as individual variation among specimens of Mazama gouazoubira. We follow this author in not recognizing any subspecies from Brazil. The form argentina Lönnberg , not analyzed by Rossi (2000), remains the only one that could merit subspecific status. Nevertheless, a thorough analysis of the original description of Mazama simplicicornis argentina shows there are no characters in the type that cannot be explained by individual or geographical variation. Therefore, at the present time we see no reason to recognize either argentina Lönnberg or any other form cited above as subspecies of Mazama gouazoubira.

The taxonomy of Mazama americana is still uncertain. Specific doubts concern subspecies number and evolution of subspecies into species. Cabrera (1961) considered there to be nine subspecies (M. a. gualea, M. a. jucunda, M. a. rosii, M. a. rufa, M. a. sarae, M. a. sheila, M. a. whitelyi, M. a. zamora and M. a. zetta). Czernay (1987) added the following six subspecies to Cabrera's list: M. a. temama, M. a. cerasina, M. a. reperticia, M. a. americana, M. a. trinitatis and M. a. carrikeri. On the other hand, Thomas (1913) considered M. zetta and M. sheila as species and not subspecies. Allen (1915) corroborated Thomas, and added M. trinitatis, M. rufa, M. sartorii, M. gualea, M. fuscata and M. zamora as species. M. temama, earlier considered as a subspecies, was reclassified as a separate species by Groves and Grubb (1987), based on cytogenetical studies carried out by other authors. Rossi (2000) did a taxonomic revision of the Mazama genus for Brazil. He did not observe differences between Mazama americana specimens collected from different regions. Cytogenetic analysis of M. americana was initially realized by Taylor et al. (1969), who reported 2n-68 and NF=74. Jorge and Bernirschke (1977) analyzed three M. americana temama and described their basic karyotype as 2n=50 and FN=70, with a chromosome fusion in one of the studied animals. The X chromosome was submetacentric and approximately the same size as chromosome pair 7. The metacentric Y was the smallest chromosome. The vast differences among the animals analyzed by Jorge and Benirschke (1977) and Taylor et al. (1969) raised questions concerning these species’ classification. Neitzel (1987) analyzed a Paraguayan female and described yet another pattern for the species. It had 2n=52, plus 4 to 5 B chromosomes and NF=56. The submetacentric X was the largest chromosome. These results increased doubts as to this species’ karyotypic pattern. More recently, Duarte (1992) analyzed four Brazilian animals, and obtained conflicting results. Diploid numbers were 48, 50, 52 and 54, and NF = 54, 54, 56 and 56, respectively. These results were similar to those obtained by Neitzel (1987). According to Duarte and Merino (1997), this polymorphism appears to indicate the existence of various species within the Red Brocket Deer.

Duarte (1992) reported the existence of a new species which he named Mazama bororo. This classification was predominantly based on karyotype differences between other red brocket Mazama species. The first individual analyzed was a captive individual originated from Capão Bonito locality, São Paulo, Brazil. A more detailed description of the animal was made by Duarte and Merino (1997), Duarte (1996) and Duarte and Jorge (2003), who recognized this species as a morphologically intermediate form between M. nana and M. americana.

The classification of Rusas in their own genus as Rusa rather than Cervus was suggested by Van Bemmel (1949, cited by Emmerson and Tate 1993) based on the geographic distribution of these animals. While simple geographical or morphological characteristics may not be enough to justify a classification, cervine and rusine deer have different chromosome numbers (cervine: 2n = 66 to 68, rusine: 2n = 56 to 65; Neitzel 1987 and Wang et al. 1982, cited by Emmerson and Tate 1993; Gilbert et al. 2006; data in Groves and Grubb 2011) and these species do not interbreed. More recently, the division of the genus Cervus into four subgenera including Rusa, and the classification of Rusas in that subgenus was suggested by Groves and Grubb (1987) and has since been supported by extensive genetic studies (Meijard and Groves 2004).


Wilson and Mittermeier (2011) have listed seven timorensis subspecies: R. t. timorensis (Timor), R. t. djonga (Muna and Buton), R. t. floresiensis (Flores), R. t. macassaricus (Sulawesi), R. t. moluccensis (Moluccan Islands), R. t. renschi (Bali), and R. t. russa (Java). Others disagree that R. timorensis can be separated into subspecies and suggest that the apparent differences between the groups listed above are simply due to the genetic effects of small populations, and to environmental effects which have caused the development of phenotypically (but not genetically) different populations.


However, it has been accepted by several authors (e.g. Hill, Thomas and Mackenzie 1987; Dahlan 2009) that Javan (designated R. timorensis russa) and Moluccan (R. t. moluccensis) deer are different subspecies. This distinction has been based in some instances on the origin of the population under consideration, and on differences in size and pelage (Mackenzie 1985, Groves and Grubb 2011), and are therefore inconclusive. However, there are distinct differences in breeding season when the two “breeds” are managed in the same environment (Woodford 1994). That the Moluccan deer may be in the process of evolving away from the Javan “parent “ population is strongly indicated by the work of Emmerson and Tate (1993) who concluded, on the basis of phenetic and cladistic analyses, that Rusas from Java and Molucca should be divided into different subspecies, with a genetic distance (Nei 1972) of about 0.08. The validity of separating the other six subspecies suggested by Grubb (2005) has apparently not been established.

Considered a synonym of Mazama gouazoubira (Fischer, 1814) until Rossi (2000) demonstrated that it is a valid species. Wilson and Reeder (2005) include nemorivaga in gouazoubira in error. M. nemorivaga and M. gouazoubira are parapatric species, but molecular and cytogenetics studies (Duarte et al. 2008, Fiorillo et al. 2013) have shown their difference.

The taxonomy and systematics of the Pampas Deer have been based primarily on morphological data. Five subspecies are recognized:

O. b. bezoarticus (Linnaeus, 1758), in the Cerrado ranging from eastern and central Brazil, south of the Amazon river between the plateau of Mato Grosso and the upper San Francisco river. While there is a population further north on the island of Marajo, at the mouth of the Amazon River (Rossetti and de Toledo 2006).

O. b. celer Cabrera, 1943, inhabiting the entire Argentinean pampas from the Atlantic coast to Sub Andean foothills and southward to the Rio Negro basin.

O. b. leucogaster (Goldfüss, 1817), located in the seasonally flooded grasslands of southwestern Brazil in southern Mato Grosso, southeastern Bolivia, Paraguay and in the Chaco savannas in northern Argentina (northern Santiago del Estero, Santa Fe, Formosa and Corrientes).

O. b. arerunguaensis González, Álvares-Valin and Maldonado, 2002. Type locality - Uruguay; northwestern Salto Department, Arerunguá, El Tapado, 31º41’51”S, 56º43’31”W.

O. b. uruguayensis González, Álvares-Valin and Maldonado, 2002. Type locality - Uruguay, grasslands of eastern Rocha Department, Sierra de Los Ajos, 33º50’01”S; 54º01’34”W.

A number of subspecies have been identified (Smith 1991):
O. v. acapulcensis (Caton, 1877). Type locality Acapulco, Guerrero, México;
O. v. borealis (Miller, 1990).Type locality “Booksport”, Maine, USA;
O. v. cariacou (Boddaert, 1784). Type locality Guyane, coastal French Guiana;
O. v. carminis Goldman & Kellogg, 1940. Type locality “Botellas Cañón, Sierra del Carmen, northern Coahuila, Mexico;
O. v. chiriquensis (J.A. Allen, 1910). Type locality “Boquerón, Chiriqui”, Panamá;
O. v. clavium Barboyr & Allen, 1922. Type locality “Big Pine Key”, Florida, USA;
O. v. couesi (Coues & Yarrow, 1875). Type locality “Rancho Santuario”, northwestern Durango, México;
O. v. curassavicus (Hummelinck, 1940). Type locality Island of Curacao;
O. v. dacotensis Goldman & Kellogg, 1940. Type locality ”White Earth River”, Mountrail Country, North Dakota, USA;
O. v. goudotti (Gay & Gervais, 1846). Type locality “vits dans les regions elevees de la Nouvelle-Grenade”;
O. v. gymnotis (Wiegmann, 1833). Type locality “British Guiana”;
O. v. hiltonensis Goldman & Kellogg, 1940. Type locality “Hilton Head Island, Beaufort County, South Carolina, USA;
O. v. leucurus (Douglas, 1829). Type locality “the districts adjoining the river Columbia, USA;
O. v. macrourus (Rafinesque, 1817). Type locality “Mer Rouge, Morehouse county, Louisiana, USA;
O. v. mcilhennyi F.W. Miller, 1928. Type locality “near Avery Island, Iberia Parish, Louisiana, USA;
O. v. margaritae (Osgood, 1910). Type locality “vicinity of Puerto Viejo”, Margarita Island, Venezuela;
O. v. mexicanus (Gmelin, 1788). Type locality “Valley of México”, México;
O. v. miquihuanensis Goldman & Kellogg, 1940. Type locality ”Sierra Madre Oriental, near Miquihuana, southwestern Tamaulipas, México”;
O. v. nelsoni Merriam, 1898. Type locality “San Cristobal, highlands of Chiapas, México”;
O. v. nigribarbis Goldman and Kellogg, 1940. Type locality “Blackbeard Island, McIntoch County, Georgia, USA;
O. v. oaxacensis Goldman & Kellogg, 1940. Type locality “mountains 15 miles west of Oaxaca, México”;
O. v. ochrourus Bailey, 1932. Type locality “Coolin, south end of Priest Lake, Idaho, USA;
O. v. osceola (Bangs, 1896). Type locality “Citronelle, Citrus county, Florida, USA;
O. v. peruvianus (Gray, 1874). Type locality “Ceuchupate”, Perú;
O. v. rothschildi (Thomas, 1902). Type locality “Island of Coiba”, Veraguas, Panamá;
O. v. seminolus Goldman & Kellog, 1940. Type locality "ten miles northeast of Everglades, Collier county, Florida, USA;
O. v. sinaloae J.A. Allen, 1903. Type locality “Escuinapa”, southern Sinaloa, México;
O. v. taurinsulae Goldman & Kellogg, 1940. Type locality “Bull’s Island, Charleston County, South Carolina, USA;
O. v. texanus (Mearns, 1898). Type locality “Fort Clark”, Kinney County, Texas, USA;
O. v. thomasi Merriam, 1898. Type locality “Huehuetan”, Chiapas, México;
O. v. toltecus (Saussure, 1860). Type locality “Orizaba”, Veracruz, México;
O. v. tropicalis (Cabrera, 1918). Type locality “La María, en el Valle del Dagua”, Colombia;
O. v. nemoralis (Hamilton-Smith, 1827). Type locality restricted to “Central America, round the Gulf of Mexico to Surinam”, further restricted to “From Honduras to Panamá" (Lydekker, 1915);
O. v. ustus (Trouessart, 1910). Type locality ”El Pelado”, au nord de Quito (4,100 m), sur la frontiere de Colombie;
O. v. venatorius Goldman & Kellogg, 1940. Type locality "Hunting Island, Beufort County, south Carolina, USA;
O. v. veraecrucis Goldman & Kellogg, 1940. Type locality “Chijol, northern Veracruz, México”;
O. v. virginiana (Zimmermann, 1780). Type locality “Wisconsin”, USA;
O. v. yucatanensis (Hays, 1872). Type locality “throughout Yucatán and the southern part of México”.

This species is treated as being monotypic pending revision (Gardner 2005). Costa et al. (2003) detailed differences between G. agilis and G. microtarsus, two taxa that Gardner (1993) suggested could prove conspecific.

Populations from southern Brazil and Northeastern Argentina usually assigned to M. sorex, are now placed under synonymy with M. dimidiata (Vilela et al. 2010, Solari 2010). M. dimidiata is the type species of the genus name Peramys Lesson 1842, by subsequent designation and of Minuania Cabrera 1919, by original designation, same as M. sorex being the type species of Monodelphiops Matschie 1916. Because of synonymy of these two species names, all three genus names become synonyms too; with Peramys being the senior one (see Solari 2010). At this time, Peramys is a junior synonym (or subgenus) of Monodelphis.
All species of Micoureus are now considered as subgenus of Marmosa (Voss and Jansa 2009).
To date considered as the only species in the genus. However, the disjunct populations from northern South America (turneri) could represents a distinct species.

This form was split from Didelphis albiventris based on morphological data (Lemos and Cerqueira 2002, Ventura et al. 2002). Unpublished data suggests that this is not a distinct species (J. Patton pers. comm.).
This species needs taxonomic revision.
Previously considered as a subspecies of P. opossum.

In the original description was named Marmosa agilis chacoensis Tate, 1931. A new name combination and synonymy, Marmosa (Thylamys) agilis agilis, was proposed by Cabrera, 1958. Gardner and Creighton, 1989 gave a new name combination, Gracilinanus agilis. Voss et al. (2005) described a new genus, Cryptonanus, and transferred Gracilinanus agilis to this new genus, and renamed the taxon as C. chacoensis.

The specimens collected in Panama, Central America are now considered to be junior synonyms of M. robinsoni (F. Reid pers. comm.). Recently, a taxonomic revision of Colombian specimens (Díaz-N. et al. 2011) revealed that M. caucae, considered a subspecies or synonym of M. impavidus, is actually a valid taxon name for the Colombian and Venezuelan populations.

Seven subspecies are recognized (Lacher 2016): C. a. anolaimae J. A. Allen, 1916 – High elevations of the Cordillera Central in Colombia and the Mérida Andes and Cordillera Central in Venezuela. C. a. aperea Erxleben, 1777 – Eastern Brazil. C. a. guianae Thomas, 1901 – Surinam, Guyana, French Guiana, Venezuela and Amazonian Colombia. C. a. hypoleuca Cabrera, 1953 – Paraguay and northern Argentina. C. a. nana Thomas, 1917 – eastern slope of the Andes and Yungas forests of central Bolivia. C. a. pamparum Thomas, 1901 – southern Brazil Uruguay and eastern Argentina. C. a. rosida Thomas, 1917 – the Serra do Mar region of the state of Paraná, Brazil.

There are three recognized subspecies (Lacher 2016):

G. s. palustris Thomas, 1911 – northeasten Brazil, south of the Amazon River.

G. s. spixii Wagler, 1831 – eastern Brazil with the western limits undefined.

G. s. wellsi Osgood, 1915 – northeastern Brazil.
Also known as Hydrochaeris hydrochaeris and Hydrochoeris hydrochaeris.
This species is monotypic (Bidau 2015).

There may be more than one species within what is currently considered to be C. minutus (Anderson 1997). Freitas (1995) suggested that specimens described as C. minutus from Bolivia represent a different species. Bidau (2015) regards this species as monotypic.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (de Freitas in press)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14781,"3":{"1":0,"3":1},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica Neue","16":10}">This species is monotypic (de Freitas 2016).
Formerly Agouti paca.

Dasyprocta leporina (Linnaeus, 1758) “forest near the boarding-school Peninika, near the confluence of the Peninika Creek and the upper Commewijnw River” Commonwealth District, Suriname. There is considerable variation in color over the back and flanks of D. leporina, and multiple subspecies have been recognized in limited parts of the species range, including cayana and flavescens.  This classification requires a comprehensive study of geographic variation.  Previously named D. aguti.  Monotypic.

Dasyprocta azarae Lichtenstein, 1823 “E província San. Paulo [=São Paulo] Brasil.”  Cabrera listed three subspecies, including the nominotypical form (with caudata Lund and aurea Cope as synonyms), catrinae Thomas, and paraguayensis Thomas.  Anderson 1997 listed two subspecies,  boliviae  Thomas and yungarum Thomas, which we assign to azarae.  Iack-Ximenes 1999 regarded aurea Cope and  catrinae Thomas as valid species.  Due to lack of comprehensive review of character variation between these species, we assign them to azarae.  Monotypic.

Considerable variation in color and mensural characteristics exist over the range of this species, suggesting that M. pratti may be a complex of closely related taxa worthy of recognition at the species level.  Further character analyses within coherent geographic units are required to determine the validity of recognizing multiple species within M. pratti.
M. exilis is a synonym of M. acouchy.  The validity of M. a. acouchy versus M. a. exilis has yet to be tested by analyses of any type of character set.  Monotypic.

This species was listed as being a synonym for Clyomys laticeps. Bezerra (2002) revised the genus placing C. bishopi in the synonymy of C. laticeps. This decision was supported by morphometric and qualitative analyses of cranial variables (Bezerra and Oliveria 2010, Bezerra and Bonvicino 2015).
The validity of a potential subspecies is still in question, pending analysis of geographic variation (Emmons et al. 2015).

Woods and Kilpatrick (2005) note that guiara is synonymous with Euryzygomatomys spinosus. However, cytogenetic data indicates that there are at least two species and potentially more within this genus (V. Fagundes pers. comm.).

Thrichomys inermis (Pictet, 1843), “la Jacobine (dans les montagnes de las Almas, province de Bahia),” Jacobina, Bahia, Brazil. The Swiss zoologist F.-J. Pictet originally placed his new species in the genus Echimys; Trouessart allocated it to Thrichomys in 1880. This species is monotypic, but samples from Tocantins state in the Northern Caatinga bioregion, also with 2n = 26, FN = 48, belong to a separate molecular clade that Nascimento et al. refer to as T. aff. inermis and suggest is a distinct, undescribed species

Originally described in the genus Isothrix by Wagner (1845) and included in Isothrix by Tate (1935) and Ellerman (1940). Included in Thrichomys apereoides by Cabrera (1961) but recognized as a distinct species based on chromosomal differentiation (Bonvicino et al. 2002) and sequence divergence (Braggio and Bonvicino 2004).

Considered a large form of Makalata didelphoides by Emmons and Freer (1997) that might represent a distinct species, a hypothesis now supported by morphological and molecular evidence (Patton et al. 2000).

This taxon is likely to contain several distinct species, however, studies are required to revise the taxonomy and distribution (Patton pers. comm.). Emmons (1993) concluded that the holotype for Echimys didelphoides was a young Makalata armata and therefore E. didelphoides Desmarest, 1817 antedates Nelomys armatus I. Geoffroy (1838).

Known only from the original description. Tate (1935) placed it first in the genus Mesomys (p. 413) and then in the genus Echimys (p. 432). Cabrera (1960) followed Tate’s first allocation and retained it in Mesomys with reservation, a placement followed by subsequent authors (Corbet and Hill 1991, Woods 1993). Emmons (1993a) suggested that the original illustrations precluded identity with Mesomys and Emmons (in press) placed it in the genus Makalata.
This is a newly described species known from only three localities.
This could be a complex of two species (Patton et al. 2000).
Populations in lowland rainforest (P. r. oris) could be considered a subspecies separate from those in semideciduous forests like P. r. roberti (Patton and Leite 2015).
Includes P. hendeei Thomas, 1926; as that is considered to be just a form of this species.
A species complex which may contain several species (J. Patton pers. comm.).

P. cuvieri comprises a series of divergent clades that replace one another across Amazonia, additional sampling is needed to determine whether any of these correspond to separate species (Patton et al. 2000).

ICZN official name changed for this species ruling that guyannensis, rather than cayennensis, was the official name dating back to Geoffroy (1803) (J. Patton pers. comm.). This species is also likely to be split into several species based on ongoing molecular studies; P. warreni is actually part of this species (Voss et al. 2001).
This may not represent a valid species (J. Patton pers. comm.).
Currently monotypic, awaiting more information for the description of possible subspecies (Emmons et al. 2015).
Also known as Echimys braziliensis and Nelomys braziliensis, but see Emmons et al. (2002) for reasons to place this form in the genus Phyllomys and for the spelling of brasiliensis.
This species is also known as Echimys blainvillei and Nelomys blainvillei, but see Emmons et al. (2002) for reasons to place this form in the genus Phyllomys.
Referred to as Echimys (Nelomys) dasythrix in Eisenberg and Redford (1999).

This species has been referred as Echimys (Nelomys) lamarum in Eisenberg and Redford (1999). Also known as Nelomys lamarum, but see Emmons et al. (2002) for reasons to place this form in the genus Phyllomys.
This species also is known as Echimys nigrispinus and Nelomys nigrispinus, but see Emmons et al. (2002) for reasons to place this form in the genus Phyllomys.
This species may be a synonym of Phyllomys nigrispinus (Emmons et al. 2002), but Leite (2003) believes the species to be valid.
Specimens of this species were formerly attributed to Phyllomys brasiliensis (Emmons et al. 2002).
Formerly placed in Echimys.
Also known as Echimys thomasi and Nelomys thomasi, but see Emmons et al. (2002) for reasons to place this form in the genus Phyllomys.

Patton et al. (1985) reviews Isothrix genus. I. bistriata was considered to be a composite of several taxa and the names negrensis and orinoci were indicated as available for these populations by Patton et al. (2000).
Included in bistriata until recognized as distinct species based on sequence, chromosomal and morphological differentiation (Bovicino et al. 2003).
This species was described in 1992 (Pessôa et al. 1992). Formerly placed in the genus Proechimys, but see Lara and Patton (2000) for reasons to place this taxon in the genus Trinomys.

The genus Trinomys was formerly placed in the genus Proechimys, but see Lara and Patton (2000) for reasons to place this taxon in the genus Trinomys. This species was recently revised (PhD dissertation by Ximenes Gilson at Sao Paulo University) splitting T. albispinus into two species. The two subspecies are T. a. albispinus and T. a. minor (Emmons et al. 2015).
This species was formerly considered a subspecies of Trinomys [=Proechimys] iheringi], but see Lara and Patton (2000) for reasons to recognize this form as a distinct species.
Described in 2002 based on morphological and molecular characters (Lara et al. 2002). See Lara and Patton (2000) for reasons to recognize the genus Trinomys instead of Proechimys for this taxon.

This species formerly was considered a subspecies of Trinomys [=Proechimys] iheringi, but see Lara and Patton (2000) for reasons to recognize this form as a distinct species. There are two subspecies: T. g. gratiosus and T. g. bonafidei (Emmons et al. 2015).
Recognized as a subspecies of iheringi by Moojen (1948) and Pessôa and Reis (1996) but elevated to a species based on sequence analysis by Lara and Patton (2000) (Wilson and Reeder 2005)
This species was formerly placed in the genus Proechimys, but see Lara and Patton (2000) for reasons to place this taxon in the genus Trinomys.

This species was formerly placed in the genus Proechimys, but see Lara and Patton (2000) for reasons to place this taxon in the genus Trinomys. It includes T. myouros. There are two subspecies, T. s. setosus and T. s. elegans (Emmons et al. 2015).

This species formerly was placed in the genus Proechimys, but see Lara and Patton (2000) for reasons to place this taxon in the genus Trinomys. Several forms (e.g., gratiosus, paratus, and eliasi) formerly considered to be subspecies of T. iheringi are now considered distinct species (Lara and Patton 2000).
Now known under a new monotypic genus Toromys (Lack-Ximenes et al. 2005).
Although similar to and sympatric with hispidus the two can be differentiated by morphology, karyotype and cytochrome b sequences (Patton et al. 2000).
Subspecies include M. ferrugineus, M. spicatus, and M. hispidus hispidus (Patton and Emmons 2015).
An adequate systematic revision of the genus would be beneficial (Patton in litt. 2006).
Part of taxon Chaetomyinae (Voss et al. 2013).

The taxa pallidus (known only from two immature individuals) had previously been postulated to be from somewhere in the West Indies (Woods 1993), however, following Voss and Angermann (1997), pallidus is synonymized with S. insidiosus (Woods and Kilpatrick 2005). This species formally was treated into Coendou (Voss 2015).
This species was included in Coendou, often referred to as C. paraguayensis (Eisenberg and Redford 1999). S. villosus has been combined with this species (Voss 2015).
The species is in need of revision (see C. quichua).

This species has a considerable geographic variation and this may be a species complex (Marinho-Filho and Langguth pers. comm.). Coendou sanctamartae has been combined with Coendou prehensilis (Voss 2015), this assessment is of the new broader concept.
There are two recognized subspecies: S. g. gilvigularis and S. g. paraensis (Koprowski et al. 2016).
Five subspecies are recognized: S. i. ignitus, S. i. argentinus, S. i. bolivensis, S. i. cabrerai, and S. i. irroratus (Koprowski et al. 2016).
Population in Colombia needs taxonomic clarification.

The taxonomy of this species needs to be updated. Currently eight subspecies are recognized: M. f. faliventer, M. f. napi, M. f. otinus, M. f. peruanus, M. f. rubrirostris, M. f. sabanillae, M. f. similis, M. f. simonsi (Koprowski et al. 2016).
There are three recognized subspecies: S. p. pusillus, S. p. glaucinus and S. p. kuhlii. It is possible that these subspecies represent distinct species (Koprowski et al. 2016).

Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This rodent was recognized as a valid species by Musser et al. (1998); however, Weksler et al. (1999) still considers this as a junior synonym of Hylaeamys megacephalus. This species is monotypic (Percequillo 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This species is monotypic (Percequillo 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). Synonyms for this species include Oryzomys emmonsae (Musser, Carleton, Brothers and Gardner 1998). This is a monotypic species (Percequillo 2015).
This may be a species complex of lenguarum and probably includes some synonyms which are valid species.
The genus need taxonomic revision; this taxa could be two species.
This rodent was formally considered to be a synonym of D. dorsalis, it was recognized as a species in 1995.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
his species is monotypic (Paresque and Hanson 2015). Previously it has been considered synonymous with Oligoryzomys transitorious.
A new species of the genus, A. chebezi, was described for the Argentinean Province of Misiones (Pardiñas et al. 2009).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Voss 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">This is a monotypic species (Voss 2015).
Daptomys is a generic synonym. This is a monotypic species (Voss 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This species is monotypic (Percequillo 2015).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).

Deltamys has been considered a subgenus of Akodon (Ellerman 1940, Cabrera 1961) and alternatively as a genus (Gyldenstolpe 1932, Massoia 1980). Genus status was determined based on morphological (Bianchini and Delupi 1994, Gonzalez and Massoia 1995) and genetic (Smith and Patton 1999) characteristics. Previous Red List assessment conducted as Akodon kempi.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Thalpomys lasiotis type specimen belongs to the genus Bolomys, the correct name for this species should be T. reinhardti (Bonvicino and Marinho-Filho pers. comm.).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Bonvicino 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Bonvicino 2015).
Wiedomys pyrrhorhinos has been variously classified as a species of Oryzomys or Thomasomys (see Musser and Carleton 2005).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Was in the Red List under the genus Oryzomys.

Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Weksler and Bonvicino 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Weksler and Bonvicino 2015).

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Weksler and Bonvicino 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Weksler and Bonvicino 2015).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Oligoryzomys delticola and O. eliurus are likely synonyms of O. nigripes (see Weksler and Bonvicino 2005).
This species could be a complex of several species.
This taxon may represent a species complex.
The species is in need of revision, likely represents a species complex (M. Weksler pers. comm.).

The genus needs taxonomic revision - this species could be a subspecies. Although the the genus Oecomys occurs in Argentina, the presence of O. mamorae is not confirmed; the isolated populations found in Paraguay should be reviewed.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Monotypic species (Carleton and Musser 2015). No new changes."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":14720,"10":0,"11":4,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Calibri","16":12}">Monotypic species (Carleton and Musser 2015).

Allied to Oecomys bicolor or O. paricola; status and distributional extent require study (Musser and Carleton 2005). Langguth et al. (1996) consider it as a subspecies of O. bicolor. It is now recognized as a monotypic species (Carleton and Musser 2015).
The two subspecies of this species are debated and need futher research to be validated, R. cariri cariri and R. cariri baturiteensis (Costa et al. 2011).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Subgenus Akodon, formerly in Muridae family. Populations assigned to this species had been formerly identified as A. serrensis (e.g., Liascovich et al. 1989), but work by Christoff et al. (2000) clarified the karyotypic and morphometric separation of the two species. Christoff et al. (2000) left the assignment of A. paranaensis as species group indeterminate pending additional study of its relationship. Pardiñas et al. (2003) discuss the tenuous basis for segregating paranaensis and reigi; resolution is needed.
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).
This species is monotypic (Pardiñas et al. 2015).

This species could be synonymous with A. paranensis (A. Langguth pers. comm.). Subgenus Akodon, A. cursor species group sensu Rieger et al. (1995). Formerly Muridae family. Principally contrasted to A. cursor and A. serrensis; misattributed reports of this new species as A. serrensis clarified by González et al. (1998). Status and distributional limits with regard to A. mystax and especially A. paranaensis require careful review (see discussion by Pardiñas et al. 2003).
This species is monotypic (Vilela et al. 2015). No new changes.
This species is monotypic (Vilela et al. 2015). No new changes.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

<span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"This species is monotypic (Pardi\u00f1as and Teta 2015)."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":15037,"3":{"1":0},"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":{"1":2,"2":0}},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"12":0,"14":{"1":2,"2":0},"15":"Helvetica","16":10}">This species is monotypic (Pardiñas and Teta 2015).
Arachis hoehnei Krapov. & W.C.Greg. is a secondary wild relative of peanut (A. hypogaea L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).
There are two varieties of Cassia ferruginea: C. ferruginea var. ferruginea and C. ferruginea var. velloziana (Irwin and Barneby 1982).
There are two varieties of Elizabetha bicolor: E. bicolor var. bicolor and E. bicolor var. velutina (Cowan 1976, Lima and Martins-da-Silva 2015).

Burkart (1948) described a new variety of this species, Mimosa selloi var. leiocarpa, from material collected in Argentina and Paraguay. Later, the same author rectified that this variety was not M. selloi but that it could probably be a new species (Burkart 1979). This variety was finally placed as M. gracilis var. leiocarpa by Barneby (1991). In the meantime, there has been some confusion between these two species, especially because their distribution overlaps in Brazil.

Irwin and Barneby (1982) recognised four varieties for this species: Senna organensis var. heterandra, S. organensis var. friburgensis, S. organensis var. extratropica and S. organensis var. organensis, of which the latter two were defined as clear geographic varieties.

This species was initially described as Sclerolobium paniculatum Vogel and in 1957 Dwyer listed three varieties of this species for Brazil: S. paniculatum var. paniculatum, S. paniculatum var. subvelutinum Benth. and S. paniculatum var. rubiginosum (Mart. ex Tul.) Benth. In 2006 Oliveira-Filho transferred the latter two varieties into the genus Tachigali and raised them to species level. One year later Silva and Lima (2007) proposed the new name Tachigali vulgaris for S. paniculatum. This has created some confusion in the literature and when information is given as S. paniculatum it's often not clear if it's referring to T. vulgaris or to any of the other species.
Does not include the subspecies insularis.
M. spicata is known to hybridise with a number of other Mentha species.

Craig and Hastings (2007) suggested changing the genus to Cephalopholis, but it remains under Paranthias for the purposes of this Red List assessment. Hybrid specimens of C. fulva and C. furcifer have been observed in the Brazilian oceanic islands of Trindade (Pinheiro et al. 2009), Atol das Rocas (Batista et al. 2012) and Fernando de Noronha (B. P. Ferreira and A.A. Bertoncini pers. comm. 2016) and in the North Atlantic from Cuba and Bermuda (Smith 1966, Bostrom et al. 2002). These were initially described by Poey in 1860 and 1875 as Menephorus dubius and M. punctiferus (Smith 1966, Bostrom et al. 2002).

Canthonella was described by Chapin in 1930. Halffter and Martínez (1977) synonymized Ipselissus under Canthonella. There are currently very few species described from South America, but there are likely to be many more to be described.
The species is accepted by  Govaerts and Simpson  (2007), however, Menapace (1993) questioned the delineation considering it to be based on immature specimens.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Canthon is a diverse and heterogeneous genus of dung beetles. Currently, the genus is composed of nine subgenera: Boreocanthon, Canthon s.str., Francmonrosia, Glaphyrocanthon, Goniocanthon, Nesocanthon, Peltecanthon, Pseudepilissus, and Trichocanthon. Of these, only Boreocanthon and Nesocanthon do not occur in South America.

Scatonomus is a small genus, containing only eight described species, of which little taxonomic and biological information is available. The genus is known from Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay and Paraguay, and its species are distributed throughout “Cerrado”, “Pampa” and Atlantic forest.
This species comprises the former Ranitomeya biolat and R. lamasi (Brown et al. 2011).

This circumglobal species is restricted to subtropical waters, and consisting of a series of disjunct subpopulations, many of which until recently were considered to represent distinct species. Until recently, most of the literature in the eastern Pacific referred to this species are Seriola dorsalis.
This species could be the natural hybrid of P. vittatum × P. sargentianum.

This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). It is unclear that all biological populations within its large range are conspecific. However, these are included in the current assessment until their taxonomic identities can be clarified.

Genetic diversity of T. inunguis has been found to be higher than any one of the three major clusters of T. manatus (Garcia-Rodriguez et al. 1998, Vianna et al. 2002, Caballero and Giraldo 2004), possibly functioning as a panmictic population (Cantanhede et al. 2005).

In a major review of the Genus Sus, Groves (1981) recognized 16, possibly 17, subspecies, whilst also either synonymizing or discounting many previously accepted subspecies. The latter including various insular southeast Asian feral and/or hybrid populations. This treatment was followed by Groves and Grubb (1993); though Groves (2001) has since suggested the likely future separation of one subspecies, i.e. the Banded Pig S. s. vittatus, as a full species (Groves 2001).

Merostachys rondoniensis is an accepted name, but it has been suggested that the taxonomy needs further clarification, particularly to confirm the differences between M. rondoniensis and  M. magnispicula (Sendulsky 1997).
Habenaria pleiophylla is closely related to H. leptoceras and has been frequently confused with it (Romanini 2006, Batista et al. 2011).

The species has taxonomic issues and so far there are no conclusive studies. It is considered as a complex of species, being considered a species for some authors or instead a variety (Cyperus virens var. drumondii) by other experts (L. Pereira da Silva pers. comm. 2020).

The taxon is closely related to Othophytum fosterianum. Orthophytum sucrei may be separated from the later by its smaller size, nearly glabrous adaxial leaf surfaces, simple inflorescence, red floral bracts (not green) and pale green petals (not white). Taxonomic uncertainties remain regarding the validity of O. sucrei as an independent species from O. fosterianum (Luther 1997).
The genus Itaya  has only this species.

This species is only known from the type localities for the two varieties originally described. It has not been collected since these original collections in 1951 and 1952, although it does occur in a well studied region. It is probable that collections have been made but were given different determinations. It is very similar to Aechmea recurvata, which has a wide distribution (M. d'Ávila de Moraes pers. comm. July 2013).

The genus Notylia is in need of revision. No work on its nomenclature has yet been published. The name Notylia inversa is currently accepted but with some associated uncertainty. The taxon may posssibly be a synonym of N. pubescens Lindl. (Nicoletti pers. comm. 2010).
Specimens reported to belong to this species by Molina et al. (2003) instead represent Anolis fuscoauratus (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2015).

Sturaro et al. (2018) revised the Cercosaura ocellata species complex, redescribing C. ocellata itself, elevating the former subspecies C. o. bassleri to specific level, removing C. olivacea from synonymy and describing the new species C. anordosquama.

It has been suggested that differences in colouration between northern coastal and southern populations in French Guiana indicate long isolation and possibly represent different species (IUCN France 2016). These populations were not included in the analysis by Sturaro et al. (2018).

This species was reassigned from Neusticurus to the new genus Potamites by Doan and Castoe (2005), in work following a wider molecular analysis of relationships within Gymnophthalmidae. While this arrangement has subsequently been widely followed, and has been adopted here, Rodrigues et al. (2007) argue that the taxonomic changes proposed by Castoe et al. (2004) - and by implication those of Doan and Castoe (2005) - are premature based on limited taxon sampling and morphological similarities between taxa recovered as distinct by Castoe et al. (2004).

This species, which has the largest distribution of any Potamites species, has a somewhat complex taxonomic history, summarized by Chávez and Vásquez (2012), as a result of uncertainty regarding the validity and distribution of Potamites ocellatus. This latter taxon is presently considered valid and known with certainty only from Bolivia following Vanzolini (1995), who assigned Peruvian records of P. ocellatus to the P. ecpleopus species complex sensu lato, but the relationship between these two taxa and their relative distributions remain unclear. Further research on the systematics of P. ecpleopus may also reveal cryptic species within this complex.

Pinto et al. (2019) evaluated the taxonomic status of the Gonatodes humeralis using molecular data. While these authors found that, contrary to these authors' expectations and evidence from similar studies on other Amazonian lizards, this widespread species is monotypic in mainland South America, they found that the populations from Trinidad and Tobago are specifically distinct. Pinto et al. (2019) resurrect the name G. ferrugineus for the Trinidadian species, although these authors note that the two taxa cannot presently be distinguished morphologically. 
Following the recognition by Rösler et al. (2019) that the holotype of Cnemaspis timoriensis represents the first known specimen of Gonatodes humeralis, these authors report that an application to the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature is in preparation to preserve the name humeralis for this taxon in order to preserve nomenclatural stability.

This species is difficult to distinguish from Kentropyx altamazonica, and taxonomists have long struggled to separate the two reliably (Harvey et al. 2012). These authors reported that K. calcarata may be more variable in characters assumed to be diagnostic than previously supposed, but as this work was not a species-level taxonomic treatment further research is needed to clarify species boundaries within the altamazonica-calcarata complex.
This is a species complex (J.C. Murphy pers. comm. 1997).

The systematics of Tupinambis teguixin remain poorly studied, with Fitzgerald et al. (1999) describing the taxonomy as “tortuous.”  Investigating the genetics of this taxon, these authors found that “…the split among T. teguixin from Cuyabeno, Ecuador and Roraima, Brazil was comparable to differences between T. teguixin and T. longilineus and even to that between T. rufescens and T. merianae.” This issue remains in need of resolution; Harvey et al. (2012) have supported the view that T. teguixin is indeed a complex of multiple taxa.

There are two common names applied to Tupinambis teguixin in the pet trade and popular literature, the golden tegu and the black and white tegu (Balsai 1998); suggesting differences in coloration. The name "black and white" tegu is also commonly applied to Salvator merianae. These two species have been long confused in the scientific and popular literature. Beebe (1945) was well aware of the variation in coloration and pattern in neonates and adults. He wrote, “The tegu is a large, heavily-built lizard, with considerable pattern and color variation. In general it is black above, spotted and blotched on the head and body and broadly banded on the tail with bright yellow. The young are banded from nape to tail tip.” In the same paper he later wrote, “Another pattern of unusual prominence was four longitudinal series of white dashes down the back from the nape to three-fourth’s the length of the tail.”

Plica plica is a widespread, common species known to be morphologically variable across its range (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2015, Murphy and Jowers 2013). De Oliveira et al. (2016), sampling the species across its range, identified five genetic lineages with a major division between the Guiana Shield and Amazonia, although their sample sizes were small and they proposed no taxonomic action.

Murphy and Jowers (2013) reviewed the taxonomy of northern subpopulations using both morphological and molecular evidence and coined new names for four populations: P. caribbeana, P. kathleenae, P. medemi and P. rayi.

The primary goal of these latter authors' work was "not to revise the entire species group" but to identify avenues for further research. These new taxa were consequently supported by data from a small number of specimens, and two of the proposed species are based only on their holotypes, Given the likely complexity of taxonomic issues within the variable P. plica, M. Hoogmoed (pers. comm. 2015) argues that Murphy and Jowers (2013) were premature in assigning novel names to these taxa, which were erected without reference to existing meristic data (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2019), and research is underway in Brazil to investigate the systematics of this genus. In an earlier examination of the specimen Murphy and Jowers (2013) designated the holotype of P. kathleenae, Hoogmoed (1973) could find no morphological differences between this specimen and material of typical P. plica from Guyana and Suriname, and ongoing taxonomic work suggests that this is not a good species (S. Gomides pers. comm. 2018).

In order to preserve nomenclatural stability, this account treats P. caribbeana, P. kathleenae, P. rayi and P. medemi as junior synonyms of P. plica pending a more comprehensive review of the putative P. plica complex.

Plica umbra is a species complex whose taxonomy is presently unresolved (T. Hrbeck pers. comm. 2016). A revision of the genus is presently underway that is likely to change our understanding of species boundaries in both P. plica and P. umbra (S. Gomides pers. comm. 2018).

In a wide-ranging revision of Chironius Hollis (2006) elevated Chironius cochranae, then a subspecies of C. multiventris, to specific status. Klazcko et al. (2010) subsequently synonymized C. cochranae within C. multiventris, as they were unable to find any characters that could differentiate the two taxa.

Three species of Atractus described by da Silva (2004), A. davidhardi, A. janethae and A. lucilae, are treated as junior synonyms of A. torquatus following Passos and Prudente (2012), who found that the characters used to diagnose them were variable throughout Amazonian populations and could not be used to recognize discrete species. These authors consider it unlikely that more than one lineage of "A. torquatus" exists within the Amazon Basin, however, further research is required to clarify whether this Amazonian population is genuinely conspecific with Guiana Shield A. torquatus (Passos and Prudente 2012).
Records of this species from Brazilian Amazonia (Cunha and Nascimento 1984) were described as a distinct species, Atractus hoogmoedi, by Prudente and Passos (2010).
It is a species complex (See Dixon 1983).

Records from Trinidad and Venezuela are now recognized as a distinct species, Erythrolamprus zweifeli (Rivas et al. 2012). Records from Tobago were described as the new species E. pseudoreginae by Murphy et al. (2019). Coluber violaceus, a taxon known only from a lost holotype, has long been treated as a junior synonym of E. reginae.
Passos and Fernandes (2005) elevated this taxon to species level, from a subspecies of Micrurus surinamensis.

Micrurus obscurus is now considered a full species by many authors (most recently Savage and McDiarmid 2017), and this scheme is followed here, however, it is considered a subspecies of M. spixii by Campbell and Lamar (2004).

Micrurus psyches is a complex, and the original description was poorly done and vague.  There are several as-yet unidentified black-and-white coral snakes in Colombia (specifically the Cordillera Oriental and La Macarena), and records of M. psyches from this country are likely to represent confusion with one or more of these.

Micrurus obscurus is now considered a full species by many authors (most recently Savage and McDiarmid 2017), and this scheme is followed here, however, it is considered a subspecies of M. spixii by Campbell and Lamar (2004).
Micrurus nattereri, previously a subspecies of M. surinamensis, was elevated to specific status by Passos and Fernandes (2005).

This species has a complex taxonomic history, and was formerly considered to include the now generally-recognized species Bothrops leucurus, B. moojeni, B. marajoensis, and B. isabelae. The taxonomic status of a further form described from Venezuela, Bothrocophias colombiensis (the Colombian type locality being in error), was discussed by Johnson and Dixon (1984) and these authors concluded that it could not be reliably diagnosed as a taxon distinct from Bothrops atrox. The species has subsequently been treated as a junior synonym of B. atrox. Recent molecular analyses have, however, recovered a cryptic clade unrelated to B. atrox within this species complex, to which the authors have applied the name B. colombiensis (Pyron et al. 2011). There is, however, no clarity on either the diagnosis or geographical distribution of "true" B. colombiensis, and as such it is not clear whether the name B. colombiensis has been correctly applied to these sequences (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014). Pending further research to clarify this situation, which "will not be solved now" (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2014), and because no formal taxonomic action has been taken to resurrect B. colombiensis, this account follows Johnson and Dixon (1984) and most subsequent authorities in treating B. colombiensis as a junior synonym of B. atrox.
Schargel et al. (2013) referred Atractus arangoi to the synonymy of A. major.

Historical records from Colombia (Perez-Santos and Moreno 1988) and Ecuador (Valencia 2007) of this Atlantic Forest endemic represent confusion with other species. The only voucher specimen in a Colombian collection belongs to the similar Taeniophallus brevirostris, while the description of Ecuadorian specimens does not match that of Echinanthera undulata (Passos et al. unpublished).

The recent description of Oxyrhopus vanidicus, which very closely resembles O. melanogenys, makes the specific identity of previously reported records of O. melanogenys in Peru, Brazil, Ecuador, and Colombia uncertain (Lynch 2009). Examining specimens from Venezuela, Rivas et al. (2012) could find no consistent differences between O. vanidicus and O. melanogenys, raising doubts about the specific validity of O. vanidicus.
This species used to be recognized with two subspecies but now Micrurus langsdorffi ornatissimus (Jan, 1858) is considered a separate species.
Zaher et al. (2009), in a molecular review of caenophidian snakes, found that Xenoxybelis was nested within Philodryas. These authors therefore synonymized Xenoxybelis with Philodryas.

The distributional pattern (occurring in Amazonia and the Colombian Andes) suggests this taxon may be a species complex (R. Caicedo pers. comm. 2013). It is widely confused with Cercosaura oshaughnessyi, with which it apparently co-occurs across much of its range. Some authors have elected to follow Uzzell (1973) in treating C. oshaughnessyi as a junior synonym of C. argulus pending resolution of the taxonomic relationship between these taxa, and Torres-Carvajal et al. (2015) found that the two taxa were only weakly differentiated both morphologically and genetically.
