While these authors did find that the two taxa exhibited reciprocal monophyly and recognized C. oshaughnessyi as distinct as a result, their sample included only two specimens of C. argulus and this account retains C. oshaughnessyi in synonymy with C. argulus pending confirmation of its status as a distinct species and clarification of its distributional limits.

The taxonomic rearrangement of Campbell and Lamar (2004) (based on morphology) was corroborated by the molecular data of Wuster et al. (2005), confining Crotalus durissus (previously understood to range throughout the Neotropics) to South America (M. Martins, pers. comm. 2010). Rivas et al. (2012) propose recognizing the current subspecies Crotalus d. vegrandis from the lowlands of Maturín and Anzoátegui (northeastern Venezuela) as a full species based only on size and colour pattern. This scheme is adopted by the Reptile Database as of November 2018 (Uetz 2018), however, other works do not (Campbell and Lamar 2004, Wuster et al. 2005) and the recognition of this species would warrant more evidence than a smaller size and a peculiar colour pattern.

This taxon actually may be a species complex; a range-wide taxonomic reevaluation is needed (Caicedo-Portilla 2011). It was formerly within the genus Typhlops but is now treated under Amerotyphlops (Hedges et al. 2014).

Tropidurus catalanensis was recently revalidated as a full species (Kunz and Borges-Martins 2013), having been relegated to subspecific status by Cei (1993). This action has since been accepted by Carreira and Maneyro (2015). Kunz and Borges-Martins (2013) identified additional groups within the T. torquatus species complex, including a restricted-range taxon from Brazil that they described as T. imbituba. Remaining northern populations of T. torquatus appear to belong to at least three taxa, however, Kunz and Borges-Martins (2013) considered the available sampling insufficient to describe these as separate taxa.

Murphy et al. (2019) described specimens from Tobago previously included within B. flavescens as a new species, B. whitei. 

Bachia flavescens has long been recognized to be a species complex (Kizirian and McDiarmid 1998) encompassing "a substantial number of taxa" (Murphy et al.  2019) but has received little taxonomic attention. The holotype has been lost, there is no associated type locality, and the available illustration of the holotype is considered "all but useless for identification" (Murphy et al. 2019). These authors recommend that the name Bachia flavescens be considered a nomen nudum, arguing that the continued use of this name of unclear provenance to apply to a composite species is unhelpful in understanding the systematics of the remaining, undescribed members of this group. 

As the systematics of this group are poorly-understood and consequently no replacement names have been proposed for any of the populations  Murphy et al. (2019) refer to as Bachia cf. flavescens this account continues to use the name B. flavescens for this species complex.

Three subspecies are recognized: Bachia trisanale trisanale (Cope, 1868), B. t. abendrothi (Peters, 1871) , and B. t. vermiformis (Cope, 1874).

Avila-Pires (1995) suggests that B. trisanale and B. peruana may not be distinct species, however, the author states that not enough specimens were available for examination to clarify this.
Some authors believe that this species is not clearly distinguishable from Thecadactylus rapicauda (R. Caicedo pers. comm. 2013)

The taxonomy of Lepus europaeus is still under debate. Clear distinction to other taxa is difficult due to sympatric occurrences with other Lepus species. The European Hare was formerly included in the Cape Hare (L. capensis) based on a cline in morphological characters (mainly size) from north-eastern Africa eastwards across the northern Arabian peninsula, the Middle East and northwards through Israel to Turkey (Petter 1961). A reanalysis showed a discontinuity between smaller “capensis” and larger “europaeus” running from the eastern Mediterranean coast through Iran (Ben Slimen et al. 2008). A study of the nuclear gene pool of the Cape Hare, the European Hare and the North African Hare, indicated that the North African Hare as well as the European Hare belong to the Cape Hare (Ben Slimen et al. 2005). However, a study of the mt DNA of these three groups indicated a significant degree of divergence supporting species specific designation (Ben Slimen et al. 2008a, 2008b). These studies show that genetic differentiation between the Cape Hare and the European Hare might be attributed to geographic distance rather than divergence. Until conclusive evidence of a single species complex is available in order to support a change in the taxonomic status of the European Hare, it remains a true species (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018, Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016).

There are 16 subspecies: Lepus europaeus caspicus, L. e. connori, L. e. creticus, L. e. cyprius, L. e. cyrensis, L. e. europaeus, L. e. hybridus, L. e. judeae, L. e. karpathorum, L. e. medius, L. e. occidentalis, L. e. parnassius, L. e. ponticus, L. e. rhodius, L. e. syriacus, and L. e. transsylvanicus (Hoffmann and Smith 2005). It is felt that there is considerable variability in many of these forms and that distinctions between subspecies may be arbitrary as they are mostly based on size and colour. Molecular phylogenetic studies in Spain revealed that the Cantabric population has singular mt DNA compared to other European populations (Palacios et al. 2004). A review of the taxonomy of this species is necessary (Hackländer and Schai-Braun 2018, Schai-Braun and Hackländer 2016).

The type locality for Sylvilagus brasiliensis designated by Linnaeus is “South America.” As such, nearly all taxa of Sylvilagus described in South America devolved to be synonymized in S. brasiliensis. Work has begun to investigate the true diversity of Sylvilagus in Central and South America – leading to several species already removed from synonymy: S. andinus, S. gabbi, S. tapetillus, S. sanctaemartae; taxonomic investigations continue. Meanwhile, only recently was a neotype designated (Linnaeus did not designate holotypes) allowing investigation into the species limits and true range occupied by S. brasiliensis and other South American Sylvilagus species (Ruedas et al. 2017, Ruedas and Smith 2018). It is the newly circumscribed geographic range of S. brasiliensis that is considered herein.
Mustela stolzanni is considered a subspecies of M. africana, while M. paraensis is a synonym of M. a. africana (Wozencraft 2005).

While many authors have traditionally considered skunks a subfamily (Mephitinae) within Mustelidae, recent molecular evidence indicates that skunks do not lie within the mustelid group and should be recognised as a single family, Mephitidae (Dragoo and Honeycutt 1997).

A recent revision including morphological, molecular and pelage coloration analyses proposed that Conepatus chinga and C. humboldtii are conspecific, and as C. chinga has page priority, this should be the valid name for the species (Schiaffini et al. 2013). The same authors (p. 341) wrote that "samples from Chile, DNA samples from this country and from north-west Argentina, and other genes will help to test this hypothesis and the conclusions presented in this paper" and pending such corroboration, the Red List maintains the treatment as two species.

While many authors have traditionally considered skunks a subfamily (Mephitinae) within Mustelidae, recent molecular evidence indicates that skunks do not lie within the mustelid group and should be recognised as a single family, Mephitidae (Wozencraft 2005).
The genus Bassaricyon was recently revised, and the content of this name changed somewhat from previous usage (Helgen et al. 2013).

In 2011 the genus of all Fur Seals other than Arctocephalus pusillus was changed from Arctocephalus to Arctophoca (Committee on Taxonomy 2011) based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2014).

In the past, two subspecies were recognized: Arctocephalus australis australis (Zimmerman, 1783) for the Falkland subpopulation and A. a. gracilis (Nehring, 1887) for the mainland subpopulation. Animals from the Falklands have been reported to be larger than animals from coastal South America (Rice 1998). However, the validity of these subspecies was disputed (Reijnders et al. 1993). In their review of pinniped taxonomy, Berta and Churchill (2012) concluded that the Fur Seals in Peru and northern Chile probably represent an unnamed subspecies. After examining all the morphological, genetic and distributional evidence, Oliveira and Brownell (2014) concluded that A. a. gracilis should be treated as a junior synonym of A. a. australis, and they supported the recognition of a Peru/northern Chile subspecies. This assessment combines the IUCN Red List assessments for the South American and Peruvian Fur Seal subspecies to assess the status of the South American Fur Seal as a species.

This species was referred to formerly as Arctocephalus elegans, A. gazella and A. tropicalis tropicalis. It is now named as A. tropicalis (Repenning et al. 1971; Rice 1998). In 2011 the Taxonomy Committee of the Society for Marine Mammalogy revised the genus of this, and many other species of fur seals to Arctophoca based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, and based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2013).
Rice (1998) states that the correct spelling of the specific name is carcinophaga, not the previously more widely used carcinophagus.
None
Although several geographic populations have been named as species, morphological and genetic data show there is one world-wide panmictic species (Gibbs and Collette 1967, Scoles and Graves 1993).
Some authors have included Skipjack Tuna in the genus Euthynnus, but recent authors agree with its placement in the monotypic genus Katsuwonus (Collette and Graves 2019).
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species from Epinephelus to Hyporthodus. The family name was changed to Epinephelidae by Smith and Craig (2007).
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name from Epinephelus to Hyporthodus and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.
This species is often confused with juvenile Thunnus obesus, which also has very long pectorals, but with rounded tips.
The genus Thunnus is divisible into two subgenera, Thunnus and Neothunnus, but the Bigeye Tuna does not neatly fit in either subgenus (Collette and Graves 2019).
This is now considered to be a separate species from the Pacific bluefin, Thunnus orientalis (Collette 1999).
Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus, and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.

The Eastern Pacific population may be a distinct species, and further future taxonomic work is planned (M. Craig pers. comm. 2018). Craig and Hastings (2007) changed the generic name of this species to Hyporthodus and Smith and Craig (2007) changed the family name to Epinephelidae.
This species can be misidentified in Brazil as Mycteroperca rubra.

This species was originally described as Syngnathus dendriticum by Thomas Barbour in 1905. The genus Amphelikturus was subsequently described by Parr (1930), with this species subsumed within it. Dawson (1984) later subsumed Amphelikturus and Idiotropiscis as subgenera of Acentronura based on morphology.
This species was recently resurrected from synonymy under S. foetens (Frable et al. 2013).

Hedges and Conn (2012) discussed the taxonomic history of this widespread species complex, and, on the basis of their results and those of Miralles and Carranza (2010), erected three new species to encompass Caribbean populations. One of these, Copeoglossum aurae, was also found to occur on Peninsula de Paria in Venezuela; unpublished data suggests this species ranges more widely in northeastern Venezuela (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2018). These authors note that taxonomic issues remain within the mainland South American skinks presently included within C. nigropunctatum, but recommended continued use of this name pending a full revision.

Three genetically distinct populations of this species occur in the states of Bahia, Espírito Santo and Rio de Janeiro (Moraes-Barros et al. 2002, 2006; Lara-Ruiz et al. 2008). The northern population (in southern Bahia) might be considered a separate subspecies (Lara-Ruiz et al. 2008), although indistinguishable from the others in external morphology (A. Chiarello pers. comm. 2010).

According to Gardner (2007) seven subspecies are recognized: B. v. boliviensis (Gray, 1871); B.v. brasiliensis Blainville, 1840; B.v. ephippiger R.A. Philippi, 1870; B.v. gorgon O. Thomas, 1926; B.v. infuscatus Wagler, 1831; B.v. trivittatus Cornalia, 1849; and B.v. variegates Schinz, 1825.

Due to the overlapping range of different Cabassous species and the description of C. chacoensis only 30 years ago (Wetzel 1980), it is possible that many specimens (especially historical records) of this genus are erroneously classified. The exact distribution and its conservation status therefore need to be revised once the taxonomic status of these species is clear and all specimens can be correctly classified.

It is possible that this taxon may comprise more than one species, with the northern and southern populations representing separate species (E. Cuéllar pers. comm. 2004). Two subspecies have been recognized (Wetzel 1980).
Five subspecies are recognized by Gardner and Naples (2007).
There are seven subspecies of Cyclopes didactylus (Gardner 2007).
Two subspecies are described (Wilson and Reeder 2005).
Six subspecies are recognized by Gardner (2007).
Five subspecies are recognized (Gardner 2007).
Three subspecies are recognized by Gardner (2007).
There are four subspecies of T. tetradactyla (Gardner 2007).
This species is also reported as Lophotus lacepedei (Quignard and Tomasini 2000).

This species is commonly confused with Laemonema barbatulum, particularly when small. This introduces uncertainty in assessing the distribution and habitat utilization of L. goodebeanorum (S. Ross pers. comm. 2018).
Further taxonomic work is needed on western Atlantic members of this family.
This species has been identified as part of the Proceratophrys cristiceps group (Martins and Giaretta 2011).
This species has been assigned to the Scinax catherinae clade (Cruz et al. 2011).
This species has been assigned to the Scinax catharinae group (Cruz et al. 2011).

authority: de Andrade Costa, Geise, Pereira & Costa 2011
taxonomicNotes: This species is monotypic (Tribe 2015).

authority: de Andrade Costa, Geise, Pereira & Costa, 2011
taxonomicNotes: This species is monotypic (Tribe 2015).
Lin and Hastings (2013) reallocated Labrisomus kalisherae to the genus Gobioclinus.

Scartella cristata is generally recognized to be a species complex. Currently it is under taxonomic review. The eastern Atlantic and Brazillian populations may represent separate species (Williams pers. comm. 2009).

Labrisomus nuchipinnis is likely a species complex and there is only one species in the Gulf of Mexico (J. Williams pers. comm. 2014). The holotype of L. nuchipinnis is from Brazil, so the name will change.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.
Macrodon atricauda was revalidated by Carvalho-Filho et al. (2010). Macrodon ancylodon (Bloch & Schneider 1801) was used prior to 2010.
Lozano et al. 2017 has stated that Acanthagrion peruvianum is a subjective synonym of A. floridense. The assessment of A. floridense includes previous records of A. peruvianum

The species Acanthagrion cuyabae was considered a junior synonym of A. lancea until 2010 (Souza et al. 2010). A. cuyabae is distributed in northern Amazon region, for this reason, several records from literature recording A. lancea in the northern Amazon were not included, since they probably are A. cuyabae.
"Micrathyria romani seems to be a distinct species, different from M. coropinae, to which it is related in possessing one row of cells in the discoidal space in the fore wings." Geijskes, 1963.
P. cerasina is considered a synonym of P. tenuissima (Garrison, 2004).

In 2011, von Ellenrieder stated that "Based on observed morphological variability of the diagnostic characters traditionally used to identify species of Microstigma, the three specific names currently used might represent only intraspecific variability", thus Microstigma species may all be M. anomalum synonym.
The taxonomic status of this species is unclear.
Only the most relevant synonyms are listed. For a complete list of synonyms please see WCSP (2018).This species often hybridizes with Psidium guineense and is often confused with it (Landrum 2017).
Populations north and south of the Amazon River probably represent different species (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2014).
Further taxonomic studies are recommended to clarify the separation of this species from T. torquatus (P. Cacciali and N. Scott pers. comm. 2014).
A record of this species from Trinidad (Murphy 1997) is believed to represent an undescribed species (CaribHerp), and is not considered in this assessment.

Cabrera (2012) described "the southernmost population" of the Cnemidophorus ocellifer complex (now Ameivula ocellifera following Harvey et al. 2012) as the Chaco endemic Cnemidophorus abalosi. The distribution provided by these authors covers most of Paraguay and northern Argentina, and by implication may therefore restrict A. ocellifera to Brazil and Bolivia. Cabrera (2012) did not discuss the distribution of the revised A. ocellifera, however, and so sympatry between the two taxa in at least part of this range cannot be ruled out. Avila et al. (2013) do not list this species for Argentina. It is likely that further species will be described from within the A. ocellifera species group (Cabrera 2012).

Cabrera et al. (2019) investigated the systematics of Contomastix lacertoides using both morphological and molecular evidence, and concluded that Argentinian populations represent a distinct species, which they named C. celata.

Contomastix charrua was described from a population then referred to Cnemidophorus (now Contomastix) lacertoides on the basis of differences in coloration, structure of the hyoid apparatus and geological history of the cape (Cabrera and Carreira 2009). Borteiro et al. (2013) found no morphological differences between the two taxa and referred C. charrua to the synonymy of C. lacertoides. S. Carreira (pers. comm. 2016) indicates that ongoing research has identified additional differences that may warrant recognizing C. charrua as a separate species, and recommends retaining C. charrua as a valid species pending comparison with material from the C. lacertoides type locality, which was not done by Borteiro et al. (2013). C. charrua was recognized as a distinct species by Cabrera et al. (2019), but these authors do not discuss this assignment.

Until the 1990s, only one species of Minke Whale was recognized, the Antarctic Minke Whale, Balaenoptera bonaerensis, being regarded as conspecific with the Common Minke Whale, B. acutorostrata. Most of the scientific literature prior to the late 1990s uses the name B. acutorostrata for all Minke Whales including Antarctic Minke Whales. Since 2000, the International Whaling Commission (IWC) Scientific Committee has recognized Antarctic Minke Whales as the separate species B. bonaerensis, and provisionally assigns all Northern Hemisphere Minke Whales and all Southern Hemisphere "Dwarf" Minke Whales to B. acutorostrata (IWC 2001). This practice has been followed by management and treaty bodies, such as the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES).

The Dwarf Minke Whale is the common name used for B. acutorostrata in the Southern Hemisphere. It was initially described by Best (1985) and Arnold et al. (1987) in terms of its differences from the Antarctic Minke Whale. Subsequent genetic analyses (Wada et al. 1991, Pastene et al. 1994) revealed that the Dwarf Minke Whale is conspecific with the "ordinary" Minke Whale of the Northern Hemisphere, which was given the name Common Minke Whale, while the Antarctic Minke Whale is the separate species B. bonaerensis (see separate Red List assessment).

Following Rice (1998) the Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy provisionally recognizes three subspecies: B. a. acutorostrata (Lacépède, 1804) in the North Atlantic, B. a. scammoni (Deméré, 1986) (= B. a . davidsoni) in the North Pacific, and the Dwarf Minke Whale as an unnamed subspecies in the Southern Hemisphere (Committee on Taxonomy 2017). However, the limited sampling of Dwarf Minke Whales to date does not support the grouping together of all Southern Hemisphere Dwarf Minke Whales. For example, Pastene et al. (2010) found Dwarf Minke Whales from Brazil and Chile to be more closely related to Common Minke Whales in the North Atlantic than to Dwarf Minke Whales in the South Pacific.

Rice’s Whale (Balaenoptera ricei) is a distinct evolutionary lineage closely related to Eden’s Whale (Balaenoptera edeni edeni), Bryde’s Whale (B. e. brydei) and Sei Whale (Balaenoptera borealis) (Rosel et al. 2021). Previously considered an undescribed subspecies of Balaenoptera edeni and referred to as the Gulf of Mexico Whale or the Gulf of Mexico Bryde’s Whale, a recent morphological study of Rice’s Whale has revealed diagnostic differences in the shape and size of bones in the skull in comparison to the two subspecies of B. edeni. This morphological evidence reinforced earlier findings of significant genetic divergence and fixed DNA differences found in several mitochondrial DNA genes; together these data supported the description of the new species B. ricei . With elevation of Rice’s Whale to species status, there is still uncertainty as to whether Eden’s Whale and Bryde’s Whale, each of which is clearly distinct, represent subspecies of B. edeni or full species.

The Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy provisionally recognizes three subspecies: the Northern Fin Whale, Balaenoptera physalus physalus, (Linnaeus, 1758); the Southern Fin Whale, B. p. quoyi (Fischer, 1829), which is larger than B. p. physalus, and the Pygmy Fin Whale, B. p. patachonica (Burmeister, 1865), proposed by Clark (2004), which is smaller than B. p. quoyi and has dark baleen (Committee on Taxonomy 2018). However, Archer et al. (2013) proposed on genetic grounds that Fin Whales in the North Atlantic and North Pacific should be considered separate subspecies. There are few records of B. p. patachonica and the type specimen is currently (May 2018) awaiting genetic analysis. In older accounts, the common name Fin Whale, and its equivalent in other languages, tended to be used for any whales of the genus Balaenoptera.

Until the 1990s, only one species of Minke Whale was recognized, the Antarctic Minke Whale Balaenoptera bonaerensis being regarded as conspecific with the Common Minke Whale (B. acutorostrata). Most of the scientific literature prior to the late 1990s uses the name B. acutorostrata for all Minke Whales including Antarctic Minke Whales. Since 2000, the International Whaling Commission (IWC) Scientific Committee has recognized Antarctic Minke Whales as the separate species B. bonaerensis, while all Northern Hemisphere Minke Whales and all Southern Hemisphere "dwarf" Minke Whales are regarded as B. acutorostrata (IWC 2001). This has been followed by management and treaty bodies, such as Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES). This is based on genetic and morphological evidence that the two Minke Whale species, which are partially sympatric in the Southern Hemisphere, are distinct species (Rice 1998, Wada et al. 1991, Pastene et al. 1994, Pastene et al. 2007).

The Southern Right Whale has for some time been widely accepted as a species separate from its Northern Hemisphere relatives, although Rice (1998) regarded the Right Whales in all oceans as a single species and placed them in the genus Balaena along with B. mysticetus, the Bowhead Whale. Genetic analyses support the concept of three separate phylogenetic species of Right Whale, one in the North Atlantic, one in the North Pacific, and one in the Southern Hemisphere (Rosenbaum et al. 2000). The International Whaling Commission (IWC 2004) and the Society for Marine Mammalogy's Taxonomy Committee (Committee on Taxonomy 2017) accept the latter taxonomy. The ranges of the three Right Whale species do not overlap.
Pygmy Killer Whales (Feresa attenuata) are easily confused with Melon-Headed Whales (Peponocephala electra) in the field because of their similar external morphology (Jefferson et al. 2015).

Two forms of Short-finned Pilot Whales (Globicephala macrorhynchus) are found off northern and southern Japan, differing in external and cranial morphology (Kasuya et al. 1988, Van Cise et al. 2016). Although it has been suggested that these might represent two distinct sub-species (Oremus et al. 2009), evidence has not been marshalled to make this distinction official and no subspecies of Short-finned Pilot Whale are currently recognized (Van Cise et al. 2016, Committee on Taxonomy 2017).

Three subspecies of the Long-finned Pilot Whale are currently recognized: Globicephala melas melas in the North Atlantic, G. m. edwardii in the Southern Hemisphere, and an un-named subspecies in Japanese waters (extinct since the 8th-12th century A.D.) (Rice 1998, Oremus et al. 2009, Committee on Taxonomy 2017).

The Southern Bottlenose Whale forms an antitropical species pair with the Northern Bottlenose Whale, Hyperoodon ampullatus. Intraspecific variation in mitochondrial control region sequences of two specimens from New Zealand was 4.12% higher than for all other cetacean species, and higher than between the antitropical species pair Berardius bairdii and B. arnuxii (3.78%) (Dalebout et al. 1998). Also, the skull characters are very distinct between the two species.

This assessment follows the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (2017) which recognizes a single species in the genus, Inia geoffrensis, the Amazon River Dolphin, with two subspecies: I. g. boliviensis (d’ Orbigny 1834), the Bolivian Bufeo, and I. g. geoffrensis (Blainville 1817), the Common Boto. The Bolivian Bufeo occurs in the Iténez-Guaporé, Mamoré, and Rio Grande River basins in Bolivia (Tavera et al. 2010) and along almost the entire length of the Madeira River in Brazil (Gravena et al. 2014a,b). The Common Boto occurs in the Amazon River system of Brazil, Peru, Ecuador, and Colombia, in the Araguaia-Tocantins River system in eastern Brazil which has no connection to the Amazon River basin (Hrbek et al., 2014, Siciliano et al. 2016a), and in the Orinoco Basin of Venezuela and Colombia (Best and da Silva 1989b, Trujillo et al. 2010a). To emphasize the taxonomic uncertainty concerning how many species should be recognized in the genus, and the fact that these dolphins inhabit several river basins in addition to the Amazon, this assessment does not use the common name Amazon River Dolphin but instead uses the genus name Inia.

A new species I. boliviensis (d’Orbigny 1834) was described from a specimen collected in the Rio Itenez (or Guapore in Brazilian Portuguese) near or at Forte Principe da Beira, Brazil. This putative species also occurs in rivers in Cochabamba, Santa Cruz, Beni, and Pando Departments of the Bolivian Amazon basin and in the Madeira River of Brazil. It does not overlap with other Inia populations in several morphological characters including rostral length, and it has significant differences in the number of teeth (da Silva 1994). The boliviensis form is considered to have been reproductively isolated by a long series of rapids for an estimated 3.1 million years (Hollatz et al. 2011). Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) and nuclear introns have been interpreted as suggesting that these dolphins are on a separate evolutionary trajectory and therefore may deserve recognition as a phylogenetic species (Banguera-Hinestroza et al. 2002, Ruiz-García et al. 2008). However, Gravena et al. (2014a,b), with better sampling of the Madeira River system above and below the Teotônio Rapids (the proposed barrier to movement of individuals and gene flow), found that these rapids did not appear to obstruct gene flow from the upstream to the downstream population. Gravena et al. (2015) nevertheless concluded that Inia along the Madeira River possess the unique mtDNA of the putative species I. boliviensis (one line of evidence for recognizing species-level difference), and they argued that even if there is hybridization in the contact zone in the Madeira River, Inia below Teotônio remain distinct and follow an independent evolutionary path.

The nominal species Inia araguaiaensis was described from the Araguaia-Tocantins River basin (Hrbek et al. 2014), which is not connected to the Amazon River basin. Examination of tissue samples and osteological material from the Araguaia River and from Marajó Island revealed diagnostic molecular and morphological characters that justified separation of I. araguaiaensis from its proposed sister taxon (I. geoffrensis) from the Amazon Basin (Hrbek et al. 2014, Siciliano et al. 2016b). These dolphins are also known from the Guamá River. The Committee on Taxonomy (2017) reasoned that because Hrbek et al. (2014) only examined samples from two extremes of the distribution of Inia it was unclear if the molecular differences observed represented real species-level separation. In addition, the Committee concluded that diagnostic osteological differences were based on the examination of very few specimens (only two for the nominal species and nine for I. geoffrensis) and did not account for effects of the significant sexual dimorphism. A few more specimens were examined by Siciliano et al. (2016b) confirming the findings of Hrbek et al. (2014) and expanding the distributional limits of the taxon to 500km further north. Additional research is needed to clarify the taxonomic status of I. araguaiaensis, and dolphins in the Araguaia-Tocantins River basin are grouped with I. geoffrensis in the present assessment.

It was only in 1966 that the two species in the genus Kogia (K. breviceps and K. sima) were recognized as distinct (Handley 1966, Chivers et al. 2005). No subspecies have been described (Committee on Taxonomy 2018). The cryptic behavior and similar external morphology of the two species mean that records are often not displayed at the species level and are instead combined into Kogia spp.

This species was not widely recognized until 1966, therefore, in literature that predates this time it is often not clear which species of Kogia is intended. No subspecies of K. sima are currently recognized. However, based on mitochondrial cytochrome b gene sequencing, it has been suggested that K. sima consists of two species: one in the Atlantic and the other in the Indo-Pacific (Chivers et al. 2005). Further evidence is required before this can be shown definitively (McAlpine 2018).
Fraser’s Dolphin was described in 1956 and the external appearance of this species was not known until 1971 (Perrin et al. 1973).

The Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy recognizes three subspecies of Humpback Whale: the nominate subspecies M. n. novaeangliae (Borowski, 1781) refers to the North Atlantic Humpback Whale; M. n. australis (Lesson, 1828) is the Southern (Hemisphere) Humpback Whale; and M. n. kuzira (Gray, 1850) is the North Pacific Humpback Whale (Committee on Taxonomy 2017). This is based on the finding that Humpback Whales in the three ocean basins, although not separate clades, appear to be on diverging genetic trajectories (Jackson et al. 2014). The Arabian Sea contains a genetically isolated population of Humpback Whales (Pomilla et al. 2014), which is also assessed on the Red List separately as a subpopulation (Minton et al. 2008).
Blainville’s Beaked Whales (Mesoplodon densirostris) is one of 15 species of Mesoplodon with a worldwide range in tropical and warm-temperate waters. No subspecies are currently recognized.

Mitochondrial DNA evidence revealed that stranded specimens from the eastern North Pacific previously identified as M. hectori were a new species of Mesoplodon subsequently described as M. perrini (Dalebout et al. 2002).

Mesoplodon layardii was described from drawings of a skull made by Roland Trimen at the South African Museum, Cape Town at the request of E. L. Layard, keeper of the museum. Layard submitted the drawings and skull measurements to J. E. Gray at the British Museum of Natural History (Gray 1865). Gray (1874) also described Dolichodon traversii from the Chatham Islands as a new species. However, it was not accepted by other researchers and considered a synonym of M. layardii until Van Helden et al. (2002) showed that it had genetic and morphological differences distinct from M. layardii. The misidentified specimen from the Chatham Islands is now known to be a Spade-toothed Beaked Whale (M. traversii) (Van Helden et al. 2002).

Although still considered a single species, True’s is the only beaked whale species known to have an anti-tropical distribution, with one population in the warm- and cold-temperate North Atlantic and the other in the warm- and cold-temperate Southern Hemisphere. The southern form has a markedly different color pattern (Baker 1999, Best 2007, Jefferson et al. 2015), and the genetic evidence further suggests that the two forms “should be considered distinct subspecies or even species” (Dalebout et al. 2007, 2014).

This taxonomic unit is treated as a single species even though there is extensive and growing evidence that it is, in fact, a complex of multiple forms with morphological, genetic, ecological, and behavioural differences that merit subspecies if not also species designations. At the time of writing (June 2017), the Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy (www.marinemammalscience.org/species-information/list-marine-mammal-species-subspecies), which is generally regarded as the authority for marine mammal taxonomy, recognized a single killer whale species, Orcinus orca (Linnaeus, 1758), and two unnamed subspecies in the eastern North Pacific, the ENP resident killer whale (O. o. un-named subsp.) and the ENP transient killer whale (O. o. un-named subsp.) also known as Bigg’s killer whale. The Committee noted, however, “Other forms of killer whales in the North Pacific, North Atlantic and Antarctic [Southern] Ocean may warrant recognition as separate subspecies or even species, but the taxonomy has not yet been fully clarified or agreed (Morin et al. 2010; Foote et al. 2009, 2013).” One population (a “distinct population segment”) of the ENP resident subspecies (the “southern resident” population) was listed as Endangered under the Canadian Species at Risk Act in 2003 and the U.S. Endangered Species Act in 2005.

No subspecies of the Melon-headed Whale (Peponocephala electra) are currently recognized (Committee on Taxonomy 2018). This species is morphologically similar to the Pygmy Killer Whale and the two species can be easily confused in the field.  Although they sometimes form resident populations around oceanic islands, Melon-headed Whales show low levels of genetic differentiation both within and between ocean basins, suggesting high levels of population connectivity (Martien et al. 2017).

Rosa et al. (2005) found fixed differences in mtDNA of Burmeister's Porpoises between Peru and strata in Chile and Argentina. Results were consistent with levels of differentiation at a subspecies or greater level (Taylor et al. 2017) but the basis for a change in taxonomy has not been evaluated. The genetic data also supported differences, though of a lesser degree, between Chile and Argentina, which would be consistent with morphological differences between Burmeister’s Porpoises in the two ocean basins reported by Corcuera et al. (1995).

The genus Stenella is paraphyletic, and it is likely that the Delphininae will be restructured in the coming years (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013). Two subspecies are recognized: S. attenuata attenuata in oceanic tropical waters worldwide, and S. a. graffmani in the coastal waters of the eastern tropical Pacific (ETP) (Jefferson et al. 2015, Perrin 2018).

The Clymene Dolphin (Stenella clymene) is likely to have evolved through a case of hybrid speciation, involving widespread hybridization of Spinner (S. longirostris) and Striped (S. coeruleoalba) Dolphins (Amaral et al., 2014). Recent genetic work suggests that the genus Stenella is paraphyletic, and it is likely that taxonomy of the Delphinidae will be restructured in coming years (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013). This species might even move to a different genus. Coloration differences between the Clymene Dolphins in the eastern and western Atlantic Ocean suggest possible population structuring, although this remains unconfirmed (Weir et al. 2014).

Recent genetic work suggests that the genus Stenella is paraphyletic, and it is likely that the Delphininae will be restructured in coming years (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013). Morphological and genetic studies strongly suggest that the Mediterranean and eastern North Atlantic Striped Dolphin populations are isolated from each other, with little or no gene flow across the Strait of Gibraltar (Calzada and Aguilar 1995, García-Martínez et al. 1995, Archer 1997, Gaspari 2004). No subspecies are recognized.

Recent molecular work suggests that the genus Stenella is paraphyletic, and it is likely that the Delphininae (the subfamily to which the species currently belongs) will be restructured in coming years, at which point this species may be assigned to a different genus (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013). Some evidence suggests a close relationship with the Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin (Tursiops aduncus) (Jefferson et al. 2015). There is a large, heavy form of Atlantic Spotted Dolphin found along the coasts on both sides of the Atlantic (formerly called Stenella plagiodon along the U.S. coast), while a smaller form that is lightly spotted or unspotted as an adult occurs in the Gulf Stream and the central North Atlantic (Perrin et al. 1987, Herzing and Perrin 2018, Viallelle 1997).

Cuvier’s Beaked Whale (Ziphius cavirostris) is the only species in the monotypic genus Ziphius (Rice 1998, Dalebout et al. 2005). During the 19th century numerous specimens of Cuvier’s Beaked Whales were described as new species but none of them have been accepted as valid and a single species is recognized to occur throughout its range.

The Spectacled Porpoise was briefly considered to be in its own genus, Australophocaena, and was listed in the 1996-2002 Red Lists as Australophocaena dioptrica. However, due to more recent genetic and morphometric findings (Rosel et al. 1995, Perrin et al. 2000), it has again been assigned to the genus Phocoena (Committee on Taxonomy 2018).

Until relatively recently the genus Sotalia was considered monotypic with two ecotypes, one riverine and one marine (da Silva and Best 1996). However, genetic (Cunha et al. 2005, Caballero et al. 2007) and morphological (Monteiro-Filho et al. 2002, Fettuccia et al. 2009) studies have shown that the two ecotypes are separate species: S. fluviatilis in the Amazon River basin and S. guianensis in marine and estuarine waters of eastern South and Central America (da Silva and Best 1996, da Silva et al. 2010).

The Sotalia dolphins recorded at Ciudad Bolívar, some 300 km upstream of the mouth of the Orinoco River, were confirmed by molecular genetics to be an isolated and probably independent population of S. guianensis occurring as far as 550 km upriver in the Orinoco (Caballero et al. 2017).

Although the taxonomic status of Sotalia dolphins in the southern freshwater portion of Maracaibo Lake (in Venezuela near the border with Colombia) is not yet fully established, there is no connection between Maracaibo Lake and the present-day known range of Sotalia fluviatilis. Maracaibo Lake has been isolated from the Amazon basin for the last 8-10 million years (Hoorn et al. 1995, Días de Gamero 1996 quoted in Cunha et al. 2010). Thus, the likelihood that Sotalia dolphins from Maracaibo Lake are of the same species that occurs in the Amazon basin is remote. The dolphins in Maracaibo Lake are included in the assessment of S. guianensis (Secchi et al. 2018).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group.  Johnson et al. (2006) and Eizirik et al. (2008) placed yagouaroundi in the genus Puma. However, Agnarsson et al. (2010) noted that the Jaguarundi is not a sister species to the Puma. More recently Segura et al. (2013) looked at cranial development within the Puma clade and found that while this is similar in Cheetah and Puma, that of the Jaguarundi is quite different. Given these phylogenetic uncertainties, and these and other morphological and behavioural differences, the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group retains this species in Herpailurus.

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group (2016). Genetic analyses found a level of divergence between L. tigrinus from Costa Rica (L. tigrinus oncilla) and from central (L. tigrinus tigrinus) and southern Brazil (L. guttulus) comparable to that between species in the Leopardus group, suggesting that these populations have been isolated, perhaps by the Amazon River, for approximately 3.7 million years. More analysis of geographic partitioning, with additional samples from other parts of the range, is needed to confirm whether this taxon should be further split into two species (Johnson et al. 1999, Eizirik et al. 2007, Trigo et al. 2013a).

There is also evidence of hybridization between L. tigrinus and L. colocolo (Johnson et al. 1999, Trigo et al. 2013a) in areas where their range overlaps.

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. This species is genetically very diverse across its range and shows a high degree of population structure, with three distinct clusters: Central America and Mexico, northern South America and southern South America. The demarcation between northern and southern South America was identified as the Amazon river. In Central America, there were weaker differences between populations from the north (Mexico and Guatemala) and those from the south of this region (Eizirik et al. 1998).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group.  Included in the genus Leopardus by Johnson et al. (2006). No genetic evidence of geographic subspecific partitioning was found in an analysis by Johnson et al. (1999). A zone of hybridization was found in southern Brazil where the northern extent of L. geoffroyi's range meets the southernmost extent of the range of the Oncilla, L. tigrinus (Eizirik et al. 2007).

Dipsas bucephala and D. cisticeps form a probable species complex whose taxonomy is unresolved. Cacciali et al. (2016) agree with Harvey and Embert (2008) that these taxa are specifically distinct from Dipsas indica, but note that these authors only examined specimens of the Bolivian subspecies which these authors recognize as Dipsas cisticeps "until further evidence proves us wrong". In light of the lack of a formal recent treatment to clarify the status of D. cisticeps, and the likelihood that further cryptic species exist within D. bucephala as presently understood (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020), this assessment follows the treatment adopted by Harvey and Embert (2008) and followed most recently by Nogueira et al. (2019), who treat D. cisticeps as a subspecies of D. bucephala.

Cadle and Myers (2003) revised the systematics of this species and referred records from Panama, Ecuador, Colombia and Peru to other species (Harvey and Embert 2008 subsequently confirmed its occurrence in the latter country and Bolivia). In a revision of Bolivian Dipsas, Harvey and Embert (2008) includes D. neivai as a junior synonym of D. variegata on the basis that specimens of D. neivai cannot "confidently" be distinguished from D. variegata and this arrangement is followed here. Wallach et al. (2014) recognize Dipsas neivai as a distinct species, but provide no justification. Research is recommended to clarify the taxonomic status of D. neivai, as Harvey and Embert (2008) did not examine the types of either taxon.
Erythrolamprus almadensis is a species complex (Dixon 1991).
Ascenso et al. (2019) supported the recognition of Erythrolamprus dorsocorallinus as distinct from E. reginae, although Wallach et al. (2014) suggested that these taxa may be conspecific.
This is a species complex (Dixon and Markezich 1992).

authority: Grazziotin, Zaher, Murphy, Scrocchi, Benavides, Zhang & Bonatto, 2012

taxonomicNotes:
Wallach (2016) summarized the controversial history of the names Epictia albifrons and E. tenella, which he divided into three schools of thought. In two of these the two taxa are synonymous, but there is disagreement over whether the correct name is albifrons or whether this name should be considered a nomen dubium and the correct name is therefore tenella. The third scheme proposes that the two taxa are validly distinct. Wallach (2016) rejected the neotype designation - based on a damaged specimen - by Natera-Munaw et al. (2015) and proposed a different neotype, further confusing the situation.

Pinto et al. (2018) investigated this issue in detail. This work found both that the name E. albifrons was applied incorrectly by Wallach (2016) due to confusion surrounding this species' diagnostic characters, and that this author's action in rejecting the earlier neotype designation violated International Commission of Zoological Nomenclature rules. Pinto et al. (2018) concluded that the names E. albifrons and E. tenella refer to the same taxon and that the name albifrons should have priority. The species recognized as E. albifrons by Wallach (2016) has not been identified, and is thought to be an undescribed species of unclear provenance by Pinto et al. (2018).

Thought by Lockwood (1973) and some subsequent authors to be a recombinant hybrid (of Brugmansia versicolor and B. suaveolens), but that has since been disproven by breeding experiments [(see Hay et al. (2012: 114)].

Frequently misidentified as B. suaveolens, especially in ethnobotanical and anthropological literature.

Brugmansia species as a whole have sometimes been viewed as cultigens (e.g. Bristol, 1966). This view was not accepted by Hay et al. (2012: 15) who view them as species long conserved through cultivation by indigenous people. There is no evidence for any of the species having come into being under human husbandry from wild progenitors, since no candidates for wild progenitors exist.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
The genus Achiropsis is now known to be a synonymy of Apionichthys (Ramos 2003).
Apistogramma genus is complex, and species are difficult to identify.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group’s Cat Classification Task Force. Although described originally as a new species, Felis guttula Hensel, 1872, this species was commonly treated as a subspecies of Leopardus tigrinus until 2013 (Trigo et al. 2013a), when they demonstrated with a comprehensive molecular study that Leopardus tigrinus and L. guttulus are clearly distinct species. L. guttulus hybridises with L. geoffroyi in Rio Grande do Sul, which is the type locality. The holotype of L. guttulus should be investigated in order to check whether it is a hybrid. Further research is required to establish whether northwestern tigrinas comprise a third species, L. pardinoides, or even a fourth species, L. oncilla, in Costa Rica (Johnson et al. 1999, Trigo et al. 2008, Nascimento 2010). Also the distribution and morphology of L. guttulus need to be better defined. Until then L. guttulus is recognised as a monotypic species: Leopardus guttulus (Hensel 1872; 73).
Rhinella alata may be conspecific with Rhinella acutirostris.
This is most likely a species complex.
Acredita tratar-se de um complexo de espécies (Pellegrino et al. 2005).
This species was likely misidentified as Hippocampus erectus prior to its description in 2004.
This is a polymorphic species, possibly representing a species complex (Gans 1971).

Due to the presence of specimens with intermediate characters, in large parts of intergradation, it is possible that specimens attributed to Amphisbaena darwini, A. trachura and A. heterozonata may belong to a single species for which A. darwini is the oldest available name (Gans 1966). If so, this would extend A. darwini's range to northern Argentina, southern Bolivia, and central Paraguay (Montero 1996, Montero and Terol 1999)

Systematic relationships among Ophiodes species are unclear. The distribution of this taxon is consequently uncertain and there is a need for further taxonomic research to clearly separate it from Ophiodes cf. striatus (Montechiario et al. 2011).

Cacciali and Scott (2012) reported that the Ophiodes striatus complex was represented in Paraguay by two species, one of which was in the process of being described. This work was published by Cacciali and Scott (2015), who named the novel taxon Ophiodes luciae.
Taxonomic research is recommended because it may represent a species complex (Giraudo et al. 2012).
There are no taxonomic issues for this species.  It is wide ranging but very consistent in form.
This species has two varieties: Cordia sebestena L. var. sebestena and Cordia sebestena L. var. caymanensis (Urb.) Proctor.
This species has two subspecies, Varronia bullata L. subsp. bullata and Varronia bullata L. subsp. humilis (Jacq.) Feuillet.

The genus Ameroglossum Eb.Fisch., S.Vogel & A.V.Lopes (Scrophulariaceae) is monotypic with A. pernambucense as the unique species described (Fischer et al. 1999). Nevertheless, several close related species are known, but are still not described. Due to the lack of taxonomic research in this genus, these species have been erroneously identified as A. pernambucense. They form a set of morphologically discrete groups, which do not fit the taxonomic entity described by Fischer et al. (1999). Main differences are found in phyllotaxy; leaf size, colour and shape; and flower size and colour. To avoid an erroneous assessment due to taxonomic uncertainty, the taxon here assessed was in strictly accordance to the taxonomic entity A. pernambucense described by (Fischer et al. 1999). The undescribed species were useful to detect the borders of the A. pernambucense distribution.
Echinochloa polystachya  (Kunth) Hitche is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of White millet/ Siberian millet (Echinochloa frumenlacca Link) (Vincent et al. 2013)

This name is often misapplied to Brugmansia insignis.

Brugmansia species as a whole have sometimes been viewed as cultigens (e.g. Bristol 1966). This view was not accepted by Hay et al. (2012: 15) who view them as species long conserved through cultivation by indigenous people. There is no evidence for any of the species having come into being under human husbandry from wild progenitors, since no candidates for wild progenitors exist.

authority: Recorder, Werneck, Teixera, Colli, Sites & Rodrigues, 2014

taxonomicNotes: It is in need of a taxonomic revision (Poulsen et al. 2009).
The genus Narcetes, and Rinoctes and Bathytroctes are in need of a taxonomic revision (Poulsen et al. 2009).
Until recently, Melanolagus bericoides was assigned to the genus Bathylagus, and it is often confused with Bathylagus euryops (Møller et al. 2010).

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be one to two hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

The taxonomy of the genus Nansenia needs revision, as there may be one or two hidden synonymies among the currently recognized species (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014). Further, the importance of vertebral counts to the correct identification of Nansenia species can be overlooked, resulting in misidentification of specimens in museum collections. These misidentifications have been perpetuated through checklists, and thus the true distribution of these species is often uncertain (O. Gon pers. comm. 2014).

Taxonomic revision of the genus Bathyonus is needed in order to verify species distributions (Nielsen et al. 1999). Nielsen et al. (2008) collected an specimen from the Southern Ocean, but did not describe it past the genus level because of unresolved taxonomic issues within the genus.
The genus Dicrolene is in need of taxonomic revision.
Mentodus perforatus Sazonov and Trunov, 1978 was described as a separate species, distinct from M. rostratus (Quéro et al. 1990).
This species was removed from the synonymy of Liotyphlops ternetzii (Boulenger, 1896) by Dixon and Kofron (1984).

Fernandes et al. (1998) synonymized Heterorhachis poecilolepis with Sibynomorphus ventrimaculatus.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

Homonota horrida has variously been treated as a full species or as a junior synonym of H. fasciata, with synonymization proposed by both Abdala and Lavilla (1993) and Cacciali et al. (2007). At present the two taxa are considered to be synonymous (A. Giraudo pers. comm. 2016), and this scheme is followed here.
This is a species complex (Langstroth 2005, Nogueira 2006) which contains two recognized subspecies: Cercosaurus schreibersii schreibersii Wiegmann, 1834 and C. s. albostrigatus (Griffin, 1917).
This species is probably a complex of more than one species.

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005), and transferred to Boana by Dubois (2017). Its phylogenetic relationships have been assessed by Sturaro et al. (2020) and recovered as the sister taxon of the Boana benitezi group, although with no significant support.

Originally described as a member of Eleutherodactylus (Rivero 1968) and later transferred to Pristimantis (Heinicke et al. 2007). Not assigned to any species group by Hedges et al. (2008) neither by Padial et al. (2014). Its phylogenetic relationships within Pristimantis have been assessed by Kok et al. (2012, 2018), Padial et al. (2014), and Jablonski et al. (2017) on the basis of molecular data. Records of P. pulvinatus documented by Duellman (1997) from La Escalera, and the sequence used by Hedges et al. (2008) from the same region, actually correspond to misidentified specimens of P. marmoratus (Kok et al. 2018).
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and the production of odorous skin secretions (Means and Savage 2007).
This species was previously within the genus Hypsiboas but has been moved to Boana following Dubois (2017).

The South American Sea Lion has been referred to by the scientific names Otaria byronia (following Blainville 1820) and O. flavescens (following Shaw 1800). Rice (1998) concluded that O. flavescens has priority. More recently, Berta and Churchill (2012) noted that the specific name for this taxa is controversial, but concluded that O. byronia is “the earliest available name applicable with certainty.” O. byronia is the name approved by the Society for Marine Mammalogy (Committee on Taxonomy 2014) and will be used in the document. However, O. flavescens is still in use, particularly by South American scientists.

Szapkievich et al. (1999) conducted the first genetic study on the species, analyzing 10 protein loci in 70 South American Sea Lion pups from two rookeries 1,300 km apart (Isla de Lobos, Uruguay and Peninsula Valdés, Argentina). They found only a small genetic distance between the rookeries, suggesting that they belong to the same population in which gene flow is currently occurring. Túnez et al. (2007) studied the population structure of South American Sea Lions by analyzing mtDNA from a few colonies along the Atlantic coast, and comparing their results with five sequences previously published from Peruvian populations (Wynen et al. 2001). They found no haplotypes shared between the Atlantic and Peruvian colonies. The South Atlantic population from Uruguay to southern Patagonia was studied by means of mtDNA (Túnez et al. 2007, 2010; Feijoó et al. 2011) and microsatellites (Feijoó et al. 2011). While mitochondrial markers showed geographically structured sub-populations, the nuclear loci showed a lack of geographical structure. These opposite patterns in genetic structure can be explained by female phylopatry and high male dispersion (Feijoo et al. 2011). On the Chilean coast, Weinberger (2013) using eight microsatellite loci showed the existence of two genetic clusters separated at approximately 41° S, supporting the existence of two sub-populations or management units.

Gehara (2009) and Túnez et al. (2007) concluded there is significant genetic differentiation between South American Sea Lions in the Atlantic and Pacific oceans, suggesting complete and prolonged isolation and distinct evolutionarily significant units (ESUs). This was based on 10 microsatellite loci and mtDNA sequences from 4 areas (Uruguay, Argentina, Chile, and Peru). However, the rookeries of southern South America need to be sampled and analyzed in order to establish the limit of gene flow between the two ocean basins (Oliveira pers. comm.).
There are two accepted infraspecifics for this species, subsp. obtusifolia and subsp. rhombifolia (G.Mey.) A.H.Gentry. The assessment covers both subspecies.
This species is comprised by ten varieties which are all included here.

This is an extremely variable polymorphic species and has been divided into number of varieties and forms by Ducke (Sacoglottis guianensis forma dolichocarpa 1922, Sacoglottis guianensis Benth, var. maior 1932) and by Cuatrecasas (Sacoglottis guianensis forma glabra 1961, Sacoglottis guianensis Benth. var. hispidula 1961). These are based on pubescence of various organs and the shape of the fruit. It is often impossible to decide to which taxon a collection belongs as they are often missing the crucial part. It seems preferable at this stage to recognise this as a single taxon as was identified by Cuatrecasas & Huber (1999), but it would make a good molecular study for the future.

The taxonomy of the three genera Laplacea, Polyspora and Gordonia are still under investigation. Weitzman recognizes, after examination of specimens throughout the distributional range, only two species in the New World, L. fruticosa and L. haematoxylon (Prince 2007, Prince 2009). Here we follow this latest treatment of the genus, and Laplacea fruticosa is treated in the wider sense.

There remains some uncertainty as to the taxonomic status of Gnatholepis thompsoni. It has previously been considered a synonym of Gnatholepis cauerensis.

The taxonomic concept of Gnatholepis cauerensis is undergoing revision. Gnatholepis has often been misidentified and confused for many years. Previously, there were four proposed subspecies (G. c. cauerensis, G. c. australis, G. c. hawaiiensis and G. c. pascuensis), and G. thompsoni was considered a synonym (Randall and Greenfield 2001). Thacker (2004) shows G. thompsoni to be a separate species and also concludes that G. cauerensis should be synonymised with G. anjerensis. Variation in mitochondrial DNA suggested that G. thompsoni is a valid species that is widespread in the Atlantic Ocean and separate from G. cauerensis (Rocha et al. 2005). However, Randall and Greenfield (2007) consider G. thompsoni a synonym of G. cauerensis. Randall (2009) elevated three subspecies to the species level (resulting in four species: G. cauerensis, G. australis, G. hawaiiensis and G. pascuensis). During a recent revision of Gnatholepis, the classification presented by Rocha et al. was discussed and validated with meristic and other morphological characters by Larson and Buckle (2012). Larson and Buckle (2012) concluded that G. cauerensis includes subspecies G. c. cauerensis, G. c. australis and G. c. hawaiiensis and G. inconsequens is considered a synonym. They elevated G. thompsoni and G. pascuensis to valid species. Gnatholepis thompsoni, as valid in Larson and Buckle (2012), is restricted to the Atlantic Ocean. Rocha et al. (2005) examined genetic differences between the Atlantic G. thompsoni and the Indo-Pacific G. cauerensis, concluding that G. thompsoni is the result of a relatively recent (~ 145,000 years ago) invasion of the Atlantic by G. cauerensis. However, Smith-Vaniz and Collette (2013) recorded G. cauerensis, not G. thompsoni, in Bermuda, as "the meristic and other morphological characters purported to separate these two 'species' have broadly over-lapping values". Despite the issues with the characters used by Larson and Buckle (2012), G. thompsoni likely forms its own monophyletic group in an isolated ocean basin, and with threats and evolutionary trajectory separate from that of G. cauerensis. Therefore, G. thompsoni is retained as a valid species.
This species is often confused with Fimbristylis miliacea in Indian floristic works. Fimbristylis miliacea is mostly common in north India (Cook 1996).
Solanum chacoense Bitter is a secondary wild relative of potato, S. tuberosum L. (Vincent et al. 2013).

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

M. aquatica hybridises within the genus and in particular, the hybrid with M. spicata L.; M. ×piperita is very common (at least in the UK). However, hybridisation is not considered likely to affect the conservation or red list assessment for M. aquatica.

Osmunda regalis is restricted to the Old World. In the New World it is replaced by O. spectabilis, which was formerly treated as a subspecies of O. regalis. However, this is now known to be more closely related to O. japonica (Metzgar et al. 2008) and is thus to be treated at the species level.

Due to the presence of specimens with intermediate characters, in large parts of intergradation, it is possible that specimens attributed to Amphisbaena darwini, A. trachura and A. heterozonata may belong to a single species for which A. darwini is the oldest available name (Gans 1966). If so, this would extend A. darwini's range to northern Argentina, southern Bolivia, and central Paraguay ( Montero 1996, Montero and Terol 1999)
Cacciali et al. (2009) synonymized Simophis rohdei within S. rhinostoma.

It was thought that the species was probably also found in parts of Bolivia, but taxonomic studies suggest that Bolivian populations may well represent undescribed species, as allopatric speciation may be prevalent in this group of rare and habitat-restricted lizards (Rodrigues et al. 2007, 2008) .

Amaral (1933) suggested that differences between the male holotype and C. kraepelini and the female holotype of C. modesta were likely to be the result of sexual dimorphism, and concluded that C. kraepelini is therefore a junior synonym of C. modesta, and this conclusion is supported by Rodrigues et al. (2007). Doubt has been cast on this assignment by Vanzolini et al. (1977), who observe that the type material of C. kraepelini consisted of one male and one female and that the description makes explicit reference to an 'Alopoglossus-like' character not shared with Colobosaura. None of these authors are thought to have examined the type material, which has been lost, and Vanzolini et al. (1977) note that "The animal has to be seen again before anything sensible can be said about it".

Most recently, Cacciali et al. (2017) reported the collection of new Colobosaura material from the Paraguay River drainage and confirmed that this specimen was not conspecific with C. modesta on the basis of both morphological and genetic data. These authors tentatively applied the the only available name - C. kraeplini - to this material on the basis that there are no known morphological characters that distinguish it from the species described by Werner.

Manihot anomala Pohl is a gene pool secondary wild relative of cassava, M. esculenta Crantz ssp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013). The synonyms listed are pro-parte synonyms (data source – USDA, ARS, National Genetic Resources Program 2015):
  • M. glabrata (Chodat & Hassl.) Pax [≡ M. anomala ssp. glabrata]
  • M. multiflora Pax & K. Hoffm. [= M. anomala ssp. glabrata]
  • M. pavoniana Müll. Arg. [≡ M. anomala ssp. pavoniana]
  • M. pubescens Pohl [≡ M. anomala ssp. pubescens]
  • M. pubescens f. glabrata Chodat & Hassl. [≡ M. anomala ssp. glabrata]
Manihot leptophylla Pax & K.Hoffm. is a gene pool secondary wild relative of cassava, M. esculenta Crantz ssp. esculenta (Vincent et al. 2013).

Jadin et al. (2013) investigated the systematics of Pseustes (for which they resurrected the senior synonym Phrynonax), within which they recognized the species P. poecilonotus, P. shropshirei, and P. polylepis (the latter resurrected from synonymy within P. poecilonotus). Taxonomic issues remain within this complex, and in particular the status of Pseustes lyoni - described from northern Venezuela and later synonymized with P. poecilonotus. Following the resurrection of P. polylepis by Jadin et al. (2013), P. lyoni should presently be considered a junior synonym of this taxon (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2015, Uetz et al. 2021). It has, however, been suggested either that it may be conspecific with P. shropshirei (Guttierez et al. in review) or that it may be a valid species (G. Rivas pers. comm. 2015), and research is required to resolve this issue.

Triphora latifolia was thought to be endemic to Florida endemic but the understanding of the taxon expanded when Ackerman (1995) determined vegetative material from Puerto Rico as T. latifolia. In 1995, the distribution of T. latifolia was thought to be Florida, Puerto Rico and Brazil, which is a bit unusual. A careful comparison between T. latifolia and T. amazonica revealed that the only detectable difference between the taxa was the middle lobe of the lip, which may be rounded in T. latifolia or acute in T. amazonica (Ackerman 2000). Triphora amazonica ranges from Brazil to Guyana, French Guiana, Surinam, Trinidad and Dominican Republic, which makes a link with Puerto Rico and Florida. Morphological and geographical information provide evidence that these two taxa are conspecific. Additional specimens are needed to confirm the full geographic extent of T. amazonica sensu lato and that T. amazonica sensu lato is one distinct species throughout its range. The taxonomic treatment followed here indicates that some rare species have much greater range extents than previously thought (Ackerman 2000).

This is a very variable species, particularly in West Africa where Hooper and Napper (1972) recognised three varieties. These were the typical variety, var. dichotoma, var. pluristriata (C.B. Clarke) Napper and var. laxa (Vahl) Napper. These subspecies and varieties have been recognised by different authors. Var. pluristriata was given subspecific rank by T. Koyama as Fimbristylis dichotoma subsp. podocarpa (Nees) T. Koyama, while var. laxa is at present on WCSP sunk into the typical species Fimbristylis dichotoma subsp. dichotoma. In some regions of Africa, namely South Africa and the area covered by the Flora Zambesiaca, Fimbristylis dichotoma is not as variable and the nutlets are entirely tuberculate like those of the typical variety as seen in West African countries.

The genus Utricularia is taxonomically complex, partly due to the desire of botanists to establish methods of identifying non-flowering populations (particularly in the field), with the consequence that the literature is complicated by vast numbers of unreliable records. Many taxa rarely flower and some have apparently never been known to flower in some regions. The majority of the data presented here is derived from Taylor (1989) which is the most reliable source. Additional information has been used where it is felt that it is both useful and reliable.

Anolis eewi has been synonymised with A. planiceps and subsequently re-elevated  to full species by several authors (Rivas et al. 2012). Most recently, Poe et al. (2017) synonymised this species within A. planiceps and this arrangement is followed here.

This species has been reported from sites outside Brazil, in French Guiana (Starace 1998) and the Koetari River in Suriname (Ouboter et al., in O'Shea et al. 2011, National Zoological Collection of Suriname). Later reexamination of French Guiana specimens by Starace in 2013 determined that these represent Amphisbaena vanzolini (M. Hoogmoed pers. comm. 2016). The Koetari record, attributed to A. slevini before Starace corrected the identification of the French Guiana specimens, has subsequently been reexamined and found also to represent A. vanzolini (P. Ouboter unpubl. data). As such, A. slevini is still known with certainty only from areas close to Manaus in Brazilian Amazonia.

Antarctic Fur Seals were formerly considered a subspecies of Arctocephalus tropicalis and were known as A. t. gazella (Repenning et al. 1971). Rice (1998) listed the species as A. gazella.  In 2011 the genus of this, and many other species of Fur Seals was changed to Arctophoca, Peters 1866 (Committee on Taxonomy 2011) based on evidence presented in Berta and Churchill (2012). However, in 2013, based on genetic evidence presented in Nyakatura and Bininda-Emonds (2012), this change was considered to be premature and these species were returned to the genus Arctocephalus pending further research (Committee on Taxonomy 2013).
Was under Iguanidae.
Information on the distribution of this and other strictly terrestrial Callitriche species is obscured by poor taxonomic resolution of the various taxa.
Was under Iguanidae.
Spelling of species epithet sometimes cangerana.
The Plant List (2017) cites around 20 synonyms for this species, three varieties and two subspecies.
There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name.

The previously, monotypic genus Manta was re-evaluated with two species identified, Reef Manta Ray (Manta alfredi) and Giant Manta Ray (Manta birostris) (Marshall et al. 2009). Genetic evidence supported the separation (Kashiwagi et al. 2012). Both species have broad global distributions and are sympatric in some locations and allopatric in others (Kashiwagi et al. 2011, Lawson et al. 2017). A third species of manta ray has also been proposed (Marshall et al. 2009) with increasing genetic support (Hinojosa-Alvarez et al. 2016, Kashiwagi et al. 2017, Hosegood et al. 2018). Genetic evidence has also resulted in the genus Manta being subsumed within the genus Mobula (Poortvliet et al. 2015, White et al. 2018).

Due to the recent taxonomic changes, both present day and historical reports can often be unclear and without adequate descriptions, photographs or geographic locations, it can be difficult to conclusively attribute fisheries data to a single species. Care should be taken when using reports or accounts of the Giant Manta Ray. Melanistic (black) and leucistic (white) colour morphs occur in all species of manta ray (Marshall et al. 2009). Variant colour morphs often contribute an added degree of confusion when attempting to visually discriminate between species of manta rays in the field or in photographs, especially when close examination is not possible. It should be noted that these colour morphs could be a source of error, resulting in misidentifications in past or future studies or surveys of distribution.
This species' eastern Pacific distribution is now known as R. samoensis.
Arachis diogoi Hoehne is a secondary wild relative of peanut (A. hypogaea L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Arachis magna Krapov., W.C.Greg. & C.E.Simpson is a secondary wild relative of peanut (A. hypogaea L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Arachis villosa Benth. is a secondary wild relative of peanut (A. hypogaea L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).

Gossypium barbadense L. is a primary wild relative of cotton, G. hirsutum L. and Sea Island cotton, G. barbadense L., and a tertiary wild relative of short-staple cotton, G. herbaceum L and tree cotton, G. arboreum L. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

Gossypium mustelinum Miers ex G.Watt is in the subgenus Karpas (Wendel et al. 2010). According to Vincent et al. (2013) it is a primary wild relative of Tree Cotton, (Gossypium arboreum L.), Sea Island Cotton (Gossypium barbadense L.), Short-staple Cotton (Gossypium herbaceum L.) and New World Cotton (Gossypium hirsutum L.). However, Fryxell (1979) shows that G. mustelinum has 52 chromosomes, the same number as Sea Island Cotton and New World Cotton, and Wendel and Grover (2015) show it has the AD genome, the same as these species, suggesting that it is likely to be a secondary genetic of Sea Island Cotton and New World Cotton, but a tertiary genetic relative of short-staple cotton and Tree Cotton.
Panicum stramineum Hitchc. & Chase is a secondary wild relative and potential breeding donor of broom millet, Panicum miliaceum L. ssp. miliaceum (Vincent et al. 2013).

Phaseolus lunatus var. silvester is included in this assessment, because it is the wild form. P. lunatus var.lunatus is the cultivated form and therefore is excluded.

In its wild form, Phaseolus lunatus L. is a primary wild relative of Lima Bean, the cultivated form of the species.

Phaseolus viridis, including P. longiplacentifer, is here considered a synonym of Phaseolus lunatus var. silvester.

Sorghum arundinaceum (Desv.) Stapf is a primary wild relative of sorghum, S. bicolor (L.) Moench, and Sudan grass, S. x drummondii (Nees ex Steud.) Millsp. & Chase (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019).
Trabalho recente alocou espécies de Anolis em diferentes gêneros (Nicholson et al. 2012), mas não foi amplamente aceito.

Trabalho recente alocou espécies de Anolis em diferentes gêneros (Nicholson et al. 2012), mas não foi amplamente aceito. Existem problemas de identificação entre A. philopunctatus e A. punctatus, principalmente de fêmeas, o que leva a algumas incertezas quanto aos limites de distribuição das espécies.
Trabalho recente alocou espécies de Anolis em diferentes gêneros (Nicholson et al. 2012), mas não foi amplamente aceito.

authority: Ribeiro, Nogueira, Cintra, da Silva & Zaher, 2011

taxonomicNotes: This is a monotypic species (Tribe 2015).

Six subspecies of Poa pratensis L. are native to Europe: P. pratensis ssp. colpodea (Th. Fr.) Tzvelev, P. pratensis ssp. dolichophylla (Hack.) Portal, P. pratensis ssp. irrigata (Lindm.) H. Lindb., P. pratensis ssp. jordanii Portal, P. pratensis L. ssp. pratensis, and P. pratensis ssp. turfosa (Litv.) Vorosch. (Valdés and Scholz; with contributions from Raab-Straube and Parolly 2009).
Tepuihyla phasmatus has been synonymized with this species (Jungfer et al. 2013).
Revised by Kuntner (2007), known from both sexes, illustrated.
Confused with and by some authors as it was considered a subspecies of Anax longipes until 1960s.
This species is the sister taxon of the also extinct, but insular, Falklands Wolf (Dusicyon australis).
This complex has recently been separated into three species: B. lacertus, B. antilliensis, and B. soporator (Tornabene et al. 2010).

Recent genetic evidence suggests three distinct lineages in the eastern Atlantic that may represent distinct species (Galvan-Quesada et al. 2016, Guiamaes-Costa et al. 2017). Recognition of these lineages at the species level would considerably reduce the range extent of this species, and would likely warrant reassessment.
Eleotris perniger has generally been reported as E. pisonis, but the latter is a continental South American species ranging only from southern Brazil to eastern Venezuela (Pezold and Cage 2002).

Heemstra and Heemstra (2004) describes the taxonomy of the Mugilidae family as confused and the genera as obscurely defined. 

Misidentification with Mugil gaimardianus, now an invalid species, has caused much confusion in the past.  

Currently, the most frequent misidentication is with Mugil rubrioculus (Harrison et al. 2007). Mugil curema and M. rubrioculus are very similar morphologically. They are clearly separated genetically both by karyotype and molecular analysis (Nirchio et al. 2005, Fraga et al. 2007, Gonzalez-Castro et al. 2009). 

Fraga et al. (2007) identified two species occurring along the Brazilian coast, Mugil curema type I (Mugil rubrioculus) and Mugil curema type II and showed that their distribution overlaps in most of their distribution. Therefore, species identification in landings and ecological studies may confuse the two species in Brazil.
This species was previously thought to be confused with C. mexicanus off Sao Paulo State (Brazil), however, it is now known these two species do not co-occur in this area.

Gonzalez Castro et al. (2008) found morphological and genetic differences between Mugil cephalus from the Mediterranean coast and M. liza/M. platanus from the Southwestern Atlantic coast. According to Fraga et al. (2007), M. liza and M. platanus should be treated as a single species or even subpopulations of M. cephalus. Heras et al. (2009) found that M. platanus and M. liza represent a continuum of a single species that is closely related to but distinct from M. cephalus, which itself appears to comprise a grouping of multiple and closely related species.

According to Menezes et al. (2010), only one species of lebranche mullet exists in the Caribbean Sea region and off the Atlantic coast of South America, with Mugil liza as the appropriate name. Considering the above, M. liza and M. platanus are considered the same species and the adopted name is M. liza. Mugil cephalus does not occur in the Southwestern Atlantic (Menezes et al. 2010).
This species is easily confused with Centropomus parallelus (Orrell FAO report).
Records of this species from Brazil represent an undescribed species.

Macrodon ancylodon is genetically distinct from the previously known southwestern population (Santos et al. 2006), which is now distinguished as M. atricauda (Günther, 1880) (Carvalho-Filho et al. 2010).
