There is some uncertainty over the taxonomy and distribution of Ceratopteris thalictroides and C. cornuta. Verdcourt (1999) includes the two as a single taxon, with justification. Al Khulaidi (in prep.) lists only C. cornuta from Yemen, while Hassler and Schmidt (2011) list them as separate species, with C. thalictroides absent from the Arabian Peninsula and C. cornuta occurring in Oman and Yemen (including Soqotra), as does The Plant List. For now, the two taxa are assessed separately for the IUCN Red List.

Several recent molecular studies have provided support for a monophyletic assemblage of South American endemic canids (Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005, Perini et al. 2010), with Chrysocyon and Speothos forming a sister-clade to the monophyletic South American foxes and Atelocynus. On the basis of morphology, Zunino et al. (1995) reviewed previous work and also supported clustering species within the two previous paraphyletic genera (Pseudalopex, Lycalopex) into a single monophyletic genus. They further argued that Lycalopex had priority over Pseudalopex, subsequently also supported by Zrzavý et al. (2004: 324). The only outstanding question would have been whether Dusicyon would have been a more appropriate name, since Perini et al. (2010) reported a close relationship between L. culpaeus and Dusicyon. However, we now know that Dusicyon is far outside this clade (Slater et al. 2009, Austin et al. 2013). Based on this evidence, the genus Lycalopex is used over Pseudalopex for all South American foxes, following Wozencraft's (2005) earlier treatment.

Two morphometric studies (Zunino et al. 2005, Prevosti et al. 2013) have suggested that Lycalopex gymnocercus and the Chilla (L. griseus) belong to the same species, with clinal differences in size. However, as Prevosti et al. (2013) note, most genetic studies have not recovered the two species as a monophyletic group (although see Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005). Given this uncertainty, and since both species are in any event assessed as Least Concern, we provisionally continue to recognize Pampas Fox and Chilla as two distinct species, pending further taxonomic investigations.

authority: Lim, Engstrom, Reid, Simmons, Voss and Fleck, 2010

taxonomicNotes: This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has been moved to the resurrected genus Hyloscirtus (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This genus has recently been moved from the family Hylidae (Faivovich et al. 2005).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla but has recently been moved to the new genus Ecnomiohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005). Comparisons of DNA sequences, external morphology, and advertisement calls between Tepuihyla tuberculosa from Ecuador and Peru indicate that a Peruvian specimen represents Tepuihyla shushupe (Ron et al. 2016).

authority: Peloso, Sturaro, Forlani, Gaucher, Motta & Wheeler, 2014
taxonomicNotes: When Syncope carvalhoi Nelson 1975 was transferred to Chiasmocleis, the existing C. carvalhoi (Cruz et al. 1997) became a homonym and hence a replacement name was assigned to it by Peloso et al. (2014).
This species is a complex of several species. Specimens from Paraguay, Argentina and Uruguay have been separated from Elachistocleis ovalis as E. bicolor (Lavilla et al. 2003).

It was previously within the genus Hypsiboas, recently considered to be a junior synonym of Boana, and therefore transferred to this genus (Faivovich et al. 2005, Dubois 2017). 

The taxonomy and synonymy of this name is convoluted and unstable. It certainly includes many species (Hoogmoed and Gruber 1983, Lima et al. 2019, Sturaro et al. 2020). The name Hypsiboas hobbsi has been employed for Venezuelan specimens (e.g. McDiarmid and Paolillo 1988). Based on molecular evidence, there appears to be two species under this binomial within the Colombian subpopulations (Guarnizo et al. 2016).

This species was previously within the genus Hyla, then was moved to the resurrected genus Hypsiboas (Faivovich et al. 2005) and subsequently to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). The 2004 and 2008 assessments reported this species from Entre Ríos and Buenos Aires provinces, Argentina; however there are no published or collection specimens of the species occurring in that area (D. Baldo and J. Faivovich pers. comms. 2018).

Descrita em: Allemão e C., 1860. Journal of the Linnean Society, Botany 4(Suppl.): 36.Popularmente conhecida por Jacarandá-caviuna, Jacarandá-da-Bahia no Brasil ou Brazilian rosewood (nome comercial em ingles) (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019). Pode ser também conhecida como jacarandá preto, caviúna, cabiúna, cabiúna rajada, cabiúna do mato, jacarandá, jacarandá cabiúna, jacarandá una, pau preto, jacarandá rajado, camborá, camburana, graúna, caviúna roxa, jacarandazinho, uraúna, imiraúna (IPEF, 2019)

Pristimantis sp. “J” from the summit of Mount Roraima in Venezuela (see McDiarmid and Donnelly 2005) could be P. aureoventris, but tissue samples and specimens are necessary to corroborate this assumption (Jablonski et al. 2017).

Previously a circumtropical species, Trachinocephalus myops was recently separated into three species: T. myops, restricted to the Atlantic Ocean; T. trachinus, known from throughout the Indo-West Pacific; and T. gauguini restricted to the Marquesas Islands (Polanco et al. 2016). The geographic range of T. myops has therefore been reduced considerably.
This species can be misidentified with Pomadasys corvinaeformis.

Recently, Caranx hippos from the eastern Atlantic and Mediterranean was split into two species. A new species, Caranx fischeri, was described by Smith-Vaniz and Carpenter (2007). Caranx hippos and C. fischeri are largely sympatric, however it is C. fischeri which is found in the Mediterranean. There have been no confirmed records of C. hippos in the Mediterranean.

According to Catalog of Fishes and Kong and Valdes (1990), Micropogonias manni, which is known to occur only in Chile, may be a junior synonym of M. furnieri. This is not correct, as M. manni is valid, but with nomen dubium (uncertain name). Micropogonias furnieri does not occur in Chile. Specimens collected from Lago Budi, southern Chile (N.L. Chao, 15 March 2011, deposited at the Museo Nacional de Historia Natural, Santiago, Chile) are distinct from M. manni. Taxonomic work on the East Pacific Micropogonias species is needed (N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2020).

Variations in body depth, eye size, etc., of individuals collected throughout this range suggest that more systematic work is needed on this taxon (Munroe 2002). It may be a synonym of Harengula clupeola (B. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2012).

In a revision of the genus Cyclopsetta, Khidir et al. (2004) noted variation in several characters between specimens of C. fimbriata from the Gulf of Mexico and those from the Caribbean Sea. However, they indicated that more specimens were needed to address the question of whether or not more than one species is represented by these specimens. To date, no further studies have addressed this question and it is the position herein that only one species is represented by all the material examined by Khidir et al. (2004).
This species has been previously confused with Strongylura marina (Collette 1968).

This species is a complex of more than one species. Diploid populations in Cordoba, Argentina were recently separated from the tetraploid nominal form americanus to create the species Odontophrynus cordobae (Martino and Sinsch 2002). Earlier records of O. americanus from Bolivia refer to an undescribed species and are not included here. Other diploid populations elsewhere in the range of O. americanus might represent new species.
This species was previously within the genus Agalychnis but has since been moved to the genus Cruziohyla (Faivovich et al. 2005).
This is a poorly circumscribed species in need of taxonomic review (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.). It is unclear that all populations are conspecific.
Calidris pugnax (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Philomachus.
Considerable evidence suggests that this nominal species is composed of several biological species.

This species was removed from synonymy of Osteocephalus taurinus by Duellman and Mendelson (1995). Further revision of available Osteocephalus collections revealed that the specimens of Osteocephalus reported from Jaú National Park by Gordo and Neckel-Oliveira (2004) actually represent O. vilarsi (Ferrão et al. 2019).
This form might consist of more than one species.

This species was discovered in 2013 (Fiejo et al. 2013). Although, there appears to be some taxonomic debate as this species is listed as synonymous with C. prehensilis due to lack of sequence data (Voss 2013).

Several recent molecular studies have provided support for a monophyletic assemblage of South American endemic canids (Lindblad-Toh et al. 2005, Perini et al. 2010), with Chrysocyon and Speothos forming a sister-clade to the monophyletic South American foxes and Atelocynus. On the basis of morphology, Zunino et al. (1995) reviewed previous work and also supported clustering species within the two previous paraphyletic genera (Pseudalopex, Lycalopex) into a single monophyletic genus. They further argued that Lycalopex had priority over Pseudalopex, subsequently also supported by Zrzavý and Řičánkova (2004). This raises the question of whether Dusicyon would have been a more appropriate name, since Perini et al. (2010) reported a close relationship between L. culpaeus and Dusicyon. However, we now know that Dusicyon is far outside this clade (Slater et al. 2009, Austin et al. 2013). Based on this evidence, the genus Lycalopex is used over Pseudalopex for all South American foxes, following Wozencraft's (2005) earlier treatment.

Faivovich et al. (2013) described Myersiohyla neblinaria based on the external morphology of adults and tadpoles, on bioacoustical analyses of advertisement calls, and on molecular phylogenetic evidence. They also commented on the phylogenetic relationships of this species with M. chamaeleo and M. kanaima, and redefined M. neblinaria as the type species for the genus after confirming that the specimen from Cerro La Neblina, miss-identified as M. inparquesi by Faivovich et al. (2005), was M. neblinaria.

This species is distinct from Cynomops planirostris; see Williams and Genoways (1980), Barquez et al.(1993), and Simmons and Voss (1998). Recently, it was distinguished from C. milleri too (Eger 2008). Cynomops generally is regarded as either a monophyletic genus or, in some cases, a subgenus of Molossops. In the molecular analysis, species traditionally included within Molossops and Cynomops each comprised two well-supported monophyletic lineages. The data also support the recognition of Cynomops and Molossops as divergent lineages worthy of generic status. Species limits and phylogenetic relationships within Cynomops, however, remain unresolved (Peters et al. 2002).
Cynomops milleri was previously included within C. paranus. Now it is considered a distinct species.
This species was previously treated as a subspecies of E. bonariensis (see Simmons 2005, Eger 2008).
Previously Pteronotus rubiginosus this was included as a subspecies Pteronotus parnellii. It has now been raised to species level.

Based on the morphological distinction observed between A. g. peruana and A. g. geoffroyi, as well as the ecological differentiation of the areas inhabited by these two taxa, Mantilla-Meluk and Baker (2010) elevated A. peruana to specific level.
This species was previously included under Carollia castanea, it is now considered a distinct species (Solari and Baker 2006).
The species was previously included within Lepus. obscura, it is now recognized as a valid species (Gardner 2008).

authority: Siles, Brooks, Aranibar, Tarifa, Vargas, Rojas & Baker, 2013

taxonomicNotes: Previously, this species was considered as part of L. bokermanni, which is now restricted to the Cerrado formations of Brazil (Dias et al. 2013).
Previously this species was included within Lasiurus blossevillii, it is now considered a distinct species (Gardner 2008).
This species has been split from P. helleri (Velazco et al. 2010).
Gardnerycteris crenulatum could be a species complex and a systematic review is needed (Patterson and Tavares pers. comm). This species does not include koepckeae.

This name is often spelled caudifera but the correct spelling is caudifer according to the Code of the International Commission on Zoological Nomenclature (Simmons 2005). Based on morphological and distributional differences between A. caudifer caudifer and A. c. aequatoris, Mantilla-Meluk and Baker (2006) elevated the latter to specific level.

Mitochondrial DNA restriction analysis reveals that genetic differentiation occurs between populations inhabiting the Mediterranean Sea and the tropical Atlantic Ocean, indicating that little genetic exchange occurs between the two (Kotoulas et al. 1995).

Recent study of mitochondrial DNA by Viñas et al. (2010) found further differentiation between populations in the eastern and western Mediterranean Sea.

It is possible that the subpopulations of this form comprise more than one species (J. Icochea pers comm.). Taylor (1968) recognized two subspecies. The taxonomy of the genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm.).

The species was described by Thomas (1900) and considered a subspecies of M. impavidus by Cabrera (1958), until Diaz-Nieto et al. (2011) recognized it as a distinct, valid species. This has been later validated by Díaz-Nieto and Voss (2016), and Díaz Nieto et al. (2016) (but see Gardner and Creighton 2008, Astúa 2015). The taxon apparently includes (at least) two different forms (subspecies?), of which the names caucae and madescens can be used to tentatively assign each one (a northern clade M. caucae caucae, and a southern clade M. caucae madescens) (Díaz-Nieto et al. 2016).

This species was resurrected from synonymy by Heyer (1985). This species appears to be synonymous with Vitreorana uranoscopa. Therefore, there are taxonomic problems that do not allow the species to be correctly assessed (Brazilian Red List Assessment Workshop 2021).

Dasyprocta croconota Wagler, 1831 “Brasilia ad flumen Amazonum” emended by Iack-Ximenes (1999) to Santarém, Rio Tapajós, Pará, Brazil.  Thomas 1923 previously recognized this species as a subspecies of  D. aguti [D. leporina herein] This species is monotypic.

A full list of synonyms are available at the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (WCSP 2016). Eragrostis domingensis (Pers.) Steud is an accepted species in some African floras, for example in the Flora of West Tropical Africa (Hutchinson and Dalziel 1972) but is listed as a synonym of E. prolifera in WCSP (2016).

The genus Trichopodus was recently considered valid from popular synonym Trichogaster. Its previous family; Belontiidae was merged into Osphronemidae based on phylogenetic research undertaken by R. Britz (pers. comm. 2011).

Laterallus spilopterus (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously in the genus Porzana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014). Stervander et al. (2019) found that Inaccessible Rail Atlantisia rogersi, Dot-winged Crake Porzana spiloptera and Yellow-breasted Crake Hapalocrex flaviventer nest within a clade of Laterallus crakes, with the first two grouped closely with Black Rail Laterallus jamaicensis. It thus appears appropriate to move all three species to the genus Laterallus, and this option is adopted by BirdLife.

Lopes et al. (2018) established a new genus for the species following confirmation that it is more closely related to Sublegatus than to Suiriri suiriri, and that there are significant and consistent differences from the three members of Sublegatus. Hence the proposed new genus Guyramemua Lopes et al. 2018 is accepted by the BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group, hence Suiriri affinis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) becomes Guyramemua affinis (HBW and BirdLife International (2019).

Previously Suiriri affinis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was newly described as Suiriri islerorum by Zimmer et al. (2001). However, the type specimen of S. affinis previously believed to belong to S. suiriri was subsequently shown to relate to this species, and takes precedence (Kirwan et al. 2014).
Furnarius leucopus, F. longirostris and F. cinnamomeus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously listed as F. leucopus following SACC (2005 & updates) and Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Sciaphylax hemimelaena (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Myrmeciza hemimelaena.
Hirundinea ferruginea and H. bellicosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. ferruginea following SACC (2005 & updates).
Xiphorhynchus guttatus and X. guttatoides (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. guttatus following SACC (2005 & updates).
Phyllomyias burmeisteri and P. zeledoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. burmeisteri following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates)

Suiriri suiriri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) and the previously named S. affinis remain lumped following SACC (2005), however the type of S. s. affinis has been shown to refer to the form subsequently described as Chapada Flycatcher (previously S. islerorum), hence the latter receives the name S. affinis and the subspecies formerly described as S. s. affinis takes the new name S. s. burmeisteri Kirwan 2014.

Setopagis parvula (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus. Caprimulgus parvula (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously split into C. parvula and C. heterurus following SACC (2006).

Geranoaetus polyosoma (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Buteo. Buteo poecilochrous (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993; Stotz et al. 1996) was also lumped with B. polyosoma following SACC (2006).
Aratinga solstitialis and A. maculata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. solstitialis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Myrmelastes humaythae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Schistocichla humaythae.
Myrmelastes rufifacies (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Schistocichla rufifacies.
Microspingus lateralis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Poospiza following SACC (2005 & updates).
Malacoptila striata and M. minor (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. striata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Systellura longirostris, S. decussata and S. roraimae (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus and lumped as C. longirostris following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Pyrrhura picta, P. snethlageae, P. parvifrons, P. amazonum, P. lucianii, P. roseifrons, P. peruviana, P. subandina, P. caeruleiceps and P. eisenmanni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. picta following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Prior to that, M. guatemalae, plus M. atricapilla and M. hoyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014), had been placed in the genus Otus and were treated as two species; O. atricapillus (including guatemalae and hoyi) and O. vermiculatus, following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Rallus longirostris, R. crepitans and R. obsoletus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. longirostris following AOU (2000). Rallus elegans and R. tenuirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as R. elegans following AOU (2000). Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) included tenuirostris within R. longirostris.
Pionites leucogaster, P. xanthomerius and P. xanthurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. leucogaster following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pionites leucogaster, P. xanthomerius and P. xanthurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. leucogaster following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Pionites leucogaster, P. xanthomerius and P. xanthurus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. leucogaster following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Galbula albirostris and G. chalcocephala (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as G. albirostris following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

This species was previously within the genus Phrynohyas which was recently synonymized with Trachycephalus (Faivovich et al. 2005).

Considering its wide distribution and known variation, the many subpopulations under this name require a careful taxonomic reassessment, as very likely more than one species is currently included under this name (J. Faivovich pers. comm. October 2018).

Apostolepis borellii has variously been considered either a valid species or a junior synonym of A. nigroterminata, with recent authors generally adopting the latter scheme (De Lema and Renner 2016). De Lema and Renner (2016) examined the holotypes of both taxa together with new material from Matto Grosso, and resurrected A. borellii as a validly distinct species.

authority: Passos, Texeira Jr, Recoder, de Sena, dal Vechio, de Arruda Pinto, Mendonça, Cassimiro & Rodrigues, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Atractus spinalis é uma espécie descrita recentemente para a Serra do Cipó por Passos et al. (2013), a espécie é morfologicamente similar a A. paraguayensis e A. potschi,  das quais se difere principalmente a partir de caracteres exclusivos de coloração (número e forma das bandas transversais), da morfologia hemipeniana (face mediana dos lobos sem ornamentação) além de diferenças merísticas (número de escamas ventrais e dentes maxilares) e morfométricas (comprimento rostro-cloacal dos adultos). Esta encontra-se alocada no grupo de espécies de A. paraguayensis (Passos et al. 2013).

authority: Pires, da Silva Jr, Feitosa, Costa-Prudente, Preira-Filho & Zaher, 2014

taxonomicNotes: This species has previously been included in Clelia rustica (Cope, 1878) on some occasions.

A.L. Silveira (pers. comm. 2010) considers this species a junior synonym of Tantilla pallida based on work in preparation to revise this widespread species complex. This work has still not been published as of 2019, and consequently this taxon is considered valid pending a formal taxonomic revision (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).

The taxonomy of the genus Zannichellia is complex, with one species recognised throughout much of the World but many taxa recognised at or below species level in different regions. The distinguishing characters for some taxa appear to be useful, but others appear to have been described based on very few samples and relatively minor morphological differences. Most taxa described to-date are treated as Z. palustris by Kew (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010).

Multivariate analysis of morphometric data based on the Czech material did not support existence of any morphologically distinguishable taxa (Kaplan 2010).

There is some evidence that Brevoortia aurea and B. pectinata may be synonyms (Cosseau and Diaz de Astarloa 1993, Garcia et al. 2008). However, for the purposes of this assessment, B. aurea and B. pectinata will be treated as two separate species.

The taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. Garcia Perea (1994) proposed that this species be subdivided into three separate species (Lynchailurus colocolo, L. pajeros, and L. braccatus) based on morphological traits. This was provisionally followed by Wozencraft (2005). However, genetic analysis supports the existence of populations subdivision in this species, but not at the species level (Johnson et al. 1999). The genetic partitioning (Uruguay and southern Brazil; Bolivia and northern Chile; and western Argentina and central Chile: Johnson et al. 1999) is somewhat different from the divisions recognized by Garcia-Perea (1994) on the basis of morphology (central Chile; the Andes from Ecuador and south to through Argentina; and Uruguay, Paraguay and Brazil). Moreover, Cossios and Angers (2007) found six highly divergent clades in genetic analysis of Andean populations (Peru, Bolivia and Argentina). Subspeciation and geographic divisions in this species requires further study. Placed in the genus Leopardus by Johnson et al. (2006).

A zone of hybridization between L. colocolo and L. tigrinus has been found through genetic analyses of specimens from central Brazil (Johnson et al. 1999, Eizirik et al. 2007).
This species is called abrasus in Hall and Kelson (1959), but see Husson (1962) and Hall (1981). Also see Best et al. (2002). The Jamaican form was reviewed by Timm and Genoways (2003).

This taxonomic concept does not include trumbulli; see Eger (1977). The large geographic gap between the North American and South American ranges of this taxon suggests that this complex may include more than one species (Simmons 2005).
This species can be called Tadarida molossa but see Husson (1962).

This species was originally described as different from other small Artibeus (sensu Handley 1987), but Koopman (1994) listed it as a synonym of A. cinereus (under A. c. pumilio, along with glaucus). However, the characters used in the original description clearly differentiated it from similar taxa, and most recent authors (Simmons 2005) listed it as distinct. Molecular analyses (Hoofer et al. 2008, Solari et al. 2009) also validate this distinction.
Status of the subspecies needs to be assessed. This may be species complex (V. Tavares pers. comm.).

Taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. This species is genetically very diverse across its range and shows a high degree of population structure, with four distinct clusters: Central America and Mexico, north-northwest South America, north-northeast South America and southern South America. The demarcation between northern and southern South America was identified as the Amazon river (Eizirik et al. 1998).

The taxonomy is currently under review by the IUCN SSC Cat Specialist Group. While 32 subspecies have been classically described, on the basis of genetic analysis Culver et al. (2000) suggest six subspecies as follows:

P. c. cougar: North America
P. c. costaricensis: Central America
P. c. capricornensis: eastern South America
P. c. concolor: northern South America
P. c. cabrerae: central South America
P. c. puma: southern South America.
The species includes Monodelphis theresa as a synonym (Pavan et al. 2014).
Appeared in IUCN Red Lists from 1996 to 2006 under the incorrectly spelt specific name P. dumeriliana.
Diodon hystrix has a very wide distribution and a genetic analysis is warranted.
Given its extremely wide distribution, genetic studies should be conducted on this species to determine its taxonomic status (Leis, Matsuura and Carpenter pers. comm. 2011).
This species has a very wide distribution and genetic analysis is warranted.

Clams of the genus Corbicula Megerle von Mühlfeld, 1811 are native to Africa, Australia, Asia, and the Middle East; however, as invasive species, they are nowadays distributed worldwide (Araujo et al. 1993).

The status of this species around the world has become confused, as the species range has been expanding rapidly, and it has also been interbreeding with other native species throughout the world.

In Japan Okawa et al. (2016) noted androgenetic Corbicula species including C. leana and C. fluminea, show a phenomenon called “egg parasitism” in which the DNA content of spermatozoa is identical to that of somatic cells, but mtDNA is maternal (Houki et al. 2011). Because C. fluminea releases larger amount of sperm than C. leana, a C. leana population could potentially be replaced with a population possessing nuclear DNA of C. fluminea via unilateral hybridization caused by certation (Sonohara 2005). However due to limits of their methodology they could not evaluate the species hybridization between C. fluminea and C. leana.

In the Pristimantis (Pristimantis) unistrigatus species group by Hedges et al. (2008), but not assigned to any species group in the last molecular analysis of the New World direct-developing frogs of Padial et al. (2014).

In the Rhinella margaritifera group according to the original publication. This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological and vocalization features (Fouquet et al. 2007).
Tentatively assigned to the Dendropsophus microcephalus group according to the original description (Moravec et al. 2008).
There have been no published papers synonymizing this species in the last five years. There are no taxonomic limitations relevant to taxon validation.

There is some evidence that Brevoortia pectinata and B. aurea may be synonyms (Cosseau and Diaz de Astarloa 1993, Garcia et al. 2008). However, for the purposes of this assessment, B. aurea and B. pectinata will be treated as two separate species.
Based on molecular phylogenetic analysis, Craig and Hastings (2007) consider the species Epinephelus marginatus to be a member of genus Mycteroperca.
Digitaria horizontalis Willd. is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Digitaria insularis (L.) Mez ex Ekman is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).

Digitaria similis Beetle ex Gould is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
This spp. is believed to be a Digitaria sellowii synonym by Kew based in herbarium samples. Nevertheless (Giraldo-Canas pers. comm.) suggests that they are not synonyms, there has not been any formal publication that can back up this.
Echinochloa crus-pavonis (Kunth) Schult is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of White millet/Siberian Millet (Echinochloa frumenlacca Link) (Vincent et al. 2013).

Tripsacum andersonii  (Guatemalan grass) J.R. Gray is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of maize (Zea mays L. ssp. mays) (Vincent et al, 2013) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017). The species is thought to be an intergeneric hybrid between Tripsacum and Zea (de Wet et al. 1983, Talbert et al. 1990, Taba 1995, Li et al. 1999, Lamb and Birchler 2006).
Solanum asperolanatum Ruiz & Pav. is a gene pool tertiary relative of Aubergine/Eggplant, Solanum melongena L. (Vincent et al. 2013).
Solanum viarum Dunal is a tertiary wild relative of aubergine/egg plant, S. melongena L. (Vincent et al. 2013).
Isostichopus macroparentheses, Stichopus badionotus, Stichopus macroparentheses and Stichopus moebii may be synonyms for this species.
Solanum malmeanum Bitter is a tertiary wild relative of potato, S. tuberosum L. (Vincent et al. 2013).

The species was first described by Risso (1810) as Squalus ferox from the type locality at Nice and most early records were from the Mediterranean and eastern North Atlantic. Whitley (1950) described O. herbsti from southeastern Australia, differentiating it from O. ferox mainly on differences in dental formulae, and the absence of pigment spots. Garrick's (1974) account of two specimens from New Zealand cast doubt on any differences in dentition between the species but retained O. herbsti for the plain-coloured Odontaspis.

However, Compagno (1984) reviewed the two species and considered that O. herbsti was a junior synonym of O. ferox, noting (as did Robins et al. 1980) that the presence or absence of spots was highly variable, much as with Carcharias taurus. The existence of spotted specimens outside the Mediterranean Sea, including from California (Seigel and Compagno 1986), is supported by in-situ observations made off Lebanon, New Zealand and Malpelo Island (Columbia), where specimens exhibit considerable variability in the presence, density and size of spots. There may be some regionalised trends controlling the intensity of such pigmentation. In the absence of any further evidence to support the validity of an O. ferox/O. herbsti dichotomy, recognition of the single Odontaspis ferox of Risso, as previously argued by Compagno (1984, 2001), remains valid.

authority: Ruocco, Lucifora, Díaz de Astarloa, Mabragaña & Delpiani, 2012

taxonomicNotes: Epinecrophylla ornata and E. hoffmannsi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previsouly lumped as E. ornata following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Sirystes sibilator, S. albogriseus, S. albocinereus and S. subcansecens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. sibilator following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Contopus cinereus , C. punensis and C. bogotensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. cinereus following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae. Petean et al. (2020) revised Hypanus americanus, separating the newly described species, H. berthalutzae, whose distribution includes the Brazilian coastline from the mouth of the Amazon River to São Paulo State.
The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis and it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

The genus Hypanus formerly was a junior synonym of Dasyatis (Kottelat, 2013); it was resurrected by Last et al. (2016) in their revision of the family Dasyatidae.

This species was mistakenly named Dasyatis macrophthalma in the title of the original description. A correction note was provided by Rosa et al. (2000).

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. The two Western Atlantic species (F. colarensis and F. geijskesi) differ significantly from the other taxa in this genus and may prove to be non-congeneric with the four species from West Africa (Last et al. 2016).

This species is often mistaken with Hypanus guttatus but snout length and pelvic fin shape differ.

Last et al. (2016) placed Dasyatis colarensis, D. garouaensis, D. geijskesi, D. margarita, D. margaritella, and Urogymnus ukpan within their newly described genus Fontitrygon. The two Western Atlantic species (F. colarensis and F. geijskesi) differ significantly from the other taxa in this genus and may prove to be non-congeneric with the four species from West Africa (Last et al. 2016).
Turdus hauxwelli and T. sanchezorum (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. hauxwelli following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Turdus ignobilis, T. debilis and T. arthuri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. ignobilis following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Physalis angulata L. is a tertiary wild relative of Low Ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).

According to USDA, ARS, GRIN (2017) Leptospron adenthum (G.Mey.) A.Delgado is the accepted name for this taxon. Vigna adenantha (G.Mey.) Maréchal, Mascherpa & Stainier and Phaseolus adenanthus G.Mey. are listed as synonyms of Leptospron adenthum (G.Mey.) A.Delgado.

Vigna adenantha (G.Mey.) Maréchal, Mascherpa & Stainier is a wild relative (in Taxon Group 4) of Bambara Groundnut, V. subterranea (L.) Verdc., and of Cowpea, V. unguiculata (L). Walp. (Maxted et al. 2004).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Callimedusa (Duellman et al. 2016).

Subopulations in Serra da Canastra could pertain to a different taxon (R. Brandão pers. comm. 2008).

This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

Originally in the Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis group. Revalidated and redescribed by Caramaschi (2006) based on morphological features and colour patterns, and since transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

The former southern subspecies Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis azurea, known from Argentina, is assessed separately as Pithecopus azureus.

This species was removed from the synonymy of Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis by Brandão (2002). Specimens associated with this name from the Serra do Cipó are not conspecific with the holotype (Brandão 2002). The species was redescribed by Caramaschi (2006). This species has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016). Ramos et al. (2017) found genetic structure along the spatial distribution of the species in the South Espinhaço Mountain Range corresponding to three population groups: northern, central and southern. These groups may represent separate species.

In the Phyllomedusa hypochondrialis group according to the original publication. Phyllomedusa nordestina was distinguished from other similar species by a combination of colour patterns and morphological features (Caramaschi 2006). This species has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).
This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).

This species was first assessed under the generic name Phyllomedusa, but has since been transferred to the genus Pithecopus (Duellman et al. 2016).This form is probably a complex of more than one species that requires taxonomic investigation (Ramos et al. 2019).
This species has two subspecies Staleochlora arcuata arcuata and Staleochlora arcuata iguazuensis.
In order to confirm its species status, a male needs to be collected and compared to those of other Typophyllum species as it might represent a synonym.
There has not been a formal synonymy, however, genetic data have suggested that Oreophrynella dendronastes is a synonym of this species (P. Kok pers. comm. November 2017).

Originally described as Colostethus praderioi (La Marca 1997) and later transferred to Anomaloglossus by Grant et al. (2006) on the basis of phylogenetic evidence combining molecular and phenotypic data. Kok (2010) redescribed the species with additional samples from Guyana. In the Anomaloglossus beebei species group sensu Grant et al. (2017).

This species was originally described on the basis of a single immature female (La Marca 1997). It was redescribed based on new material and direct comparison with the holotype by Kok et al. (2013). 

Like many other Anomaloglossus species, A. roraima displays an impressive intraspecific variation in color pattern. This phenotypic variability, coupled with the fact that the species occurs on different tepuis, could lead to inappropriate taxonomic decisions (i.e., describing subpopulations from different tepuis as new), which has been done in the past with other Pantepui taxa (Kok et al. 2013).

Originally described in the Hyla geographica group (Duellman and Hoogmoed 1992), but later transferred to the Hypsiboas benitezi group of Faivovich et al. (2005). It was then subsequently moved to the genus Boana (Dubois 2017). Barrio-Amorós et al. (2011) considered Hypsiboas angelicus Myers and Donnelly 2008 as a junior synonym of this species.

Removed from the synonymy of Hyla (as Hypsiboas), and placed in the Hypsiboas benitezi Group by Faivovich, et al. (2005, 2006). Dubois (2017) concluded that Boana is the appropriate generic name for Hypsiboas.
Kok et al. (2017) provided a molecular phylogeny and biogeography of eastern Guianan Stefania populations, and noted several unnamed species.

This species is still missing in phylogenetic analyses, and its relationships with others members of the genus are unknown. Two specimens collected in Serra da Mocidade at 960 m asl, state of Roraima, northern Brazil (Moraes et al. 2017) are morphological similar and apparently closely related to S. tamacuarina, but additional molecular analysis is required to fully identify them.

This species belongs to the L. pentadactylus species group, based on molecular phylogeny and non-molecular characters. It also shows, within the L. pentadactyus group, speciation in rocky outcrops (although not restricted in all; see habitat use), a kind of habitat also used for three species in the L. pentadactyus group, to which L. rugosus is related (De Sá et al. 2014).
This taxon was long considered a subspecies of Otophryne robusta, until the taxonomic treatment by Campbell and Clarke (1998).

The species is sometimes incorrectly cited as Epicrionops nigrus. The taxonomy of the genus is in need of revision (M. Wilkinson pers. comm. 2004). The holotype described by Dunn (1942) is lost, and Taylor (1968) designated UCVMB 5360, described by Roze and Solano (1963), as the neotype (as Epicrionops nigrus). Moraes et al. (2017) noted a specimen from the Serra da Mocidade in the Guiana Shield region of northern Brazil, similar to this species but genetically distinct, presumably representing an unnamed species. Return to the genus Rhinatrema after the phylogenetic revision of Maciel et al. (2018).
Centrolene lema and Centrolene papillahallicum have been synonymized under this species by Castroviejo-Fisher et al. (2009), and Kok and Castroviejo-Fisher (2008).
This species has not been seen since its original description.
According to Rosser Garrison, this species is a synonym of Argia tinctipennis.

There are currently 20 subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies polydamas; subspecies lucayus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies cubensis (Dufrane, 1946); subspecies jamaicensis (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies polycrates (Hopffer, 1865); subspecies thyamus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies antiquus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies christopheranus (A. Hall, 1936); subspecies neodamas (Lucas, 1852); subspecies dominicus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies cebriones (Dalman, 1823); subspecies lucianus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies vincentius (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies grenadensis (A. Hall, 1930); subspecies streckerianus (Honrath, 1884); subspecies peruanus (Fuchs, 1954); subspecies atahualpa T. Racheli & Pischedda, 1987; subspecies weyrauchi Lamas, 1998; subspecies renani Lamas, 1998; and subspecies psittacus (J. Molina, 1782).

There are currently seven known subspecies for this species: the nominate subspecies dolicaon; subspecies septentrionalis K. Brown, 1994; subspecies hebreus K. Brown & Lamas, 1994; subspecies tromes (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies cauraensis Möhn, 2002; subspecies deileon (C. Felder & R. Felder, 1865); and subspecies deicoon (C. Felder & R. Felder, 1864).

There are currently twenty subspecies known for this species, according to Warren et al. (2010): the nominate subspecies anchises; subspecies nephalion (Godart, 1819); subspecies stilbon (Kollar, 1839); subspecies alyattes (C. & R. Felder, 1865); subspecies cymochles (Doubleday, 1844); subspecies etias (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies serapis (Boisduval, 1836); subspecies thelios (Gray, [1853]); subspecies humaita D'Abrera, 1981; subspecies osyris (C. & R. Felder, 1861); subspecies drucei (Butler, 1874); subspecies orbignyanus (Lucas, 1852); subspecies foetterlei (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies orinocensis (Rousseau-Decelle, 1960); subspecies marinae Racheli, 1981; subspecies koenigi Racheli, 1989; subspecies bukuti Brévignon, 1998; subspecies farfan Brown, 1994; subspecies marthilia Maza, 1999 and subspecies zygma Lamas, 2001.

There are currently four subspecies reported for this species, following the treatment by  Racheli (2006): the nominate subspecies sesostris; subspecies tarquinius (Boisduval, 1836); susbpecies zestos (Gray, [1853]); and subspecies trinitensis Brown, 1994. Another taxon, zischkai, has been considered a fifth subspecies of this species (Warren et al. 2013), but is considered a synonym of the nominate subspecies by Racheli (2006).
Cercomacroides serva (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Cercomacra serva.

Cercomacroides nigrescens and C. fuscicauda (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Cercomacra nigrescens following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Troglodytes aedon and T. beani (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. aedon following Woods (1993).
Calidris subruficollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Tryngites.
Synallaxis albilora and S. simoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. albilora following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Machaeropterus regulus and M. striolatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. regulus following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Stigmatura napensis and S. bahiae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. napensis (see SACC [2005 and updates]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]).

Sirystes sibilator, S. albogriseus, S. albocinereus and S. subcansecens (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. sibilator following AOU (1998 and supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Knipolegus orenocensis and K. sclateri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as K. orenocensis following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Rhynchocyclus olivaceus and R. aequinoctialis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. olivaceus following AOU (1998 and supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Elaenia pallatangae and E. olivina (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as E. pallatangae following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Schiffornis turdina, S. olivacea, S. stenorhyncha, S. aenea and S. veraepacis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. turdina following AOU (1998 and   supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Schiffornis turdina, S. olivacea, S. stenorhyncha, S. aenea and S. veraepacis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. turdina following AOU (1998 and   supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Epinecrophylla haematonota and E. fjeldsaai (SACC [2005 and updates]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]) have been lumped and subsequently split into E. haematonota and E. amazonica following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

Myrmotherula axillaris (AOU [1998 and supplements]; SACC [2005 and updates]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]) and M. fluminensis (SACC [2005 and updates]; Sibley and Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]) have been lumped and subsequently split into M. axillaris and M. luctuosa following del Hoyo and Collar (2016).

Herpsilochmus rufimarginatus and H. scapularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. rufimarginatus following AOU (1998 and supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Willisornis poecilinotus and W. nigrigula (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as W. poecilinotus following SACC (2005 and updates).
Conopophaga aurita and C. snethlageae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. aurita following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Campylorhamphus procurvoides, C. probatus and C. multostriatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. procurvoides following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Cercomacroides nigrescens and C. fuscicauda (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Cercomacra nigrescens following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Xiphorhynchus ocellatus, X. beauperthuysii and X. chunchotambo (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. ocellatus following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Xenops minutus and X. genibarbis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. minutus following AOU (1998 and supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Ortalis guttata, O. araucuan and O. squamata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. guttata following Stotz et al. (1996) and SACC (2011), and before then were also lumped with O. colombiana as O. guttata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Chlorostilbon mellisugus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split into C. mellisugus and C. melanorhynchus following SACC (2005), and before then lumped as C. mellisugus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Turdus nigriceps and T. subalaris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. nigriceps following SACC (2005 and updates).
Hemitriccus cohnhafti (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Zimmer et al. (2013).
Knipolegus orenocensis and K. sclateri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped asK. orenocensis following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Hylophilus thoracicus and H. griseiventris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. thoracicus following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Future studies of this widespread species are required to more accurately define its taxonomic boundaries.
Future studies are required to more accurately define its taxonomic boundaries.

The International Code of Botanical Nomenclature (ISPT 2012) Art. 11.4 stipulates that for any taxon below the rank of genus, the correct name is the combination of the final epithet of the earliest legitimate name of the taxon in the same rank, with the correct name of the genus or species to which it is assigned. For this reason the superfluous name Myrcia neotomentosa E.Lucas & C.E.Wilson is here placed in synonymy of Myrcia strigipes Mart., the correct name for this taxon.
This species is morphologically similar to Myrcia amazonica and further study is needed to determine if they are conspecific or not (Lucas et al. 2016).
Future studies of this widespread species are required to more accurately define its taxonomic boundaries.

Only a few specimens of Euplassa bahiensis are known, and there are not enough to determine whether E. bahiensis should be placed in E. incana as a subspecies. These species are allopatric and separated by almost 2,000 km, but certain facets of E. bahiensis are reminiscent of E. incana, especially the leaves.
Euplassa incana is assessed seperately.

Descrita em: Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 76(2): 191. 1954 [Jan 1954]. Nomes vernáculos: "carvalho brasileiro" (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019), Cuvatã (PR) (Roderjan 1037), Carvalho-brasileiro, Carvalho-paulista, Carvalho-rosa (SP) (Koscinski 60)
Descrita em: Contr. Gray Herb. 73: 41. 1924. Nome vernáculo: "carvalho do Brasil" (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019).
Descrita em: Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 76(2): 193. 1954 [Jan 1954]
Descrita em: Kew Bull. 53(4): 969. 1998 [23 Dec 1998]
Descrita em: Brittonia 55(1), 61, 2003. É reconhecida pelos frutos relativamente grandes e alongados, e folhas arrendondadas com manchas vermelhas nas superfícies inferiores (Edwards e Prance, 2003).
Oryza alta Swallen is a secondary genetic relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.) (Ge et al., 1999).
O. glumipatula Steud is a primary wild relative of rice (O. sativa L.) and African rice (O. glaberrima Steud.).

We have not been able to see material in sufficient detail to uptake the synonymisation suggested by Rosário et al. (2014) but if this Myrcia uniflora is synonymous with Calyptranthes moaensis Alain, the distribution would be extended to Cuba. Although the two species cannot not be distinguished based on the type descriptions or images, both names should be used until DNA studies are done (B. Holst pers. comm. 2018).

A. montensis was confused with this species. Subgenus Akodon, A. mollis species group (Hershkovitz, 1990) or A. cursor species group (Geise et al. 2001, Rieger et al. 1995). Earlier recognized as a subspecies of arviculoides (Cabrera 1961, Gyldenstolpe 1932), which Reig (1978, 1987) reallocated to Bolomys lasiurus (see Necromys).

This species previously was considered to occur in Argentina; however, the specimens found there are now considered to represent Akodon paranaensis (Christoff et al. 2000). Subgenus Akodon, A. mollis species group (Hershkovitz, 1990). Has been recognized as a species since its description (Cabrera 1961, Gyldenstolpe 1932, Moojen 1952). This species has been most strongly differentiated from other Akodon species based on cytochrome b sequences by Geise et al. (2001). D’Elía et al. (2003) found a single example of A. serrensis to be genetically most similar to Thaptomys nigrita. The taxonomy of this species remains uncertain, further research is required.
Necromys urichi is considered a species complex; a taxonomic review is underway which will result in several new species (M. Gómez-Laverde pers. comm.).
Includes minor.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Silva et al. (2003) have suggested that B. breviceps is extinct at the type locality and confined to the more mesic Atlantic Forest zone.

The taxonomy of this species is in need of revision (J. Dunnum pers. comm.). C. callosus is the species inhabiting the Chaco and associated habitats in southeastern Bolivia (Salazar-Bravo et al. 2003). The populations of Bolivia (Beni) could be a different and unknown species (G. D'Elia pers. comm.)
There appear to be no genetic differences between the northern and southern Venezuelan populations (Martino et al. 2000, Martino and Capanna 2002).
The records found in Uruguay should be taxonomically reviewed (G. D'Elias pers. comm.).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Ctenomys nattereri is treated here as being conspecific with this species (some authors consider it to be a subspecies) hence its distribution extends to Brazil (Cook and Yates 1994).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
The genus needs taxonomic revision.
Voss and Carleton (1993) propose Holochilus magnus as the same as Hesperomys molitor and synonymize these as Lundomys molitor.
Holochilus sciureus may include a species complex.
Apparently closely related to nigricans.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
This taxon needs taxonomic revision because it may contain several species.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Was in the Red List Oryzomys utiaritensis. The above was treated as a synonym by Musser & Carleton in Wilson and Reeder (1993).

Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
The species is in need of revision; it is likely a species complex (M. Weksler pers. comm.).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). Probably includes a complex species (Patton pers. comm.).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006) and probably includes a species complex.
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). Probably includes a species complex.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

This species has been assigned various generic associations; ncluded in Microxus or Akodon (Cabrera 1961, Ellerman 1941, Gyldenstolpe 1932, Moojen 1952); reallocated to Oxymycterus by Massoia (1963) and thereafter classified (Musser and Carleton 1993); recently assigned to the new genus Brucepattersonius by Hershkovitz (1998) - the Argentinian populations are doubted to belong to this species Hershkovitz (1998). An allocation supported by Bonvicino et al. (1998) and Mares and Braun (2000).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Might include more than one species (Davalos 2006). The species is under taxonomic review and will be split into two species at Panama, the southern population is P. personatus (L. Davalos pers. comm.). Often placed in the subgenus Chilonycteris (e.g., Smith 1972, Simmons and Conway 2001), but recent molecular studies suggest that it represents an unnamed subgenus (Lewis-Oritt et al. 2001, Van Den Bussche and Weyandt 2003).
This species needs taxonomic revision.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.
Genus was recently split from Tonatia.
Also known as Wilfredomys pictipes or Thomasomys pictipes (see Musser and Carleton 2005).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). Pires-Costa (2003) indicates that the megacephalus complex may contain two species, on either side of the Amazon River.
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). This species includes Oryzomys intermedia and O. kelloggi.
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006). O. buccinatus and O. ratticeps are synonyms of S. angouya (Weksler et al. 2006).

Subgenus Akodon, A. cursor species group (Rieger et al. 1995). Originally named as a subspecies of A. arviculoides, a ranking observed by Gyldenstolpe (1932) and Cabrera (1961). Where A. cursor and A. montensis occur in proximity, the latter species is found at higher elevations, 800 m and above (Geise et al. 2001). Past reports for this species in Uruguay (e.g., Ximénez and Langguth 1970) have proven to be A. reigi (González et al. 1998).

The taxonomic status unresolved. It was demoted to subspecies under Akodon obscurus (Cabrera, 1961) or placed in full synonymy with Bolomys l. lasiurus (Macêdo and Mares, 1987), or generally if equivocally recognized as a species (Anderson 1997, Anderson and Olds 1989, Galliari and Pardiñas 2000, Reig 1987). Anderson (1997) maintained tapiropoanus, type locality in Mato Grosso, W Brazil, as a subspecies for Bolivian populations. Also see remarks under N. lasiurus. It was previously known in Peru as Bolomys lasiurus, collected in Pampas del Heath (Pacheco et al. 1995).
Oryzomys is a generic synonym (Weksler et al. 2006).
It was considered a synonym of O. microtus by Carleton and Musser (1999).
It is considered a species complex (Musser and Carleton 2005)
There is a possibility that Stegastes fuscus and Stegastes dorsopunicans are the same species, in which case the species would be called S. fuscus (Lavett-Smith 1997).

Seven geographic subspecies were recognized by Collette and Parin (1970):

Platybelone argalus argalus from the western Atlantic;
P. a. lovii from the Cape Verde Islands;
P. a. annobonensis from Annobón and Fernando Po islands in the Gulf of Guinea;
P. a. trachura from Ascension and St. Helena;
P. a. platyura in most of the Indo-West Pacific;
P. a. platura in the Red Sea and Persian Gulf; and
P. a. pterura from the eastern Pacific.
The Azores population is of taxonomic interest (B. Collette pers. comm. 2012).

Although considered a worldwide species by previous authors, T. lepturus is now known with certainty only from the western Atlantic and Indo-west Pacific. The eastern Atlantic population reported as this species is probably an undescribed species. There are multiple lines of evidence showing geographically-correlated divergence and supporting the treatment of at least 3 species in the T. lepturus complex (Chakrabarty and Iwatsuki 2006, Hsu et al. 2009). 

Trichiurus japonicus, which was originally described from Japan as Trichiurus lepturus japonicus, was synonymized with Trichiurus lepturus. Another nominal species synonymized with Trichiurus lepturus is Trichiurus nitens from the eastern Pacific Ocean (California to Peru).

Gibbs and Staiger (1970) found some minor difference between the western and eastern Atlantic populations of C. cyanopterus (considered at that time as disjunct) in two meristic characters, visible number of vertebrae and number of predorsal scales. Atlantic and Indo-West Pacific populations of C. cyanopterus have been never compared.This species has been historically known as Cypselurus cyanopterus.
Taxonomic note: This species is difficult to distinguish from the closely related Echeneis neucratoides which occurs only in the western central Atlantic (O’Toole 2002)

Recent work indicates significant genetic divergence between specimens from deep waters off Central America and in the Gulf of Mexico, indicating the possibility that the name poeyi may represent two species (Baldwin et al. in press).
The northern populations of this species show genetic differences in comparison to the southern populations, and may be different species (L. Rocha pers. comm. 2014)

According to a redescription of this species by Frable et al. (2013), the taxonomic authority was changed from (Spix and Agassiz, 1829) to (Agassiz, 1829). Additionally, S. intermedius was split into a new species named S. macrostigmus.

This species has been confused with Diodon hystrix (Brito et al. 2002). This latter species is littoral, with a generally brown colouration and rounded anal and dorsal fins; D. eydouxii is, in contrast, a pelagic species, with back and sides blue and belly white, and pointed anal and dorsal fins (Leis 1978). Given its extremely wide distribution, genetic studies are warranted.
This species has a very wide distribution and a genetic analysis is warranted.

Tyler (1980) tentatively recognized four species in this complex that have different distributions, based on his material examined and text: Chilomycterus atringa (western Atlantic); C. reticulatus (eastern Atlantic and Indo-Pacific); C. tigrinus (western Indian Ocean); and C. affinis (Eastern Pacific). However, Tyler (1980) said that C. tigrinus may be the young of C. reticulatus.
This species has a very wide distribution and a genetic analysis is warranted. Leis (1978) noted some differences in spine morphology between Pacific and north Atlantic specimens.
This species was previously known as Pomadasys corvinaeformis and all Haemulopsis species, like Pomadasys, are associated with softbottom habitats (Tavera et al. 2012).

Earlier records may have been recorded as Lampris guttatus or Lampris regius (Hawn and Collette 2012). Southern Ocean records pertain to a second species L. immaculata (Parin and Kukuyev 1983). The species may consist of multiple cryptic species (Hawn and Collette 2012). The correct spelling for the family Lampridae is Lamprididae (Olney in press). Genetic data suggests that there may be several species of Opah (B. Collette pers. comm. 2015). Further conformation of additional species may be found at (Underkoffler et al. 2018).
Some of the specimens listed as C. munozorum by Duellman (1976) have been referred to C. bergeri by Cannatella (1980).

Disjunct populations of S. aurita in the western and eastern Atlantic are in need of further study to determine their taxonomic status (Whitehead 1985). Sardinella brasiliensis is a species which has been described from the southeast Brazilian Bight and is a valid species according to Eschmeyer (Figueiredo et al. 2010). There are reports of sympatric occurrence with S. aurita in the Gulf of Mexico; however, these may be based on misidentifications (Kinsey et al. 1994). We accept the conclusions presented in Tringali and Wilson (1993) that S. brasiliensis is a junior subjective synonym of S. aurita.
This species is commonly misidentified as Seriola rivoliana and S. carpenteri, making market data unreliable (W. Smith-Vaniz pers. comm. 2013).

The name Synodus synodus (Linnaeus 1758) (type locality: "America") has been widely used for this species. Genetic evidence indicates approximately 5-6% divergence in COI between eastern and western Atlantic populations indicating deep population structure or potential cryptic species within its lineage (Frable et al. 2013). This suggests that populations on either side of the Atlantic may represent distinct species. The nominal Synodus atlanticus (Johnson 1863) is currently available for this species.  However, further work is needed to stabilize the nomenclature.

There is molecular and morphological evidence available that Atlantic specimens identified as Antennarius striatus represent a separate species (Antennarius scaber) (Arnold and Pietsch 2012). Work is underway to resurrect the species (R. Arnold pers. comm. 2013).

The higher taxonomy of this species is currently uncertain, though it is currently included in the family Caproidae (Perciformes). However, there is currently no evidence to suggest that the genera Antigonia and Capros belong in the same family (Heemstra in press). Some authors suggest that it should be placed in the Beryciformes due to otolith shape (Zehren 1987).
A geminate species, Chloroscombrus orqueta Jordan and Gilbert, occurs in the eastern Pacific Ocean (Smith-Vaniz FAO ECA Guide in prep).

Taxonomic study needs to be conducted for this species complex. Adults of Uraspis helvola and U. secunda are virtually impossible to distinguish although juvenile characters involving allometric growth patterns suggest that they may be distinct species. If subsequent studies indicate that these two nominal species are conspecific, the oldest available name is Uraspis helvola. A complete description is given only for U. secunda because that name has been widely used for Atlantic Uraspis (Carpenter in prep.).
This species was previously known as Priacanthus cruentatas and Cookeolus boops.
Fistularia petimba has often wrongly been cited as the more common Fistularia commersonii (Randall et al. 1990).
In the field, this species is difficult to distinguish from Stephanolepis setifer (R. Robertson and J. Tyler pers. comm. 2015).
Sphyraena picudilla, considered by some authors to be a different species, is here regarded as a junior synonym of S. borealis (for discussion see Smith-Vaniz et al. 1999).

Pseudophallus brasiliensis Dawson 1974 is a junior synonym of P. mindii. Dawson (1974) originally described P. brasiliensis based on low meristic counts in Brazil compared to the previously described P. mindii. Later research revealed similar or lower counts in other parts of the range of P. mindii, indicating that the two are one and the same (Dawson 1982). From Dawson (1982): "Specimens with low counts from the Amazon drainage were described as P. brasiliensis, but samples with similar or lower counts have subsequently been examined from the Orinoco River and Lake Izabal, Guatemala. In the apparent absence of consistent differences in coloration or other morphological features, these specimens are considered to represent local populations of P. mindii wherein low meristic values result from unknown environmental influences."

The taxonomy of the genus Aotus has been a matter of academic dispute due to the wide number of different karyotypes reported without clear phenotypic distinctions between intra- and inter-population variations (Ruiz-Herrera et al. 2005, Defler and Bueno 2007). Fernandez-Duque et al. (2013), recognized 11 species, and 13 taxa. A preliminary study on the distribution of the Genus Aotus in the Southern Colombian Amazon confirms the presence of A. nancymaae in Colombian territory. The results suggest the existence of a historical distribution of A. nancymaae north of the Amazon River in Colombia, as well as of another population of A. nancymaae, not of historical lineage but probably introduced in Colombia in more recent times (Bloor et al. 2012). Ruiz-García et al. (2011) discuss interesting insights about the evolution of Aotus that is beyond the scope of this description of A. nancymaae. Nevertheless, their evidence suggests that (1) the red-necked/grey-necked split among the Aotus, posited by Hershkovitz (1983) is artificial, since Aotus nancymaae is more related to the grey-necked Aotus than to the other red-necked Aotus and that (2) Aotus vociferans is likely the origin of other modern Aotus species due to its high number of haplotypes and lowest number of chromosomes among the species of the genus.
Descrita em: Bot. Jahrb. Syst. 76(2): 160. 1954 [Jan 1954]. Nome vulgar: "carne-de-vaca" - RJ (Sobrinho, 2007).

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).
Cenchrus latifolius (Spreng.) Morrone is a tertiary wild relative of pearl millet C. americanus (L.) Morrone (syn. Pennisetum glaucum (L.) Br.) (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017).
Daucus pusillus Michx. is a tertiary wild relative of carrot, D. carota subsp. sativus var. sativus Hoffm. and D. carota subsp. sativus var. atrorubens Alef. (USDA, ARS, GRIN 2017)
Digitaria aequiglumis (Hack. & Arechav.) Parodi is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Digitaria lehmanniana Henrard is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Digitaria pittieri (Hack.) is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Digitaria sacchariflora (Raddi) Henrard is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Theobroma obovatum Klotzsch ex Bernoulli is a gene pool tertiary relative of Cacao, Theobroma cacao L. (Vincent et al. 2013).
Theobroma sinuosum Pavón ex Hubber is a gene pool tertiary relative of Cacao, Theobroma cacao L. (Vincent et al. 2013).
Theobroma subincanum Mart. is a gene pool tertiary relative of cacao, Theobroma cacao L. (Vincent et al. 2013).
Tripsacum australe H. C. Cutler & E. S. Anderson is a gene pool Tertiary relative of maize (Zea mays L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).

Xanthosoma helleborifolium is a wild relative of the New Cocoyam, X. sagittifolium (L.)Schott, X. mafaffa Schott and other cultivated Xanthosoma species. According to Croat et al. (2017), X. helleborifolium is classified in TG4 of the X. sagittifolium and X. mafaffa, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006). In addition, Croat et al. (2017) sub-divided the genus into six groups placing X. helleborifolium in a different group (Basisectum) from the related crops, X. sagittifolium and X. mafaffa (group Xanthosoma).

Xanthosoma poeppigii is a wild relative of the New Cocoyam, X. sagittifolium (L.) Schott, X. mafaffa Schott and other cultivated Xanthosoma species. According to Croat et al. (2017), X. poeppigii is classified in TG2 of the X. sagittifolium and X. mafaffa, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006). In addition, Croat et al. (2017) sub-divided the genus into six groups placing X. poeppigii in the same group (Xanthosoma) as the related crops, X. sagittifolium and X. mafaffa.

Xanthosoma pubescens is a wild relative of the New Cocoyam, X. sagittifolium (L.) Schott, X. mafaffa Schott and other cultivated Xanthosoma species. According to Croat et al. (2017), X. pubescens is classified in TG4 of the X. sagittifolium and X. mafaffa, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006). In addition, Croat et al. (2017) sub-divided the genus into six groups placing X. pubescens in a group (Elobatum) different from the related crops, X. sagittifolium and X. mafaffa (group Xanthosoma).

Acanthagrion franciscoi fits none of the species groups defined by Leonard (1977). It keys out to
couplet 7 in Leonard’s key that leads to the viridescens, adustum and chararum groups. It differs
from the species of the viridescens group by having the modifications of genital ligula segment
3 not visible in ectal view. It differs from the species of the adustum group because the distal
part of genital ligula segment 3 is not incised. From the species of the chararum group it differs
by having the cercus slanting forward relative to the paraprocts from base to apex. A. franciscoi
differs from all known species of Acanthagrion by its small size (Rw 13.0 mm, Abd 17 mm),
a character it shares only with A. minutum Leonard, 1977, regarded by Leonard (1977) as the
smallest species of Acanthagrion.
Erythrodiplax ana fits in Borror’s Basalis Group.
Oxyagrion franciscoi is easily distinguished from all other congeners by its dominantly blue colours, a character it shares only with Oxyagrion ablutum (Calvert, 1909).
Synallaxis hellmayri (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Gyalophylax hellmayri.
Myrmelastes leucostigma (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Schistocichla leucostigma.

Xiphorhynchus ocellatus, X. beauperthuysii and X. chunchotambo (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. ocellatus following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Cranioleuca vulpina and C. dissita (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. vulpina following AOU (1998 and supplements) and SACC (2005 and updates).
Hirundinea ferruginea and H. bellicosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. ferruginea following SACC (2005 & updates).
Celeus flavescens and C. ochraceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. flavescens following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Serpophaga subcristata and S. munda (SACC [2005 & updates]; Sibley & Monroe [1990, 1993]; Stotz et al. [1996]) have been lumped and split into S. subcristata and S. griseicapilla following del Hoyo and Collar 2016.

In 2011, von Ellenrieder stated that "Based on observed morphological variability of the diagnostic characters traditionally used to identify species of Microstigma, the three specific names currently used might represent only intraspecific variability", thus Microstigma species may all be M. anomalum synonym.

Pyrrhura leucotis and P. emma (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. leucotis, under which P. griseipectus and P. pfrimeri were also formerly subsumed following (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993).
Cyanocorax coeruleus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as C. caeruleus.
Pygochelidon melanoleuca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Atticora melanoleuca.
Amazilia lactea and A. bartletti (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. lactea following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Descrita em: Kew Bulletin 72(48): 6, figs. 2A–D, 3A–M, 4. 2017. (06 Oct. 2017). Conhecida popularmente como jueirana-facão, a espécie representa somente a segunda espécie do gênero e a única representante na Mata Atlântica (Lewis et al., 2017). Dinizia jueirana-facao difere de sua espécie irmã D. excelsa por ter folíolos em (9 -) 15 - 23 (- 24) pares por pinna (vs 7 - 14 pares), os folíolos completamente glabrosos (vs puberulentos a glabrescentes na face inferior), seus racemos individuais 28 - 35 × 3 - 4,5 cm (vs 10 - 18 × 1 - 2 cm), botões elipsóides a obovóides (vs globosos), flores 8,5 - 10 mm de comprimento (vs 4 - 5 mm de comprimento), suas brácteas florais espatuladas e caducas (vs lanceoladas e frequentemente persistentes), seus frutos lenhosos e deiscentes ao longo de ambas as suturas (vs indeiscentes), sementes 25 - 30 × 16 - 19 mm (vs (10 -) 14 - 15 × 6 - 7 mm ); e pólen em mônadas (vs tetrads) (Lewis et al., 2017).
Herpsilochmus praedictus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized following evidence presented in Cohn-Haft and Bravo (2013).
Scytalopus petrophilus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Whitney et al. (2010).
Scytalopus gonzagi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Maurício et al. (2014).
Lepidocolaptes fatimalimae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Rodrigues et al. (2013).
Tityra leucura (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Pelzeln (1868) and a field sighting in 2006 (Whittaker [2008]).
Cyanocorax hafferi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Cohn-Haft et al. (2013).
Sporophila beltoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was newly described by Repenning and Fontana (2013).
Laniisoma elegans and L. buckleyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as L. elegans following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Agelaioides badius and A. fringillarius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. badius following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Agelaioides badius and A. fringillarius (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. badius following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Basileuterus culicivorus, B. cabanisi and B. auricapilla (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as B. culicivorus, following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Cyanoloxia cyanoides and C. rothschildii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped and placed in the genus Cyanocompsa as Cyanocompsa cyanoides following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Dacnis lineata and D. egregia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. lineata following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Geothlypis aequinoctialis, G. auricularis and G. chiriquensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were lumped as G. aequinoctialis, following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
