Granatellus pelzelni and G. paraensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. pelzelni following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Granatellus pelzelni and G. paraensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as G. pelzelni following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Myiothlypis rivularis and M. mesoleuca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Phaeothlypis and lumped as P. rivularis following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Myiothlypis rivularis and M. mesoleuca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Phaeothlypis and lumped as P. rivularis following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Myiothlypis bivittata and M. roraimae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Basileuterus and lumped as B. bivittatus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Pipraeidea bonariensis and P. darwinii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped and placed in the genus Thraupis as T. bonariensis following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Piranga hepatica and P. flava (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. hepatica following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Poospiza nigrorufa and P. whitii (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped following SACC (2005 & updates).
Psarocolius bifasciatus and P. yuracares (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. bifasciatus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Psarocolius bifasciatus and P. yuracares (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. bifasciatus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Saltator coerulescens, S. olivascens and S. grandis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. coerulescens following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Sporophila bouvreuil and S. pileata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. bouvreuil following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Sporophila bouvreuil and S. pileata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. bouvreuil following Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Tangara mexicana and T. brasiliensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. mexicana following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Tangara velia and T. cyanomelas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. velia following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993).
Tangara cayana and T. flava (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. cayana following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Tangara mexicana and T. brasiliensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as T. mexicana following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Tangara velia and T. cyanomelas (del Hoyo and Collar   2016) were previously lumped as T. velia following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe   (1990, 1993).
Originally described as Leptobasis costalimai Santos 1957. Later was included in the genus Tuberculobasis by Machado (2009).

About the taxonomic similarities between Heteragrion silvarum Sjöstedt 1918 and Heteragrion melanurum Williamson 1919, Lencioni (2013) stated as follows: "...Other material from Manaus (paratype of H. melanurum) is close to H. silvarum, as noted by De Marmels (1987). All comparisons with the morphology of the appendages was based on Sjöstedt's figures, as the appendages were missing when De Marmels examined the holotype in 1987. Based on his examination, Garrison agrees with De Marmels that H. melanurum = H. silvarum but acknowledges that this species is wide-ranging and variable as to color. The specimen in the Lencioni collection from Porto Velho includes a note from R. Garrison: "specimens darker than normal H. silvarum but agree with appendage morphology to topotypical material."

authority: MacCulloch, Lathrop, Kok, Minter, Khan & Barrio-Amorós, 2008

taxonomicNotes: The species name is sometimes spelled Melanoides tuberculatus (see Madhyastha 2012), but this is incorrect because Melanoides Olivier, 1804 was clearly intended to be feminine as it was combined with the feminine specific epithet fasciolata in the original description.
In the Flora of tropical East Africa treated as a synonym of L. perpusilla, but now generally accepted as a species in its own right.

There are no significant taxonomic issues associated with this name. However, there is a degree of confusion over separation of L. gibba from L. minor when the former is not expanded and this may obscure differences in the distribution of the two species.
This species can be differentiated from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, tadpole morphology, advertisement call and ecological traits (Kok et al. 2006).

Ceratophyllum is a complicated genus with a range of taxa named but inconsistently recognized. Cook (1970) states that the genus includes four polymorphic species, but in parts of Europe some of the morphological variants are recognised as species or at a subordinate level. Whilst at least in the west, C. demersum s.s. is so widespread and abundant that it is unlikely that taxonomic issues will affect its conservation or Red List assessment, inconsistent recording within the C. demersum complex is likely to affect the Red List assessments of any subordinate taxa assessed.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
This species previously appeared on the IUCN Red List in the genus Pycreus but is now considered valid in the genus Cyperus.
Numerous subspecies have been described within this species (Triest 1988) but these are not consistently recognised.

This is a very wide ranging and variable species that has similar morphological characteristics to closely related Elaphoglossum species, such as E. erinaceum, so some records may be misidentified. With additional study some populations with unique characteristics may also be described as distinct species, for example in Madagascar and South America in Argentina, Bolivia and southern Brazil (de Matos 2015). Until new information becomes available, these populations are assessed under E. hybridum.

Marsilea minuta is quite close to M. quadrifolia, and in fact specimens of Marsilea from China seem intermediate between the two species in sporocarp size and peduncle attachment. Study of a wide range of Old World material of Marsilea would be required, however, to resolve the question of whether M. quadrifolia and M. minuta represent distinct species (Johnson 1986).

P. pusillus is a taxonomically difficult species. Difficulties of identification (particularly in the field) mean that distribution data are likely to include records that refer to the concept of P. berchtoldii employed here, as well as records of P. pusillus.

Wiegleb and Kaplan (1998) included P. berchtoldii within their concept of P. pusillus, although they have since accepted the separation of these two taxa. They state that "P. pusillus is regarded [..] as a highly polymorphic species with numerous regional forms and ecomorphoses. More detailed classification seems to be impossible because of the highly reticular variation. No correlated set of characters which would make discrimination of taxa possible have been confirmed". They also state that "Some of the plants called P. groenlandicus show certain characters deviant from the present concept of P. pusillus. They are characterized especially by the leaves with up 8 additional sclerenchymatous strands. These plants are known only from a geographically limited area in Western Greenland. Further research, such as experimental cultivation, is necessary in order to clarify its status."

The Flora of North America recognises three subspecies (Haynes and Barre-Hellquist 2000), while the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families (The Board of Trustees of the Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew 2010) recognises only one at a global level.

Two hybrid combinations have been reported involving P. pusillus; P. perfoliatus × P. pusillus (P. × mysticus Morong) and P. pusillus × P. trichoides (P. × grovesii Dandy et G. Taylor), both are extremely rare and unlikely to affect either the survival of the species or this evaluation.

There is some uncertainty over the taxonomy and distribution of Ceratopteris thalictroides and C. cornuta. Verdcourt (1999) includes the two as a single taxon, with justification. Al Khulaidi (in prep.) lists only C. cornuta from Yemen, while Hassler and Schmidt (2011) list them as separate species, with C. thalictroides absent from the Arabian Peninsula and C. cornuta occurring in Oman and Yemen (including Socotra), as does The Plant List. For now, the two taxa are assessed separately for the IUCN Red List.
Current taxonomic opinion suggests that Tovomita longifolia is a single species with a disjunct distribution, however taxonomic studies are continuing.

Tovomita rubella shares similar characteristics with T. gracilipes Planch. & Triana and T. schomburgkii Planch. & Triana. Although some herbaria and databases have specimens from localities other than Brazil, those specimens have never been seen or are misidentifications. It is possible that this species may be treated as a synonym in the future.
This species can be distinguished from other similar species by a combination of morphological features, colour pattern and the production of odorous skin secretions (Means and Savage 2007).
Digitaria fragilis (Steud.) Luces is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.

A. dinae, A. multiflora, A. eriocaulis and A. beateae are a group of well distinct but related species in Minas Gerais and Bahia. In the past some authors regarded them as conspecific under the oldest nameA. dinae. Recent studies and better knowledge in the field, however, show that it is better to maintain these taxa as separate species. In some cases they even grow together (A. dinae, A. eriocaulis) without hybridization (P. Braun pers. comm. 2012). (In CoL notes.)

Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate, subsp. magnus  N.P.Taylor & Zappi and subsp. odorus (F.Ritter) N.P.Taylor & Zappi. All the subspecies were previously assessed in 2002, but as they have not been reassessed they are now excluded. Subspecies magnus was listed as NT and the other two as VU.

Two subspecies are recognized, the typical form and subsp. boomianus (Buining & Brederoo) N.P.Taylor & Zappi. Both subspecies were assessed in 2002 as Data Deficient and Vulnerable respectively, but they are not reassessed here.
Discocactus catingicola was previously included under this species as a subspecies, but is now treated as a good species.
Treated by some authors under Opuntia.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. rubrocoronatum (Kimnach) Bauer.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate (assessed in 2002 as Endangered) and subsp. leiocarpus N.P.Taylor & Zappi. The susbpecies are not assessed here.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. decumbens (F.Ritter) N.P.Taylor & Zappi. The latter was assessed in 2002 as Endangered, but neither subspecies is assessed here.
This species includes E. tubiflora (Pfeiff) Zucc. ex A.Dietr., from Salta and Tucuman in Argentina, which is considered a different species by Kiesling (in Zuloaga and Morrone 1999).
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. chacoana (Schütz) P.J.Braun & Esteves.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and subsp. sericifer (F.Ritter) N.P.Taylor & Zappi.; these are not assessed separately.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and subsp. uruguayanus (R.Kiesling) N.P.Taylor. These are not assessed separately.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and subsp. calcrupicola (F.Ritter) N.P.Taylor & Zappi. These are not assessed separately.

A. dinae, A. multiflora, A. eriocaulis and A. beateae are a group of clearly distinct but related species occurring in Minas Gerais and Bahia. In the past some authors regarded them as conspecific under the oldest name A. dinae. Recent studies and better knowledge in the field, however, show that it is better to maintain these taxa at the rank of separate species. In some cases they even grow together (A. dinae, A. eriocaulis) without hybridization (P. Braun pers. comm. 2012).
This species was treated as belonging first to D. heptacanthus and later D. diersianus but is treated as distinct species in this assessment.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. viridis N.P.Taylor. Both subspecies were previously assessed in 2002, the nominate was assessed as Endangered and subsp. viridis as Critically Endangered. Neither of these subspecies has been reassessed and hence they are now excluded from the Red List.

Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. margaritaceus N.P.Taylor and subsp. ritteri N.P.Taylor. All of the subspecies were previously assessed in 2002, the nominate and subsp. margaritaceus were assessed as Vulnerable and subsp. ritteri as Critically Endangered. None of these subspecies has been reassessed and hence they are now excluded from the Red List.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. estevesii (P.J.Braun) N.P.Taylor & Zappi. Both subspecies were assessed in 2002 as Vulnerable but have not been assessed again here and are hence not included as separate assessments.
Synonyms = Selenicereus setaceus (Salm-Dyck) Werderm. (name used in CITES Checklist).
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. longicarpus (Buining & Brederoo) N.P.Taylor.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. matoense (Buining & Brederoo) P.J.Braun & Esteves.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. cremnophilus (Buining & Brederoo) P.J.Braun & Esteves.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. amethystinus (Buining & Brederoo) N.P.Taylor.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. damsii (K.Schum.) G.J.Charles.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. concepcionensis (Buining & G.Moser) P.J.Braun & Esteves.

According to M. Machado and J. Larocca (pers. comms.) the name Frailea perumbilicata F.Ritter should be resurrected for this species.
The taxon described as Micranthocereus polyanthus ssp. alvinii M.Machado & Hofacker will be included in this species (M. Machado pers. comm. 2010).
Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. albicolumnaris (F.Ritter) Hofacker and subsp. tuyensis (Buining & G.Moser) Metzing.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. horstii (F.Ritter) P.J.Braun & Esteves.
Hunt et al. (2006) consider this to be an untypifiable name of disputed application and recommended that it be abandoned.
Espécie descrita em: Cact. & Succ. journ. Brit. xix. 67 (1957).

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. quadricostatus (F.Ritter) Zappi. Both subspecies were previously assessed in 2002 - Near Threatened for the nominate and Vulnerable for quadricostatus, but as they have not been reassessed they are now excluded.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. rosae (P.J.Braun) Zappi. Both subspecies were previously assessed in 2002 - Vulnerable for the nominate and Critically Endangered for rosae, but as they have not been reassessed they are now excluded.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. violacea(Leuenb.) N.P.Taylor & Zappi. The latter subspecies was previously assessed as Data Deficient in 2002, but it has not been reassessed and is now excluded from the Red List.
The former subspecies estevesii (Braun) N.P.Taylor & Stuppy is now treated as a good species and assessed separately.

Six subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. hohenauensis (F.Ritter) Barthlott & N.P.Taylor, subsp. oreophila N.P.Taylor & Zappi, subsp. pittieri (Britton & Rose) Barthlott & N.P.Taylor , subsp. pulvinigera (G. Lindb.) Barthlott & N.P.Taylor and subsp. tucumanensis (F.A.C.Weber) Barthlott & N.P.Taylor .

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. septentrionalis N.P.Taylor & Barthlott. The latter subspecies was previously assessed as Endangered in 2002, but it has not been reassessed and is now excluded from the Red List.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. aurilanatus (F.Ritter) Zappi. The latter subspecies was previously assessed as Endangered in 2002, but as it not been reassessed it has been excluded from the Red List.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. ruschianus (Buining & Brederoo) Zappi. The nominate subspecies was previously assessed as Vulnerable in 2002, but as it has not been reassessed it is now excluded from the Red List.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. salvadorensis (Werderm.) Zappi. The latter subspecies was previously assessed as Near Threatened in 2002, but as it not been reassessed it has been excluded from the Red List.

Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. robustus Zappi. The latter subspecies was previously assessed as Near Threatened in 2002, but as it has not been reassessed it is now excluded from the Red List.

Hunt et al. (2006) recognize seven subspecies of Rhipsalis baccifera:
  • the nominate subspecies;
  • subsp. cleistogama M.Kessler, Ibisch & Barthlott;
  • subsp. erythrocarpa (K.Schum.) Barthlott;
  • subsp. hileiabaiana N.P.Taylor & Barthlott (this subspecies was previously assessed for the 2002 IUCN Red List as Vulnerable but it has not been reassessed here);
  • subsp. horrida (Baker) Barthlott;
  • subsp. mauritiana (DC.) Barthlott; and
  • subsp. shaferi (Britton & Rose) Bartlott & N.P.Taylor.

Subspecies schaferi, should be treated as a good species (N.P. Taylor and W. Barthlott pers. comms. 2010). This is further confirmed by the work of Korotkova (2011). For the purposes of this assessment, R. shaferi is included under R. baccifera.

Additional subspecies have been described in Africa and Madagascar but these are not recognized by Hunt et al. (2006).
This species may be a spiny form of O. elata (L. Oakley, pers. comm. 2010).
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. jamaicensis (Britton & Harris) Doweld.

Five subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. diffusus (Britton & Rose) N.P.Taylor, subsp. jaenensis (Rauh & Backeb.) Ostolaza, subsp. amazonicus  (K Schum. ex Vaupel) N.P.Taylor and subsp. smithianus (Britton & Rose) N.P.Taylor.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and subsp. horstii (F.Ritter) Hofacker.
Three subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. panamensis (Britton & Rose) Ralf Bauer and subsp. chocoensis Ralf Bauer.
It is not clear whether the northernmost population belongs to this species. Hunt et al. (2006) suggest that this subpopulation belongs to Pilosocereus rizzoanus.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. gracilis (F.Ritter) Hofacker.
Several authors recognized the genus Wigginsia as different taxa and is included in this taxa.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. claviceps (F.Ritter) Hofacker & P.J.Braun.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. zehntneri (Britton & Rose) Zappi.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate form and subsp. pernambucoensis (F.Ritter) Zappi.
This species may include P. estevesii and P. goianus.
This species was previous listed as O. dillenii.
Four subspecies are recognized, the nominate form, subsp. marchesii (W.R.Abraham) Hofacker, subsp. neobuenekeri (F.Ritter) Rogoz. & P.J.Braun and subsp. succina (F.Ritter) Rogoz. & P.J.Braun.
Two subspecies are recognized, the nominate and subsp. graessneri (K.Schum.) Hofacker & P.J.Braun.
This species cannot be assigned to a species group with confidence on present knowledge (Hunt et al. 2006).
Will be transferred to family Cricetidae.

Arachis glandulifera Stalker is a secondary wild relative of Peanut, A. hypogaea L., according to the Harlan and De Wet (1971) Gene Pool concept (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2020).

Arachis matiensis Krapov. & W.C.Greg. is a tertiary wild relative of Peanut, A. hypogaea L., according to the Harlan and De Wet (1971) Gene Pool concept (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2020).
Digitaria dioica Killeen & Rúgolo is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Digitaria nuda Schumach. is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of Fonio millet/White fonio (Digitaria exilis (Kippist) Stapf) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Saccharum angustifolium (Nees) Trin. is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Saccharum villosum Steud. is a gene pool tertiary wild relative of sugarcane (Saccharum officinarum L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Theobroma glaucum Karst is a gene pool tertiary relative of cacao, Theobroma cacao L. (Vincent et al. 2013).

Xanthosoma striatipes is a wild relative of the New Cocoyam, X. sagittifolium (L.) Schott, X. mafaffa Schott and other cultivated Xanthosoma species. According to Croat et al. (2017), X. striatipes is classified in TG4 of the X. sagittifolium and X. mafaffa, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006). In addition, Croat et al. (2017) sub-divided the genus into six groups placing X. striatipes in a group (Camporum) different from the related crops, X. sagittifolium and X. mafaffa (group Xanthosoma).

There are three subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies garleppi; subspecies interruptus (Staudinger, 1892); and subspecies lecerfi Brown & Lamas, 1994. It has been suggested in the past that P. garleppi could possibly be a hybrid between P. torquatus and P. astyalus, two sympatric species (Collins and Morris 1985). However, more recent studies treat it is a distinct species (e.g. Lewis 2010).
There are two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies polystictus and subspecies galenus (Fruhstorfer, 1907).

There are three subspecies of this butterfly: the nominate subspecies astyalus (Godart, 1819); subspecies hippomedon (Felder & Felder, 1859); and subspecies phanias (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906) (Warren et al. 2016).  


Some taxonomic sources have elevated the subgenus Heraclides to species level (e.g. Hancock 1983, Warren et al. 2016); however, molecular studies on Papilio phylogeny (e.g. Aubert et al. 1999, Caterino and Sperling 1999) showed that there was little support for this. Additional ongoing work has come to the same conclusion that there is no evidence for splitting Papilio into several subgenera (F. Sperling and F. Condamine pers. comm. March 2020).

There are four subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies chiansiades; subspecies maroni Moreau, 1923; subspecies dospassosi Rütimeyer, 1969; and subspecies mossi (Brown, 1994). This latter subspecies, mossi (Brown, 1994), has a consistent geographic range, morphology and type with that of the nominate subspecies and is by some authors considered to be a likely synonym of subspecies chiansides (Lewis 2010).

There are 13 subspecies reported for this species, according to Warren et al. (2010): the nominate subspecies aeneas; subspecies bolivar (Hewitson, 1850); subspecies opalinus (Butler, 1877); subspecies damis (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies locris (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies gabrielensis (Bryk, 1953); subspecies marcius (Hübner, [1816]); subspecies huallaga Racheli, 1988; subspecies lamasi Racheli, 1988; subspecies tucha Racheli, 1988; subspecies linoides Brown & Lamas, 1994; subspecies lucasi Brown & Lamas, 1994; and subspecies didas Brown & Lamas, 1994.

There are currently six subspecies recognised for this species: the nominate subspecies bunichus; subspecies chamissonia (Eschscholtz, 1821); subspecies damocrates (Guenée, 1872); subspecies diodorus (Hopffer, 1866); subspecies perrhebus (Boisduval, 1836), and the recently described subspecies almas Casagrande & Mielke, 2007.

There are currently four subspecies known for this species (Racheli 2006): the nominate subspecies chabrias; subspecies ygdrasilla Hemming, 1935; subspecies mithras (Grose-Smith, 1902) and subspecies marajoara (Brown, 1994).

There are currently four subspecies recognised for this species, according to Warren et al. 2010): the nominate subspecies echemon; subspecies ergeteles (Gray, [1853]); subspecies empistocles Küppers, 1975; and subspecies pisander (C. & R. Felder, 1865).

According to Tyler et al. (1994) and Warren et al. (2013) there are seven subspecies: the nominate subspecies neophilus; subspecies anaximenes (C. & R. Felder, 1862); subspecies consus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies ecbolius (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies eurybates (Gray, [1853]); subspecies parianus (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); and subspecies olivencius (Bates, 1861).

Based on the information in Racheli (2006), there are currently six subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies panthonus (Cramer, 1780), subspecies barbotini Brévignon, 1998, subspecies ecaudatus (Joicey & Talbot, 1924), subspecies castilhoi (d'Almeida, 1967), subspecies callicles (Bates 1861) and subspecies aglaope (Gray 1853). According to Warren et al. (2013) there are currently only two subspecies: the nominate subspecies panthonus; and subspecies phylarchus (Hopffer, 1866); however, no basis is provided to support this arrangement. A previous status assessment of the world's swallowtails in 1985 referred to numa which is now considered a synonym of P. burchellanus (Tyler et al. 1994), a taxon that could be conspecific with P. panthonus (Silva-Brandão et al. 2008). Parides aglaope has been considered as a separate species (Warren et al. 2013, see above); however, for this assessment, we stand by the information given in Racheli (2006).

There are currently five subspecies reported for this species (Tyler et al, 1994, Racheli 2006, Warren et al. 2013): the nominate subspecies phosphorus; subspecies gratianus (Hewitson, 1861); susbpecies vavi Racheli, 1992; subspecies zopyron Lamas, 1998; and subspecies laurae Bollino & Costa, 2004.
There are two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies quadratus; and subspecies spoliatus (Staudinger, 1898) (Tyler et al. 1994, Racheli 2006, Warren et al. 2013).
There are currently two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies tros; and subspecies danunciae Mielke, Casagrande & Mielke, 2000 (Warren et al. 2013).

There are currently nine subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies vertumnus; subspecies cutora (Gray, [1853]); subspecies diceros (Gray, [1853]); subspecies bogotanus (C. & R. Felder, 1864); subspecies autumnus (Staudinger, 1898); subspecies yuracares (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies pseudobogotanus (Krüger, 1926); subspecies pyrophanus (Zikán, 1937) and subspecies astorius (Zikán, 1940) (Tyler et al. 1994, Warren et al. 2013).
There are currently two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies zacynthus; and subspecies polymetus (Godart, 1819) (Tyler et al. 1994, Warren et al. 2013).

This species is closely related to Trichilia surinamensis and Trichilia tuberculata and is often confused. Details on the taxonomic differences are given in Pennington (1981) and Pennington and Clarkson (2016).

This species has two subspecies: Trichilia elegans subsp. elegans and Trichilia elegans subsp. richardiana (Pennington 1981). This species has a wide distribution and considerable ecological and morphological diversity.
This species has two accepted subspecies: subsp. quadrijuga and subsp. cinerascens. Pennington (1981) describes the distinctions between these two subspecies in detail.
Further studies are necessary to clarify the status of a population from Chapada Diamantina, Minas Gerais, which exhibits different colouration from those elsewhere (A.S. Argôlo pers. comm. 2012).
Recent molecular systematics work by Ghedotti et al. (2015) placed this species in the family Paralepididae.
According to Ghedotti et al. (2015), this species should be placed in the family Lestidiidae.
The genus of this species was changed from Benthalbella to Lagiacrusichthys according to Davis (2015).

According to Moore (2002), this species is only known from juvenile specimens and some specimens identified as Anoplogaster cornuta may be adult forms of A. brachycera. The validity of this species is in question due to recent genetic analyses (J. Moore pers. comm. 2018).

The taxonomy of Lophotus species remains uncertain due to the lack of type specimens, comparative material and oversight of previous taxonomic treatment (Craig et al. 2004). It has been suggested that Lophotus machadoi may be a synonym of L. lacepede, and its taxonomy requires further investigation (Menezes et al. 2003, Koeda and Ho 2017).
This species
This species is known only from the holotype and its taxonomic status is consequently uncertain (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2012).

authority: Curcio, Sales Nunes, Suzart Argolo, Skuk & Rodrigues, 2012

taxonomicNotes: This species is known from only two specimens. One of them is considered lost and the other preserved in poor condition, making comparisons with more recent material difficult. Any new collections need to be compared with the surviving specimen to confirm their identity.
A record of this species from the Serra de Baturité, state of Ceará was reidentified as Epictia albifrons by Borges-Nojosa in 2006, following a survey of diversity in this area.

Arteaga et al. (2018) found that Sibynomorphus was non-monophyletic and that species assigned to this genus instead belonged to four distinct clades within Dipsas. These authors consequently proposed that Sibynomorphus be considered a junior synonym of Dipsas.

Entiauspe-Neto et al. (2021) examined the only known specimen of Phalotris cerradensis, originally described as a range extension for P. concolor to Bahia State, and confirmed that P. cerradensis represents a junior synonym of P. concolor.

authority: Da Silva, Rodrigues Silva, Ribeiro, Souza & Do Amaral Souza, 2005
taxonomicNotes: The validity of the taxon uncertain, as it is known from a single specimen that may be an anomalous individual of Atractus pantostictus (P. Passos pers. comm. 2012).

Apostolepis striata was described based on its type specimen alone (Lema 2004). More data is necessary for a more complete description, including comparisons with other Apostolepis such as Apostolepis serrana Lema, 2004, A. nigroterminata Boulenger, 1896, and A. phillipsae Harvey, 1999.

authority: Curcio, Sales Nunes, Suzart Argolo, Skuk & Rodrigues, 2012

taxonomicNotes: The identity of two records from Santa Cruz in Bolivia, assigned to this species by Harvey (1999), based on two specimens that these authors acknowledged differ from the holotype, remains uncertain. Entiauspe and Lema (2015) concluded that these represented Apostolepis christineae based on photographs of the museum specimens, but did not examine the specimens to confirm this identification and A. christineae is so far known with certainty only from the Brazilian type locality. Pending direct examination of the specimens it is considered speculative to assign these records to either species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020), and they are consequently excluded from this assessment.

H. Zaher (pers. comm. 2012) reported that this species was being reviewed and will possibly be synonymized with Erythrolamprus almadensis. This synonymy has never been published and ecologically distinct form "may well" represent a validly distinct species (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019).

This species is only weakly distinguishable from Bothrops atrox, and a preliminary investigations of the relationships between these taxa concluded that further research is required to fully resolve its status (Wüster et al. 1996, Alencar et al. 2016).

The taxonomic status of Apostolepis sanctaeritae is unresolved. This species was long considered a junior synonym of A. flavotorquata following Amaral (1930), but more recently has variously been treated as either a full species (Lema and Fernandes 1997, Lema 2002) or a junior synonym of A. cearensis (Ferrazzi et al. 1993). Ferrarezzi et al. (2005) adopt the latter arrangement, but despite summarizing the taxonomic confusion surrounding this species they do not comment on this assignment. Most recently, molecular samples referred to A. sanctaeritae were recovered as distinct from A. caerensis by Grazziotin et al. (2012), but these authors do not comment on this finding and the "A. sanctaeritae" samples used are now recognized to have been mislabelled sequences referabble to A. ammodytes (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2018). This account follows the advice of C. Nogueira (pers. comm. 2018) in retaining A. sanctaeritae as a junior synonym of A. caerensis pending further research.

This species was described from a specimen which may have erroneous locality data (H. Zaher pers. comm. 2019), as it does not resemble any other known South Anerican snake (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2019). It is consequently possible it is from another continent.

The name Micrurus ibiboboca is applied to a complex of at least three species endemic to Brazil. M. ibiboboca sensu stricto has a range evidently restricted to the Caatinga and to the Atlantic Forest of Northeast Brazil.

The status of the subspecies is unclear. Although eight subspecies have been recognized (Seymour 1989), morphological and genetic analyses do not support the existence of discrete subspecies (Larson 1997, Eizirik et al. 2001, Ruiz-Garcia et al. 2006). While not elevating the regional differences to the subspecies level, Eizirk et al. (2001) found evidence for four incompletely isolated phylogeographic groups: Mexico and Guatemala, southern Central America, northern South America, and South America south of the Amazon River. Similarly, Ruiz-Garcia et al. (2006) found that the Andes Mountains incompletely isolates Jaguar populations in Colombia.

This species was listed in the 1996-2002 IUCN Red Lists under the family Platanistidae. It is now most commonly assigned to the family Pontoporiidae, and at least sometimes in the superfamily Inioidea (Muizon et al. 2017).
This species has been synonymized with Brucepattersonius griserufescens (Vilela et al. 2006). It is treated as monotypic by Vilela et al. (2015).
Previous taxonomic issues relating to Paratrygon aiereba have been resolved by Rosa (1985).

A species of Amblyraja has been taken around South Georgia Island which appears not to be A. georgiana, but may be either A. frerichsi or A. robertsi (Mike Endicott via M. Stehmann pers. comm. 2004). The occurrence of this species in the Falklands Islands (Malvinas) is uncertain. Since the inception of the longline fishery around the islands in 1994, this species has been captured in the Falklands as the primary skate by-catch, and recorded as A. cf. georgiana (J. Pompert unpubl. data 2020).

The distinction between R. atlantica and R. pacifica is problematic and based solely on the number of caudal tubercles, a highly variable and often overlapping characteristic (tends to be greater in R. atlantica). Resolution on the distinction of these two species will require examination of a larger series of specimens and potentially molecular data (Compagno et al. 1990).

While there are reported subpopulations of Squalus acanthias (Linnaeus, 1758) elsewhere in the world, the North Pacific subpopulation is now considered a separate species, Squalus suckleyi (Girard, 1854) (see Ebert et al. 2010). Further taxonomic studies on this genus are required, including in relation to Mediterranean and Black Sea subpopulations. In Europe, three subpopulations are inferred to occur.

Claravis, as previously defined, was shown to be paraphyletic, with two of the three species grouping separately to C. pretiosi. These two need generic reallocation, moving to the new genus Paraclaravis (Sangster et al. 2018): hence P. geoffroyi and P. mondetoura.
Description (Santos 1965) does not fit with generic diagnosis of Acanthagrion - taxonomic revision needed (von Ellenrieder and Garrison 2007).
Psophia viridis, P. dextralis and P. obscura (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. viridis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
According to Tropicos (2019) and The Plant List (2019), Cestrum elegans is an accepted name for this species.
Crax fasciolata and C. pinna (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as Crax fasciolata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Machado (2005) erected the genus Schizocordulia for this species, based on its cleft male epiproct, long inner branch of hamule, pilose plate on male sternum 7 and large vulvar lamina. Garrison et al. (2006) regarded these differences as specific rather than generic.

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 23 species. Since the taxonomic revisions of Hershkovitz (1963, 1990), the titi monkeys living in northern Bolivia and southern Peru were considered to be P. brunneus. The result is that a karyotype of 2n=48 was attributed to P. brunneus (Minezawa et al. 1989) and that many authors referred to titi monkeys observed in that region as being P. brunneus (v. Castro et al. 1990; Buchanan-Smith et al. 2000; Porter 2001; Rowe & Martinez 2003; Phillips et al. 2004).  However, new evidence shows that the animals in that region should be identified as P. toppini (v. Martinez & Wallace 2013; Porter et al. 2013; Vermeer & Tello-Alvarado 2015).
This species is easily confused with Neoscopelus macrolepidotus (Roberts 2015).

Two subspecies are recognized: C. c. commersonii in southern South America and C. c. kerguelenensis in the Kerguelen Islands (Robineau et al. 2007). The Kerguelen subspecies was apparently founded by a few individuals as recently as 10,000 years ago.
Squalus albicaudus is a member of the Squalus megalops species-complex. The taxonomic description includes specimens that were formerly identified as S. megalops and S. cubensis (Viana et al. 2016).

Squalus bahiensis is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. The taxonomic description includes mostly specimens formerly identified as S. blainvillei and S. mitsukurii, and fewer specimens formerly identified as S. cubensis and S. fernandinus.
Squalus lobularis is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. Its taxonomic description includes specimens formerly identified as S. cubensis and S. mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2016).

Squalus quasimodo is a member of the Squalus mitsukurii species-complex. Its taxonomic description includes specimens formerly identified as S. blainvillei, S. fernandinus, S. lebruni, and S. mitsukurii (Viana et al. 2016).
This species can be easily confused with other Lampanyctus species (A. Williams pers. comm. 2018).

Phaethornis longirostris, P. mexicanus and P. baroni (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. longirostris following SACC (2005), and before then were also lumped with P. superciliosus as P. superciliosus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Amazilia oenone (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously listed as Chrysuronia oenone (del Hoyo et al. 2014), but Ornelas et al. (2014) found Chrysuronia nested within Amazilia.
Nyctipolus hirundinaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus.
Myrmoderus squamosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Myrmeciza squamosa.
Akletos melanoceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Myrmeciza melanoceps.
Hafferia fortis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Myrmeciza fortis.
Myrmophylax atrothorax (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Myrmeciza atrothorax.
Oneillornis salvini (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Gymnopithys salvini.
Ceratopipra chloromeros (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pipra chloromeros.
Ceratopipra cornuta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Pipra cornuta.
Anabacerthia ruficaudata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Philydor ruficaudatum.

Vaz and Carvalho (2018) carried out morphological analysis of South- and Northwestern Atlantic specimens of Squatina revealing this previously undescribed species of angel shark occurring on the continental slope of Brazil between latitudes 11° and 22°S.

The new taxonomic concept for Squatina guggenheim includes S. punctata as a junior synonym.

There is some controversy concerning the taxonomy and nomenclature of Squatina species of the Southwest Atlantic. Squatina occulta described by Vooren and da Silva (1991) has been regarded as being a junior synonym of S. guggenheim by Soto (2001) in a species-level checklist of the region. Although evidence was not given to support this statement, Bernardes et al. (2005) followed Soto’s proposal. However, later studies have re-evaluated the species’ validity. The validity of S. occulta Vooren and da Silva, 1991 as a distinct species has been confirmed through the study of mitochondrial DNA by Stelbrink et al. (2010) and in a comparative study of Southwest Atlantic Squatina neurocrania (Carvalho et al. 2012). Both studies also recognized S. argentina, S. guggenheim, and S. occulta as the only valid species in the Southwest Atlantic (preceding the description of new species since that time, S. david and S. varii).

Ipomoea cynanchifolia Meisn. is in the series Batatas (Khoury et al. 2015). It should not be confused with I. cynanchifolia C.B.Clarke, which is a synonym of I. plebeia subsp. africana A.Meeuse (J.R.I. Wood pers. comm. 2018). It is a poorly understood species and cannot be reliably separated from I. ramosissima except when in fruit (J.R.I Wood pers. comm. 2018). It is a tertiary genetic relative of Sweet Potato, I. batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas (L.) Lam. (Vincent et al. 2013, USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2018).

The Sei Whale, Balaenoptera borealis is a recognized species but catch and sightings records of Sei Whales prior to 1972 tended to include Bryde's Whales (B. edeni or B. brydei) in areas where both species occur. The Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (Committee on Taxonomy 2017) recognizes two subspecies, B. b. borealis in the Northern Hemisphere and B. b. schlegelii in the Southern Hemisphere, as proposed by Tomilin (1957). The Sei Whales found in the North Pacific and North Atlantic have not been formally compared and so are still placed in the same nominate subspecies by default, although Huijser et al. (2018) found a high degree of genetic divergence between North Atlantic and North Pacific Sei Whales.
Formicivora paludicola (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized following evidence presented in Buzzetti et al. (2013).
This species has been frequently misidentified as P. squamosissimus (L Casatti pers. comm. 2009).
Phaethornis aethopygus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously listed as P. aethopyga.

Microspingus cinereus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Poospiza and listed as P. cinerea following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Setophaga striata (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Aratinga nenday (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Nandayus.

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.

Hydrobates leucorhous has been split into H. leucorhous, H. socorroensis and H. cheimomnestes (which see) (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2018), based on the proposal of Howell (2012).

Following Kennedy and Spencer (2014) the genus Phalacrocorax has been divided into six genera, with P. auritus, P. brasilianus and P. harrisi moved into Nannopterum (HBW and BirdLife International 2018).
Não há sinonímias. Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes. A espécie pertence a Acestrorhynchus gr. nasutus (Toledo-Piza 2007).

Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.

Não existem revisões recentes do gênero, nem chaves de classificação disponíveis, o que impede a identificação acurada da maior parte das espécies de Ancistrus. Neste sentido, é possível que Ancistrus minutus ocorra em outros locais e esteja disponível em lotes depositados em coleções científicas, mas sem identificação taxonômica correta (C. Chamon, C. Cramer, J. Zuanon, L. Sousa e R. Oliveira obs. pess.).

A última revisão foi de Souza-Lima (2003). O táxon é mal definido, os tipos encontram-se em mal estado e isto gera um problema taxonômico de difícil resolução. Não é um táxon introduzido nem errante, mas enquanto sua identidade taxonômica não for estabelecida sem dúvidas não permitirá delimitação de sua área de distribuição e, portanto, não permitirá a avaliação de seu grau de conservação.
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.

Espécie incertae sedis em Characidae, mas não válido em Cheirodon (Reis et al. 2003). Cheirodon macropterus não é um Cheirodontinae, mas membro do “clado Hemigrammus” sensu (Mirande 2010), como Cheirodon jaguaribensis.
Não é possível afirmar se Cichlasoma zarskei é uma espécie válida, provavelmente se trata de um sinônimo-júnior de C. orientale (W. J. da Graça com. pess. 2013).

A princípio, não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon. Hipóteses prévias de relações filogenéticas entre os gêneros de Diapomini, Planaltina, Diapoma e Acrobrycon são discutidas com base em informações morfológicas preliminares (Menezes et al. 2011). É proposto que o grupo a que pertencem, Diapomini, seja monofilético.

taxonomicNotes: The placement of this species in the Macrouridae is not supported by current morphological and genetic analyses; instead, it belongs in the family Steindachneriidae (Howes 1993, Roa-Varón and Ortí 2009).
Species in the genus Barathronus were previously classified in the family Aphyonidae before reclassification to Bythitidae by Moller et al. (2016).
This species is commonly confused with Malacocephalus occidentalis and Ventrifossa mucocephalus (Cohen et al. 1990).
This species is commonly confused with Ventrifossa macropogon.

The systematics of the genus Chiasmodon is still poorly understood and the exact number of species is unknown. There are two main theories: Prokofiev and Kukuev (2009) consider the existence of only two species in the genus (C. niger and C. lavenbergi), while Melo (2009) defends the existence of seven species in the genus (including C. microcephalus). For the purposes of this assessment, we are treating C. microcephalus as a valid species. Further taxonomic research on this genus is needed.

The systematics of the genus Chiasmodon is still poorly understood and the exact number of species is unknown. There are two main theories: Prokofiev and Kukuev (2009) consider the existence of only two species in the genus (C. niger and C. lavenbergi), while Melo (2009) defends the existence of seven species in the genus (including C. pluriradiatus). For the purpose of this assessment, we are treating C. pluriradiatus as a valid species. Further taxonomic research on this genus is needed.

Two species descriptions were occurring simultaneously, Kali caribbaea Prokofiev 2008 and K. colubrina Melo 2008. These descriptions were accepted and published within a very short time, leading to disagreement as to which species name had priority (Melo 2010, Prokofiev 2011). Based on the ICZN rules and interpretations, K. colubrina was given priority (e.g., Melo 2010, Eschmeyer et al. 2018).
This species is part of the ‘Poromitra cristiceps-group’ (Stewart and Bray 2015).

This species was recently described from one specimen previously identified as Poromitra crassiceps (Kotlyar 2008). Subsequently, Mincarone et al. (2014) suggested that P. kukuevi and P. indooceanica are synonyms and that further taxonomic work is needed.
This species was previously referred to as Maurolicus muelleri by Vazzoler (1975), Zavala-Camin (1981), Séret and Andreata (1992) and Haimovici et al. (1994).
Não existem limitações taxonômicas relevantes à validação do táxon.

Guatteria guianensis is easily recognizable by a combination of often very large verruculose leaves with a quite distinct marginal vein and by young twigs covered with a velutinous indument of erect mostly curly brown hairs when young. It resembles G. decurrens from which it differs by the indument of the young leafy twigs: erect brown soft curly hairs to c. 0.5 mm long in G. guianensis vs erect to half-appressed stiff hairs to c. 3 mm long in G. decurrens (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria megalophylla is a species very widely spread all over Amazonian America (Colombia Ecuador Peru Brazil and in Guyana) mostly at low elevations up to 600 m. It is easily recognizable by having very large leaves (of up to 75 by 20 cm!) with a very distinct and impressed marginal vein rather long petioles shortly pedicellate flowers (mostly produced from leafless branchlets) and shortly stipitate monocarps (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria trichocarpa can be recognized by a dense indument of appressed to erect brown hairs on most parts of the plant. Furthermore it is characterized by large thick walled monocarps with short stipes up to 5 mm diam. The elongation of the fruiting pedicel is caused by growth of the part below the articulation rather than growth of the upper part as is most commonly seen in other species of Guatteria (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria ucayalina is well recognizable by a combination of a dense indument of brown erect hairs on young twigs lower side of leaves and pedicels a mostly greyish upper leaf side strongly recurved sepals and long-stipitate monocarps. The leaf indument is variable from dense in most specimens to rather dense or sparse in mainly Venezuelan collections. Guatteria ucayalina is widely distributed ranging from Central America in the north (where it was previously known as G. recurvisepala) to Bolivia in the south and Venezuela and Guyana in the east (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria blepharophylla is recognizable by shortly pedicellate flowers (pedicels generally up to c. 10 mm long) and by petals which are densely covered with apressed silvery hairs (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria scandens is one of the very few species with a scandent habit in the genus Guatteria It can also be recognized by its cauliflory and the scabridulous "rough") leaves. The occurrence of lianas or plants of liana-like habit is rather exceptional in Neotropical Annonaceae in contrast to the Old World where the percentage of climbing is much higher. Other Neotropical climbers are e.g. Annona haematantha and A. scandens (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria meliodora resembles G. dura (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria inundata is a species quite often collected in periodically inundated varzea tahuampa and igapo forests of Amazonian Brazil Peru and Venezuela. It is most easy to recognize by the long-apiculate and almost pointed monocarps very rarely met with in the genus. The seeds of this species have a spongy outer layer which may be an adaptation to hydrochory (the species is restricted to river banks!) (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria maguirei one of the few savanna inhabiting species in the genus is easily distinguished by its thick and tiny ovate leaves combined with relatively long pedicels (up to c. 35 mm long in fruit) and small stipes (up to c. 2 mm long). Like in the probably related G. atabapensis there is a strongly reticulate venation on the upper side of the lamina (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria capixabae endemic to the Brazilian state of Espírito Santo is recognizable by very shortly stipitate monocarps and an attenuate leaf base (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria scytophylla is quite distinctive by the very densely sericeous and almost silvery lower leaf side a feature not often seen in the genus Guatteria Another feature is encountered in the distinctly umbonate connective shield. The seeds in this species are almost smooth with only very weak and shallow pits and grooves (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria villosissima is characterized by almost sessile leaves densely covered with erect hairs on the lower side an obtuse to cordate leaf base revolute leaf margins and by short stipes (3-4 mm long). The species is quite similar to the widely distributed G. tomentosa (Central America and in many parts of tropical South America) differing by: obtuse vs pointed flower buds leaf margins revolute all over its length vs basally revolute in G. tomentosa and generally shorter stipes (3-4 vs 4-20 mm long) (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria schomburgkiana is widely distributed throughout tropical South America and in contrast to the other three species is often found in savanna-like vegetation on white sandy soils. It differs from the other three species by an indument of appressed hairs on the lower side of the lamina. Most hairs are colourless but a few hairs with brown cell content (as in the closely related G. citriodora) may be spotted among the other hairs. The leaf base mainly varies from acute to obtuse but attenuate bases are also met with (mainly in Bolivian material) (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria richardii slightly resembles the French Guianan endemic G. ouregou by its erect brown hairs on the leafy twigs. It differs however by the primary vein retaining its indument above for some time (not soon becoming glabrous) yellow instead of orange to orange yellow petals and by much smaller monocarps (6-8 vs 8-15 mm long) (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria citriodora can be recognized by the erect hairs best seen on the lower side of the leaf on the primary vein and the lamina surface along the primary vein in contrast to G. schomburgkiana with appressed hairs. Note though that hairs on the lower leaf side in G. citriodora may become more or less appressed towards the margin therefore the primary vein area should be examined. Many leaf hairs in G. citriodora are filled with brown cell content in sicco. Also there may be some bundled hairs intermixed with simple hairs. Guatteria citriodora when not in fruit may become difficult to distinguish from G. stipitata (Maas et al. 2015).
The recently described Guatteria intermedia differs from G. ouregou and G. richardii by having semi-erect to appressed instead of erect hairs on young twigs and pedicels (Maas et al. 2015)."

Guatteria pastazae can be recognized by verruculose leaves with obscure venation and by an attenuate leaf base combined with shortly pedicellate flowers and shortly stipitate monocarps. Guatteria pastazae shows some features of G. modesta but it differs by its much shorter stipes (stipes shorter than to almost equaling monocarp length vs stipes longer than the monocarp in G. modesta) (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria tomentosa is very well recognizable by the long-persistent indument of erect stiff hairs pointed flower buds and long sepals of 5-13 mm long. The leaf base of this species is extremely variable. It goes from obtuse cordate to even stem-clasping and is often oblique. It could be confused with G. hirsuta but from that species it differs by its erect instead of erect and appressed indument on most parts of the plant and by often revolute basal leaf margins (Maas et al. 2015).

Plants of Guatteria longicuspis studied by us are mostly cauliflorous. The leaves are frequently oblong-elliptic in shape. The number of minute warts on the lamina varies greatly the leaves ranging from densely to sparsely verruculose. The equally cauliflorous G. novogranatensis from Colombia (Boyaca and Santander) differs from G. longicuspis by much larger sepals (10-13 mm long and 5-7 mm long respectively). A third cauliflorous species G. scalarinervia is easily distinguished from G. longicuspis by the long petioles (15-20 mm long and 2-5 mm long respectively). In addition to these three species cauliflory occurs in G. conspicua and G. wachenheimii which are quite distinct as mentioned in the notes of those species. Finally G. scandens being a liana stands on its own in the genus with regard to cauliflory (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria oriximinae is a narrow endemic mainly restricted to the Mun. Oriximina in the Brazilian state of Para. It can at first glance be recognized by a combination of shortly stipitate monocarps (stipes shorter than the monocarps) and very small sepals (to 3 mm long) which moreover are rugulose on the outer side. The latter feature is not known in any other Guatteria species. It is one of the few species of Guatteria that occur in periodically inundated forests. Furthermore it is growing on sandy-rocky soils near water falls (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria dura resembles G. meliodora in many aspects (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria procera and G. monticola look very similar and can be confused (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria campestris is distinct by mostly narrowly elliptic leaves with an obtuse base with secondary veins forming an angle of 40-55 degrees to the primary vein which is a narrow angle for the genus. It resembles G. australis in the size and the shape of the leaves (narrowly elliptic to elliptic). However G. australis has secondary leaf veins forming an angle of 70-90 degrees with the primary vein (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria insculpta can be recognized by very densely and minutely verruculose leaves and by young twigs covered with a velutinous indument of erect red-brown hairs. Furthermore this species stands out by the dense cover of erect brown hairs on the lower side of the leaves (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria wachenheimii is very easily recognizable by the scabridulous leaves which have a marginal vein and by its very small monocarps (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria beckii a small shrub tree or even liana ("vine") occurs in the Bolivian states of Beni and Santa Cruz the Peruvian state of Junin and the adjacent Brazilian states of Acre and Amazonas where it mostly inhabits wet savannas or floodplain forests. It is recognizable by a distinct reticulate tertiary venation on the upper side of the leaves and by seeds with a very distinct raphe a feature rarely seen in Guatteria. It might be confused with G. maypurensis another savanna inhabiting species occurring in Bolivia but in the latter the leaves are often folded lengthwise in dry condition and the pedicels are shorter while the sepals are longer (pedicels 15-20 mm vs 15-50 mm in G. maypurensis and sepals 5-8 vs 3-4 mm) (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria australis is very variable and many names have been synonimised into this species in the last revision (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria japurensis is most distinctive by the long and slender fruiting pedicels bearing rather long monocarps a combination very uncommon in Guatteria. Another noteworthy feature is found in the leaves which are indistinctly veined and are scabridulous on the upper surface (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria odorata is recognizable by very small leaves (5-6 cm long) covered with long appressed hairs below and by small sepals (4-5 mm long) (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria amapaensis only known from the type locality has previously been considered to be an extreme form of G. blepharophylla by Maas and Westra (2011) and was included in that species. It is different from it, however, by the total lack of verruculae on the leaves and by the densely hairy monocarps and also by the rugose seeds (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria foliosa is one of the species of this genus most easy to recognize by its long and slender petioles a mostly obtuse leaf base that is abruptly and long-attenuate at the extreme base and secondary veins which are strongly raised on the upper side of the lamina (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria flabellata is recognizable by petals which are very well marked by a distinct impressed venation on their outer side furthermore the petals are distinctly narrowed towards the base (almost clawed) whereas the apex is often somewhat emarginate (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria elata is recognizable by its brownish (in sicco!) lamina an indistinct secondary leaf venation an attenuate leaf base and an inconspicuous indument of appressed hairs on the lower side of the lamina (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria duodecima at first glance can be distinguished by relatively narrow and verruculose leaves usually narrowed towards both ends and which are densely to rather densely covered with appressed almost silvery hairs on the lower side. Other distinctive features are the shortly pedicellate flowers and monocarps that are always longer that the stipes (Maas et al. 2015).

Contradictory to what the name might suggest Guatteria modesta contains some of the tallest trees within the genus reaching a height of up to 55 m and a diameter up to 1 m! By contrast most Guatterias are small to medium-sized trees with only relatively few species having been reported as tall trees with a trunk up to 50 cm diam. Guatteria modesta can easily be recognized by its long-attenuate often narrowly obovate leaves which have a quite dark colour when dry (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria discolor can be distinguished fairly easily by its 2-coloured leaves which are covered with an indument of erect reddish brown curly hairs on the lower side. Furthermore the monocarps are fairly large and wrinkled when dry the latter feature not often seen in the genus. A third remarkable aspect are the distinctly pointed flower buds. (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria maypurensis is one of the few species of Guatteria that is mostly found in savanna-like vegetations. It is a shrub or small tree with leaves that are mostly folded lengthwise in dry state other features are the sepals that are distinctly connate in the basal third and the narrowly oblongoid-ellipsoid monocarps. These features distinguish it from G. foliosa which it more or less resembles (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria rubrinervis is recognizable by its long pedicels with foliaceous bracts sometimes persisting till flowering time by erect hairs to c. 2 mm long on most of its parts and basally connate sepals (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria liesneri is generally easy to recognize by its blackish to dark brown leaves with mostly a strongly raised tertiary venation. From G. foliosa it differs by often blackish leaves smaller petioles (3-7 by 1-2 vs 5-15 by 0.5-1 mm) and pitted to transversely grooved instead of smooth seeds (Maas et al. 2015).

The main features of Guatteria hirsuta are narrow often greyish black coloured leaves an indument of erect to appressed brown hairs on the leafy twigs relatively long pedicels and pitted seeds (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria campinensis shares the velutinous indument of most parts and the leaf venation with G. trichocarpa. It differs from that species however by its much shorter petioles (2-5 vs 5-10 mm) and the lack of verruculose structures in the leaves (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria myriocarpa much resembles G. hirsuta but differs by the indument on young twigs which consists of mainly appressed hairs of up to c. 0.5 mm long vs erect hairs 1.5-2 mm long in G. hirsuta (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria pohliana is characterized by small leaves mostly not exceeding 10 cm in length often glabrous on both sides (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria trichostemon only known from the type collection (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria subsessilis is one of the few species often occurring in periodically flooded igapo and varzea forests along rivers at low elevations and less often on dry ground. It is well marked by coriaceous leaves in which the primary vein is often slightly raised on the upper side very narrow petals and by relatively short pedicels and stipes (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria stenophylla one of the few savanna inhabiting species of the genus can at first glance be recognized by very narrow and long-tipped leaves and very small petals (up to 11 mm long) (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria sellowiana is characterized by young twigs and lower leaf sides which are densely covered with erect brown and long-persisting hairs and by short pedicels. Among the species of the Atlantic Forest of Brazil G. sellowiana stands out by its characteristic dense indument (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria sabuletorum is characterized by a truncate and somewhat oblique leaf base loops far removed from the leaf margin (3-7 mm) and short stipes of 4-5 mm long (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria rupestris shares many features with the cerrado inhabiting G. rigida (Maas et al. 2015).
A noteworthy feature of Guatteria polyantha is the location of the articulation of the pedicel usually above the middle (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria pannosa is quite distinctive by having relatively narrow and coriaceous leaves pointed flower buds and a felt-like indument of small appressed hairs (hence the species name "pannosa") on various parts of the plant. With G. discolor a species occurring in Amazonian Bolivia Brazil Peru and French Guiana it shares the pointed flower buds differing by smaller monocarps (10-14 vs 15-30 mm long) longer stipes (20-25 vs 2-10 mm) and an indument of small appressed instead of erect and curly hairs on the lower side of the lamina. It also shares a number of features with the Panamanian species G. aberrans differing, however, by much narrower leaves (2.5-5 vs 4-9.5 cm) and longer stipes (20-25 vs 9-14 mm) (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria heteropetala is one of the few species in the genus occurring in periodically inundated forests. It is easily recognizable by strongly unequal petals the inner ones being almost twice as long as the outer ones (Maas et al. 2015).
Guatteria ramiflora is well marked by a very long winged petiole combined with leaves with a large number of secondary veins and often percurrent tertiary veins (Maas et al. 2015).

Guatteria notabilis one of the most beautiful species in the genus cannot be confused with any species in the genus because of the combination of terminal 1-3-flowered inflorescences densely hairy leaves and flowers almost sessile monocarps and densely verruculose leaves (Maas et al. 2015).

Two specimens from Serra do Navio, Amapá, Brazil were initially identified as Adelophryne gutturosa (Hoogmoed et al. 1994), but this material was later described as A. amapaensis (Taucce et al. 2020).

Simpson (1988) considered that there are two subspecies in Africa. The subsp. schweinfurthiana (Boeck) D.A. Simpson is distributed from West Africa to Sudan and subsp. setifolia (A.Rich.) J. Raynal is more widespread. The former differs for the latter in the perianth bristles, which are at least half as long as the nutlet.

Sporophila crassirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Oryzoborus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Myiothlypis fulvicauda (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Phaeothlypis following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Setophaga petechia (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Setophaga fusca (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
A taxonomic revision is needed (F. Uiblein pers. comm. 2019).

Atticora tibialis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Neochelidon tibialis.
Spatula discors (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Anas.

Vireo olivaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into Red-eyed Vireo V. olivaceus and Chivi Vireo V. chivi, as previously adopted by Stotz et al. (1996). Battey and Klicka (2017) strengthen this case on the basis of complete genetic separation and entirely antithetical patterns of movement but make no attempt to consider morphological characters. Boesman (2016) provides further support via finding that there is an extreme likelihood that there are consistent differences between the songs, (allowing a score of 4), plus chivi has a dark brown versus ruby-red iris (3) and the different migratory habits (maximum permitted score 1). Consequently, Chivi Vireo V. chivi is accorded species status.

Chaunax stigmaeus is highly suspected to be a synonym of C. pictus, but until gene sequencing research is conducted, C. stigmaeus remains recognized as distinct (J. Caruso and R. Robertson pers. comm. 2018). Chaunax pictus is the older name, therefore, C. stigmaeus would be designated as a synonym of C. pictus.
Pietsch and Kenaley (2011) recently described a new species from the Himantolophus appelii species group based on specimens that had been misidentified as H. appelii.
Sagittaria guayanensis is divided into two subspecies, S. guayanensis subsp. guayanensis from the Neotropics and subsp. lappula (D.Don) Bogin from the Palaeotropics.

This has been treated at times as a monospecific genus or a number of different species within the genus. It is extremely variable and many subordinate taxa have been described (e.g. TROPICOS lists 199 synonyms for this name). TROPICOS lists this taxon as P. communis Trin. by which name it was formerly known in the UK.


There is a degree of uncertainty over the taxonomic status of this species, some authorities consider that there is only species worldwide (e.g. T.A. Cope pers. comm.), however, a number of taxa are generally recognized (e.g. The Plant List). As a consequence of this uncertainty, it is very difficult to establish the true distribution of the various taxa. This assessment uses a combination of the World Checklist of Selected Plant Families and the Invasive Species Compendium (CABI International) to derive a country list, however, it is not certain that this list is comprehensive.

Casatti (2005) included Plagioscion surinamensis (Bleeker, 1873) as a junior synonym of P. squamosissimus (Heckel,1840), based on examination of the holotype.  However, other Amazonian specimens that had previously identified as Plagioscion surinamensis were incorrectly identified as Plagioscion magdalenae, which is endemic to the Magdalena River basin, Colombia (Casatti 2005, N.L. Chao pers. comm. 2019).
Thaumatichthys is a very poorly understood genus, and identifications of specimens are subject to change, pending the discovery of additional material (T. Pietsch pers. comm. 2019).

Colaptes rubiginosus and C. aeruginosus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. rubiginosus following SACC (2007), which prior to that was placed in the genus Piculus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
