In a recent study, Faria et al. (2013) demonstrated that the existing taxonomy of the Pristidae required modification, recognising a total of five species in two genera. Pristis pristis had been recognised previously as consisting of up to three species (Pristis pristis, P. microdon and P. perotteti), but utilising a combination of mitochondrial DNA and morphological characters appears to be one species. While the P. pristis group is best considered a single species, it can be composed of a network of geographical units (subpopulations) that are not genetically distinct, but may be considered ecologically different.
 
Pristis pristis, has been referred to by many other names throughout its range. It was formerly known as P. perotteti in the Atlantic and sometimes in the Eastern Pacific, and P. microdon in the Indo-West Pacific.

Faria et al. (2013) state that both morphology and genetics support the current specific status of the Smalltooth Sawfish (Pristis pectinata) and propose modification of the distribution of the species to an Atlantic only range. No geographical structure of Smalltooth Sawfish subpopulations is present, and Western and Eastern Atlantic subpopulations of Smalltooth Sawfish likely represent separate units for conservation purposes.
Annona prevostiae has recently been included as synonym for A. paludosa following (Maas et al. Flora of the Guianas, unpublished data).
This species has two recognized subspecies, Inga ciliata subsp. ciliata and Inga ciliata subsp. subcapitata (Pennington 1997).

Arachis paraguarensis Chodat & Hassl. is composed of two subspecies, subsp. capibarensis Krapov. & W.C.Greg. and subsp. paraguarensis (USDA, Agricultural Research Service, National Plant Germplasm System 2019). They are are difficult to distinguish using exomorphological characters (Krapovickas and Gregory 1994) but they have distinct geographic distributions and subsp. paraguarensis has a SAT chromosome which is not present in subsp. capibarensis (Fernández and Krapovickas 1994). Arachis paraguarensis is a tertiary wild relative of peanut (A. hypogaea L.) (Vincent et al. 2013).
Descrita em: Blumea 52(3): 454 (-457; figs. 12-13, map). 2007
This species is likely to be placed in the genus Nebris and thus be Nebris microps, not Plagioscion microps (Casatti 2005, N.L. Chao pers. comm 2019).

Chabanaud (1928) described this nominal species on the basis of about 11 specimens taken from Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil. In an unpublished dissertation, Ramos (1998) indicated that Catathyridium grandirivi is a junior, subjective synonym of C. garmani. This opinion has not been recognized by subsequent authors (e.g. Desoutter et al. 2001, Fricke et al. 2021). For the purposes of this assessment, C. grandirivi is treated as a valid species. Further work is needed to determine the taxonomic status of this nominal species.

Hibiscus tiliaceus is a widespread and well-known tropical and subtropical coastal species. Variety tiliaceaus is largely Old World occurring on the shores of the Indian Ocean and around much of the Pacific Basin whereas variety pernambucucensis is a New World variant occurring on both the Atlantic and Pacific shores of the American tropics. A small group of additional species, each of more limited distribution are centred taxonomically around these two taxa forming a natural group. This group is sometimes treated as a section within Hibiscus or separately from Hibiscus under a different genus (e.g. as Talipariti following Fryxell 2001). Sometimes the species are lumped into one or a few species. This group is kept under a broad concept of Hibiscus following Pfeil and Crisp (2005).

Separation of S. aurita from S. brasiliensis based on gill raker shape is tentative (Whitehead 1985). Sardinella brasiliensis may be a junior synonym of S. aurita (Whitehead 1985).  Purported differences in gill raker morphology between these two nominal species need to be confirmed.  More study is needed to evaluate the morphological and genetic differences between and among these populations in order to determine their taxonomic status (Whitehead 1985, Munroe 2002). Recent studies based on molecular data indicate that S. brasiliensis is a junior synonym of S. aurita (Mabragana et al. 2011, Stern et al. 2017) but this species is still recognized as valid (Eschmeyer et al. 2017). Sardinella janeiro (Eigenmann, 1894) has been erroneously applied for Sardinella brasiliensis in some older publications (Figueiredo et al. 2010). For the purposes of this assessment, Sardinella brasiliensis will be treated as valid.
This species is part of a species complex that includes at least three species, which have yet to be formally recognized taxonomically (Di Dario 2013).

authority: Barbosa, Gomes da Silva, da Rocha Araújo & Carvalho, 2017

taxonomicNotes: This species is morphological very diverse. Several subpopulations sometimes attributed to this species from Colombia, Venezuela, Brazil, Peru have been excluded following Rohwer (1993).

Symphurus trewavasae Chabanaud 1948 was described from specimens collected off Cape Frio, Brazil. In his revision of western Atlantic Symphurus, Ginsburg (1951) suggested that S. trewavasae was possibly not distinct from S. plagiusa (Linnaeus 1776). Subsequent authors (Menezes and Benvengú 1976, Munroe 1998) provided data warranting recognition of these as distinct species.

The Shorttail Yellownose Skate (Dipturus brevicaudatus) was split out from the former species concept of Zearaja chilensis (Gabbanelli et al. 2018). Concha et al. (2019) re-described Zearaja chilensis as Dipturus chilensis and subsumed the genus Zearaja Whitley 1939 as a junior synonym of Dipturus Rafinesque 1810.

Two species are recognized in the genus Sotalia: S. guianensis, the Guiana Dolphin, and S. fluviatilis, the Tucuxi. They are very similar in appearance and the genus was long considered monotypic. Two issues concerning the taxonomy of the dolphins in particular parts of the range of the genus deserve mention.

First, there is some uncertainty about the taxonomic status and range of Guiana Dolphins in the Orinoco River. There are frequent records of Sotalia at Ciudad Bolívar, some 300 km upstream from the river mouth. Such records are suspected to correspond to S. guianensis (da Silva and Best 1996, Meade and Koehnken 1991, Flores and da Silva 2009, da Silva et al. 2010). It is generally assumed that Sotalia dolphins cannot traverse the rapids at the Casiquiare Channel, which connects the Orinoco and Amazon basins (da Silva and Best 1996). This barrier has existed since the uplift of the Mérida Cordillera (10 million years ago; Lundberg et al. 1998), which predates the divergence of the two species of Sotalia (Cunha et al. 2005, Caballero et al. 2007, 2008). Thus, Sotalia in the Middle Orinoco are likely to be an isolated population of Guiana Dolphins (da Silva et al. 2010, Cunha et al. 2010). Seven animals from the Orinoco all possessed the same mitochondrial DNA sequences and had an estimated divergence from S. guianensis of 640,000 years ago (Caballero et al. 2017). Caballero et al. (2017) suggested that the Orinoco River animals belong to an independent population unit isolated from other coastal populations and worthy of separate conservation and management efforts.

The second issue relates to the taxonomic status of Sotalia dolphins from the southern freshwater portion of Maracaibo Lake. Those individuals are morphologically different from the marine Sotalia that inhabit the northern portion of the lake, adjacent to the Gulf of Venezuela. Dolphins from southern Maracaibo are smaller than marine Sotalia and about the same size as S. fluviatilis (Casinos et al. 1981, da Silva and Best 1996, León 2005). However, there is no connection between Maracaibo Lake and the known present-day range of riverine Sotalia, and the lake has been isolated from the Amazon basin for the last 8-10 million years (Hoorn et al. 1995, Días de Gamero 1996 cited in Cunha et al. 2010). The morphological distinctiveness of the southern Maracaibo Lake Sotalia population could be a result of phenotypic plasticity, unlike the difference between S. guianensis and S. fluviatilis. However, it may also indicate a lack of gene flow with the marine Sotalia from the mouth of the lake and the Gulf of Venezuela. Indeed, Caballero et al. (2006) observed some exclusive haplotypes in samples from the lake, but they did not consider this to signify a species-level difference. All haplotypes in Maracaibo Lake were S. guianensis (Caballero et al. 2017) with one of those being most closely related to the single haplotype found in the Orinoco River. Both of the populations here—in Maracaibo Lake and the Orinoco River—would meet the IUCN definition of a subpopulation.

The species Acanthochelys chacoensis (Fritz and Pauler 1992) was included in the 1996 and 2000 IUCN Red Lists, was been determined by Fritz and Pauler (1999) to be a junior synonym of A. macrocephala.

Although it was only recently described (Wada et al. 2003), the separate species identity of Omura’s Whale, Balaenoptera omurai, is now well established phylogenetically (Sasaki et al. 2006). It was formerly regarded as a pygmy form of Bryde’s Whale (B. brydei/edeni), but it is not closely related to that group, lying outside the clade formed by the Sei Whale (B. borealis) and two forms of Bryde's Whales). The morphology of Omura’s Whale is quite distinct from those of Bryde’s Whales and other known baleen whales, but its colouration resembles that of the Fin Whale (B. physalus) while lacking lateral rostral ridges (Wada et al. 2003).

To date (December 2017), the only genetically confirmed observations of living Omura’s Whales are of 18 biopsied individuals in an apparently resident population off northwestern Madagascar (Cerchio et al. 2015). Specimens collected in 1976 in the Solomon Sea (Ohsumi 1978) and in 1978 in the eastern Indian Ocean (Ohsumi 1980) were originally taken under a scientific permit for Bryde’s Whales and were subsequently genetically identified as Omura’s Whales (Wada et al. 2003). LeDuc and Dizon (2002) genetically analysed specimens of small “Bryde’s Whales” from the Bohol Sea, Philippines, and found that they segregated phylogenetically outside the Sei/Bryde’s Whale clade and basal to B. edeni/B. borealis. From a comparison of the published phylogenies, Sasaki et al. (2006) concluded that these specimens corresponded to Omura’s Whale. Yamada et al. (2008) identified 24 skulls from a whaling operation in the Philippines as Omura’s Whales.

This species is very closely related to Humiriastrum cuspidatum and should perhaps be synonymised. It differs in the oblong rather than globose fruit, and in the larger elongate and dentate leave (Prance in prep.).

This species is closely related to Humiriastrum piraparanense (Prance in prep.).

This species is accepted in the treatment for the family Humeriaceae in press (G. Prance 2019 pers. comm.).
Plants of the world online, treats this species as a synonym of Humiria balsamifera var. parvifolia.
Cuatrecasas (1961) described variety froesii of this species.
This species is close to Vantanea compacta (Prance in prep.).
This is a dubious species, the type specimen is not good and it is difficult to identify. There is doubts this is a good species (G. Prance pers. comm. 2007).
This species has two recognised varieties: Vantanea compacta var. compacta and Vantanea compacta var. microcarpa (Prance in prep.).
This species is known to have two varieties: var. glaziovii and var. angustifolia (Prance in prep.).

Sacoglottis glomerata is close to Sacoglottis ceratocarpa, but differs in the smaller leaves and fruit and the inconspicuous primary veins and venation. Similar to some forms of Sacoglottis mattogrossensis, but differs in the smaller leaves, the consistently long cuspidate apex, the oblong rather than round fruits and the glomerulate inflorescence (Prance in prep.).
This species is closely related to Vantanea bahiaensis and Vantanea obovata (Prance, in prep.).
Experts have suggested that this species may be a spring form of Eurytides dolicaon deicoon (Tyler et al. 1994).
There are two subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies himeros; and subspecies baia Rothschild & Jordan, 1906.

Previously, some authors recognised two subspecies for this species: the nominate subspecies burchellanus; and subspecies jaguarae (Foetterle, 1902). The latter was previously considered a subspecies of Parides panthonus, but was synonimised with P. burchellanus at the species level by both morphological observations as well as by genetic analysis (Mielke et al. 2004, Silva-Brandão et al. 2008).
There are currently three subspecies known for this species: the nominate subspecies pizarro; subspecies kuhlmanni (May, 1925); and subspecies steinbachi (Rothschild, 1905).

There are seven subspecies reported for this species: the nominate subspecies agesilaus; subspecies eimeri (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906): subspecies fortis (Rothschild & Jordan, 1906); subspecies neosilaus (Hopffer, 1866); subspecies autosilaus (Bates, 1861); subspecies montanum (Küppers, 1974); and subspecies viridis (Röber, 1926).

There are currently five subspecies recognised for this species: the nominate subspecies lysithous; subspecies eupatorion (Lucas, [1859]); subspecies harrisianus (Swainson, 1822); subspecies rurik (Eschscholtz, 1821); and subspecies sebastianus (Oberthür, 1879).
In 2009, Craig et al. confirmed that the Pacific “subpopulations” of Epinephelus itajara as a distinct species: E. quinquefasciatus (Craig et al. 2009).

No subspecies of False Killer Whale (Pseudorca crassidens) are currently recognized. However, there is evidence of geographic variability in skull morphology and life history (Kitchener et al. 1990, Ferreira et al. 2014). Based on genetics there is substantial population structure, both between and within-ocean basins, and even within a single archipelago (Martien et al. 2014). This species has been intensively studied only in Hawaii (Baird 2016) and more recently in New Zealand (Zaeschmar 2014). In Hawaii, three subpopulations have been identified based on a combination of genetic studies (Martien et al. 2014), satellite tagging (Baird et al. 2010, 2012, 2014, Bradford et al. 2014a), and analyses of photo-identification data (Baird et al. 2008, Baird 2016). These include two partially overlapping insular populations, one around the main Hawaiian Islands, and one in the northwestern Hawaiian Islands, as well as a partially overlapping pelagic population that ranges throughout and beyond the U.S. Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) around the Hawaiian Archipelago. In New Zealand, based on high resighting rates of photo-identified individuals and a relatively small number of individuals documented, it is likely that this represents a distinct subpopulation (Zaeschmar 2014). While the number of subpopulations world-wide is unknown, this is due primarily to incomplete sampling in most of the range. Based on the evidence from Hawaii, subpopulation structure likely exists throughout their range.

authority: (Mart. & Zucc. ex Marchal) D.A.Neill, Lowry & G.M.Plunkett

taxonomicNotes:
From 1976 until 1983, nomenclatural confusion designated Paspalum distichum for P. vaginatum and Paspalum paspaloides for P. distichum (Schulz 1962, Guedes 1976, 1981; Fosberg 1977, Renvoize and Clayton 1980). The matter was resolved in 1983 (Brummitt 1983) and appropriate taxonomic and morphological distinctions can be found in Echarte and Clausen (1993) and Webster (1987).

The main difference between the two species is that P. vaginatum inherently colonizes saline ecosystems while P. distichum can be found in freshwater habitats. Genetically, they are quite distinct (Echarte and Clausen 1993), and the two species can be differentiated by 20 morphological traits [adapted from Duncan 1997].
In Costa Rica, this species is very closely related to Aiouea pittieri and A. tonduzii (González and Hammel 2007).
Polyporus cryptopus is currently considered to be a synonym of Picipes rhizophilus.
This species may actually include several taxa (S.Knapp pers. comm. 2019).
Hay evidencias que muestran a una de las variedades de Copaifera venezuelana (C.venezuelana laxa), como taxa endémico de Venezuela.

This species has three accepted subspecies: subsp. trifolia, subsp. palmeri (C.DC.) Pennington, and subsp. pteleaefolia (Adr. Jussieu) Pennington. The differences between these is discussed in Pennington (1981).
This species has two recognized subspecies: subsp. tuberculata and subsp. lanceolata. The differences are described by Pennington and Clarkson (2016).

authority: (Mart. ex DC.) Penneys, F.A. Michelangeli, Judd & Almeda

taxonomicNotes: Al parecer también está en Brasil, pero no ha podido comprobarse.

Passos et al. (2018) synonymized Atractus limitaneus within Atractus collaris based on comparison of the type material of A. limitaneus and the description of A. collaris (for which the type has apparently been lost). These authors report that the state of one character distinguishing the two species is impossible to determine from the damaged A. limitaneus holotype, but note that this character is unlikely to be a reliable diagnostic feature. Atractus collaris as defined by Passos et al. (2018) is likely to exhibit some degree of divergence across its broad range, and a number of related species exhibit very restricted ranges. Passos et al. (2018) recommend further taxonomic studies at a higher resolution may be required to fully clarify the systematics of this species and to identify cryptic diversity.

Eiselt (1963) renamed Procteria viridis to Xenodon werneri, because X. viridis is preoccupied by Xenodon viridis Duméril & Bibron, 1854 (= Macropisthodon plumbicolor Cantor, 1839). Yuki (1993) erected a new genus, Thalesius, for Procteria, however, this is pre-occupied. The correct name for this taxon, which some authors have continued to call Thalesius viridis following Yuki (1993), is therefore Xenodon werneri.

The holotype was supposedly from Tsumeb, Namibia, but Eiselt  (1963) questioned this and indicated it was possibly from South America.
The concept of this taxon may be subject to change.

Laterallus flaviventer (Handbook of the Birds of the World and BirdLife International 2020) was previously in the genus Hapalocrex (del Hoyo and Collar 2014). Stervander et al. (2019) found that Inaccessible Rail Atlantisia rogersi, Dot-winged Crake Porzana spiloptera and Yellow-breasted Crake Hapalocrex flaviventer nest within a clade of Laterallus crakes, with the first two grouped closely with Black Rail Laterallus jamaicensis. It thus appears appropriate to move all three species to the genus Laterallus, and this option is adopted by BirdLife. 

Previously, the taxon had been placed in the genus Porzana.
Sclerurus scansor and S. cearensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. scansor following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Carduelis carduelis and C. caniceps (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. carduelis following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); Christidis & Boles (2008); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Turbott (1990).

According to the protologue (Sobral et al. 2016), this tree species is closely related to the widespread and very variable Myrcia splendens (Swartz) De Candolle, which ranges from Central America to southern South America.

The characters given in the diagnosis, especially for the consistently longitudinally ridged fruits, distinguish this species from its most widespread relative. This species matches most of the characters that define Myrcia section Myrcia in the classification of Lucas et al. (2018), such as paniculiform inflorescences, flowers with absent calyx tube (in some species short but visible) and a bilocular ovary, such as in M. splendens (Sobral et al. 2016).
Descrita em: Fl. Bras. Merid. (A. St.-Hil.). ii. 322.
The species epithet is given as 'vauthiereana' by some resources, but is considered correct as 'vauthieriana' here, following IPNI (2021) and Flora Mesoamericana (Missouri Botanical Garden 2019).
Gelochelidon nilotica and G. macrotarsa (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously placed in the genus Sterna and lumped as S. nilotica following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Recent studies have placed Cnemidophorus abaetensis in the genus Ameivula Harvey et al. 2012. Pyron et al. (2013) recommended it should remain in Cnemidophorus until a more extensive review of Brazilian species is concluded. Nonetheless the Sociedade Brasileira de Herpetologia and this evaluation follow Harvey et al. (2012).

Recent studies listed Cnemidophorus nativo within the genus Ameivula (Harvey et al. 2012). Pyron et al. (2013) suggested that it should remain within Cnemidophorus until a more extensive revision is completed. Following common usage among workers in the area where this species occurs, this evaluation follows Harvey et al. (2012) and Arias et al. (2014) in treating this species within Ameivula.

Leposternon octostegum was described in 1851 from a specimen now archived in the Muséum national d'Histoire naturelle, in Paris, with uncertain locality (Brèsil). Other specimens were lost due to uncertain taxonomic status; destroyed during World War II (Deutsches Museum Bonn, Germany), or deposited in unknown collections (Barros-Filho et al. 2013). It was rediscovered in 2003 from five subpopulations (Barros-Filho et al. 2013), and was subsequently re-described in detail by Barros-Filhos et al. (2019).

authority: Rodrigues, Texeira, Recoder, Dal Vechio, Damasceno & Machado-Pellegrino, 2013
(Rocha, Bamberg Araújo, Vrcibradic & Mamede Da Costa, 2000)
taxonomicNotes: A recent study listed Cnemidophorus littoralis under the genus Ameivula (Harvey et al. 2012). Pyron et al. (2013) suggested it remain under Cnemidophorus before a more extensive revision is completed.

Recent studies have placed Cnemidophorus nigrigula in the genus Ameivula Harvey et al. 2012. Pyron et al. (2013) recommended it should remain as Cnemidophorus until a more extensive review of Brazilian species is concluded. However, the Sociedade Brasileira de Herpetologia and this evaluation follow Harvey et al. (2012).

authority: (Colli, Costa, Garda, Kopp, Mesquita, Péres, Valdujo, Vieira & Wiederhecker, 2003)
taxonomicNotes: Morphological and molecular studies have shown that Ameiva parecis belongs within Ameiva, and not Cnemidophorus as in its original description (Arias et al. 2011, Harvey et al. 2012, Giugliano et al. 2013).

authority: Teixeira, Sousa-Recoder, Camacho, de Sena, Navas & Rodrigues, 2013
taxonomicNotes: Formerly considered to be Bachia bresslaui.

A recent study (Hedges and Conn 2012) separated the species previously, included in Mabuya, in a different genus. Vrcibradic et al. (2006) analysed the complex M. agilis, M. caissara, and M. heathi, and found that the genetic distances between them were small. They suggested that the three may represent a single species, but indicated the need for further data.

authority: Teixeira, dal Vechio, Sales-Nunes, Mollo-Neto, Moreira-Lobo, Storti, Junqueira-Gaiga, Freire-Dias & Rodrigues, 2013
de Freitas, Strüssmann, de Carvalho, Kawashita-Ribeiro & Mott, 2011
taxonomicNotes: Gainsbury and Colli (2003) included this population within Bachia cacerencis. De Freitas et al. (2011) confirmed it represented a new species, which they named Bachia didactyla.
On the basis of morphology and distribution, Costa et al. (2019) synonymized Amphisbaena mensae within A. talisiae.

The species was described from its holotype found in the state of Bahia (no specific locality; Peters 1878), and later Gans (1965) redescribed it based on an individual found in the municipality of Itabuna, also in Bahia.

authority: Teixeira Jr, dal Vechio, Neto & Rodrigues, 2014

taxonomicNotes: Péres (2003) indicated that Tupinambis palustris is a junior synonym of Tupinambis teguixin. While this - from an unpublished review - has not been widely accepted, and the species was treated as valid by Harvey et al. (2012) without comment, it is possible that confusion between the two taxa has contributed to the scarcity of data on this species.

Recent studies have listed Cnemidophorus cyanurus in the genus Ameivula Harvey et al. 2012. Pyron et al. (2013) recommended that it remain in the genus Cnemidophorus until a more extensive review is carried out. For this evaluation, the specialists followed Harvey et al. (2012).

authority: Rodrigues, De Freitas, Santos Silva & Viña Bertolotto, 2006

taxonomicNotes: The species of Anolis have been divided into eight genera (Nicholson et al. 2012, Castañeda and de Queiroz 2013) but the classification has not been widely accepted. In this assessment A. pseudotigrinus Amaral, 1933, is placed in the genus Anolis Daudin, 1802.

The species of Anolis have been divided into eight genera (Nicholson et al. 2012, Castañeda and de Queiroz 2013) but the classification has not been widely accepted. In this assessment A. nasofrontalis Amaral, 1933, is placed in the genus Anolis Daudin, 1802.
Ardenna grisea (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus as P. griseus.
Thalasseus sandvicensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna.
Nothura chacoensis has been lumped into Nothura maculosa after Hayes et al. (2018) determined that there is no support for the former as an independent species.

Phaethornis bourcieri has been split into P. bourcieri and P. major Hinkelmann 1989, following genetic evidence that the latter is actually more closely related to P. philippii and P. koepckeae (Araujo-Silva et al. 2017), plus morphological characters supporting the separation.
This species is in need of a detailed taxonomic review since there are indications that more than a single species is included within the current concept.

Waved Woodpecker Celeus undatus and Scaly-breasted Woodpecker C. grammicus have been lumped as Waved Woodpecker C. undatus, following the finding that there was no genetic or morphological differences between representatives of the two (Sampaio et al. 2018), and the previous observation that the calls were extremely similar (Benz and Robbins 2011).

Pyrrhura melanura has been split into P. melanura and P. chapmani following an assessment of the latter by Donegan et al. (2018), in light of the previous split of Maroon-tailed Parakeet into P. melanura and P. pacifica (del Hoyo and Collar 2014). While Donegan et al. (2018) are mistaken in scoring two covarying measurements twice, and only 1 is allowed for habitat difference, which in any case is not accepted here as too vague (the elevational difference may well be responsible for the increase in body size). However, in reviewing the photographs used to illustrate these differences it certainly appears that the blue primaries and the darker crown merit 2 each, the buffy nuchal region perhaps only 1 (3 seems extreme), but the size difference vs. melanura (mean wing 136.8 vs 126.6, tail 125.2 vs 109.9 in Table 1 in Ridgely & Robbins 1988, Wilson Bull. 100: 173-182) clearly scores 2, on which basis the form reaches and is accepted here as holding species rank.

Himantopus himantopus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as H. himantopus, H. leucocephalus and H. mexicanus and following AOU (1998) and SACC (2006). Prior to that, H. melanurus had been split from H. mexicanus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Machaeropterus regulus and M. striolatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as M. regulus following SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Ardea alba (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Casmerodius as C. albus. Casmerodius albus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993) was previously retained as a cross-regional species contra Christidis and Boles (2008) who moved C. albus into the genus Ardea and split it into two cross-regional species A. alba and A. modesta (note gender agreement of specific name for alba).
Sporophila maximiliani (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Oryzoborus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Passer domesticus and P. italiae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. domesticus following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 and supplements); Christidis and Boles (2008); Cramp et al. (1977-1994); Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993); SACC (2005 and updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996); Turbott (1990).

Riparia riparia and R. diluta (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. riparia following AERC TAC (2003), AOU (1998 and supplements), Cramp et al. (1977–1994), Dowsett and Forbes-Watson (1993), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993), and Stotz et al. (1996).

The BirdLife Taxonomic Working Group is aware that phylogenetic analyses have been published which have proposed generic rearrangements which may affect this species, but prefers to wait until work by other taxonomists reveals how these changes affect the entire groups involved.

Phaethornis bourcieri has been split into P. bourcieri and P. major Hinkelmann 1989, following genetic evidence that the latter is actually more closely related to P. philippii and P. koepckeae (Araujo-Silva et al. 2017), plus morphological characters supporting the separation.

Arremon flavirostris has been split into Saffron-billed Sparrow A. flavirostris and Stripe-crowned Sparrow A. dorbignii following the evidence of genetic separation and after comparison of museum specimens revealed that dorbignii differs by its; grey central crown-stripe vs none or just a grey nuchal patch (3); white vs black preocular supercilium (2); narrower breast-stripe (somewhat variable in other taxa; hence only 1); different song (at least 1).

Ortalis guttata, O. araucuan and O. squamata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. guttata following Stotz et al. (1996) and SACC (2011), and before then were also lumped with O. colombiana as O. guttata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The form remota has been recognised as a subspecies of O. guttata, having previously been an unrecognised form included within O. squamata, following the description of minor plumage differences in Silveira et al. (2017).

Vireo olivaceus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) has been split into Red-eyed Vireo V. olivaceus and Chivi Vireo V. chivi, as previously adopted by Stotz et al. (1996). Battey and Klicka (2017) strengthen this case on the basis of complete genetic separation and entirely antithetical patterns of movement but make no attempt to consider morphological characters. Boesman (2016) provides further support via finding that there is an extreme likelihood that there are consistent differences between the songs, (allowing a score of 4), plus chivi has a dark brown versus ruby-red iris (3) and the different migratory habits (maximum permitted score 1). Consequently, Chivi Vireo V. chivi is accorded species status.

Ortalis guttata, O. araucuan and O. squamata (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as O. guttata following Stotz et al. (1996) and SACC (2011), and before then were also lumped with O. colombiana as O. guttata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The form remota has been recognised as a subspecies of O. guttata, having previously been an unrecognised form included within O. squamata, following the description of minor plumage differences in Silveira et al. (2017).
Formicivora acutirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Stymphalornis acutirostris.
Lipaugus ater (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Tijuca atra.

The Committee on Taxonomy of the Society for Marine Mammalogy (Committee on Taxonomy 2016) provisionally lists the following subspecies: Balaenoptera musculus musculus (Linnaeus, 1758) - Northern Blue Whale (found in the North Atlantic and the North Pacific); B. m. intermedia (Burmeister, 1871) - Antarctic Blue Whale; B. m. indica (Blyth 1859) - Northern Indian Ocean Blue Whale; B. m. brevicauda (Ichihara, 1966) - Pygmy Blue Whale; and B. m. un-named subspecies - Chilean Blue Whale.

The nominate subspecies B. m. musculus refers at least to the North Atlantic Blue Whale which was the basis for the first description of the species by Linnaeus. Animals in the North Pacific are similar in size and morphology to North Atlantic Blue Whales and are also regarded as B. m. musculus, pending a genetic comparison of these populations. The Antarctic form B. m. intermedia is distinguished by its large body size and Antarctic distribution in summer. The Pygmy Blue Whale B. m. brevicauda has a number of morphological characteristics that distinguish it from B. m. intermedia and B. m. musculus. It occurs in the Indian Ocean, excluding the Antarctic, from Africa and Madagascar across to Indonesia and Australia, and in the southwestern Pacific, including Tasmania and New Zealand. Blue Whales in the northern Indian Ocean have been tentatively assigned the name B. m. indica, but a clear distinction between B. m. indica and B. m. brevicauda has not yet been established.

Blue Whales in the southeastern Pacific are intermediate in size between B. m. intermedia and B. m. brevicauda (Branch et al. 2007a) and are genetically differentiated from both groups (LeDuc et al. 2017). They are provisionally designated as an unnamed subspecies with the common name Chilean Blue Whales. Chilean Blue Whales are genetically most similar to Blue Whales in the northeast Pacific (LeDuc et al. 2017); investigations into the genetic and morphological distinction between these two groups are ongoing. The respective winter ranges of Blue Whales from the eastern South Pacific (Chilean Blue whales) and from the eastern North Pacific may overlap in the eastern equatorial Pacific but their breeding seasons are probably six months out of phase (LeDuc et al. 2017).

Recent genetic work indicates that the genus Stenella is paraphyletic and it is likely that the Delphininae will be restructured in the coming years (LeDuc et al. 1999, Perrin et al. 2013).

Four subspecies of Spinner Dolphins are currently recognized: S. l. longirostris (Gray’s Spinner Dolphin), S. l. orientalis (Eastern Spinner Dolphin), S. l. centroamericana (Central American Spinner Dolphin) and S. l. roseiventris (Dwarf Spinner Dolphin) (Perrin 1990, Perrin et al. 1999). There is a zone of hydridisation between Gray’s Spinner and the Eastern Spinner where an intermediate form called the White-bellied Spinner occurs (Andrews et al. 2013). Smaller individuals in Arabian waters (Red Sea and Arabian Gulf) (Van Waerebeek et al. 1999) and morphologically different animals in West Africa may represent as yet undescribed subspecies (Cadenat 1959, Jefferson et al. 1997). Several studies have demonstrated significant meta-population genetic structure, especially where relatively insular dolphin communities are strongly associated with island resting habitat such as in the Hawaiian Archipelago (Andrews et al. 2013) and in the South Pacific (Oremus et al. 2007).

All Bottlenose Dolphins around the world were previously recognized as Tursiops truncatus, but currently, the genus is considered to be composed of two species: T. truncatus (Common Bottlenose Dolphin) and T. aduncus (the smaller Indo-Pacific Bottlenose Dolphin) (Wang et al. 1999, 2000a,b). The Common Bottlenose Dolphin has a worldwide distribution in tropical and temperate latitudes but exhibits a strong ability to adapt to local conditions, a complex social structure and strong site fidelity which results in considerable habitat partitioning throughout its range. This, in turn, has created strong population differentiation accompanied, in some cases, by marked morphological differentiation. The taxonomy of Bottlenose Dolphins is confused due to this geographical variation, and it is very possible that additional species will be recognized in the future.

Three subspecies are currently recognized by the Society for Marine Mammalogy’s Committee on Taxonomy (2017) and a recent re-assessment of Tursiops taxonomy worldwide conducted by the International Whaling Commission confirmed their validity (IWC 2018). These subspecies are the Black Sea Bottlenose Dolphin (T. t. ponticus Barabash-Nikiforov, 1940) which differs morphologically and genetically from other forms including those in the nearby Mediterranean Sea (Barabash-Nikiforov 1960, Geptner et al. 1976, Natoli et al. 2005, Viaud-Martinez et al. 2008). The Lahille Bottlenose Dolphin (T. t. gephyreus) (Lahille, 1908), a larger form in the coastal waters of the western South Atlantic Ocean, is morphologically and genetically different from the offshore population in eastern South America (Costa et al. 2015, 2016; Fruet et al. 2011, 2015). The third subspecies is the nominate subspecies that includes the remaining Common Bottlenose Dolphins worldwide (T. t. truncatus (Montagu, 1821)). In the western North Atlantic, two forms, offshore and coastal, are distinguishable on the basis of morphology and ecological markers (Mead and Potter 1995) and have fixed genetic differences (Le Duc and Curry 1997, Hoelzel et al. 1998, Kingston et al. 2009, Rosel et al. 2009, Van Waerebeek et al. 2017a) and according to the recent IWC review the coastal population should be recognized as at least a different subspecies.

Plant specimens collected in Bahia (Brazil) have recently been classified as Psidium amplexicaule. According to Landrum (2017) this species appears to belong to a complex of a few Caribbean species with a disjunct occurrence along the coast of Bahia. Further taxonomic studies are required.

There are two species described under the name Celtis spinosa: C. spinosa Spreng. and C. spinosa Ruiz ex Miq., the latter being a synonym of Celtis iguanaea (Jacq.) Sarg. (POWO 2019). Some authors also consider C. spinosa Spreng to be a synonym of C. iguanaea (Jacq.) Sarg. (Dottori and Hunziker 1994, Zuloaga and Morrone 1999, Berg and Dahlberg 2001, JBRJ 2019). However, we follow here the latest revisions accepting C. spinosa Spreng as an accepted species (Torres and Luca 2005, Pederneiras et al. 2011, POWO 2019, Souza 2019).
There are two accepted infraspecifics of Protium heptaphyllum: P. heptaphyllum subsp. heptaphyllum and P. heptaphyllum subsp. ulei (Damasco et al. 2019, POWO 2019).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.

Here we consider Anadoras regani a junior synonym of A. weddellii following Sousa (2010), a taxonomic status largely accepted by fish specialists (B.B. Calegari pers. comm. 2020). This is contrary to Fricke et al. (2020) who consider Anadoras regani a valid species.

Anadoras weddellii has been identified as Amblydoras hancockii in French Guiana (ICMBio 2018).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.

authority: Marceniuk, Molina, Caires, Rotundo, Wosiacki & Oliveira, 2019

taxonomicNotes: This species was recently separated from Pogonias cromis (Azpelicueta et al. 2019).

Avila-Pires et al. (2010) state that a large sample of small amphisbaenians from the area around the Amphisbaena tragorrhectes type locality confirm that this species is a junior synonym of A. vanzolini. It appears that a "forthcoming paper" providing the evidence for this synonymy has never been published, and at present A. tragorrhectes is recognized as a valid species.

Recent molecular studies (Geurgas et al., 2008) indicate that the taxonomic diversity within Coleodactylus is largely underestimated, resulting from ancient vicariant events started back in the late Cretaceous (64.2 - 75.2 mya). The genus includes a large number of cryptic species, and Coleodactylus natalensis is nested within a clade including undescribed species currently assigned to C. meridionalis. Further taxonomic studies are necessary for describing the real diversity within this genus. Despite the overall ancient nature of divergence within the genus, molecular data indicate a relatively recent (1.9 ± 1.3 mya) divergence between C. natalensis and undescribed species allocated to C. meridionalis.

authority: Verrastro, Veronese, Bujes & Martins Dias Filho, 2003

taxonomicNotes: The genus Platynotus has been revalidated by Schmidt and Inger (1951) and by Vanzolini et al. (1980).

Acanthistius patachonicus and A. brasilianus have been confused in the past, but are confirmed as separate species. Acanthistius brasilianus does not occur in Argentine waters (Irigoyen et al. 2008, 2010).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
This species was on the 2000 IUCN Red List as Isothrix picta (DD). The Rodent Specialist Group note that Echimys pictus is the correct name. Now listed by IUCN as Callistomys pictus.

Although Physeter catodon is still occasionally used in the literature, P. macrocephalus is recommended (Rice 1989). Both names are listed on the same page of the original description by Linnaeus (1758), and priority is unclear. However, P. macrocephalus is preferable because it is used much more frequently, and this will support nomenclatural stability.

Although some authors consider this species a synonym of Acrocomia aculeata (Jacq.) Lodd. ex R.Keith (Henderson et al. 1995, Moreno and Moreno 2013, Gauto and Stauffer 2017), it is here treated as a distinct species following Lorenzi et al. (2010), Moraes (2015) and POWO (2019). Based on the collections that Alcides d'Orbigny obtained in Bolivia (Beni), Martius assigned the epithet of "totaí" because this is the name by which this species is locally known.
Exemplares deste táxon vinham sendo identificados como outras espécies (Apostolepis pymi, Apostolepis gr. nigrolineata ou Apostolepis sp.) (Costa e Bérnils 2018).

Aegiphila panamensis is closely related to Aegiphila mollis and they are difficult to separate. There are older names that can be apply for this species (A. panamensis), including:  A. mollis Kunth, A. filipes Mart. & Schauer and A. peruviana Turcz.; a taxonomic research is needed in order to clarify this complex. (Rueda and Hammel 2015).
For this assessments, we treat this species as Balizia elegans, following Zamora 2010.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
This species is taxonomically problematic and is in need of revision (T.P. Carvalho pers. comm. 2020).
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.

Antrostomus rufus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus. Caprimulgus otiosus (Stotz 1996) was lumped into C. rufus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and AOU (1998). Note that this taxon was treated as a species in Collar and Andrew (1988) but not subsequently.
Hydropsalis cayennensis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus.
Hydropsalis maculicaudus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Caprimulgus.
Eupsittula pertinax (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Aratinga.
Pionus menstruus and P. reichenowi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. menstruus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Piaya cayana and P. mexicana (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cayana following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Anous tenuirostris and A. minutus (Sibley and Monroe 1990, 1993), cross-regional species, are retained as separate species contra Turbott (1990) who includes minutus as a subspecies of tenuirostris.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.
There are no relevant taxonomic limitations.

The taxonomy of the genus has been debated, but recent work supports the use of the name Lontra rather than Lutra for New World river otters (van Zyll de Jong 1982, Larivière and Walton 1998, Wozencraft 1993, Koepfli and Wayne 1998). Three proposed subspecies are suggested by their present disjunct distribution: L. longicaudis annectens, restricted to México, Central America and north-western South America; L. l. enudris, distributed across the Amazon region, from eastern Venezuela, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru to north-western Bolivia and northern Brazil; and L. l. longicaudis, southern part of its distribution in South America (Larivière 1999, Trinca et al. 2012, Hernández-Romero et al. 2018).

Two subspecies have been described (Duplaix 1980): (1) P. b. brasiliensis (Gmelin, 1788) from Suriname, the Guianas, southern Venezuela, southern Colombia, eastern Ecuador, eastern Peru, Bolivia, Paraguay, and Brazil; (2) P. b. paranensis (Rengger, 1830) from the Paraguay and Parana rivers in Brazil, northern Argentina and Uruguay. However, this subspecific division was rejected by Carter and Rosas (1997) and described as being of “doubtful value” by Duplaix (1980).  Wozencraft (2005) treated subspecies paranensis as a synonym of a different subspecies P. b. paraguensis (Schinz, 1821). Subsequent mitochondrial DNA and microsatellite analysis supports subdivision of the species into four evolutionary distinct units (ESUs). These comprise: (1) the Rio Madre de Dios with the Rio Madeira (2); the Pantanal (3) the Amazon with the Orinoco and Guianas drainages (4) The Itenez/Guapore basin (Garcia et al. 2007; Pickles et al. 2011, 2012).

Many authors have considered this species to be a junior synonym of Paralichthys brasiliensis, a species that is often confused with; however, these species can be distinguished by meristic characteristics and both are currently accepted as separate nominal species (Díaz de Astarloa et al. 2006).

No subspecies. Only three specimens definitively identified as Sylvilagus tapetillus exist. The Rio de Janeiro Dwarf Cottontail was originally described as an independent species, and later subsumed as a subspecies of the Tapetí (S. brasiliensis). Recently, on the basis of a comprehensive morphological evaluation, cytochrome-B data, and karyotypic attributes, it was classified as independent and removed from synonymy from brasiliensis (Bonvicino et al. 2015, Ruedas et al. 2017).

Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.

authority: Pontes, Gadelha, Melo, de Sá, Loss Junior, Costa & Leite, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This species was described in 2013 (Mendes Pontes et al. 2013).

The identity of this species needs to be revised. According to Kirby (1897) Micrathyria cambridgei differs from M. didyma in the number of post-triangular cells. This character is likely to be variable. Therefore,  this species needs revision.

Aramides cajaneus has been split into Grey-cowled Wood-rail A. cajaneus (with one subspecies A. c. avicenniae: latens and morrisoni are synonymised with cajaneus) and Russet-naped Wood-rail A. albiventris (with mexicanus, vanrossemi, pacificus, and plumbeicollis synonymised with albiventris) following an assessment of the evidence provided by Marcondes and Silveira (2015).

Tunchiornis ochraceiceps and T. luteifrons (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Hylophilus ochraceiceps following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Cantorchilus leucotis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Thryothorus leucotis.

Anthus lutescens and A. peruvianus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as A. lutescens following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Herpsilochmus rufimarginatus and H. scapularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as H. rufimarginatus following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Tangara episcopus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Thraupis following AOU (1998 & supplements); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Apostolepis tertullianobuei was synonymized within Apostolepis assimilis within a year of its description (Ferrarezi et al. 2005) on the basis that the described characters fell within the latter species' range of variation. These authors did not, however, examine the holotype of A. tertullianobuei, and following a subsequent comparison of the holotypes of the two species Lema and Renner (2007) revalidated it. This was not followed in the checklist by Wallach et al. (2014) but was accepted by Costa and Bérnils (2015), who determined that A. parassimilis represents a junior synonym of A. tertullianobeui. The validity of this species remains in question (C. Nogueira pers. comm. 2020); and is considered doubtful, but it is accepted as valid in a recent atlas for Brazilian snakes (Nogueira et al. 2019).

Islerothraupis luctuosa (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Tachyphonus and listed as T. luctuosus following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Saltator coerulescens, S. olivascens and S. grandis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. coerulescens following AOU (1998 and supplements); SACC (2005 and updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Asio clamator (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Pseudoscops.
Notharchus tectus and N. subtectus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as N. tectus following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Chaetura chapmani (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as C. chapmani and C. viridipennis following SACC (2005), and before then lumped as C. chapmani following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Platyrinchus mystaceus and P. albogularis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as P. mystaceus following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Rhynchocyclus olivaceus and R. aequinoctialis (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as R. olivaceus following AOU (1998 and supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Sittasomus griseicapillus and S. griseus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as S. griseicapillus following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Deconychura longicauda, D. typica and D. pallida (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as D. longicauda following AOU (1998 and supplements), SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Xenops rutilus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously listed as Xenops rutilans.

Automolus subulatus and A. viragtus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as Hyloctistes subulatus following AOU (1998 & supplements), SACC (2005 & updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).
Rupornis magnirostris (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Buteo.
Pseudastur albicollis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Leucopternis.

Buteo nitidus and B. plagiatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as B. nitidus following AOU (2006), the gender agreement of which follows David and Gosselin (2002a), and before then were placed in the genus Asturina following AOU (1998), and before then were split as A. nitida and A. plagiata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Setophaga pitiayumi and S. graysoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously placed in the genus Parula and lumped as P. pitiayumi following AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).
Onychoprion fuscatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Sterna as S. fuscata.
Ardenna gravis (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Puffinus.
Geranoaetus albicaudatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Buteo.

Descrita em: Boletim do Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi, Série Botânica 9: 1. 1960. Espécie conhecida pelo material-tipo. Coleta de J.M. Pires, 6149. Registrada pelo especialista B. Wallnöfer na Flora do Brasil on line 2020 com endêmica do Pará.

Descrita em: Plantarum Brasiliae Icones et Descriptiones 1: 57. 1827. Em coleções de herbário, a espécie é confundida com C. obtusifolius, que ocorre em AL, BA, ES e PE. Melo & Sales (2008), também comentam a semelhança entre as referidas espécies e o erro de identificação comum entre as mesmas, mas realçam as características que as distinguem (Casas e Dominguez, 2005).
Descrita em: Flora 47: 230. 1864, como Lonchocarpus peckoltii Wawra. Foi recombinada na obra: Brittonia 64(3): 275. 2012.

Descrita em: Memoirs of The New York Botanical Garden 20(1): 61–62. 1969. É a única espécie do gênero que apresenta o tronco armado com espinhos longos retos enquanto os râmulos são providos com ganchos lenhosos semelhantes a gavinhas (Flora do Brasil 2019). Conhecida popularmente como: Esporão-de-galo (Sant'Ana 208), Amora Preta (Folli 2646).
Descrita em: U.S. Expl. Exped. 1: 591. 1854, como Clidemia e em Fl. Bras. 14(4): 179, fig. 39-I. 1886, como Leandra.

Descrita em: Taxon 61(5): 1054, f. 9. 2012. Esta espécie é similar a M. bullata, mas dela difere principalmente desta pela superfície rugosa do hipanto e pelo cálice apendiculado. As folhas com a base peltada são bastante distintas, apesar desta característica não ter sido mencionada na descrição original (Goldenberg et al., 2012; Bochorny e Goldenberg, 2017).

Descrita em: Kew Bull. 58(2): 477. 2003. É conhecida apenas pela coleta tipo, que data do ano de 1999. Conhecida popularmente pelo nome "laranjinha". Diferencia-se de D. ierensis principalmente pela morfologia do fruto.

Descrita em: BioLlania, Edición Especial 6: 492, f. 1C–J, 2B. 1997. Tapura wurdackiana, a espécie de Tapura mais amplamente distribuída na Mata Atlântica, é simpátrica a T. follii no Espírito Santo e a T. martiniae no estado da Bahia. Pode ser distinguido de T. follii por suas lâminas de folhas maiores que são 5–18 × 3–5.5 (vs. 5–9 × 2.2–4 cm) e pecíolos muito mais longos, com 17 a 27 mm (vs. 5 a 8 mm). Tapura wurdackiana difere de T. amazonica por suas laminas foliares elípticas-obovadas (vs. estreitamente oblongasem T. amazonica) com indumento densamente velutinoso abaxialmente (vs. indumentário tomentoso abaxialmente), ovário inteiramente canescente (vs. ovário pilose) e estigma ca 1 mm de comprimento (vs. ca 0,5 mm de comprimento) (Amorim et al., 2016).

Descrita em: Kew Bulletin 42(1): 223, f. 1987. Kielmeyera bifaria assemelha-se a K. petiolaris e K. lathrophyton devido às sépalas oblatas a orbiculares, mas difere de ambas pelas folhas com nervuras secundárias imersas na face adaxial (vs. planas a proeminentes) e pecíolo geralmente mais curto (até 2 cm vs. 1,5x4,5 cm compr.) (Santos et al., 2015).
Descrita em: Goldenberg, R. & Reginato, M., Brittonia, 59(4): 339-342, f. 3, 2007.
Descrita em: Gardner, G., London J. Bot., 4: 102, 1845.Registros do estado do Espirito Santo não são confirmados a determinação pelo especialista.

Descrita em: Hoehnea 21: 202 (1994). Popularmente conhecida por Batinga, Aperta-guela, Rapa-guela, Jabuticaba-branca, Jabuticaba-verde, Jabuticabatinga em diferentes regiões do Brasil (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019) e por jabuticaba da mata na região de Linhares (ES) (Folli 2230).
Descrita em: Prodromus Systematis Naturalis Regni Vegetabilis 13(1): 133. 1852. Nomes populares: panaceia e milho-de-cobra (Leitão et al. 2014).

Descrita em: Novon 14(1): 45–47, f. 2. 2004. Na descrição original de Styrax griseus, Fritsch (2004) inclui vários materiais coletados nas cangas de Carajás na relação de parátipos,sendo uma espécie relativamente comum na região. Distingue-se de Styrax pohlii, que também ocorre na área, pelas lâminas foliares cartáceas a subcoriáceas, com margens revolutas face adaxial com tricomas estrelados, mesmo nas folhas mais velhas (Viana e Mota, 2016).

Styrax griseus assemelha-se a S. camporum pelas folhas cartáceas a subcoriáceas, fortemente discolores, com a face abaxial cinérea e o cálice cinéreoesverdeado. Porém, diferencia-se por apresentar folhas com margem revoluta (vs. plana), indumento abaxial heterogêneo, com tricomas castanhos esparsos sobre indumento de tricomas cinéreos (vs. indumento abaxial homogêneo com predominância de tricomas cinéreos), tricomas com raio 0,1–0,12 mm (vs. 0,3–0,6 mm), sendo ásperas ao toque (vs. aveludadas ao toque) e face adaxial pubescente com tricomas cinéreos esparsos (vs. face adaxial glabrescente) (Aspirino e Amorim, 2013).

As espécies mais similares morfologicamente ao Acritopappus pereirae são provavelmente A. confertus, que tem a distribuição mais ampla entre as espécies do gênero, incluindo os estados da Bahia, Ceará, Pernambuco e Sergipe, embora não esteja presente em Minas Gerais; A. diamantinicus Bautista, S. Ortiz e Rodr. Oubiña, do estado da Bahia; e A. longifolius distribuídos principalmente ao longo de Minas Gerais, mas também presentes nos estados do Rio de Janeiro e São Paulo (Bautista et al., 2011).

Tapura follii é simpático a T. wurdackiana no Espírito Santo. Essas duas espécies têm um hábito semelhante e ambas têm folhas coriáceas; no entanto, T. follii tem uma veia mediana vilosa na superfície da folha abaxial (vs.velutinoso em T. wurdackiana) (Amorim et al., 2016).

Descrita em: Ann. Naturhist. Mus. Wien, B 106: 239 (-240). 2005. Conhecida popularmente como "Caquí baiano" (Folli, D.A. 6429). "Árvore de 5 a 12 m de altura. Folhas subelípticas, glabras, coriáceas. Flores tetrâmeras, com os lobos do cálice triangulares. Ocorre na Mata Atlântica, incluindo áreas de restinga. Floresce em dezembro e fevereiro, frutifica em novembro e julho. Conhecida apenas por quatro coletas, a última há 10 anos" ( Wallnöfer, 2005 apud Santos e Sano, 2009). Foi citada pelo coletor com o nome popular de caqui baiano (Folli, D.A., 6429).
Descrita em: Annalen des Naturhistorischen Museums in Wien. Serie B, Botanik und Zoologie 102B: 418–419. 2000. Espécie conhecida pelo material-tipo. Foi coletada por I.L. Amaral et al., 411.

Descrita em: Brittonia 2 (2): 162-163, 1936. Seu material-tipo é B.A. Krukoff, 6758, foi coletado em Humaitá no estado de Amazonas e depositado nos diversos herbários: MG, LE, K, G, F, BR, BM, A, US, U, S, RB, NY, MO, MICH, (AM),(Wallnöfer, 2015). Foi coletada em "terra firme", perto do rio Livramento (Smith, 1936).

Descrita em: Bradea, Boletim do Herbarium Bradeanum 3(24): 188–190, f. 2 a–d. 1981. Popularmente conhecida por sucupira-preta (Rodrigues 8040). Possui grande afinidade com D. purpurea var. leptophylla, da qual é bem distinta principalmente pelos folíolos subcoriaceos com indumento viloso ou esparso-vílosona face dorsal (Lima, 1985). D. rodriguesii foi inicialmente citada como D. ferruginea (Rodrigues, 1974). Entretanto, esta espécie é facilmente reconhecida pelas flores menores providas de indumento fulvo-tomentoso e pelos folíolos glabros ou esparso-viIoso na face dorsal (Lima, 1985).

Descrita em: Phytotaxa 177(1): 37. 2014. O epíteto é a palavra latina para entrelaçado, "perplicatus", e faz referência a corola difusa da planta, formada por seus ramos curvos, sinuosos e um tanto relaxados. Também é alusivo à suarelação intrincada com as espécies simpátricas relacionadas Mimosa paludosa, M. acroconica e M. caliciadenia (Borges e Pirani, 2014).

Descrita em: Systematic Botany 39 (4): 1134–1138, f. 1a–d, 2a–d. 2014. (3 Sep 2014). A segregação de Ormosia lewisii como uma nova espécie distinta de O. costulata e O. trifoliolata é sustentada por diferenças multiple morfológicas e uma grande disjunção geográfica (Cardoso, 2014).
Descrita em: Notizblatt des Königlichen botanischen Gartens und Museums zu Berlin 6: 358. 1915.
Descrita em: Monographiae Phanerogamarum 7: 795. 1891. Foi documentada pela última vez em 1950.
Descrita em: Transactions of the Linnean Society of London 28(1): 104. 1871.
Descrita em: Loefgrenia; communicaçoes avulsas de botânica 94: 4. 1993.
Descrita em: Kew Bulletin 64(1): 151–153, f. 4. 2009. O epíteto específico refere-se ao túnel curto das inflorescências dessa espécie (Mazine e Souza, 2009).
Descrita em: Hoehnea 21: 202. 1994. Nomes populares: Jaboticaba e Jabuticaba-de-folha-grande (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019).
Descrita em: Flora Neotropica, Monograph 77: 179–181, f. 10B,F, 18E, 77B, 79A–F. 1999. Nomes populares amarelinha e pau amarelo (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019).
Descrita em: Brittonia 37(1): 109–110, f. 1–4. 1985. Conhecida pelo nome popular de "rabo-de-arara" (Lorenzi, 1998).

Descrita em: Florae Fluminensis, seu, Descriptionum plantarum parectura Fluminensi sponte mascentium liber primus ad systema sexuale concinnatus 66: 2, t. 30. 1825. Conhecida pelo nome popular Grandiúva d’anta (Felitto et al. 2017).
Descrita em: Sitzungsberichte der Mathematisch-Physikalischen Classe (Klasse) der K. B. Akademie der Wissenschaften zu München 9: 634. 1879.
Descrita em: Conspectus sectionum specierumque generis Serjaniae 353. 1874.

Descrita em: Nordic Journal of Botany 30(4): 402. 2012. Nome Popular Bapeba (Alves-Araújo 2019). A espécie foi considerada como ‘Least Concern’ (LC) pelos autores da espécie (Alves-Araújo & Alves, 2012).

Descrita em: Novon 9(3): 345–348, f. 1. 1999. e recombinada recentemente em Phytotaxa 366(1): 29–30, f. 13, 19C. 2018. O epíteto específico homenageia Paulo Cavalcante, pesquisador que contribuiu para o conhecimento desse grupo de plantas (Devecchi et a., 2018). Homalolepis cavalcantei é morfologicamente bastante distinto de H. paraensis e H. morettii, por terem arvoretas de até 9 m de altura com o hábito peculiar semelhante a uma palmeira, enquanto as outras duas espécies são árvores grandes, formando um tronco e copa evidente, atingindo até 40 m de altura (Devecchi et al., 2018).
Descrita em: J. Bot. Res. Inst. Texas 8(1): 62–64, f. 1a–3. 2014.Segundo os autores, o estado de conservação da espécie apresenta-se na categoria de dados deficientes (DD) (Seigler, et al. 2014).

Descrita em: Linnaea 34: 137. 1865. Croton sapiifolius pode ser reconhecido por apresentar folhas coriáceas com margens inteiras a sinuosas; pelas inflorescência unissexuais, sendo as estaminadas axilares e as pistiladas terminais e pelo ovário geralmente 2-locular (Riina et al., 2010).
Descrita em: Kew Bull. 4(4): 481. 1950. Conhecida apenas pela coleta tipo, datada de 1919 (Ducke s.n., RB 12613).
Descrita em: Flora Brasiliensis 14(4): 572, t. 122, f. 1. 1888. Conhecida popularmente como trançadinha (Folli 5017).
Descrita em: Flora Brasiliensis 14(4): 572, t. 122, f. 2. 1888. Popularmente conhecida por pau-rato ou pau-de-colher.

Descrita em: Flora Brasiliensis, 14 (1): 266, 1857. A especialista Valdemarin K. (com. pess.) relata que "Não é possível confirmar a determinação, pois a taxonomia da espécie não é bem resolvida. Existe apenas uma ilustração de Vellozo para a espécia (o tipo nunca foi encontrado), que não é muito informativa."
Descrita em: Flora Brasiliensis 14(1): 262. 1857. Conhecida popularmente como: Batinga gigante (Folli 7266).
Descrita em: Flora Brasiliensis 14(1): 575. 1859. Conhecida popularmente como Jamelão Selvagem em Linhares, ES (Folli 2088).
Descrita em: Flora Brasiliensis, 14 (1): 274, 1857. Popularmente conhecida como Batinga do nativo (Instituto terra, 2019).
Descrita em: Arquivos do Instituto de Biologia Vegetal 4: 50. 1938. Foi documentada pela última vez em 1977.
Descrita em: Arbeiten aus dem Königl. Botanischen Garten zu Breslau 1: 115. 1892. Conhecida popularmente como Canella (Glaziou 17182).
Descrita em: Berg, O., Fl. bras., 14(1): 400, 1857.Popularmente conhecida por araçá-cagão no estado de Minas Gerais (Flora do Brasil, 2019).

Descrita em: Novon 9(3): 345–348, f. 1. 1999. e recombinada recentemente em Phytotaxa 366(1): 29–30, f. 13, 19C. 2018. O epíteto específico “docensis” refere-se ao local de coleta (Parque Estadual do Rio Doce), únicos dois registros conhecidos desta espécie (Devecchi et al., 2018). Embora Homalolepis docensis compartilhe várias semelhanças com o endêmico da Amazônia H. paraensis, como apontado por Franceschinelli e Yamamoto (1999), uma relação estreita entre as duas espécies não é suportado por dados moleculares (Devecchi et al. 2018). Muitos dos caracteres apresentados na descrição original para distinguir as duas espécies sobrepõe-se, como tamanho dos foliolos, forma e indumentum e características das flores, como tamanho das pétalas e ginóforo. Por outro lado, outros caracteres que não se sobrepõem são a presença em H. docensis das glândulas laminares nos foliolos apenas na superfície adaxial (vs. presença nas duas superfícies de H. paraensis), inflorescências mais curtas com o eixo principal medindo 13-18 cm de comprimento e presença de tricomas glandulares espalhados pelos ramos (vs. 23–33 cm, ausência de tricomas glandulares), apêndices estaminais com a metade basal adnada ao filamento e a metade distal livre com ápice bidentado (vs. apêndice estaminal adnado a filamento ao longo de toda a extensão, exceto as projeções laterais distais que terminam em duas projeções laterais).

Descrita em: Acta Amazonica 7: 191. 1977. Espécie conhecida apenas pelo material-tipo. Diospyros landii Cavalcante foi coletada por N.T. Silva, 3512. O material tipo está depositado nos herbários NY e IAN.A espécie é endêmica do Brasil, do estado do Acre.

Descrita em: Botanische Jahrbücher für Systematik, Pflanzengeschichte und Pflanzengeographie xxx. Beibl. lxvii. 14. 1901. Popularmente conhecida por canela. Até 2005, era conhecida somente pelas coleções-tipo, realizadas em Goiás (Moraes, 2004). A espécie pode ser diferenciada de P. aurata pelapubescência levemente crespa, lanosa (Moraes, 2004).

Descrita em: Harvard Papers in Botany 16(2): 408. 2011. Macrocarpaea dolichophylla parece estar relacionada com M. orbiculata no tamanho e na forma das flores, mas difere em apresentar brácteas arredondadas ovadas e não orbiculadas, e bracteolas imperceptíveis, trianguares, de 1 × 1 mm. É notavelmente distinta de todos os membros do gênero conhecidos até hoje em suas grandes folhas lineares longas como cintas (Grant e Trunz, 2011).
Descrita em: Prodromus Systematis Naturalis Regni Vegetabilis 15(2): 530. 1866. C. medusae é uma espécie bem delimitada e facilmente diferenciada das demais espécies congêneres.

Descrita em: Mém. Mus. Hist. Nat. 10: 277 e recombinada recentemente em Phytotaxa 366(1): 29–30, f. 13, 19C. 2018. Esta espécie é morfologicamente semelhante a H. cuneata. Embora o espécime tipo de Homalolepis floribunda seja um espécime bastante pobre, Devecchi et al. (2018) conseguiram analisar partes florais suficientes, e juntamente com coleções recentes adicionais, definiram uma espécie distinta. Os dois táxons podem ser distinguidos um do outro pelas folhas maiores, com rachis medindo 18 a 21 cm de comprimento em H. floribunda (vs. 8,2-15,4 cm), portando mais foliolos [11–15 (vs. 7–9)], com glândulas laminares na superfície adaxial restritas à base (vs. dispersas da base até a porção mediana do folheto ou mais, mas nunca no ápice), flores menores com pétalas elípticas, medindo 7,6 a 8,1 mm de comprimento (vs. estreitamente elíptico a lanceolado e 8,8 a 10,1 mm), filamento de 2,9 a 3,5 mm de comprimento (vs. 5,3 a 7,1 mm), apêndice estaminal de 2,3 a 3,5 mm de comprimento com ápice truncado (vs. 3,7 a 4,4 mm com ápice bidentado), ginóforo pubescente ( vs. sericose) e frutos oblongo-obovóides, vermelho a laranja (elipsóide a obovóide, amarelo a laranja). Além disso, são alopátricos e ecologicamente separados: H. cuneata ocorre em restingas e florestas tabulares semideciduais da Bahia, Espírito Santo e Rio de Janeiro, com poucos registros de enclaves de florestas semidecíduas no domínio do Cerrado em Minas Gerais. Além disso, marcadores moleculares suportam uma estreita relação entre essas duas espécies e também a H. subcymosa (Devecchi et al. 2018a). A última espécie é distinta de H. floribunda por rachis mais curtas, de 6,5 a 10 (–14,5) mm (vs. 18–21 mm), foliolos cartáceas (vs. coriáceas), flores menores com pedicelo mais curto, ca. 2,6 mm (vs. 5,1-6,4 mm), pétalas 7,6-8,1 mm (vs. 8,9-11,5 mm) e apêndices estaminais com 2,3-2,8 mm de comprimento com ápice truncado (vs. 3,5-4,7 mm, ápice acuminado).
Descrita em: Novon 8: 449 (449-451, fig. 2) (1998). Nome vulgar: arapoca-ostra (PA) (Salomão 608); batiputazinho (PA) (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2019); jaborandi (Rodrigues 660)
Descrita em: Mattos, J.R., Loefgrenia, 28: 1, 1969.Comumente conhecida como: Araçá-peludo (Barbosa et al, 2017)
Descrita em: Arquivos do Instituto de Biologia Vegetal 1(3): 207. 1935.Não são conhecidos nomes comuns para esta espécie (Groppo, 2012).

Descrita em: Taxon 61(5): 1050, f. 7. 2012. Difere de M. sipolisii pela face abaxial lanata das folhas, com araquinoide-amorfo tricomas e também pelos estames adisepalos no qual apêndice ascendente apresenta lobos arredondados (Goldenberg et al., 2012).
Descrita em: Nomenclator Botanicus. Editio secunda 2: 279. 1841. Espéice documentada pela última vez em 1984.

Descrita em: Boletim do Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi, Série Botânica 22: 2. 1966. Diospyros manausensis Cavalcante é uma espécie endêmica e nativa do Brasil. Seu material-tipo é L.Coelho s/n, foi coletado em Manaus no estado de Amazonas e depositado nos diversos herbários: INPA, MG, (Wallnöfer, 2015). O material tipo foi coletada em Florestas de terra firme Km 12 da estrada do Aleixo (Cavalcante, 1666)
This species was previously considered a subspecies of the Pacific Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus orientalis) or Atlantic Bluefin Tuna (Thunnus thynnus).

This species has been taxonomically problematic and there have been several published varieties of it. However, recent studies showed that Hymenaea stigonocarpa var. stigonocarpa and H. stigonocarpa var. pubescens are synonyms (Pinto 2017) and a revision in preparation concluded that Hymenaea stigonocarpa var. brevipetiolata should be treated as a different species (Pinto pers. comm. 2020).
There are two varieties of Anadenanthera colubrina: A. colubrina var. colubrina and A. colubrina var. cebil (Altschul 1964).

Descrita em: Nomencl. Bot. (ed. 2) 2(1): 191. 1840. É reconhecida por apresentar folhas bilobadas, face adaxial glabra e abaxial de pubescente a hirsuta, inflorescência até 20cm de comprimento (Vaz e Tozzi, 2003).
Descrita em: Journal of the Washington Academy of Sciences 11(7): 157. 1921. Popularmente conhecida como moirá jibóia preta no Acre (Flora do Brasil 2020 em construção, 2020).
Descrita em: Fl. Bras. 15(2): 188, 1870. É reconhecida por folhas bilobadas, face adaxial glabra e face abaxial pubescente, inflorescência geralmente ramificada (Vaz e Tozzi, 2003).

Descrita em: Linnaea 11: 388, 1837. É afim de L. parvifolium e L. elegans, mas difere por pulvínulos menores, tubo do cálice maior, ovário tomentoso e por apresentar brácteas e bractéolas geralmente maiores (Rodrigues e Tozzi, 2012). Popularmente conhecida como amargozinho no centro-oeste e perobinha no sudeste, romã-brava, pau-pratudo, perobinha-de-chapada, unha-de-anta, amargosa e cascudinho (Rodrigues, 2020).As informações da espécie foram validadas pelo especialista através do questionário (Rodrigo Schütz Rodrigues, comunicação pessoal, 2020).

Descrita em: Nomencl. Bot. [Steudel], ed. 2. 1: 191, 1840. É afim de Bauhinia subclavata, mas difere por suas flores com bractéolas estreito lanceoladas e pétalas obovado-oblongas, obtusas, e bractéolas ovadas e pétalas linear-lanceoladas, obtusiúsculas, respectivamente. Popularmente conhecida como miroró, mororó, pata-de-vaca e unha-de-vaca (Pereira et al., 2018).

Descrita em: Linnaea 11: 390, 1837. Popularmente conhecida como leptolóbio e perobinha-do-campo no Sudeste, amendoim-falso, chapadinha, sucupira-branca, genciana, cascudinho, óleo-bálsamo-do-campo e no Paraguai como incienso-del-campo (Rodrigues, 2020). As informações da espécie foram validadas pelo especialista através do questionário (Rodrigo Schütz Rodrigues, comunicação pessoal, 2020).

Descrita em: Arch. Jard. Bot. Rio de Janeiro 4: 311, 1925. É reconhecida por folíolos ovados ou largo-ovados, de ápice acuminado, estandarte externamente velutino e fruto do tipo legume samaroide, seríceo (Polido e Sartori, 2011).
This species has two varieties: the widespread M. herbertii var. herbertii and M. herbertii var. tepuiensis, endemic to Bolivia.

This species has been moved to Aspidosperma schultesii Woodson - there are two syn: Aspidosperma mori (L. Allorge) L. Allorge and Aspidospserma microphyllum Muell. Arg. ssp. morii L. Allorge (Allorge  2002).

There is some confusion with the name Rheedia benthaiana Planch. & Triana being the synonym of Garcinia benthamiana (Pl. & Tr.) Pipoly and also of Garcinia microphylla Mart.In this treatment Garcinia benthamiana (Pl. & Tr.) Pipoly is the accepted name with a native range from Colombia to N. South America.
The taxonomic disposition of the name is yet resolved (Anderson et al. 2006).
Geissospermum sericeum Benth. & Hook. f. ex Miers - homonym
Amazona autumnalis, A. diadema and A. lilacina (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as A. autumnalis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: Quattro, Driggers III, Grady, Ulrich & Roberts, 2013
taxonomicNotes: This cryptic species is most closely related to the Scalloped Hammerhead (Sphyrna lewini), and is morphologically distinguishable by the number of precaudal vertebrae (Quattro et al. 2013).

authority: Boubli, Byrne, da Silva, Silva-Júnior, Costa Araújo, Bertuol, Gonçalves, de Melo, Rylands, Mittermeier, Silva, Nash, Canale, Alencar, Rossi, Carneiro, Sampaio, Farias, Schneider, & Hrbek, 2019
Gusmão, Messias, Carneiro, Schneider, de Alencar, Calouro, Dalponte, de Souza Mattos, Ferrari, Buss, de Azevedo, Santos Júnior, Nash, Rylands & Barnett, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Anumara forbesi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Curaeus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

The taxonomy of this family is currently highly fluid - this species may therefore move into a new genus. There are records assigned to this species name from Brazil, Guyana and Colombia, however the sequences are sufficiently different that it is unlikely that they represent the same species. We therefore consider this species to be restricted to the coastal Atlantic forest of Brazil, with other cryptic species requiring new names.
Macro- and micromorphology, ecology, and sequence data from the ITS and 28S confirm the generic placement of Clavulina kunmudlutsa.

authority: Sulzbacher, Orihara, Grebenc, M.P. Martín & Baseia

taxonomicNotes: At present it is classified within its own genus, but this may change when the phylogeny of the family stabilizes (Henkel et al. 2016).
Fomitiporia bambusarum belongs to a bamboo-specific species complex, which includes F. sanctichampagnatii, F. spinescens, F. uncinata and Phellinus garuhapensis.

Aegis luteocontexta was originally described by Ryvarden and Meijer (2002) as Antrodiella lueteocontexta Ryvarden and Meijer 2002. It would be a Trametopsis based only on morphological characters (Gomez-Montoya et al. 2017); however, using phylogenetic analysis the species was transferred to Aegis by Westphalen et al. (2019).

This species is part of the Antrodia heteromorpha complex, being macromorphologically very difficult to discriminate. It was described in 2016 based on phylogenetic, morphological and ecological data, and can be distinguished by its occurence on Baccharis uncinella, specially in the Vassourais (Kaipper-Figueiró et al. 2016).

Meruliopsis cystidiata (≡Gloeoporus cystidiatus Ryvarden) is a new combination proposed by (Jung et al. 2018) based on molecular phylogenetic evidence. Gloeoporus guerreroanus G. Coelho, R.M. Silveira & Rajchenb was also shown to be conspecific with M. cystidiata.

Rickiella edulis was originally described by Spegazzini (1891) as Peziza edulis. Now this species belongs to the monotypic genus Rickiella (Pfister 1987). The species Rickiella transiens Sydow, described in 1904 (Sydow in Rick 1904) was considered a synonymy of R. edulis by Pfister (1987).
At present it is classified within its own genus, but this may change when the phylogeny of the family stabilizes (Henkel et al. 2016).
There are two subspecies of Diptychandra aurantiaca: D. aurantiaca subsp. aurantiaca and D. aurantiaca subsp. epunctata (Tul.) H.C.Lima, Carvalho & M.J.Costa (POWO 2019).
Core (1936) treated Scleria tenella as a synonym of the related species Scleria verticillata Muhl. ex Willd.

Physalis cordata Houst. ex Mill. is a wild relative of Cape gooseberry, P. peruviana L., low ground-cherry, P. pubescens L. and tomatillo, P. philadelphica Lam. The species is classified in Taxon Group 4, following the definition of Maxted et al. (2006).
Malacoptila striata and M. minor (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as M. striata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

authority: (Ochoa, Silva, Costa e Silva, Oliveira & Datovo, 2017)

taxonomicNotes: The inclusion of Ferrarissoaresia ferrarisi in a phylogenetic context is necessary to confirm its generic position (Calegari et al. 2019).

authority: Costa e Silva, Ribeiro, Lucena & Lucinda, 2018
Deprá, da Graça, Pavanelli, Avelino & Oliveira, 2018

taxonomicNotes: Caryothraustes erythromelas (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Periporphyrus following SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

The Celtis subgenus Mertensia was revised and the former Celtis punctata (Urb. & Ekman) Urb. & Ekman was placed in synonymy under C. ehrenbergiana (Klotzsch) Liebm. (Berg and Dahlberg 2001). Tropicos (2020) lists 57 synonyms for Celtis ehrenbergiana. Liogier (1996) and Acevedo and Strong (2012) recognize Celtis punctata as a separate species endemic to Hispaniola. However, given the revision of the genus, C. ehrenbergiana, as revised is now considered to be widely distributed in southern US, Mexico, Hispaniola, Puerto Rico and South America.

Setophaga cerulea (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) was previously placed in the genus Dendroica following AERC TAC (2003); AOU (1998 & supplements); SACC (2005 & updates); Sibley & Monroe (1990, 1993); Stotz et al. (1996).

Ipomoea tiliacea (Willd.) Choisy is a tertiary wild relative of Sweet Potato, Ipomoea batatas (L.) Lam. var. batatas (Jarret and Austin 1994, Huang et al. 2002, Rajapakse et al. 2004, Vincent et al. 2013).

Microsatellite markers demonstrated within- and among-population genetic variability. Over most of its range, genetic differentiation was subtle. Geographically isolated and peripheral populations were much more distinct. Populations from Florida, the Pacific of Panama, Gulf of Guinea, and Costa Rica, were genetically differentiated (Ward et al. 2008). It is unknown to what extent larval dispersal versus adult migrations contribute to this differentiation (Adams pers. comm. 2011).

Allobates was formerly included within Dendrobatidae (Grant et al. 2006). Three subpopulations assigned to this species in the original description are included only tentatively (Lima et al. 2010), and the taxonomy of this species remains to be resolved (A. Lima and I. Kaefer pers. comm. October 2010).
