Stewart of preserved materials in nearly all museums of the world that house wild-caught voucher specimens of Arapaima. Stewart (2013) provides selected distinguishing characteristics within the diagnosis of A. agassizii.

According to Hilton and Lavoué (2018), Osteoglossidae is the most diverse family of Osteoglossomorpha, with four extant genera, classified in two subfamilies (Osteoglossinae, including Osteoglossum from South America and Scleropages from Southeast Asia and Australia, and Arapaiminae (= Heterotidinae) including Heterotis from Africa and Arapaima from South America).
Taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1977, 1979a).

Hershkovitz (1977) considered Saguinus bicolor to have three subspecies: the nominate, S. b. ochraceus and S. b. martinsi. Groves (2001, 2005) and Rylands et al. (1993, 2000) listed the forms ochraceus and martinsi as subspecies of S. martinsi.

Leontocebus midas inustus Schwarz, 1951, Tabocal, Amazonas, Brazil. J. Hernández-Camacho and T. Defler (1989) indicated the possibility of two subspecies of S. inustus in Colombia. The taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012) is followed.

Taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1977) except for Saguinus labiatus rufiventer (Gray, 1843), which he listed as a junior synonym of S. l. labiatus. He recognized that red-bellied tamarins in the north of their range were distinct but argued that there is probably a clinal variation between populations. However, it was considered a valid subspecies by Groves (2001, 2005), with a provisional distribution (also indicated by Hershkovitz) which extends south from the Rio Solimões between the Rios Madeira and Purus to the Rio Ipixuna, an east bank tributary of the Rio Purus.

Taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1977), except in the recognition of the two former subspecies (S. m. midas and S. m. niger) as full species (see S. niger). Vallinoto et al. (2006) found that samples from S. midas from the Río Uatumã separated out from those from the Rio Trombetas to the east, about 200km. This indicates a possibility that red-handed and yellow-handed forms of S. midas may be geographical races or distinct species (J. de Sousa e Silva Jr. pers. comm., April 2007).

Taxonomy according to Hershkovitz (1977), but Groves (2001, 2005) found that, while S. m. mystax and S. m. pluto are very similar to each other, the form pileatus is quite distinct, and he listed it as a separate species, S. pileatus. The problem with this is geographic. The three forms have a continuous distribution but pileatus completely separates the geographic ranges of mystax and pluto (see Rylands et al. 1993). The taxonomic status – species or subspecies – remains to be determined in future genetic analyses.

Hershkovitz (1977) considered Saguinus bicolor to have three subspecies: S. b. bicolor, S. b. ochraceus and S. b. martinsi, besides the nominate form. Groves (2001, 2005) and Rylands et al. (2000) listed the forms ochraceus and martinsi, as subspecies of S. martinsi.

Vallinoto et al. (2006) indicated that the Rio Tocantins could act as a barrier to gene flow for Saguinus niger. This was presaged in a molecular genetic analysis by Tagliaro et al. (2005). The form described as Mystax ursulus umbratus Thomas, 1922, from Cametá, Rio Tocantins, Pará, listed by Groves (2001, 2005) as a junior synonym of S. niger, and by Hershkovitz (1977) as a junior synonym of S. midas niger, was indicated as a distinct geographical race or species (J. de Sousa and Silva Jr. pers. comm., cited in Rylands and Mittermeier 2008). Recently, Gregorin and de Vivo (2013) revalidated Saguinus ursula Hoffmannsegg, 1807 as a distinct species. Based on pelage coloration, morphology and molecular data, the authors described the samples from the east bank of the Tocantins River as S. ursulus which are distinct from specimens of S. niger from the west bank. Saguinus niger and S. ursulus are allopatric, and Tocantins River is acting as an effective barrier for gene flow (Gregorin and De Vivo 2013).

Hershkovitz (1977), Eisenberg (1989), Rylands et al. (1993) and Rylands and Mittermeier (2008) listed the Black-handed Tamarin as a subspecies of Saguinus midas. It is now considered as a distinct species (Rylands et al. 1993, 2000; Groves 2001, 2005). Vallinoto et al. (2006) indicated that the Rio Tocantins could act as a barrier to gene flow for Saguinus niger. This was presaged in a molecular genetic analysis by Tagliaro et al. (2005). The form described as Mystax ursulus umbratus Thomas, 1922, from Cametá, Rio Tocantins, Pará, listed by Groves (2001, 2005) as a junior synonym of S. niger, and by Hershkovitz (1977) as a junior synonym of S. midas niger, was indicated as a distinct geographical race or species (J. de Sousa e Silva Jr. pers. comm., cited in Rylands and Mittermeier 2008). Recently, Gregorinand and de Vivo (2013) revalidated Saguinus ursula Hoffmannsegg, 1807 as a distinct species from Saguinus niger. Based on pelage coloration, pattern of morphological divergence and molecular data, the authors described the samples from the east bank of the Tocantins River as S. ursulus which are distinct from specimens of S. niger from the west bank. Saguinus niger and S. ursulus are allopatric, and the Tocantins River is acting as an effective barrier for gene flow (Gregorin and De Vivo 2013).

Saimiri taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). An alternative taxonomy is presented by Thorington Jr. (1985) as follows: S. sciureus sciureus (includes the forms albigena, macrodon, and ustus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), S. sciureus boliviensis (includes the forms pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 and jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 recognized by Hershkovitz [1987]), S. sciureus cassiquiarensis, S. sciureus oerstedii (includes the form citrinellus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), and S. madeirae (given as a junior synonym of S. ustus by Hershkovitz [1984]). Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) recognize S. sciureus caquetensis Allen 1916, given as a junior synonym of S. sciureus macrodon by Hershkovitz (1984). Costello et al. (1993) argued for the recognition of just two species: S. sciureus in South America, and S. oerstedii in Panama and Costa Rica. Boinski and Cropp (1999) using two nuclear genes (IRBP and ZFX) and one mitochondrial (D-Loop) strongly support the Hershkovitz (1984) taxonomy, advocating four distinct species: Saimiri sciureus, S. boliviensis, S. oerstedii and S. ustus.

Hershkovitz (1987, footnote page 22) recognized Saimiri boliviensis jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 and S. b. pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 (given as junior synonyms of S. b. boliviensis in Hershkovitz 1984) as valid subspecies. They are listed by Groves (2001, 2005) as synonyms of S. b. boliviensis.

Saimiri ustus I. Geoffroy, 1843 was described based on material collected by Alexandre Rodrigues Ferreira, deposited initially in the Museu Real d’Ajuda, in Lisbon. During Napoleon’s invasion of Portugal, the specimen was confiscated and taken to the Museum National d’Histoire Naturelle, in Paris, registered as number 476 (532), and later described by I. Geoffroy (Hershkovitz 1984). In his description, Geoffroy (1843) gave the diagnostic characters as bright golden-orange forearms, hands and feet and nearly completely nude ears. The validity of Saimiri ustus was accepted by Allen (1916), Elliot (1913), Cruz Lima (1945), Hill (1960) and Hershkovitz (1984).

Saimiri madeirae Thomas, 1908 was described based on a specimen collected in Humaitá, on the left bank of the Madeira River, Amazonas, Brazil, and deposited in the British Museum of Natural History, registered as number 1908.5.9.6. Thomas (1908) emphasized among the diagnostic characters of the new species the general blue grey colouration of the dorsal area and the yellow of the extremities, confined to the hands and feet. The validity of the name Saimiri madeirae was accepted by Elliot (1913), Allen (1916), Cruz Lima (1945) and Hill (1960), who all considered S. madeirae as a species distinct from S. ustus.

Hershkovitz (1984) considered S. madeirae as a junior synonym of S. ustus. On the other hand, Thorington (1985) validated S. madeirae, as distinct from S. ustus. Following Thorington (1985), S. ustus would be a variant form of S. sciureus, with nearly hairless ears. Costello et al. (1993) invalidated S. ustus, considering it a junior synonym of S. sciureus. Subsequent authors (e.g. Rylands et al. 2000, 2012; Groves 2001, 2005; Rylands and Mittermeier 2009; Lavergne et al. 2010; Chiou et al. 2011; Paglia et al. 2012) follow Hershkovitz (1984), considering S. ustus the valid name for the squirrel monkey species with naked ears.

Saimiri taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). An alternative taxonomy is presented by Thorington Jr. (1985) as follows: S. sciureus sciureus (includes the forms albigena, macrodon, and ustus recognized by Hershkovitz, [1984]), S. sciureus boliviensis (includes the forms pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 and jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 recognized by Hershkovitz [1987]), S. sciureus cassiquiarensis, S. sciureus oerstedii (includes the form citrinellus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), and S. madeirae (given as a junior synonym of S. ustus by Hershkovitz [1984]). Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) recognize S. sciureus caquetensis Allen 1916, given as a junior synonym of S. sciureus macrodon by Hershkovitz (1984). Costello et al. (1993) argued for the recognition of just two species: S. sciureus in South America, and S. oerstedii in Panama and Costa Rica.  Boinski and Cropp (1999) using two nuclear genes (IRBP and ZFX) and one mitochondrial (D-Loop) strongly support the Hershkovitz (1984) taxonomy, advocating four distinct species: Saimiri sciureus, S. boliviensis, S. oerstedii and S. ustus. Thorington (1985) described the existence of two different pelage colouration phenotypes (S. ustus vs. S. madeirae) based on geography (see Lynch Alfaro et al. 2015). Mitochondrial molecular data suggests S. ustus as currently defined may be paraphyletic (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2015).

Saimiri taxonomy follows Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). An alternative taxonomy is presented by Thorington Jr. (1985) as follows: S. sciureus sciureus (includes the forms albigena, macrodon, and ustus recognized by Hershkovitz, [1984]), S. sciureus boliviensis (includes the forms pluvialis Lönnberg, 1940 and jaburuensis Lönnberg, 1940 recognized by Hershkovitz [1987]), S. sciureus cassiquiarensis, S. sciureus oerstedii (includes the form citrinellus recognized by Hershkovitz [1984]), and S. madeirae (given as a junior synonym of S. ustus by Hershkovitz [1984]). Hernández-Camacho and Defler (1989) recognize S. sciureus caquetensis Allen 1916, given as a junior synonym of S. sciureus macrodon by Hershkovitz (1984). Costello et al. (1993) argued for the recognition of just two species: S. sciureus in South America, and S. oerstedii in Panama and Costa Rica. Boinski and Cropp (1999) using two nuclear genes (IRBP and ZFX) and one mitochondrial (D-Loop) strongly support the Hershkovitz (1984) taxonomy, advocating four distinct species: Saimiri sciureus, S. boliviensis, S. oerstedii and S. ustus.

Phylogenetic studies by Lynch Alfaro et al. (2015) and Mercês et al. (2015) resulted in the classification  of Saimiri sciureus as a monotypic species, restricted to the northeastern Amazon on the Guiana Shield extending in Brazil, north of the Amazon into French Guiana, Suriname and Guyana.

The description of Saimiri sciurea collinsi Osgood, 1916 was based on a specimen that belonged to a series of four collected by Emília Snethlage, an ornithologist and at the time the Director of the Museu Paraense Emílio Goeldi (MPEG).  The holotype was depoited in the Field Museum of Natural History (specimen number 19534). In the original description, Osgood (1916) omitted the other three specimens from the same series that remained in the mammal collection at MPEG (MPEG 1378, 1379, 1380). The type locality is Fazenda Teso, Soure municipality, Marajó Island, Pará, Brazil. Cruz Lima (1945), Cabrera (1958) and Hill (1960) reiterated the validity of the taxon as a subspecies of S. sciureus. However, Hershkovitz (1984) considered S. s. collinsi a junior synonym of S. s. sciureus, and this designation was followed by most subsequent authors (e.g., Thorington 1985, Boinski & Cropp 1999, Rylands et al. 2000, Groves 2001, 2005, Rylands & Mittermeier 2009). Despite having observed morphological diferences between specimens from the two banks of the Amazon River, Thorington (1985) interpreted these differences as geographic variation. While Costello et al. (1993) included S. collinsi representatives in their samples, they did not mention the name published by Osgood. In fact, Costello et al. (1993) considered all the names that had been applied to different forms of South American Saimiri to be junior synonyms of Saimiri sciureus. Despite the large differences among the taxonomic arrangements of Hershkovitz (1984), Thorington (1985) and Costello et al. (1993), there was consensus (see also Hill 1960, Boinski & Cropp 1999) in recognizing the populations in all of the eastern Amazon as belonging to a single terminal taxon. More recently, Pinheiro (2003) observed, using mitochondrial genetic analysis of the D-loop region, that the samples coming from the two sides of the Amazon River were presenting genetic differentiation of a similar magnitude as that observed across other taxa within Saimiri. Pinheiro (2003) proposed that the forms north and south of the eastern Amazon River were distinct taxa but did not verify the available names for these taxa. Lavergne et al. (2010) found similar results and proposed the revalidation of Saimiri collinsi Osgood, 1916 as a species, more closely related to Saimiri ustus than to Saimiri sciureus (= S. s. sciureus, also elevated to the level of species). Chiou et al. (2011) replicated the results of Lavergne et al. (2010) with a larger data set. The taxonomic recommendations of Lavergne et al. (2010) and Chiou et al. (2011) were followed by Paglia et al. (2012). Using a larger dataset and an interdisciplinary framework, Mercês et al. (2015) corroborated the results of Lavergne et al. (2010) and updated our knowledge of the geographic distribution of S. collinsi.

The forms macrodon and cassiquiarensis were considered to be subspecies of S. sciureus by Hill (1960), Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005). Lavergne et al. (2010; see also Carretero-Pinzón et al., 2009) considered them to be full species following a molecular genetic study of the MtDNA cytochrome b gene. The Colombian endemic albigena was considered a junior synonym of S. s. caquetensis J. A. Allen, 1916, by Hill (1960). Hershkovitz (1984), on the other hand, considered caquetensis to be a junior synonym of macrodon, and recognized albigena as a subspecies of S. sciureus (see also Groves, 2001, 2005).  In recognizing the three taxa as species, Carretero-Pinzón et al. (2009) and Lavergne et al. (2010) argued that it would be consistent to consider that peruviensis, a subspecies of boliviensis according to Hershkovitz (1984) and Groves (2001, 2005), be listed as a full species.

A phylogenetic, phylogeographic study by Lynch Alfaro et al. (2015) found that the forms albigena, cassiquiarensis and macrodon formed a clade, and that macrodon was paraphyletic, indicating three lineages (taxa), macrodon A, macrodon B and macrodon C.  They termed this group the “cassiquiarensis complex” and suggested that albigena, and the three lineages of macrodon be considered subspecies of cassiquiarensis, the oldest named taxon.

Silva Jr (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted capuchins and the untufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera. Cebus Erxleben, 1777 for the untufted group, and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 is the name available for the tufted capuchins.

With a unique karyotype (Seuánez et al. 1986) and evidence for relatively early divergence from other Sapajus species (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012; Nascimento et al. 2015), Sapajus xanthosternos is considered a distinct species based on morphological characteristics by both Groves (2001, 2005) and Silva Jr. (2001).

Silva Jr (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted capuchins and the un-tufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera: Cebus Erxleben, 1777 for the un-tufted group; and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 for the tufted capuchins.

Taxonomy of the tufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) follows Silva Jr (2001), who did not recognise any subspecific forms. Groves (2001, 2005) presented an alternative taxonomy for the tufted capuchins as follows: C. apella apella Linnaeus, 1758; C. apella fatuellus Linnaeus, 1766; C. apella macrocephalus Spix, 1823; C. apella peruanus Thomas, 1901; C. apella tocantinus Lönnberg, 1939; C. apella margaritae Hollister, 1914; C. libidinosus libidinosus Spix, 1823; C. libidinosus pallidus Gray, 1866; C. libidinosus paraguayanus Fischer, 1829; C. libidinosus juruanus Lönnberg, 1939; C. nigritus nigritus Goldfuss, 1809; C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820; C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823; C. xanthosternos Wied-Neuwied, 1826 (see Fragaszy et al. 2004; Rylands et al. 2005).

Groves (2001) listed three subspecific forms for C. nigritus: C. nigritus nigritus Goldfuss, 1809; C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820, considered a distinct species by Silva Jr. (2001); and C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823, considered a junior synonym of C. nigritus by Silva Jr. (2001).

The species was transferred to Sapajus (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012).

Georg Marcgrave (1648) described a capuchin monkey from the northeastern Atlantic Forest of Brazil as "caitaia". This monkey had bright yellow long fur, a rounded head and a not prominent forehead. At least three names have been used for this primate species: Simia flavia Schreber 1774, Cebus flavus Geoffroy 1812 and Cebus apella libidinosus (Spix 1823). Until recently, specimens of Simia flavia did not exist in scientific collections. For this reason the animal depicted in plate 31-b of Schreber (1774) had never been properly identified. A specimen collected in the state of Pernambuco, Brazil was considered the neotype of Simia flavia Schreber, 1774 and was named Cebus flavius (Schreber, 1774) (Oliveira and Langguth 2006). There is a junior synonym: Cebus queirozi (Pontes et al. 2006).

Historically the capuchins were classified in the genus Cebus Erxleben, 1777 by Hershkovitz (1949, 1955). Silva Jr. (2001) argued that the tufted and untufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera. Based on genetic, morphological, and phylogeographic analyses, Silva Jr. (2002) and Lynch Alfaro et al. (2012a, b) grouped the untufted capuchins in the genus Cebus and the tufted capuchins in the genus Sapajus Kerr, 1792. Hershkovitz (1949, 1955) recognized only a single species of tufted capuchins, i.e. C. apella. Groves (2001, 2005) presented an alternative taxonomy for the tufted capuchins: C. apella apella (Linnaeus, 1758); C. apella fatuellus (Linnaeus, 1766); C. apella macrocephalus Spix, 1823; C. apella peruanus Thomas, 1901; C. apella tocantinus Lönnberg, 1939; C. apella margaritae Hollister, 1914; C. libidinosus libidinosus Spix, 1823; C. libidinosus pallidus Gray, 1866; C. libidinosus paraguayanus Fischer, 1829; C. libidinosus juruanus Lönnberg, 1939; C. nigritus nigritus (Goldfuss, 1809); C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820; C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823; C. xanthosternos Wied-Neuwied, 1826 (see Fragaszy et al. 2004; Rylands et al. 2005). However, Silva Jr. (2001) did not recognize any subspecific forms. Additionally, Silva Jr. (2001) considered C. libidinosus juruanus as a junior synonym of C. macrocephalus, and C. libidinosus pallidus and C. libidinosus paraguayanus as junior synonyms of C. cay.

As early as in the 1980’s, taxonomic research on the ‘races’ of the genus Cebus confirmed the hypothesis that variations in the size and morphology of the tufted capuchins, could serve as important systematic and taxonomic criteria for intra-generic and intraspecific classification (Torres de Assumpção 1983, 1986; Torres 1988).

Further studies completed in the last two decades have confirmed this hypothesis. According to Wallace (2008), Silva Jr. (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted and the untufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered a two separate genera, Cebus Erxleben, 1777 for the untufted group, and Sapajus Kerr, 1792 for the tufted capuchins.

Here, the taxonomy of the tufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) follows Silva Jr. (2001), who did not recognize any subspecific forms. Groves (2001, 2005) presented an alternative taxonomy for the tufted capuchins as follows: C. apella apella (Linnaeus, 1758); C. apella fatuellus (Linnaeus, 1766); C. apella macrocephalus Spix, 1823; C. apella peruanus Thomas, 1901; C. apella tocantinus Lönnberg, 1939; C. apella margaritae Hollister, 1914; C. libidinosus libidinosus Spix, 1823; C. libidinosus pallidus Gray, 1866; C. libidinosus paraguayanus Fischer, 1829; C. libidinosus juruanus Lönnberg, 1939; C. nigritus nigritus (Goldfuss, 1809); C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820; C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823; C. xanthosternos Wied-Neuwied, 1826 (see also Fragaszy et al. 2004; Rylands et al. 2005). In this aseessment C. libidinosus paraguayanus Fischer, 1829, also listed by Groves (2001) is referred to as Cebus cay following Silva Jr. (2001).

The latest information resulting from genetic studies (Lynch Alfaro et al. 2012a, 2012b) on the species of the genus Cebus confirmed the separation between tufted (robust) capuchins, and untufted (gracile) capuchins. Lynch Alfaro et al. (2012a, 2012b) thus consolidated the separation into two genera (Sapajus and Cebus) suggested earlier by Silva Jr. (2001).

As a consensus this assessment follows the most current taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012) and Lynch Alfaro et al. (2012a, 2012b), which present the nomenclature for nine tufted capuchin monkeys: genus Sapajus (S. apella, S. macrocephalus, S. libidinosus, S. cay, S. flavius, S. nigritus nigritus, S. nigritus cuculatus, S. robustus and S. xanthosternos) and for six untufted forms: genus Cebus (C. albifrons, C. cuscinus, C. unicolor, C. olivaceus olivaceus, C. olivaceus castaneus and Cebus kaapori).

Silva Jr (2001, 2002) argued that the tufted capuchins and the un-tufted capuchins (sensu Hershkovitz 1949, 1955) are so distinct in their morphology that they should be considered separate genera: Cebus Erxleben, 1777 for the un-tufted group; and then Sapajus Kerr, 1792 is available for the tufted capuchins. Silva Jr (2001) did not recognize any sub-specific forms (such as those used by Hershkovitz 1949, 1955). Groves (2001, 2005) presented an alternative taxonomy for the tufted capuchins as follows: C. apella apella (Linnaeus, 1758); C. apella fatuellus (Linnaeus, 1766); C. apella macrocephalus Spix, 1823; C. apella peruanus Thomas, 1901; C. apella tocantinus Lönnberg, 1939; C. apella margaritae Hollister, 1914; C. libidinosus libidinosus Spix, 1823; C. libidinosus pallidus Gray, 1866; C. libidinosus paraguayanus Fischer, 1829; C. libidinosus juruanus Lönnberg, 1939; C. nigritus nigritus (Goldfuss, 1809); C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820; C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823; C. xanthosternos Wied-Neuwied, 1826 (Fragaszy et al. 2004; Rylands et al. 2005). Groves (2001) listed three sub-specific forms for C. nigritus: C. nigritus nigritus (Goldfuss, 1809); C. nigritus robustus Kuhl, 1820, considered a distinct species by Silva Jr. (2001); and C. nigritus cucullatus Spix, 1823, considered a junior synonym of C. nigritus by Silva Jr. (2001). Here we follow the taxonomy proposed by Silva Jr (2001) at the subgenus level and raised by Lynch Alfaro et al. (2012) to the genus level, that recognizes Sapajus with eight species (S. apella, S. cay, S. flavius, S. libidinosus, S. macrocephalus, S. nigritus, S. robustus and S. xanthosternos).

Phylogenomic analyses of Sapajus by Lima et al. (2017, 2018) provided support for the validity of Sapajus nigritus, S. robustus and S. xanthosternos as distinct species but lumped the putative species S. cay, S. libidinosus, S. apella, S. macrocephalus, and S. flavius together as a single widespread lineage. A single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) phylogeny recovered S. flavius and S. libidinosus as sister species. Sapajus apella, S. macrocephalus, and S. cay individuals, however, were recovered in two geographic clades, from northeastern and southwestern Amazon, rather than clustering by currently defined morphospecies. A STRUCTURE analysis of population clustering revealed widespread admixture among Sapajus populations within the Amazon and even into the Cerrado and Atlantic Forest (Lima et al. 2018). Difficulty in assigning species by morphology may be a result of widespread population admixture facilitated through frequent movement across major rivers and even ecosystems by robust capuchin monkeys (Lima et al. 2018). While the form macrocephalus Spix, 1823 is now considered a synonym of Sapajus apella, for conservation purposes we maintain the forms cay Illiger, 1815 (LC), libidinosus Spix, 1823 (VU), and flavius Schreber, 1774 (CR), each with distinct external morphologies overall (Silva-Júnior 2001). They occur in different phyto- and zoogeographic regions and, correspondingly occupy distinct adaptive zones, and each have their particular conservation issues and threats.
There have been no taxonomic changes or doubts since the description of this species.
Crax fasciolata and C. pinima (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as C. fasciolata following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Guatteria anteridifera is well marked by large buttresses of up to 2 m high. It seems similar to some species of sect. Mecocarpus (G. blepharophylla) but it completely lacks the verruculose structures so typical for that section. Instead it has scabridulous leaves which are covered with minute circular structures. It perhaps comes closest to the Guyanan endemic G. paludosa but that species lacks the buttresses has much larger leaves (30-55 cm vs 9-21 cm long in G. anteridifera) long-acuminate vs shortly acuminate leaves (acumen 10-45 mm vs 3-10 mm long in G. anteridifera) and larger stamens (2-3 mm vs 1 mm long in G. anteridifera) (Maas et al. 2015).

Pleurotus rickii was originally regarded by Rick (1907) as a new record of Armillaria procera for Rio Grande do Sul state, southern Brazil. Later, Bresadola (1920) revised the specimen and described it as P. rickii in honour of the mycologist.

Some researchers have suggested that Baird’s and Arnoux’s Beaked Whales are members of the same species (see Kasuya 2009), but the lack of known morphological differences may simply be due to the small number of measured specimens (especially for Arnoux’s Beaked Whale). Analysis of mitochondrial and nuclear intron sequence data has however revealed multiple fixed genetic differences, confirming that these species are reproductively isolated and valid taxonomic entities (Dalebout 2002, 2004). The species name has frequently been misspelled arnouxi or arnuxi. However, the generic and specific name given by Duvernoy (1851) was Berardius arnuxii. The type specimen was collected during the exploring voyage of the French corvette Rhin while in New Zealand. Berardius is from the name of the Le Rhin’s captain Auguste Bérard and the arnuxii is from the ship’s surgeon M. Arnoux who collected the specimen near Akaroa, New Zealand and presented the skull to the Paris Museum of Natural History in 1846. Unfortunately, Duvernoy misspelled the species name, omitting the 'o'.

Voss et al. (2001) reported the following: "Systematic research with nonvolant mammal specimens collected as voucher material resulted in the discovery of new taxa, documented range extensions of previously described species, and helped resolve many longstanding taxonomic problems: (1) Gracilinanus emiliae (Thomas), herein reported for the first time from French Guiana, is redescribed and its known geographic distribution documented; based on examination of type material and original descriptions, G. longicaudus Hershkovitz is considered a junior synonym of G. emiliae, but Marmosa agricolai Moojen is not...."
This species is currently under revision by Rogerio Vieira Rossi (Museum Zool Sao Paulo), and is likely to be split into three species.
All species of Micoureus are now considered as subgenus of Marmosa (Voss and Jansa 2009).
All species of Micoureus are now considered as subgenus of Marmosa (Voss and Jansa 2009). It may be a species complex.

Voss et al. (2001) place this in a separate genus Hyladelphys, and have expanded the range to French Guiana. Further taxonomic study may divide this species into several separate species, which would require evaluation of their threat status (Patton pers. comm.).

Ojeda and Monjeau (1995) argued that Caluromys lanatus dates from Illiger (1815), not from Olfers (1818). However, as pointed out by Hershkovitz (1959), Illiger’s name (Didelphys lanata) is a nomen nudum because it simply appeared on a list and lacked a description or indication (Pinto and Gardner 2004).
Didelphis paraguayensis (=D. albiventris) is the type species of Leucodidelphis Ihering, 1914 (Gardner 2005).

Molecular phylogenetics studies (Costa 2003, Patton and Costa 2003) showed high sequences divergences between specimens from different regions. These results suggest the possibility of there being more than one species named nudicaudatus (Silva 2005). The genus is under taxonomic review.
Gracilinanus is the generic synonym (Gardner 2008).
This species includes Marmosops dorothea (Voss et al., 2004).
Neomorphus geoffroyi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as N. geoffroyi and N. squamiger following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

The northern Venezuelan subpopulations, including Margarita Island and Trinidad, likely represent a distinct species, which is currently under revision by Perez-Hernandez and Lopez-Fuster (Lew and Soriano pers. comm.).
This species was formerly considered to be part of M. brevicaudata (Voss et al. 2001). It now includes M. maraxina as a junior synonym (Pavan et al. 2014).
All species of Micoureus are now considered as subgenus of Marmosa (Voss and Jansa 2009).
The species includes Monodelphis rubida and M. umbristriatus as synonyms (Pavan et al. 2014).
Pipile cumanensis and P. grayi (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. cumanensis following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Includes domesticus as a subspecies (Wilson and Reeder 2005). All Philippine populations of Mus are now placed in the species M. musculus (subspecies castaneus) and the species is considered to be non-native (Marshall 1977).
Psophia crepitans and P. ochroptera (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) were previously lumped as P. crepitans following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Phylloporia minuta was described by Bittencourt et al. (2018) based on specimens collected in Blumenau, southern Brazil. Currently, the species has no synonyms. Its epithet refers to the very small size of its basidiomata.

Hill (1962) and Stanyon et al. (1995) listed nine subspecies of the Red Howler Monkey, Alouatta seniculus: A. s. amazonica, A. s. arctoidea, A. s. insulanus, A. s. juara, A. s. macconnelli, A. s. puruensis, A. s. sara, A. s. seniculus, and A. s. stramineus.

The holotype of the form straminea Humboldt, 1812 is a female A. caraya, and is, therefore, not available for the Red Howler (Rylands and Brandon-Jones 1998). Bonvicino et al. (1996) argued that Red Howlers east of the Rio Trombetas are distinct from those to the west (and gave them the name of macconnelli (however, see Sampaio et al. 1996, Figueiredo et al. 1998, Rylands and Brandon-Jones 1998). Groves (2001, 2005) listed the Guiana Red Howler as A. macconnelli (Linnaeus, 1766).

The form occurring on the island of Trinidad (insulanus) was formerly considered a subspecies of A. seniculus, but following Groves (2001, 2005) it was included as a junior synonym of A. macconnelli. However, Ruiz-García et al. (2017) concluded that the Red Howler Monkeys from the island of Trinidad in the Caribbean Sea were not A. macconnelli as Groves maintained, and that this taxon is more related to A. seniculus. Therefore, insulanus is again considered a subspecies of Alouatta seniculus.

Hill (1962) listed nine subspecies of the Red Howler Monkey, Alouatta seniculus: amazonica, arctoidea, insulanus, juara, macconnelli, puruensis, sara, seniculus, and stramineus. Since then, except for juara and puruensis, these subspecies were synonymized or considered full species or, in the case of straminea, found to be erroneous.

Groves (2001, 2005) considered A. s. amazonica Lönnberg, 1941, from Codajás, north of the Rio Solimões, west of the Rio Negro, as a junior synonym A. juara Elliot, 1910.

Alouatta s. arctoidea is now recognized as a full species because Stanyon et al. (1995) concluded that the number of chromosomal differences between A. s. sara and A. s. seniculus (see Minezawa et al. 1985), which resulted in A. s. sara being a considered a full species, was similar in scale to that found between A. s. sara and A. s. arctoidea.

Alouatta s. insulanus Elliot, 1910, of the Island of Trinidad, was considered to be a junior synonym of A. macconnelli, following Groves (2001, 2005). However, Ruiz-García et al. (2017) concluded that the Red Howler Monkeys from the island of Trinidad in the Caribbean Sea were not A. macconnelli as Groves maintained, and that this taxon is more related to A. seniculus. Therefore, insulanus is again considered a subspecies of A. seniculus.

Alouatta s. juara Elliot, 1910, from the Rio Juruá, was recognized as a full species following Gregorin (2006), but subsequently was considered a subspecies of A. seniculus by Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2015). Its range is from the west of the Rio Purus in the states of Acre and Amazonas into Peru (Gregorin 2006, Cortés-Ortiz et al. 2015).

Bonvicino et al. (1996) argued that Red Howlers east of the Rio Trombetas are distinct from those to the west and gave them the name of macconnelli (however, see Sampaio et al. 1996, Figueiredo et al. 1998, Rylands and Brandon-Jones 1998). Groves (2001, 2005) listed the Guiana Red Howler as A. macconnelli (Linnaeus, 1766).

Alouatta s. puruensis Lönnberg, 1941, from Jaburú, Rio Purus, was placed as a junior synonym of puruensis by Groves (2001) but was recognized as a full species by Gregorin (2006). Subsequently, it was provisionally considered to be a subspecies of A. seniculus by Cortés-Ortiz et al. (2015). It occurs on both margins of the Rio Purus, east to the lower Rio Madeira and middle Rio Aripuanã, east as far as the Rio Teles Pires. To the south it is restricted to the north bank of the Rio Abunã on the Bolivian border. Placido de Castro, Acre, is the southernmost locality (Gregorin 2006).

Alouatta s. straminea is not a valid name for the Red Howler Monkey because its type specimen is a female Alouatta caraya, as demonstrated by Rylands and Brandon-Jones (1998). It was replaced by Alouatta macconnelli Elliott, 1910.

Alouatta s. sara is recognized as a full species following Minezawa et al. (1985; see also Stanyon et al. 1995; Groves, 2001, 2005; Cortés-Ortiz et al. 2015).
Herpsilochmus stotzi (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized following evidence presented in Whitney et al. (2013).
Hypocnemis rondoni (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) is recognized as a species following work by Whitney et al. (2013).
Conopophaga lineata and C. cearae (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. lineata following SACC (2005 and updates) and Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).
Xiphorhynchus fuscus and X. atlanticus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as X. fuscus following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

Campylorhamphus procurvoides, C. probatus and C. multostriatus (del Hoyo and Collar 2016) were previously lumped as C. procurvoides following SACC (2005 and updates), Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993) and Stotz et al. (1996).

authority: Souza e Souza, Sarmento-Soares, Canto & Ribeiro 2020

taxonomicNotes:
Until recently, two species were recognised in the genus Delphinus: the Short-beaked Common Dolphin (D. delphis) and the Long-beaked Common Dolphin (D. capensis), as described by Heyning and Perrin (1994). The morphological differences between D. delphis and D. capensis in the North Pacific (Heyning and Perrin 1994) were supported by molecular evidence from both mitochondrial and nuclear markers (Rosel et al. 1994). However, the genus exhibits a great deal of morphological variation globally and the criteria used to distinguish between the two species in the North Pacific appear not to apply elsewhere (Best 2007). In South Africa, Samaai et al. (2005) found that based on skull morphology the majority of specimens belonged to D. capensis, however two specimens were within the range for D. delphis from the North Pacific, and a third specimen fell between the ranges for D. delphis and D. capensis (Samaai et al. 2005). The same molecular markers that were used to differentiate the two sympatric species in the North Pacific failed to reveal any genetic distinction between the described morphotypes in South Africa (Best 2007).

Subsequently, Cunha et al. (2015), in a global analysis of Delphinus which included nine specimens from the west coast of South Africa (eastern South Atlantic), concluded that all specimens analysed from the Atlantic Ocean belonged to D. delphis, and that D. capensis was not a genetically valid species.

In 2016 the Society for Marine Mammalogy Committee on Taxonomy removed Delphinus capensis from its accepted list of marine mammal species and now recognises all Common Dolphins globally as belonging to a single species, Delphinus delphis (Committee on Taxonomy 2020). It recognises the following subspecies:

  • D. d. delphis Linnaeus, 1758. Common Dolphin
  • D. d. bairdii Dall, 1873. Eastern North Pacific Long-beaked Common Dolphin
  • D. d. ponticus Barabash, 1935. Black Sea Common Dolphin
  • D. d. tropicalis van Bree, 1971. Indo-Pacific Common Dolphin

Cunha et al. (2015) noted that because the sympatric or parapatric Long-beaked and Short-beaked Common Dolphins off California in the eastern North Pacific appear not to interbreed, the Long-beaked Common Dolphins might eventually be described and recognised as a separate species, D. bairdii. Some researchers have considered the Long-beaked Common Dolphins in the Indo-Pacific, which has an exceptionally long beak, to constitute a separate species, D. tropicalis (Van Bree and Gallagher 1978; Rice 1998). However, another morphometric study concluded that that form should be considered a subspecies (Jefferson and Van Waerebeek 2002) and it is currently recognised as such, D. delphis tropicalis.

The non-concordance of morphological and genetic data for Common Dolphins has caused much confusion and a rigorous global taxonomic study of the genus is needed. Further phylogenetic analyses are necessary to resolve the controversies surrounding the classification and nomenclature. More changes to Delphinus taxonomy should be expected.

Cebuella was proposed by Gray (1866) as a subgenus of Hapale (later Callithrix), and soon after as a distinct genus (Gray, 1870). Rosenberger (1981), Rosenberger and Coimbra-Filho (1984), and Natori (1994) argued, on morphological terms, that the Pygmy Marmoset should correctly be included in the genus Callithrix. This was not maintained in Rosenberger et al. (1990), although Barroso (1995), Barroso et al. (1997), Moreira et al. (1996), Schneider et al. (1996), Schneider and Rosenberger (1996), Tagliaro et al. (1997), Porter et al. (1997a), and Canavez et al. (1999a) also argued for this arrangement on the basis of molecular genetics. The argument that Cebuella should be included in the genus Callithrix centres on the conclusion, from both morphological and genetic studies, that the Pygmy Marmoset is more closely related to the Amazonian marmosets (the argentata group of Hershkovitz [1977]) than the latter are to the Atlantic forest marmosets (the jacchus group of Hershkovitz [1977]). Schneider et al. (1993) and Schneider and Rosenberger (1996) also concluded that their molecular genetic data are compatible with jacchus and pygmaea being congeneric. Groves (2001, 2005) places the species in the genus Callithrix, subgenus Cebuella. Although closely related to the Amazonian marmosets, we believe that Cebuella pygmaea deserves generic status. The species shows very distinct features, unique among the callitrichids, involving not only its diminutive size, but also the tree-gouging specialization not observed to nearly the same extent in its Amazonian sister group.

If Cebuella is maintained as a separate genus, then the group would be paraphyletic unless the argentata group marmosets and the jacchus group marmosets are placed in different genera. This was the option adopted, with the Amazonian marmosets being placed in the genus Mico Lesson, 1840 (see below). This decision was also based on the clear identity of the three genera shown in all morphological and molecular studies available.

In 1940, Lönnberg described the subspecies Cebuella pygmaea niveiventris from Lago Ipixuna, south bank of the Rio Solimões, based on its sharply contrasting whitish chest, belly, and inner surface of arms and legs. The ventral surface of C. p. pygmaea is ochraceous. Cruz Lima (1945) and Napier (1976) also recognized and described the two subspecies. Hershkovitz (1977) argued that the colour of the underparts is individually and locally variable and not justifying the subspecific status of niveiventris. However, Van Roosmalen and van Roosmalen (1997) recently presented evidence for the validity of the two subspecies based on field observations and captive specimens of C. p. niveiventris, and confirmed its presence in the interfluvium of the Rios Purus and Madeira.

A phylogenetic study by Boubli et al. (2018), which included the mtDNA cytochrome b gene and a reduced representation genome sequencing approach (ddRADseq) for geographically representative samples from the Brazil, showed that the forms pygmaea Spix (from the north of the Solimões-Amazonas) and niveiventris Lönnberg (from the south of the Solimões-Amazonas) were distinct species.
Until Bathyraja cousseauae was described recently, this was often identified as B. brachyurops.

Previously recognised subspecies calcirupicola and diamantinensis (del Hoyo & Collar 2014) now regarded as full species, which see. Subspecies obscurus might also be better regarded as a full species (Lopes et al. 2017). C. l. largipennis differs from C. l. obscurus by its longer ‘LTTs’ (light tail-tips) (effect size 7.22 for male LTT1 vs the slightly longer values under ‘aequatorialis’; score 3); white vs greyish-white tail-tips (1); dark grey vs blackish-blue rest of outer rectrices (1); distinctly different call, higher-pitched and lacking the rolling ‘r’ tone in obscurus (at least 2). Subspecies aequatorialis regarded as a synonym of obscurus. Two subspecies recognized.

Previously regarded as a subspecies of C. largipennis (HBW/BirdLife International 2018) but split following Lopes et al. (2017, 2020). Differs from largipennis by its smaller size (effect size −2.73 for male tails in Lopes et al. [2017: 6, Table 1]; score 2); longer ‘LTTs’ (light tail-tips) (effect size 2.01 for male LTT2 in same source; score 2); totally different habitat (1); totally different voice, with the song a high tittering trill, quite unlike anything on Xeno-canto for largipennis (at least 4). The map in Lopes et al. (2017) shows collecting localities for calcirupicola and diamantinensis that are only 25 km apart. It seems reasonable that this should be considered evidence of parapatry. Differs from C. diamantinensis by its smaller size (effect size −4.02 for male tails in Lopes et al. [2017: 6, Table 1]; score 2), larger white tips to tail (effect size 2.39 for male LTT2 in same source; score 2) and parapatric distribution (3). It is arguable also that the nesting in caves should be scored, but it is not clear that this habit is not shared by diamantinensis. It is worth noting, however, that the limited vocal evidence now available suggests that the voices of the two taxa are very similar. Monotypic.

This species was originally described as Stereum sclerotioides by Lloyd (1922), based on a specimen with no precise geographic data, from the Amazon Forest. In 1959, D.A. Reid placed this species in the genus Cymatoderma Reid (1958).

Previously regarded as a subspecies of C. largipennis (HBW/BirdLife International 2018) but split following Lopes et al. (2017, 2020). Differs from C. l. largipennis by its longer ‘LTTs’ (light tail-tips) (effect size 2.39 for male LTT1; score 2); base of outer rectrices bright bronzy-green vs dark grey (1); totally different habitat (1); totally different voice, with the song a high tittering trill, quite unlike anything on Xeno-canto for largipennis (at least 4). For difference from C. calcirupicola, see that species. Monotypic.
Pseudastur polionotus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously placed in the genus Leucopternis.
Easily confused with the Southern Eagle Ray (Myliobatis goodei) (Last et al. 2016).

The Whitespotted Eagle Ray (Aetobatus narinari) (Euphrasen 1790) was originally restricted to the Western Central and Southwest Atlantic (Sales et al. 2019) but the range now also extends to the eastern Atlantic (Fricke et al. 2020).

authority: Dutra, Peixoto, Ochoa, Ohara, de Santana, Menezes & Datovo, 2021
de Santana, Wosiacki, Crampton, Sabaj, Dillman, Castro e C., Bastos & Vari, 2019

taxonomicNotes: Falco peregrinus (del Hoyo and Collar 2014) was previously split as F. peregrinus and F. pelegrinoides following Sibley and Monroe (1990, 1993).

Four species of Lion Tamarins are recognized. Coimbra-Filho (1990) suggested that Leontopithecus caissara was a subspecies, or colour variant of L. chrysopygus. Burity et al. (1999) and Perez-Sweeney et al. (2008) concluded that this was not so, and that L. caissara is a valid species. Perez-Sweeney et al. (2008) concluded that there are three unambiguous clades revealed by phylogenetic analysis of mtDNA control region sequences: Leontopithecus chysomelas, L. caissara and L. chrysopygus/L. rosalia. According to these authors, L. chysomelas occupies a basal phylogenetic position. Here we follow the taxonomy proposed by Rylands (2012).

Formerly in the genus Callithrix (see Rylands et al. 2000, 2008). Groves (2001, 2005) lists this species as Callithrix (Mico) marcai. The species was described only from three specimens in the Museu Nacional, Rio de Janeiro, and was not recorded in the wild until 2012. Until then it was only known from the type locality, “Foz do Rio Castanho (= Rio Roosevelt), left influx into Rio Aripuanã, Amazonas State, Brasil” (Alperin 1993, 2002). Silva et al. 2014 reported the rediscovery of the species in the confluence of Roosevelt and Aripuanã Rivers. Garbino (2014) described the resemblance of the pelage pattern between M. manicorensis and M. marcai and proposed M. manicorensis as a junior synonymous of M. marcai. Silva et al. (in prep.) are reassessing the taxonomic status of the marmosets from Aripuanã and Madeira/Ji-paraná interfluve based on molecular and morphological analysis.

First described by Spix (1823) from a specimen assumed to have been collected along the Rio Iça in Brazil, near the border with Peru (Noronha et al. 2007). All subsequent records were for the right bank of the Rio Madeira (Rylands 1982, Hershkovitz 1990, van Roosmalen et al. 2002).  van Roosmalen et al. (2002) suggested therefore that the type locality must have been incorrect. The species was included until recently in the group moloch, one of the five species group of the genus Callicebus sensu Kobayashi and Langguth (1999) and van Roosmalen et al. (2002). However, in a recent taxonomic review, Hazel et al. (2016) include the donacophilus and moloch species groups (which includes cinerascens) as members of the new described Plecturocebus genus. Byrne et al. (2016) split the genus Callicebus into three new genera, namely:  Cheracebus (torquatus-group sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002), Plecturocebus (cupreus-, moloch-, donacophilus-groups sensu Roosmalen et al. (2002) and Callicebus (personatus-group, sensu Roosmalen et al. 2002). According to Byrne et al. (2016), Plecturocebus includes 22 species.
All Pithecia taxonomy follows Marsh (2014).

Dalponte et al. (2014) described the species based on a morphological data set and compared it with the Callicebus moloch species group (sensu Groves 2005), especially with the geographically neighbouring forms, C. bernhardi and C. cinerascens. These exclusive morphological characters distinguish the new species from all other Amazonian titi monkeys. In a recent taxonomic review, Byrne et al. (2016) include the donacophilus and moloch species groups (which includes P. miltoni) into the newly described named Plecturocebus.

authority: Barbosa du Bocage & de Brito Capello, 1864

taxonomicNotes: Descrita em: Flora. Neotropica., 44: 1-128., 1986.

Descrita em: Fl. Bras. 14(2): 92 1867. Conhecida popularmente como merindiba ou guarajuba (Allemão, 1844; BFG, 2015), a espécie foi descrita originalmente por Freire Allemão y Cysneiros em 1846 como a única representante do gênero Vicentia. Posteriormente, Eichler recombinou o nome na obra Flora Brasiliensis em 1867, sinonimizando Vicentia e transformado o gênero em uma seção monotípica da família Combretaceae (Stace, 2010). De acordo com Silva e Valente (2002), as Combretáceas que ocorrem no estado do Rio de Janeiro são facilmente diferenciadas pelas características de suas epidermes foliares. Stace (2010) aponta a seção monotípica Vicentia como morfologicamente única dentre as Combretáceas Neotropicais. T. acuminata pode ser facilmente reconhecida pela distinta inflorescência paniculada, flores diminutas tetrâmeras, frutos alados - 3(-4) e grãos de pólen verrucosos quase equinados. As folhas alternas são acuminadas no ápice e cuneiformes a amplamente cuneadas na base, com a face adaxial frequentemente glabra. O pecíolo bi-glandular proeminente (raramente 3, 4-glandular), bem como domácias afiladas e muitas vezes hirsutas nas axilas das venações secundárias na superfície abaxial são características morfológicas que delimitam o táxon.

Polyporus sapurema has been confused with Polyporus indigenous since both species grow from a pseudosclerotia, and are known as “Indian Bread” The two species are morphologically and phylogenetically distinct and are easily separated in the field.

Polyporus diabolicus Berk.= Polyporus vernicosus Berk. Atroporus diabolicus was considered as a synonym of Neodictyopus dictyopus (= Polyporus dictyopus), however with detailed morphological and phylogenetic analyses it was confirmed as an independent species (Palacio et al. 2017).

authority: (Möller) G.H. Sung, J.M. Sung, Hywel-Jones & Spatafora
taxonomicNotes: Ophiocordyceps ainictos was originally described as Cordyceps ainictos Möller. The species is readily recognizable for bearing two types of stromata: one capitate with immersed perithecia and the other linear with superficial perithecia. This unique morphology was suggested as representing two distinct species (Petch 1935), but the morphology of both the type illustration and the recent record are indisputably very similar.
